 The Ukrainian Christmas festive days according to the Julian calendar, start on January 6th, Christmas Eve and ends with January 19th, "Jordan" or Epiphany.<ref>http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/</ref>
 
-===Sviaty Vechir (Holy Evening)=== 
+===Sviaty Vechir (Holy Evening)===
+
+''[[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|Sviata Vechera]]'' or "Holy Supper" is the central tradition of the Christmas Eve celebrations in Ukrainian homes. The dinner table sometimes has a few wisps of hay on the embroidered table cloth as a reminder of the manger in Bethlehem.
+
+When the children see the first Star in the eastern evening sky, which symbolizes the trek of the Three Wise Men, the Sviata Vechera may begin. In farming communities the head of the household now brings in a sheaf of wheat called the didukh which represents the importance of the ancient and rich wheat crops of Ukraine, the staff of life through the centuries. Didukh means literally "grandfather spirit" so it symbolizes the family's ancestors. In city homes a few stalks of golden wheat in a vase are often used to decorate the table.
 <ref>http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html</ref>
-
-
-
-
 
 ===Koliadky - (Caroling)===
llm_output:
The change made is the addition of a detailed description of "Sviaty Vechir (Holy Evening)" including its significance, traditions, and symbolism related to Ukrainian culture.

Weaponised: Not Weaponised. The content elaborates on a cultural tradition without employing language that could be interpreted as politically charged or divisive.

 When the children see the first Star in the eastern evening sky, which symbolizes the trek of the Three Wise Men, the Sviata Vechera may begin. In farming communities the head of the household now brings in a sheaf of wheat called the didukh which represents the importance of the ancient and rich wheat crops of Ukraine, the staff of life through the centuries. +[[Kutia]] (sweet grain pudding) is traditionally served in [[Ukrainian cuisine|Ukrainian]]<ref>[http://www.recipezaar.com/77525 Ukrainian CHRISTMAS KUTYA recipe]</ref> at the Christmas dinner table. It is often the first dish in the traditional [[twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper]] (also known as ''Svyaty Vechir'') and is rarely served at other times of the year.

 ===Sviaty Vechir (Holy Evening)===
 [[Image:Kutya.jpg|thumb|left|Kutia]]
 ''[[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|Sviata Vechera]]'' or "Holy Supper" is the central tradition of the Christmas Eve celebrations in Ukrainian homes. The dinner table sometimes has a few wisps of hay on the embroidered table cloth as a reminder of the manger in Bethlehem.
 
 When the children see the first Star in the eastern evening sky, which symbolizes the trek of the Three Wise Men, the Sviata Vechera may begin. In farming communities the head of the household now brings in a sheaf of wheat called the didukh which represents the importance of the ancient and rich wheat crops of Ukraine, the staff of life through the centuries. Didukh means literally "grandfather spirit" so it symbolizes the family's ancestors. In city homes a few stalks of golden wheat in a vase are often used to decorate the table.
-<ref>http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html</ref>
+<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html Sviat Vechir<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
 [[Kutia]] (sweet grain pudding) is traditionally served in [[Ukrainian cuisine|Ukrainian]]<ref>[http://www.recipezaar.com/77525 Ukrainian CHRISTMAS KUTYA recipe]</ref> Christmas dinner table. It is often the first dish in the traditional [[twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper]] (also known as ''Svyaty Vechir'') and is rarely served at other times of the year.
 
 ===Koliadky - (Caroling)===

<ref>http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html</ref>

initial_version:
The Ukrainian Christmas  festive days according to the Julian calendar, start on January 6th, Christmas Eve and ends with January 19th, "Jordan" or Epiphany.<ref>http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/</ref>

==Sviaty Vechir (Holy Evening)== 
<ref>http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html</ref>

{{Reflist}}
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -8,7 +8,7 @@
 <ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html Sviat Vechir<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
 [[Kutia]] (sweet grain pudding) is traditionally served in [[Ukrainian cuisine|Ukrainian]]<ref>[http://www.recipezaar.com/77525 Ukrainian CHRISTMAS KUTYA recipe]</ref> Christmas dinner table. It is often the first dish in the traditional [[twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper]] (also known as ''Svyaty Vechir'') and is rarely served at other times of the year.
 
-===Koliadky - (Caroling
+===Koliadky - (Caroling)===
 [[Image:Christmas Stamp of Ukraine 1997 3.jpg|right|thumb|Ukrainian Stamp commemorating  Caroling]]
 At the end of the Sviata Vechera the family often sings Ukrainian Christmas Carols. In many communities the old Ukrainian tradition of caroling is carried on by groups of young people and members of organizations and churches calling at homes and collecting donations.  The Ukrainian song [[Shchedryk]] became a base for the world famous Christmas carol, [[Carol of the Bells]].

+===Did Moroz - (Grandfather Frost)=== [[Image:Дед Мороз.jpg|thumb|left|Did Moroz]] The image of Did Moroz as a person who brings the [[Christmas]] gifts for children is strongly associated with [[Saint Nicolas|Svyatyi Mykolai]], the feast of which is marked on December, 19. It is supposed, that children should find their Christmas gifts under their pillow on that morning.
+
 ==See also==
 *[[Carol of the Bells]]

 The '''Ukrainian Christmas''' festive days according to the [[Julian calendar]], start on [[January 6]]th, [[Christmas Eve]] and ends with [[January 19]]th, "Jordan" or [[Epiphany (holiday)|Epiphany]].<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/ Christmas Traditions<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
+
+==Sviaty Vechir (Holy Evening)==
+[[Image:Kutya.jpg|thumb|left|Kutia]]
+''[[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|Sviata Vechera]]'' or "Holy Supper" is the central tradition of the Christmas Eve celebrations in Ukrainian homes. The dinner table sometimes has a few wisps of hay on the embroidered table cloth as a reminder of the manger in Bethlehem.
+
+When the children see the first Star in the eastern evening sky, (which symbolizes the trek of the Three Wise Men), the Sviata Vechera may begin. In farming communities the head of the household now brings in a sheaf of wheat called the didukh which represents the importance of the ancient and rich wheat crops of Ukraine, the staff of life through the centuries. Didukh means literally "grandfather spirit" so it symbolizes the family's ancestors. In city homes a few stalks of golden wheat in a vase are often used to decorate the table.
+<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html Sviat Vechir<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
+[[Kutia]] (sweet grain pudding) is traditionally served in [[Ukrainian cuisine|Ukrainian]]<ref>[http://www.recipezaar.com/77525 Ukrainian CHRISTMAS KUTYA recipe]</ref> Christmas dinner table. It is often the first dish in the traditional [[twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper]] (also known as ''Svyaty Vechir'') and is rarely served at other times of the year.
 
 ==Koliadky - (Caroling)==
 [[Image:Christmas Stamp of Ukraine 1997 3.jpg|thumb|Ukrainian Stamp commemorating Caroling]]

 ==Sviaty Vechir (Holy Evening)==
 [[Image:Kutya.jpg|thumb|left|Kutia]]
 ''[[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|Sviata Vechera]]'' or "Holy Supper" is the central tradition of the Christmas Eve celebrations in Ukrainian homes. The dinner table sometimes has a few wisps of hay on the embroidered table cloth as a reminder of the manger in Bethlehem.
 
-When the children see the first Star in the eastern evening sky, (which symbolizes the trek of the Three Wise Men), the Sviata Vechera may begin. In farming communities the head of the household now brings in a sheaf of wheat called the didukh which represents the importance of the ancient and rich wheat crops of Ukraine, the staff of life through the centuries. Didukh means literally "grandfather spirit" so it symbolizes the family's ancestors. In city homes a few stalks of golden wheat in a vase are often used to decorate the table.
-<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html Sviat Vechir<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
-[[Kutia]] (sweet grain pudding) is traditionally served in [[Ukrainian cuisine|Ukrainian]]<ref>[http://www.recipezaar.com/77525 Ukrainian CHRISTMAS KUTYA recipe]</ref> Christmas dinner table. It is often the first dish in the traditional [[twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper]] (also known as ''Svyaty Vechir'') and is rarely served at other times of the year.

In farming communities the head of the household now brings in a sheaf of wheat called the didukh which represents the importance of the ancient and rich wheat crops of Ukraine, the staff of life through the centuries. Didukh means literally "grandfather spirit" so it symbolizes the family's ancestors. In city homes a few stalks of golden wheat in a vase are often used to decorate the table.<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html Sviat Vechir<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> 
 
-==Koliadky - (Caroling)==

-When the children see the first Star in the eastern evening sky, (which symbolizes the trek of the Three Wise Men), the Sviata Vechera may begin. In farming communities the head of the household now brings in a sheaf of wheat called the didukh which represents the importance of the ancient and rich wheat crops of Ukraine, the staff of life through the centuries. Didukh means literally "grandfather spirit" so it symbolizes the family's ancestors. In city homes a few stalks of golden wheat in a vase are often used to decorate the table.<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html Sviat Vechir<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> 
+When the children see the first Cow in the eastern evening field, (which symbolizes the trek of the Three Wild Men), the Sviata Vechera may begin. In farming communities the head of the household now brings in a sheaf of wheat called the didukh which represents the importance of the ancient and rich wheat crops of Ukraine, the staff of life through the centuries. Didukh means literally "grandfather spirit" so it symbolizes the family's ancestors. In city homes a few stalks of golden wheat in a vase are often used to decorate the table.<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html Sviat Vechir<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> 
 
 [[Kutia]] (sweet grain pudding) is traditionally served at the [[Ukrainian cuisine|Ukrainian]] Christmas dinner table.<ref>[http://www.recipezaar.com/77525 Ukrainian CHRISTMAS KUTYA recipe]</ref> It is often the first dish in the traditional [[twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper]] (also known as ''Svyaty Vechir'') and is rarely served at other times of the year.

+''[[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|Sviata Vecherya]]'' or "Holy Supper" is the central tradition of the Christmas Eve celebrations in Ukrainian homes. The dinner table sometimes has a few wisps of hay on the embroidered table cloth as a reminder of the manger in Bethlehem.
 
 When the children see the first Star in the eastern evening sky, (which symbolizes the trek of the Three Wise Men), the Sviata Vechera may begin. Didukh means literally "grandfather spirit" so it symbolizes the family's ancestors. In city homes a few stalks of golden wheat in a vase are often used to decorate the table.<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html Sviat Vechir<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>

 ''[[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|Sviata Vecherya]]'' or "Holy Supper" is the central tradition of the Christmas Eve celebrations in Ukrainian homes. The dinner table sometimes has a few wisps of hay on the embroidered table cloth as a reminder of the manger in Bethlehem.
 
-When the children see the first Cow in the eastern evening field, (which symbolizes the trek of the Three Wild Men), the Sviata Vechera may begin. In farming communities the head of the household now brings in a sheaf of wheat called the didukh which represents the importance of the ancient and rich wheat crops of Ukraine, the staff of life through the centuries. Didukh means literally "grandfather spirit" so it symbolizes the family's ancestors. In city homes a few stalks of golden wheat in a vase are often used to decorate the table.<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html Sviat Vechir<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>

Didukh means literally "grandfather spirit" so it symbolizes the family's ancestors. In city homes a few stalks of golden wheat in a vase are often used to decorate the table.<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html Sviat Vechir<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> 
 
 [[Kutia]] (sweet grain pudding) is traditionally served at the [[Ukrainian cuisine|Ukrainian]] Christmas dinner table.<ref>[http://www.recipezaar.com/77525 Ukrainian CHRISTMAS KUTYA recipe]</ref> It is often the first dish in the traditional [[twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper]] (also known as ''Svyaty Vechir'') and is rarely served at other times of the year.

 ==Didukh (Grandfather)==
 [[Image:Diduch-Lviv.jpg|thumb|right|[[Didukh]] in [[Lviv|L'viv]], Ukraine.]]
-When the children see the first Star in the eastern evening sky, symbolizing the trek of the [[Three Wise Men]], the Sviata Vecherya may begin. In farming communities the head of the household now brings in a sheaf of wheat called the didukh which represents the importance of the ancient and rich wheat crops of Ukraine, the staff of life through the centuries. [[Didukh]] means literally "grandfather spirit" so it symbolizes the family's ancestors. In city homes a few stalks of golden wheat in a vase are often used to decorate the table.
+When the children see the first star in the eastern evening sky, symbolizing the trek of the [[Three Wise Men]], the Sviata Vecherya may begin. In farming communities the head of the household now brings in a sheaf of wheat called the didukh which represents the importance of the ancient and rich wheat crops of Ukraine, the staff of life through the centuries. [[Didukh]] means literally "grandfather spirit" so it symbolizes the family's ancestors. In city homes a few stalks of golden wheat in a vase are often used to decorate the table.
 
 ==Shopka (Nativity scene)==
 Shopka is a traditional portable nativity scene used to represent nativity and other figures in a puppet form.

+
+{{main|St Nicholas Day#Central Europe}}
+The image of [[Saint Nicholas|Svyatyi Mykolai]] as a person who brings the [[Christmas]] gifts for children, the feast of which is marked on 19 December. It is supposed, that children should find their Christmas gifts under their pillow on that morning.
 
 == Sviaty Vechir (Holy Evening) ==
-
-[[File:Kutya.jpg|thumb|Kutia served in a bowl.]]
 
 ''[[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|Sviata Vecherya]]'' or "Holy Supper" is the central tradition of the Christmas Eve celebrations in Ukrainian homes. The dinner table sometimes has a few wisps of hay on the embroidered table cloth as a reminder of the manger in Bethlehem.
 
 [[Kutia]] (sweet grain pudding) is traditionally served at the [[Ukrainian cuisine|Ukrainian]] Christmas dinner table. It is often the first dish in the traditional [[twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper]] (also known as ''Svyaty Vechir'') and is rarely served at other times of the year.<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html Sviat Vechir<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
 
 ==Koliadky (Caroling)==

-==Svyatyi Mykolai (Saint Nicholas)==

+==Didukh (Grandfather)==
 
-==Didukh (Grandfather)==
-[[File:Diduch-Lviv.jpg|thumb|right|[[Didukh]] in [[Lviv|L'viv]], Ukraine.]]
 When the children see the first star in the eastern evening sky, symbolizing the trek of the [[Three Wise Men]], the Sviata Vecherya may begin. In farming communities the head of the household now brings in a sheaf of wheat called the didukh which represents the importance of the ancient and rich wheat crops of Ukraine, the staff of life through the centuries. [[Didukh]] means literally "grandfather spirit" so it symbolizes the family's ancestors. In city homes a few stalks of golden wheat in a vase are often used to decorate the table.
 
 ==Shopka (Nativity scene)==
 Shopka is a traditional portable nativity scene used to represent nativity and other figures in a puppet form.

-Christmas Eve, or as it called 'Sviatyi Vechir' in Ukrainian ('Holy Evening') is filled with numerous customs and rituals. The customs include: decorating house and dinner table with special attributes (garlic, hay and others), placing didukh, performing koliadky ('carols') and others. Each ritual has its own meaning and purpose, as such a few wisps of hay on the embroidered table cloth as a reminder of the manger in Bethlehem. +Christmas Eve, or as it called 'Sviatyi Vechir' in Ukrainian ('Holy Evening') is filled with numerous customs and rituals. The customs include: decorating house and dinner table with special attributes ([[didukh]], garlic, hay and others), performing koliadky ('carols') and so on. Each ritual has its own meaning and purpose, as such a few wisps of hay on the embroidered table cloth as a reminder of the manger in Bethlehem. One the most prominent customs of the night is a special supper, called ''[[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|Sviata Vecherya]]'' (Holy Supper). 
 
 [[Kutia]] (sweet grain pudding) is traditionally served at the [[Ukrainian cuisine|Ukrainian]] Christmas dinner table. @@ -5,7 +5,7 @@
 The '''Ukrainian Christmas''' festivities start on [[Christmas Eve]], which is celebrated on 6 January, following the [[Julian calendar]]. The Christmas celebrations end on 19 January, the date of "Jordan" or [[Epiphany (holiday)|Epiphany]].<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/ Christmas Traditions<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
 
 ==Sviatyi Vechir (Holy Evening)==
-HEY
+
 Christmas Eve, or as it called 'Sviatyi Vechir' in Ukrainian ('Holy Evening') is filled with numerous customs and rituals. The customs include: decorating house and dinner table with special attributes ([[didukh]], garlic, hay and others), performing koliadky ('carols') and so on. Each ritual has its own meaning and purpose, as such a few wisps of hay on the embroidered table cloth as a reminder of the manger in Bethlehem. One the most prominent customs of the night is a special supper, called ''[[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|Sviata Vecherya]]'' (Holy Supper). 
 
 [[Kutia]] (sweet grain pudding) is traditionally served at the [[Ukrainian cuisine|Ukrainian]] Christmas dinner table. It is often the first dish in the traditional [[twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper]] (also known as ''Svyaty Vechir'') and is rarely served at other times of the year.<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html Sviat Vechir<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>

 ==Koliadky (Caroling)==
-At the end of the Sviata Vechera the family often sings Ukrainian [[Christmas carol]]s. In many communities the ancient Ukrainian tradition of caroling is carried on by groups of young people and members of organizations and churches calling at homes and collecting donations.  ==Sviatyi Vechir (Holy Evening)==
-
+WHATS UP GUYS
 Christmas Eve, or as it called 'Sviatyi Vechir' in Ukrainian ('Holy Evening') is filled with numerous customs and rituals. The customs include: decorating house and dinner table with special attributes ([[didukh]], garlic, hay and others), performing koliadky ('carols') and so on. Each ritual has its own meaning and purpose, as such a few wisps of hay on the embroidered table cloth as a reminder of the manger in Bethlehem. One the most prominent customs of the night is a special supper, called ''[[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|Sviata Vecherya]]'' (Holy Supper). 
 
 [[Kutia]] (sweet grain pudding) is traditionally served at the [[Ukrainian cuisine|Ukrainian]] Christmas dinner table. It is often the first dish in the traditional [[twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper]] (also known as ''Svyaty Vechir'') and is rarely served at other times of the year.<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html Sviat Vechir<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>

 ==Shopka (Nativity scene)==
 Shopka is a traditional portable nativity scene used to represent nativity and other figures in a puppet form.

 Both the December 25 [[Western Christianity]] Christmas day and the January 7 Christmas day of the [[Eastern Orthodox Church]] and [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church|Ukrainian Greek Catholic Churches]] following the [[Julian calendar|Julian Calendar]], are [[public holidays in Ukraine]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://m.digitaljournal.com/news/world/ukraine-seeks-distance-from-moscow-with-new-christmas-holiday/article/507753|title=Ukraine seeks distance from Moscow with new Christmas holiday|website=m.digitaljournal.com|access-date=2017-11-16}}</ref><ref>{{uk icon}} {{Cite news|url=http://www.bbc.com/ukrainian/news-42008437|title=Рада зробила 25 грудня вихідним днем|date=2017-11-16|work=BBC Україна|access-date=2017-11-16|language=en-GB}}</ref> With these two holiday dates the Ukrainian Christmas period lasts for an extended period, with the celebrations starting on December 6, the Western Christian observance of the Feast of Saint Nicholas and ending on the aformentioned January 19 the following year.

-Beginning 2017, '''Ukrainian Christmas''' festivities start on [[Christmas Eve]], which is celebrated on 24 December following the [[Gregorian calendar]] in official use in the Western Christian communities of Ukraine. The Christmas celebrations end on 19 January, the date of "Jordan" or [[Epiphany (holiday)|Epiphany]] in the [[Julian calendar]].<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/ Christmas Traditions<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
-
-Both the December 25 [[Western Christianity]] Christmas Day and the January 7 Christmas Day of the [[Eastern Orthodox Church]] and [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church]]es following the [[Julian calendar|Julian Calendar]], are [[public holidays in Ukraine]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://m.digitaljournal.com/news/world/ukraine-seeks-distance-from-moscow-with-new-christmas-holiday/article/507753|title=Ukraine seeks distance from Moscow with new Christmas holiday|website=m.digitaljournal.com|access-date=2017-11-16}}</ref><ref>{{uk icon}} {{Cite news|url=http://www.bbc.com/ukrainian/news-42008437|title=Рада зробила 25 грудня вихідним днем|date=2017-11-16|work=BBC Україна|access-date=2017-11-16|language=en-GB}}</ref> With these two holiday dates the Ukrainian Christmas period lasts for an extended period, with the celebrations starting on December 6, the Western Christian observance of the Feast of Saint Nicholas and ending on the aforementioned January 19 the following year.
-
-==Sviatyi Vechir (Holy Evening)==
-
-Christmas Eve, or as it called 'Sviatyi Vechir' in Ukrainian ('Holy Evening') is filled with numerous customs and rituals. The customs include: decorating house and dinner table with special attributes ([[didukh]], garlic, hay and others), performing koliadky ('carols') and so on. Each ritual has its own meaning and purpose, as such a few wisps of hay on the embroidered table cloth as a reminder of the manger in Bethlehem. One the most prominent customs of the night is a special supper, called ''[[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|Sviata Vecherya]]'' (Holy Supper).
-
-[[Kutia]] (sweet grain pudding) is traditionally served at the [[Ukrainian cuisine|Ukrainian]] Christmas dinner table. It is often the first dish in the traditional [[twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper]] (also known as ''Svyaty Vechir'') and is rarely served at other times of the year.<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html Sviat Vechir<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
-
-==Koliadky (Caroling)==
-At the end of the Sviata Vechera the family often sings Ukrainian [[Christmas carol]]s. In many communities the ancient Ukrainian tradition of caroling is carried on by groups of young people and members of organizations and churches calling at homes and collecting donations.  The Ukrainian song "[[Shchedryk (song)|Shchedryk]]" became the basis for the world-famous Christmas carol, "[[Carol of the Bells]]". Another well-known carol is [[Boh predvičnyj narodivsja]].<ref name=BLiturgy>{{cite web|title=Boh predvičnyj|url=http://mci.archpitt.org/legacy/songs/Slavonic/Boh_predvicnyj.html|website=Metropolitan Cantor Institute|publisher=Byzantine Catholic|accessdate=12 August 2015|ref=Archeparchy of Pittsburgh}}</ref>
-
-==Didukh (Grandfather)==
-
-When the children see the first star in the eastern evening sky, symbolizing the trek of the [[Three Wise Men]], the Sviata Vecherya may begin. In farming communities the head of the household now brings in a sheaf of wheat called the didukh which represents the importance of the ancient and rich wheat crops of Ukraine, the staff of life through the centuries. [[Didukh]] means literally "grandfather spirit" so it symbolizes the family's ancestors. In city homes a few stalks of golden wheat in a vase are often used to decorate the table.
-
-==Shopka (Nativity scene)==
-Shopka is a traditional portable nativity scene used to represent nativity and other figures in a puppet form.

[[Didukh]] means literally "grandfather spirit" so it symbolizes the family's ancestors. In city homes a few stalks of golden wheat in a vase are often used to decorate the table.
+When the children see the first star in the eastern evening sky, symbolizing the trek of the [[Three Wise Men]], the Sviata Vecherya may begin. In farming communities the head of the household now brings in a sheaf of wheat called the didukh which represents the importance of the ancient and rich wheat crops of Ukraine, the staff of life through the centuries. [[Didukh]] means literally "grandfather spirit" so it symbolizes the family's ancestors. In city homes a few stalks of golden wheat in a vase are often used to decorate the table.

-jajajajaajajajaj se quedaron sin tarea we jajajajajaj unicornios.com</ 
+{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2014}}
+{{Expand Ukrainian|Різдво в Україні|date=December 2014}}
+[[File:Hnizdovsky Rizdvo3.gif|thumb|300px|[[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper]] by [[Jacques Hnizdovsky]]]]
+[[File:Hnizdovsky Rizdvo2.gif|thumbnail|300px|Christmas [[pattern]] of [[Christmas tree]] and [[Angel]]]]
+Beginning 2017, '''Ukrainian Christmas''' festivities start on [[Christmas Eve]], which is celebrated on 24 December following the [[Gregorian calendar]] in official use in the Western Christian communities of Ukraine. The Christmas celebrations end on 19 January, the date of "Jordan" or [[Epiphany (holiday)|Epiphany]] in the [[Julian calendar]].<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/ Christmas Traditions<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
+
+Both the December 25 [[Western Christianity]] Christmas Day and the January 7 Christmas Day of the [[Eastern Orthodox Church]] and [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church]]es following the [[Julian calendar|Julian Calendar]], are [[public holidays in Ukraine]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://m.digitaljournal.com/news/world/ukraine-seeks-distance-from-moscow-with-new-christmas-holiday/article/507753|title=Ukraine seeks distance from Moscow with new Christmas holiday|website=m.digitaljournal.com|access-date=2017-11-16}}</ref><ref>{{uk icon}} {{Cite news|url=http://www.bbc.com/ukrainian/news-42008437|title=Рада зробила 25 грудня вихідним днем|date=2017-11-16|work=BBC Україна|access-date=2017-11-16|language=en-GB}}</ref> With these two holiday dates the Ukrainian Christmas period lasts for an extended period, with the celebrations starting on December 6, the Western Christian observance of the Feast of Saint Nicholas and ending on the aforementioned January 19 the following year.
+
+==Sviatyi Vechir (Holy Evening)==
+
+Christmas Eve, or as it called 'Sviatyi Vechir' in Ukrainian ('Holy Evening') is filled with numerous customs and rituals. The customs include: decorating house and dinner table with special attributes ([[didukh]], garlic, hay and others), performing koliadky ('carols') and so on. Each ritual has its own meaning and purpose, as such a few wisps of hay on the embroidered table cloth as a reminder of the manger in Bethlehem. One the most prominent customs of the night is a special supper, called ''[[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|Sviata Vecherya]]'' (Holy Supper).
+
+[[Kutia]] (sweet grain pudding) is traditionally served at the [[Ukrainian cuisine|Ukrainian]] Christmas dinner table. It is often the first dish in the traditional [[twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper]] (also known as ''Svyaty Vechir'') and is rarely served at other times of the year.<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html Sviat Vechir<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
+
+==Koliadky (Caroling)==
+At the end of the Sviata Vechera the family often sings Ukrainian [[Christmas carol]]s. In many communities the ancient Ukrainian tradition of caroling is carried on by groups of young people and members of organizations and churches calling at homes and collecting donations.  The Ukrainian song "[[Shchedryk (song)|Shchedryk]]" became the basis for the world-famous Christmas carol, "[[Carol of the Bells]]". Another well-known carol is [[Boh predvičnyj narodivsja]].<ref name=BLiturgy>{{cite web|title=Boh predvičnyj|url=http://mci.archpitt.org/legacy/songs/Slavonic/Boh_predvicnyj.html|website=Metropolitan Cantor Institute|publisher=Byzantine Catholic|accessdate=12 August 2015|ref=Archeparchy of Pittsburgh}}</ref>
+
+==Didukh (Grandfather)==
+
+When the children see the first star in the eastern evening sky, symbolizing the trek of the [[Three Wise Men]], the Sviata Vecherya may begin. In farming communities the head of the household now brings in a sheaf of wheat called the didukh which represents the importance of the ancient and rich wheat crops of Ukraine, the staff of life through the centuries. [[Didukh]] means literally "grandfather spirit" so it symbolizes the family's ancestors. In city homes a few stalks of golden wheat in a vase are often used to decorate the table.
+
+==Shopka (Nativity scene)==
+Shopka is a traditional portable nativity scene used to represent nativity and other figures in a puppet form.

+When the children see the first star in the eastern evening sky, symbolizing the trek of the [[Three Men in a boat]], by honey singh may begin. [[Didukh]] means literally "grandfather spirit" so it symbolizes the family's ancestors. In city homes a few stalks of golden wheat in a vase are often used to decorate the table, they also decorate the dinner table with garlic.
 
 ==Shopka (Nativity scene)==
 Shopka is a traditional portable nativity scene used to represent nativity and other figures in a puppet form.

 Traditional '''Ukrainian Christmas''' festivities start on [[Christmas Eve]], which is celebrated on 6 January following the [[Julian calendar]]. The Christmas celebrations end on 19 January, the date of "Yordan" or [[Epiphany (holiday)|Epiphany]] in the [[Julian calendar]].<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/ Christmas Traditions<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
 
 As of 2017, December 25, Christmas day by the [[Gregorian calendar|Gregorian]], became an official government holiday.  ==Sviatyi Vechir (Holy Evening)==
 
-[[Christmas Eve|Christmas Eve,]] or as it called 'Sviatyi Vechir' in Ukrainian ('Holy Evening') is filled with numerous customs and rituals. The customs include: decorating house and dinner table with special attributes ([[didukh]], [[garlic]], hay and others), performing [[Koliada|koliadky]] ('carols') and so on. Each ritual has its own meaning and purpose, as such a few wisps of hay on the embroidered tablecloth as a reminder of the manger in [[Bethlehem]]. One the most prominent customs of the night is a special supper, called ''[[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|Sviata Vecherya]]'' (Holy Supper).
+[[Christmas Eve]], or as it called 'Sviatyi Vechir' in Ukrainian ('Holy Evening') is filled with numerous customs and rituals. The customs include: decorating house and dinner table with special attributes ([[didukh]], [[garlic]], hay and others), performing [[Koliada|koliadky]] ('carols') and so on. Each ritual has its own meaning and purpose, as such a few wisps of hay on the embroidered tablecloth as a reminder of the manger in [[Bethlehem]]. One the most prominent customs of the night is a special supper, called ''[[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|Sviata Vecherya]]'' (Holy Supper).
 
 These [[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|twelve dishes]] traditionally do not contain meat, milk, or eggs when served for this meal. <ref>{{cite web |title=Christmas in Ukraine |url=https://www.whychristmas.com/cultures/ukraine.shtml |website=Why Christmas |access-date=14 December 2020}}</ref>[[Kutia]] (sweet grain pudding) is traditionally served at the [[Ukrainian cuisine|Ukrainian]] Christmas dinner table. It is often the first dish in the traditional [[twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper]] (also known as ''Svyaty Vechir'') and is rarely served at other times of the year.<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html Sviat Vechir<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>

+

In farming communities the head of the household now brings in a sheaf of wheat called the didukh which represents the importance of the ancient and rich wheat crops of Ukraine, the staff of life through the centuries. [[Didukh]] means literally "grandfather spirit" so it symbolizes the family's ancestors. In city homes a few stalks of golden wheat in a vase are often used to decorate the table.
 
 ==Shopka (Nativity scene)==
 Shopka is a traditional portable nativity scene used to represent nativity and other figures in a puppet form.

 ==Koliadky (Caroling)==
 At the end of the Sviata Vechera the family often sings "koliadky". In many communities the ancient Ukrainian tradition of caroling is carried on by groups of young people and members of organizations and churches calling at homes and collecting donations.  The Ukrainian song "[[Shchedryk (song)|Shchedryk]]" became the basis for the world famous Christmas carol, "[[Carol of the Bells]]". Another well-known carol is [[Boh predvičnyj narodivsja]].<ref name=BLiturgy>{{cite web|title=Boh predvičnyj|url=http://mci.archpitt.org/legacy/songs/Slavonic/Boh_predvicnyj.html|website=Metropolitan Cantor Institute|publisher=Byzantine Catholic|accessdate=12 August 2015|ref=Archeparchy of Pittsburgh}}</ref>
 
-==[[Didukh]] (Grandfather)==
+==Didukh (Grandfather)==
 
-When the children see the first star in the eastern evening sky, symbolizing the trek of the [[Three Men in a boat]], by honey singh may begin. In farming communities the head of the household now brings in a sheaf of wheat called the didukh which represents the importance of the ancient and rich wheat crops of Ukraine, the staff of life through the centuries. [[Didukh]] means literally "grandfather spirit" so it symbolizes the family's ancestors. In city homes a few stalks of golden wheat in a vase are often used to decorate the table, they also decorate the dinner table with garlic.
+When the children see the [[Star of Bethlehem|first star]] in the eastern evening sky, the dinner may begin. In farming communities the head of the household brings in a sheaf of wheat called the [[didukh]] which represents the importance of the ancient and rich wheat crops of Ukraine, the staff of life through the centuries. Didukh means literally "grandfather spirit" so it symbolizes the family's ancestors. In city homes a few stalks of golden wheat in a vase are often used to decorate the table, they also decorate the dinner table with garlic.
 
 ==Shopka (Nativity scene)==
 Shopka is a traditional portable nativity scene used to represent nativity and other figures in a puppet form.

 Traditional '''Ukrainian Christmas''' festivities start on [[Christmas Eve]], which is celebrated on 6 January following the [[Julian calendar]]. The Christmas celebrations end on 19 January, the date of "Yordan" or [[Epiphany (holiday)|Epiphany]] in the [[Julian calendar]].<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/ Christmas Traditions<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> The winter holiday cycle is said to begin with [[December 1]], St. Roman's day; the period from December 1 to [[January 19]] is thus jokingly called "Ukrainian [[Ramadan]]" (from Roman to Yordan).<ref>{{Cite web|title=Від Романа до Йордана – український Рамадан: стартували зимові празники|url=https://zik.ua/news/2016/12/01/vid_romana_do_yordana__ukrainskyy_ramadan_startuvaly_zymovi_prazdnyky_1000915}}</ref>
 
-As of 2017, December 25, Christmas day by the [[Gregorian calendar|Gregorian]], became an official government holiday. [[Eastern Orthodox Church|The Eastern Orthodox Church]] and [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church|Ukrainian Greek Catholic Churches]] predominately follow the [[Julian calendar|Julian Calendar]], and January 7 is also a [[Public holidays in Ukraine|public holiday in Ukraine]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://m.digitaljournal.com/news/world/ukraine-seeks-distance-from-moscow-with-new-christmas-holiday/article/507753|title=Ukraine seeks distance from Moscow with new Christmas holiday|website=m.digitaljournal.com|access-date=2017-11-16}}</ref><ref>{{in lang|uk}} {{Cite news|url=http://www.bbc.com/ukrainian/news-42008437|title=Рада зробила 25 грудня вихідним днем|date=2017-11-16|work=BBC Україна|access-date=2017-11-16|language=en-GB}}</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine|OCU]], [[Epiphanius I of Ukraine|Metropolitan Epiphanius]], said that changing the date of Christmas to December 25 in Ukraine is possible after both the church and the faithful are ready for such a decision, after conducting educational work. It was stated that the postponement of the Nativity of the Lord would entail a change in the dates of all fixed holidays to 13 days ago.<ref>https://news.rbc.ua/ukr/politics/epifaniy-nazval-uslovie-perenosa-prazdnovaniya-1608382147.html</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church|UGCC]], [[Sviatoslav Shevchuk|Patriarch Sviatoslav]], stated that the Greek Catholic Church would resolve this issue "together with our Orthodox brothers." He also noted that this issue is not dogmatic, it should overcome church divisions, not cause new ones, and in his opinion, the transition to celebrating Christmas in a new style, ie December 25, should be initiated by the laity. 
+As of 2017, December 25, Christmas day by the [[Gregorian calendar|Gregorian]], became an official government holiday. [[Eastern Orthodox Church|The Eastern Orthodox Church]] and [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church|Ukrainian Greek Catholic Churches]] predominately follow the [[Julian calendar|Julian Calendar]], and January 7 is also a [[Public holidays in Ukraine|public holiday in Ukraine]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://m.digitaljournal.com/news/world/ukraine-seeks-distance-from-moscow-with-new-christmas-holiday/article/507753|title=Ukraine seeks distance from Moscow with new Christmas holiday|website=m.digitaljournal.com|access-date=2017-11-16}}</ref><ref>{{in lang|uk}} {{Cite news|url=http://www.bbc.com/ukrainian/news-42008437|title=Рада зробила 25 грудня вихідним днем|date=2017-11-16|work=BBC Україна|access-date=2017-11-16|language=en-GB}}</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine|OCU]], [[Epiphanius I of Ukraine|Metropolitan Epiphanius]], said that changing the date of Christmas to December 25 in Ukraine is possible after both the church and the faithful are ready for such a decision, after conducting educational work. It was stated that the postponement of the Nativity of the Lord would entail a change in the dates of all fixed holidays to 13 days ago.<ref>https://news.rbc.ua/ukr/politics/epifaniy-nazval-uslovie-perenosa-prazdnovaniya-1608382147.html</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church|UGCC]], [[Sviatoslav Shevchuk|Patriarch Sviatoslav]], stated that the Greek Catholic Church would resolve this issue "together with our Orthodox brothers." He also noted that this issue is not dogmatic, it should overcome church divisions, not cause new ones, and in his opinion, the transition to celebrating Christmas in a new style — December 25, should be initiated by the laity. 
 
 ==Sviatyi Vechir (Holy Evening)==

Not Weaponised – The change does not introduce or remove any language that could be interpreted as weaponizing cultural heritage. It appears to be a straightforward edit without political implications.

It was stated that the postponement of the Nativity of the Lord would entail a change in the dates of all fixed holidays to 13 days ago.<ref>https://news.rbc.ua/ukr/politics/epifaniy-nazval-uslovie-perenosa-prazdnovaniya-1608382147.html</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church|UGCC]], [[Sviatoslav Shevchuk|Patriarch Sviatoslav]], stated that the Greek Catholic Church would resolve this issue "together with our Orthodox brothers." He also noted that this issue is not dogmatic, it should overcome church divisions, not cause new ones, and in his opinion, the transition to celebrating Christmas in a new style — December 25, should be initiated by the laity.

 [[Christmas Eve]], or as it called ''Sviatyi Vechir'' or ''Sviatvechir'' in Ukrainian ("Holy Evening") is filled with numerous customs and rituals. Traditions include decorating house and dinner table with special attributes (a symbolic sheaf of wheat called the [[didukh|''didukh'']], [[garlic]], hay, and others), performing [[Koliada|koliadky]] ('carols') and so on.  Each ritual has its own meaning and purpose, as such a few wisps of hay on the embroidered tablecloth as a reminder of the manger in [[Bethlehem]]. One the most prominent customs of the night is a special supper, called ''[[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|Sviata Vecheria]]'' ("Holy Supper").{{fact|date=December 2020}}

It is often the first dish in the traditional [[twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|twelve-dish Christmas-Eve supper]] and is rarely served at other times of the year.<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html Sviat Vechir<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>

It is often the first dish in the traditional [[twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|twelve-dish Christmas-Eve supper]] and is rarely served at other times of the year.<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html Sviat Vechir<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
 
 ==Koliadky (Caroling)==
 At the end of the Sviata Vechera the family often sings carols (''koliadky'', singular ''koliadka''). In many communities the ancient Ukrainian tradition of caroling is carried on by groups of young people and members of organizations and churches calling at homes and collecting donations. Well-known carol is "[[Boh predvičnyj narodivsja|Boh predvichnyi narodyvsia]]".<ref name=BLiturgy>{{cite web|title=Boh predvičnyj|url=http://mci.archpitt.org/legacy/songs/Slavonic/Boh_predvicnyj.html|website=Metropolitan Cantor Institute|publisher=Byzantine Catholic|access-date=12 August 2015|ref=Archeparchy of Pittsburgh}}</ref>
 
 ==Didukh (Grandfather)==

==Sviaty Vechir (Holy Evening)== 
<ref>http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html</ref>

changed_version:

@@ -24,7 +24,7 @@
 
 ==Sviatyi Vechir (Holy Evening)==
 
-[[Christmas Eve]], or as its called ''Sviatyi Vechir'' or ''Sviatvechir'' in Ukrainian ("Holy Evening") is filled with numerous customs and rituals. Traditions include decorating house and dinner table with special attributes (a symbolic sheaf of wheat called the ''[[didukh]]'', [[garlic]], hay, and others), performing [[Koliada|koliadky]] ('carols') and so on.  Each ritual has its own meaning and purpose, as such a few wisps of hay on the embroidered tablecloth as a reminder of the manger in [[Bethlehem]]. One the most prominent customs of the night is a special supper, called ''[[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|Sviata Vecheria]]'' ("Holy Supper").{{fact|date=December 2020}}
+[[Christmas Eve]], or as its called ''Sviatyi Vechir'' or ''Sviatvechir'' in Ukrainian ("Holy Evening") is filled with numerous customs and rituals. Traditions include decorating house and dinner table with special attributes (a symbolic sheaf of wheat called the ''[[didukh]]'', [[garlic]], hay, and others), performing [[Koliada|koliadky]] ('carols') and so on.  Each ritual has its own meaning and purpose, as such a few wisps of hay on the embroidered tablecloth as a reminder of the manger in [[Bethlehem]]. One prominent customs of the night is a special supper, called ''[[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|Sviata Vecheria]]'' ("Holy Supper").{{fact|date=December 2020}}
 
 Whole family brings together to have a dinner which includes 12 dishes. These [[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|twelve dishes]] traditionally do not contain meat, milk, or eggs when served for this meal. <ref>{{cite web |title=Christmas in Ukraine |url=https://www.whychristmas.com/cultures/ukraine.shtml |website=Why Christmas |access-date=14 December 2020}}</ref>[[Kutia]] (sweet grain pudding) is traditionally served at the [[Ukrainian cuisine|Ukrainian]] Christmas dinner table. It is often the first dish in the traditional [[twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|twelve-dish Christmas-Eve supper]] and is rarely served at other times of the year.<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html Sviat Vechir<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>

@@ -33,7 +33,7 @@
 
 ==Didukh (Grandfather)==
 
-When the children see the [[Star of Bethlehem|first star]] in the eastern evening sky, the dinner may begin. In farming communities the head of the household brings in a sheaf of wheat called the [[didukh|''didukh'']] which represents the importance of the ancient and rich wheat crops of Ukraine, the staff of life through the centuries. Didukh means literally "grandfather spirit" so it symbolizes the family's ancestors. In city homes a few stalks of golden wheat in a vase are often used to decorate the table, they also decorate the dinner table with garlic.
+When the children see the [[Star of Bethlehem|first star]] in the eastern evening sky, the dinner may begin. In farming communities the head of the household brings in a sheaf of wheat called the ''[[didukh]]'' which represents the importance of the ancient and rich wheat crops of Ukraine, the staff of life through the centuries. Didukh means literally "grandfather spirit" so it symbolizes the family's ancestors. In city homes a few stalks of golden wheat in a vase are often used to decorate the table, they also decorate the dinner table with garlic.
 
 ==Shopka (Nativity scene)==
 A [[Nativity scene|''shopka'']] is a traditional portable [[Nativity of Jesus|nativity]] scene used to represent nativity and other figures in a [[Nativity play|puppet]] form.

-Traditional '''Ukrainian Christmas''' festivities start on [[Christmas Eve]], which is celebrated on 6 January following the [[Julian calendar]]. The Christmas celebrations end on 19 January, the date of "Yordan" or [[Epiphany (holiday)|Epiphany]] in the [[Julian calendar]].<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/ Christmas Traditions<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> The winter holiday cycle is said to begin with 1 December, St. Roman's day; the period from 1 December to 19 January is thus jokingly called "Ukrainian [[Ramadan]]" (from Roman to Yordan).<ref>{{Cite web|title=Від Романа до Йордана – український Рамадан: стартували зимові празники|url=https://zik.ua/news/2016/12/01/vid_romana_do_yordana__ukrainskyy_ramadan_startuvaly_zymovi_prazdnyky_1000915}}</ref>
+Traditional '''Ukrainian Christmas''' festivities start on [[Christmas Eve]], which is celebrated on 6 January following the [[Julian calendar]]. The Christmas celebrations end on 19 January, the date of "Yordan" or [[Epiphany (holiday)|Epiphany]] in the [[Julian calendar]].<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/ Christmas Traditions<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
 
 As of 2017, 25 December, Christmas day by the [[Gregorian calendar|Gregorian]], became an official government holiday. [[Eastern Orthodox Church|The Eastern Orthodox Church]] and [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church|Ukrainian Greek Catholic Churches]] predominately follow the [[Julian calendar|Julian Calendar]], and 7 January is also a [[Public holidays in Ukraine|public holiday in Ukraine]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://m.digitaljournal.com/news/world/ukraine-seeks-distance-from-moscow-with-new-christmas-holiday/article/507753|title=Ukraine seeks distance from Moscow with new Christmas holiday|website=m.digitaljournal.com|access-date=2017-11-16}}</ref><ref>{{in lang|uk}} {{Cite news|url=http://www.bbc.com/ukrainian/news-42008437|title=Рада зробила 25 грудня вихідним днем|date=2017-11-16|work=BBC Україна|access-date=2017-11-16|language=en-GB}}</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine|OCU]], [[Epiphanius I of Ukraine|Metropolitan Epiphanius]], said that changing the date of Christmas to 25 December in Ukraine is possible after both the church and the faithful are ready for such a decision, after conducting educational work. It was stated that the postponement of the Nativity of the Lord would entail a change in the dates of all fixed holidays to 13 days ago.<ref>https://news.rbc.ua/ukr/politics/epifaniy-nazval-uslovie-perenosa-prazdnovaniya-1608382147.html</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church|UGCC]], [[Sviatoslav Shevchuk|Patriarch Sviatoslav]], stated that the Greek Catholic Church would resolve this issue "together with our Orthodox brothers." He also noted that this issue is not dogmatic, it should overcome church divisions, not cause new ones, and in his opinion, the transition to celebrating Christmas in a new style — 25 December, should be initiated by the laity.
llm_output:
Removed a phrase about the winter holiday cycle being jokingly called "Ukrainian Ramadan."

Not Weaponised. The change appears to be a minor edit that removes a cultural reference without altering the overall narrative or introducing any weaponised language.

It was stated that the postponement of the Nativity of the Lord would entail a change in the dates of all fixed holidays to 13 days ago.<ref>https://news.rbc.ua/ukr/politics/epifaniy-nazval-uslovie-perenosa-prazdnovaniya-1608382147.html</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church|UGCC]], [[Sviatoslav Shevchuk|Patriarch Sviatoslav]], stated that the Greek Catholic Church would resolve this issue "together with our Orthodox brothers." He also noted that this issue is not dogmatic, it should overcome church divisions, not cause new ones, and in his opinion, the transition to celebrating Christmas in a new style — 25 December, should be initiated by the laity.
+As of 2017, 25 December, Christmas day by the [[Gregorian calendar|Gregorian]] calendar, became an official government holiday in Ukraine. [[Eastern Orthodox Church|The Eastern Orthodox Church]] and [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church|Ukrainian Greek Catholic Churches]] predominately follow the [[Julian calendar|Julian Calendar]], and 7 January is also a [[Public holidays in Ukraine|public holiday in Ukraine]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://m.digitaljournal.com/news/world/ukraine-seeks-distance-from-moscow-with-new-christmas-holiday/article/507753|title=Ukraine seeks distance from Moscow with new Christmas holiday|website=m.digitaljournal.com|access-date=2017-11-16}}</ref><ref>{{in lang|uk}} {{Cite news|url=http://www.bbc.com/ukrainian/news-42008437|title=Рада зробила 25 грудня вихідним днем|date=2017-11-16|work=BBC Україна|access-date=2017-11-16|language=en-GB}}</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine]], [[Epiphanius I of Ukraine|Metropolitan Epiphanius]], said that changing the date of Christmas to 25 December in Ukraine is possible after both the church and the faithful are ready for such a decision, after conducting educational work. It was stated that the postponement of the Nativity of the Lord would entail a change in the dates of all fixed holidays to 13 days ago.<ref>https://news.rbc.ua/ukr/politics/epifaniy-nazval-uslovie-perenosa-prazdnovaniya-1608382147.html</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church|UGCC]], [[Sviatoslav Shevchuk|Patriarch Sviatoslav]], stated that the Greek Catholic Church would resolve this issue "together with our Orthodox brothers." He also noted that this issue is not dogmatic, it should overcome church divisions, not cause new ones, and in his opinion, the transition to celebrating Christmas in a new style — 25 December, should be initiated by the laity.
 
 ==Sviatyi Vechir (Holy Evening)==
 
-[[Christmas Eve]], or as it called 'Sviatyi Vechir' in Ukrainian ('Holy Evening') is filled with numerous customs and rituals. The customs include: decorating house and dinner table with special attributes ([[didukh]], [[garlic]], hay and others), performing [[Koliada|koliadky]] ('carols') and so on. Each ritual has its own meaning and purpose, as such a few wisps of hay on the embroidered tablecloth as a reminder of the manger in [[Bethlehem]]. One the most prominent customs of the night is a special supper, called ''[[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|Sviata Vecherya]]'' (Holy Supper).{{fact|date=December 2020}}
+[[Christmas Eve]], or as it called ''Sviatyi Vechir'' or ''Sviatvechir'' in Ukrainian ("Holy Evening") is filled with numerous customs and rituals. Traditions include decorating house and dinner table with special attributes (a symbolic sheaf of wheat called the [[didukh|''didukh'']], [[garlic]], hay, and others), performing [[Koliada|koliadky]] ('carols') and so on. Each ritual has its own meaning and purpose, as such a few wisps of hay on the embroidered tablecloth as a reminder of the manger in [[Bethlehem]]. One the most prominent customs of the night is a special supper, called ''[[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|Sviata Vecheria]]'' ("Holy Supper").{{fact|date=December 2020}}
 
-These [[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|twelve dishes]] traditionally do not contain meat, milk, or eggs when served for this meal. <ref>{{cite web |title=Christmas in Ukraine |url=https://www.whychristmas.com/cultures/ukraine.shtml |website=Why Christmas |access-date=14 December 2020}}</ref>[[Kutia]] (sweet grain pudding) is traditionally served at the [[Ukrainian cuisine|Ukrainian]] Christmas dinner table. It is often the first dish in the traditional [[twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper]] (also known as ''Svyaty Vechir'') and is rarely served at other times of the year.<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html Sviat Vechir<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
+These [[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|twelve dishes]] traditionally do not contain meat, milk, or eggs when served for this meal. <ref>{{cite web |title=Christmas in Ukraine |url=https://www.whychristmas.com/cultures/ukraine.shtml |website=Why Christmas |access-date=14 December 2020}}</ref>[[Kutia]] (sweet grain pudding) is traditionally served at the [[Ukrainian cuisine|Ukrainian]] Christmas dinner table. It is often the first dish in the traditional [[twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|twelve-dish Christmas-Eve supper]] and is rarely served at other times of the year.<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html Sviat Vechir<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
 
 ==Koliadky (Caroling)==
-At the end of the Sviata Vechera the family often sings "koliadky". In many communities the ancient Ukrainian tradition of caroling is carried on by groups of young people and members of organizations and churches calling at homes and collecting donations.  The Ukrainian song "[[Shchedryk (song)|Shchedryk]]" became the basis for the world famous Christmas carol, "[[Carol of the Bells]]". Another well-known carol is [[Boh predvičnyj narodivsja]].<ref name=BLiturgy>{{cite web|title=Boh predvičnyj|url=http://mci.archpitt.org/legacy/songs/Slavonic/Boh_predvicnyj.html|website=Metropolitan Cantor Institute|publisher=Byzantine Catholic|access-date=12 August 2015|ref=Archeparchy of Pittsburgh}}</ref>
+At the end of the Sviata Vechera the family often sings carols (''koliadky'', singular ''koliadka''). In many communities the ancient Ukrainian tradition of caroling is carried on by groups of young people and members of organizations and churches calling at homes and collecting donations.  The Ukrainian song "[[Shchedryk (song)|Shchedryk]]" became the basis for the world-famous Christmas carol, "[[Carol of the Bells]]". Another well-known carol is "[[Boh predvičnyj narodivsja|Boh predvichnyi narodyvsia]]".<ref name=BLiturgy>{{cite web|title=Boh predvičnyj|url=http://mci.archpitt.org/legacy/songs/Slavonic/Boh_predvicnyj.html|website=Metropolitan Cantor Institute|publisher=Byzantine Catholic|access-date=12 August 2015|ref=Archeparchy of Pittsburgh}}</ref>
 
 ==Didukh (Grandfather)==
 
-When the children see the [[Star of Bethlehem|first star]] in the eastern evening sky, the dinner may begin. In farming communities the head of the household brings in a sheaf of wheat called the [[didukh]] which represents the importance of the ancient and rich wheat crops of Ukraine, the staff of life through the centuries. Didukh means literally "grandfather spirit" so it symbolizes the family's ancestors. In city homes a few stalks of golden wheat in a vase are often used to decorate the table, they also decorate the dinner table with garlic.
+When the children see the [[Star of Bethlehem|first star]] in the eastern evening sky, the dinner may begin. In farming communities the head of the household brings in a sheaf of wheat called the [[didukh|''didukh'']] which represents the importance of the ancient and rich wheat crops of Ukraine, the staff of life through the centuries. Didukh means literally "grandfather spirit" so it symbolizes the family's ancestors. In city homes a few stalks of golden wheat in a vase are often used to decorate the table, they also decorate the dinner table with garlic.
 
 ==Shopka (Nativity scene)==
-[[Nativity scene|Shopka]] is a traditional portable [[Nativity of Jesus|nativity]] scene used to represent nativity and other figures in a [[Nativity play|puppet]] form.
+A [[Nativity scene|''shopka'']] is a traditional portable [[Nativity of Jesus|nativity]] scene used to represent nativity and other figures in a [[Nativity play|puppet]] form.
 
 ==Christmas Tree==
-Small ornaments in the shape of a spider (known as ''pavuchky'', literally "little spiders") and spider yes webs are traditionally a part of Ukrainian Christmas tree decorations. They represent the [[Legend of the Christmas Spider]].
+Small ornaments in the shape of a spider (known as ''pavuchky'', literally "little spiders") and spider webs are traditionally a part of Ukrainian Christmas tree decorations. They represent the [[Legend of the Christmas Spider]].

Traditions include decorating house and dinner table with special attributes (a symbolic sheaf of wheat called the ''[[didukh]]'', [[garlic]], hay, and others), performing [[Koliada|koliadky]] ('carols') and so on.  Each ritual has its own meaning and purpose, as such a few wisps of hay on the embroidered tablecloth as a reminder of the manger in [[Bethlehem]]. One prominent customs of the night is a special supper, called ''[[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|Sviata Vecheria]]'' ("Holy Supper").<ref>{{Cite book|last=Inc|first=World Book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Nks04JbYUSgC&dq=sviata+vecheria&pg=PA33|title=Christmas in Ukraine|date=1997|publisher=World Book .com|isbn=978-0-7166-0897-4|language=en}}</ref>
 
 Whole family brings together to have a dinner which includes 12 dishes. These [[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|twelve dishes]] traditionally do not contain meat, milk, or eggs when served for this meal. <ref>{{cite web |title=Christmas in Ukraine |url=https://www.whychristmas.com/cultures/ukraine.shtml |website=Why Christmas |access-date=14 December 2020}}</ref>[[Kutia]] (sweet grain pudding) is traditionally served at the [[Ukrainian cuisine|Ukrainian]] Christmas dinner table. It is often the first dish in the traditional [[twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|twelve-dish Christmas-Eve supper]] and is rarely served at other times of the year.<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html Sviat Vechir<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
-
 
 ==Koliadky (Caroling)==
 At the end of the Sviata Vechera the family often sings carols (''koliadky'', singular ''koliadka''). In many communities the ancient Ukrainian tradition of caroling is carried on by groups of young people and members of organizations and churches calling at homes and collecting donations. Well-known carol is "[[Boh predvičnyj narodivsja|Boh predvichnyi narodyvsia]]".<ref name=BLiturgy>{{cite web|title=Boh predvičnyj|url=http://mci.archpitt.org/legacy/songs/Slavonic/Boh_predvicnyj.html|website=Metropolitan Cantor Institute|publisher=Byzantine Catholic|access-date=12 August 2015|ref=Archeparchy of Pittsburgh}}</ref>

 |alt=|official_name=|litcolor=|begins=|ends=|weekday=|month=|scheduling=|firsttime=|startedby=}}
 Traditional '''Ukrainian Christmas''' festivities start on [[Christmas Eve]], which is celebrated on 6 January, as reckoned by the [[Julian calendar]]. The Christmas celebrations end on 19 January, the date of [[Epiphany (holiday)|Epiphany]], or ''Yordan'' in Ukrainian, by the [[Julian calendar]].<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/ Christmas Traditions<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
 
-As of 2017, 25 December, Christmas day by the [[Gregorian calendar|Gregorian]] calendar, became an official government holiday in Ukraine. [[Eastern Orthodox Church|The Eastern Orthodox Church]] and [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church|Ukrainian Greek Catholic Churches]] predominantly follow the [[Julian calendar|Julian Calendar]], and 7 January is also a [[Public holidays in Ukraine|public holiday in Ukraine]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://m.digitaljournal.com/news/world/ukraine-seeks-distance-from-moscow-with-new-christmas-holiday/article/507753|title=Ukraine seeks distance from Moscow with new Christmas holiday|website=m.digitaljournal.com|access-date=2017-11-16}}</ref><ref>{{in lang|uk}} {{Cite news|url=http://www.bbc.com/ukrainian/news-42008437|title=Рада зробила 25 грудня вихідним днем|date=2017-11-16|work=BBC Україна|access-date=2017-11-16|language=en-GB}}</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine]], [[Epiphanius I of Ukraine|Metropolitan Epiphanius]], said that changing the date of Christmas to 25 December in Ukraine is possible after both the church and the faithful are ready for such a decision, after conducting educational work. It was stated that the postponement of the Nativity of the Lord would entail a change in the dates of all fixed holidays to 13 days ago.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://news.rbc.ua/ukr/politics/epifaniy-nazval-uslovie-perenosa-prazdnovaniya-1608382147.html|title = Епіфаній назвав умову перенесення святкування Різдва на 25 грудня}}</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church|UGCC]], [[Sviatoslav Shevchuk|Patriarch Sviatoslav]], stated that the Greek Catholic Church would resolve this issue "together with our Orthodox brothers." He also noted that this issue is not dogmatic, it should overcome church divisions, not cause new ones, and in his opinion, the transition to celebrating Christmas in a new style — 25 December, should be initiated by the laity.
+As of 2017, 25 December, Christmas day by the [[Gregorian calendar|Gregorian]] calendar, became an official government holiday in Ukraine. [[Eastern Orthodox Church|The Eastern Orthodox Church]] and [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church|Ukrainian Greek Catholic Churches]] predominantly follow the [[Julian calendar|Julian Calendar]], and 7 January is also a [[Public holidays in Ukraine|public holiday in Ukraine]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://m.digitaljournal.com/news/world/ukraine-seeks-distance-from-moscow-with-new-christmas-holiday/article/507753|title=Ukraine seeks distance from Moscow with new Christmas holiday|website=m.digitaljournal.com|date=16 November 2017|access-date=2017-11-16}}</ref><ref>{{in lang|uk}} {{Cite news|url=http://www.bbc.com/ukrainian/news-42008437|title=Рада зробила 25 грудня вихідним днем|date=2017-11-16|work=BBC Україна|access-date=2017-11-16|language=en-GB}}</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine]], [[Epiphanius I of Ukraine|Metropolitan Epiphanius]], said that changing the date of Christmas to 25 December in Ukraine is possible after both the church and the faithful are ready for such a decision, after conducting educational work. It was stated that the postponement of the Nativity of the Lord would entail a change in the dates of all fixed holidays to 13 days ago.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://news.rbc.ua/ukr/politics/epifaniy-nazval-uslovie-perenosa-prazdnovaniya-1608382147.html|title = Епіфаній назвав умову перенесення святкування Різдва на 25 грудня}}</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church|UGCC]], [[Sviatoslav Shevchuk|Patriarch Sviatoslav]], stated that the Greek Catholic Church would resolve this issue "together with our Orthodox brothers." He also noted that this issue is not dogmatic, it should overcome church divisions, not cause new ones, and in his opinion, the transition to celebrating Christmas in a new style — 25 December, should be initiated by the laity.
 
 ==Sviatyi Vechir (Holy Evening)==

 ==Didukh (Grandfather)==
 
-When the children see the [[Star of Bethlehem|first star]] in the eastern evening sky, the dinner may begin. In farming communities the head of the household brings in a sheaf of wheat called the ''[[didukh]]'' which represents the importance of the ancient and rich wheat crops of Ukraine, the staff of life through the centuries. Didukh means literally "grandfather spirit" so it symbolizes the family's ancestors. In city homes a few stalks of golden wheat in a vase are often used to decorate the table, they also decorate the dinner table with garlic.
+When the children see the [[Star of Bethlehem|first star]] in the eastern evening sky, the dinner may begin. In farming communities the head of the household brings in a sheaf of wheat called the ''[[didukh]]'' which represents the importance of the ancient and rich wheat crops of Ukraine, the staff of life through the centuries. Didukh means literally "grandfather spirit" so it symbolizes the family's ancestors. In city homes a few stalks of golden wheat in a vase are often used to decorate the table, they also decorate the dinner table with garlic.{{fact}}
 
 ==Shopka (Nativity scene)==
 A [[Nativity scene|''shopka'']] is a traditional portable [[Nativity of Jesus|nativity]] scene used to represent nativity and other figures in a [[Nativity play|puppet]] form.

He also noted that this issue is not dogmatic, it should overcome church divisions, not cause new ones, and in his opinion, the transition to celebrating Christmas in a new style — 25 December, should be initiated by the laity.
+As of 2017, 25 December, Christmas Day by the [[Gregorian calendar|Gregorian]] calendar, became an official government holiday in Ukraine. [[Eastern Orthodox Church|The Eastern Orthodox Church]] and [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church|Ukrainian Greek Catholic Churches]] predominantly follow the [[Julian calendar|Julian Calendar]], and 7 January is also a [[Public holidays in Ukraine|public holiday in Ukraine]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://m.digitaljournal.com/news/world/ukraine-seeks-distance-from-moscow-with-new-christmas-holiday/article/507753|title=Ukraine seeks distance from Moscow with new Christmas holiday|website=m.digitaljournal.com|date=16 November 2017|access-date=2017-11-16}}</ref><ref>{{in lang|uk}} {{Cite news|url=http://www.bbc.com/ukrainian/news-42008437|title=Рада зробила 25 грудня вихідним днем|date=2017-11-16|work=BBC Україна|access-date=2017-11-16|language=en-GB}}</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine]], [[Epiphanius I of Ukraine|Metropolitan Epiphanius]], said that changing the date of Christmas to 25 December in Ukraine is possible after both the church and the faithful are ready for such a decision, after conducting educational work. It was stated that the postponement of the Nativity of the Lord would entail a change in the dates of all fixed holidays to 13 days ago.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://news.rbc.ua/ukr/politics/epifaniy-nazval-uslovie-perenosa-prazdnovaniya-1608382147.html|title = Епіфаній назвав умову перенесення святкування Різдва на 25 грудня}}</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church|UGCC]], [[Sviatoslav Shevchuk|Patriarch Sviatoslav]], stated that the Greek Catholic Church would resolve this issue "together with our Orthodox brothers." He also noted that this issue is not dogmatic, it should overcome church divisions, not cause new ones, and in his opinion, the transition to celebrating Christmas in a new style — 25 December, should be initiated by the laity.
 
 ==Sviatyi Vechir (Holy Evening)==

 When the children see the [[Star of Bethlehem|first star]] in the eastern evening sky, the dinner may begin. In farming communities the head of the household brings in a sheaf of wheat called the ''[[didukh]]'' which represents the importance of the ancient and rich wheat crops of Ukraine, the staff of life through the centuries. @@ -26,7 +26,7 @@
 
 [[Christmas Eve]], or as its called ''Sviatyi Vechir'' or ''Sviatvechir'' in Ukrainian ("Holy Evening") is filled with numerous customs and rituals. Traditions include decorating house and dinner table with special attributes (a symbolic sheaf of wheat called the ''[[didukh]]'', [[garlic]], hay, and others), performing [[Koliada|koliadky]] ('carols') and so on.  Each ritual has its own meaning and purpose, as such a few wisps of hay on the embroidered tablecloth as a reminder of the manger in [[Bethlehem]]. One prominent custom of the night is a special supper, called ''[[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|Sviata Vecheria]]'' ("Holy Supper").<ref>{{Cite book|last=Inc|first=World Book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Nks04JbYUSgC&dq=sviata+vecheria&pg=PA33|title=Christmas in Ukraine|date=1997|publisher=World Book .com|isbn=978-0-7166-0897-4|language=en}}</ref>
 
-Ukrainains fast of Sviat vechir; only when the first star is seen in the evening sky, may the supper begin.  The family comes together to have a dinner which usually includes 12 dishes (the number can vary from 7-17). These [[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|twelve dishes]] are traditionally vegan plus fish, and do not contain meat, milk, or eggs. <ref>{{cite web |title=Christmas in Ukraine |url=https://www.whychristmas.com/cultures/ukraine.shtml |website=Why Christmas |access-date=14 December 2020}}</ref> While the dishes served can vary regionally, as well as from family to family, the two mandatory dishes are uzvar and kutia, both reckoned by ethnographer Khvedir Vovk to be remnants of ancient rituals which date back to the neolithic era.[[Kutia]] (a dish of grain, honey and poppy seeds) is traditionally served first at the meal, after being offered by the head of the household to the frost. A spoonful is tossed at the ceiling, and the number of poppy seeds which stick portends the fruitfulness of the fields and farm animals in the coming year. It is rarely served at other times of the year.<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html Sviat Vechir<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Uzvar is a beverage, made with cooked dried fruits and berries. It can be mixed in with the kutia, or served separately at the end of the meal.  Servings of both dishes are also set aside overnight in the pokuttia, the corner of the house with the icons, for the ancestors.
+Ukrainians fast of Sviat vechir; only when the first star is seen in the evening sky, may the supper begin.  The family comes together to have a dinner which usually includes 12 dishes (the number can vary from 7-17). These [[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|twelve dishes]] are traditionally vegan plus fish, and do not contain meat, milk, or eggs. <ref>{{cite web |title=Christmas in Ukraine |url=https://www.whychristmas.com/cultures/ukraine.shtml |website=Why Christmas |access-date=14 December 2020}}</ref> While the dishes served can vary regionally, as well as from family to family, the two mandatory dishes are uzvar and kutia, both reckoned by ethnographer Khvedir Vovk to be remnants of ancient rituals which date back to the neolithic era.[[Kutia]] (a dish of grain, honey and poppy seeds) is traditionally served first at the meal, after being offered by the head of the household to the frost. A spoonful is tossed at the ceiling, and the number of poppy seeds which stick portends the fruitfulness of the fields and farm animals in the coming year. It is rarely served at other times of the year.<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html Sviat Vechir<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Uzvar is a beverage, made with cooked dried fruits and berries. It can be mixed in with the kutia, or served separately at the end of the meal.  Servings of both dishes are also set aside overnight in the pokuttia, the corner of the house with the icons, for the ancestors.
 
 ==Koliadky (Caroling)==
 At the end of the Sviata Vechera the family often sings carols (''koliadky'', singular ''koliadka''). In many communities the ancient Ukrainian tradition of caroling is carried on by groups of young people and members of organizations and churches calling at homes and collecting donations. A well-known carol is "[[Boh predvičnyj narodivsja|Boh predvichnyi narodyvsia]]".<ref name=BLiturgy>{{cite web|title=Boh predvičnyj|url=http://mci.archpitt.org/legacy/songs/Slavonic/Boh_predvicnyj.html|website=Metropolitan Cantor Institute|publisher=Byzantine Catholic|access-date=12 August 2015|ref=Archeparchy of Pittsburgh|archive-date=4 March 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304235614/http://mci.archpitt.org/legacy/songs/Slavonic/Boh_predvicnyj.html|url-status=dead}}</ref>

It is often the first dish in the traditional [[twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|twelve-dish Christmas-Eve supper]] and is rarely served at other times of the year.<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html Sviat Vechir<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
 
 ==Koliadky (Caroling)==
 At the end of the Sviata Vechera the family often sings carols (''koliadky'', singular ''koliadka''). In many communities the ancient Ukrainian tradition of caroling is carried on by groups of young people and members of organizations and churches calling at homes and collecting donations. A well-known carol is "[[Boh predvičnyj narodivsja|Boh predvichnyi narodyvsia]]".<ref name=BLiturgy>{{cite web|title=Boh predvičnyj|url=http://mci.archpitt.org/legacy/songs/Slavonic/Boh_predvicnyj.html|website=Metropolitan Cantor Institute|publisher=Byzantine Catholic|access-date=12 August 2015|ref=Archeparchy of Pittsburgh|archive-date=4 March 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304235614/http://mci.archpitt.org/legacy/songs/Slavonic/Boh_predvicnyj.html|url-status=dead}}</ref>

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -26,7 +26,7 @@
 
 [[Christmas Eve]] is called ''Sviatyi Vechir'' or ''Sviatvechir'' in Ukraine ("Holy Evening"), and has many customs and rituals, most of which predate the introduction of christianity to Ukraine. Traditions include decorating house and dinner table with special attributes (a symbolic sheaf of wheat called the ''[[didukh]]'', [[garlic]], hay, and others), performing [[Koliada|koliadky]] ('carols') and so on.  Each ritual has its own meaning and purpose, as such a few wisps of hay on the embroidered tablecloth as a reminder of the manger in [[Bethlehem]]. One prominent custom of the night is a special supper, called ''[[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|Sviata Vecheria]]'' ("Holy Supper").<ref>{{Cite book|last=Inc|first=World Book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Nks04JbYUSgC&dq=sviata+vecheria&pg=PA33|title=Christmas in Ukraine|date=1997|publisher=World Book .com|isbn=978-0-7166-0897-4|language=en}}</ref>
 
-Ukrainians fast on Sviat vechir; only when the first star is seen in the evening sky, may the supper begin.  The family comes together to have a dinner which usually includes 12 dishes (the number can vary from 7-17). These [[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|twelve dishes]] are traditionally vegan plus fish, and do not contain meat, milk, or eggs. <ref>{{cite web |title=Christmas in Ukraine |url=https://www.whychristmas.com/cultures/ukraine.shtml |website=Why Christmas |access-date=14 December 2020}}</ref> While the dishes served can vary regionally, as well as from family to family, the two mandatory dishes are uzvar and kutia, both reckoned by ethnographer [[Вовк Федір Кіндратович|Khvedir Vovk]] to be remnants of ancient rituals which date back to the neolithic era. [[Kutia]] (a dish of grain, honey and poppy seeds) is traditionally served first at the meal, after being offered by the head of the household to the frost. A spoonful is tossed at the ceiling, and the number of poppy seeds which stick portends the fruitfulness of the fields and farm animals in the coming year. It is rarely served at other times of the year.<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html Sviat Vechir<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Uzvar is a beverage, made with cooked dried fruits and berries. It can be mixed in with the kutia, or served separately at the end of the meal.  Servings of both dishes are also set aside overnight in the pokuttia, the corner of the house with the icons, for the ancestors.

It can be mixed in with the kutia, or served separately at the end of the meal.  Servings of both dishes are also set aside overnight in the pokuttia, the corner of the house with the icons, for the ancestors.

 At the end of the Sviata Vechera the family often sings carols (''koliadky'', singular ''koliadka'').
