-Traditional '''Ukrainian Christmas''' festivities start on [[Christmas Eve]], which is celebrated on 6 January, as reckoned by the [[Julian calendar]]. The Christmas celebrations end on 19 January, the date of [[Epiphany (holiday)|Epiphany]], or ''Yordan'' in Ukrainian, by the [[Julian calendar]].<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/ Christmas Traditions<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
+Traditional '''Ukrainian Christmas''' festivities start on [[Christmas Eve]], which is celebrated on 6 January, as reckoned by the [[Julian calendar]]. The Christmas celebrations end on 19 January, the date of the celebration of the Baptism of Jesus, known in Ukraine as Vodokhreschhe or Yordan.<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/ Christmas Traditions<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
 
 As of 2017, 25 December, Christmas Day by the [[Gregorian calendar|Gregorian]] calendar, became an official government holiday in Ukraine. [[Eastern Orthodox Church|The Eastern Orthodox Church]] and [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church|Ukrainian Greek Catholic Churches]] predominantly follow the [[Julian calendar|Julian Calendar]], and 7 January is also a [[Public holidays in Ukraine|public holiday in Ukraine]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://m.digitaljournal.com/news/world/ukraine-seeks-distance-from-moscow-with-new-christmas-holiday/article/507753|title=Ukraine seeks distance from Moscow with new Christmas holiday|website=m.digitaljournal.com|date=16 November 2017|access-date=2017-11-16}}</ref><ref>{{in lang|uk}} {{Cite news|url=http://www.bbc.com/ukrainian/news-42008437|title=Рада зробила 25 грудня вихідним днем|date=2017-11-16|work=BBC Україна|access-date=2017-11-16|language=en-GB}}</ref> In December 2020, the disputed and not universally recognised head of the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine]], [[Epiphanius I of Ukraine|Metropolitan Epiphanius]], said that changing the date of Christmas to 25 December in Ukraine is possible after both the church and the faithful are ready for such a decision, after conducting educational work. It was stated that the postponement of the Nativity of the Lord would entail a change in the dates of all fixed holidays to 13 days ago.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://news.rbc.ua/ukr/politics/epifaniy-nazval-uslovie-perenosa-prazdnovaniya-1608382147.html|title = Епіфаній назвав умову перенесення святкування Різдва на 25 грудня}}</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church|UGCC]], [[Sviatoslav Shevchuk|Patriarch Sviatoslav]], stated that the Greek Catholic Church would resolve this issue "together with our Orthodox brothers." He also noted that this issue is not dogmatic, it should overcome church divisions, not cause new ones, and in his opinion, the transition to celebrating Christmas in a new style — 25 December, should be initiated by the laity.
comment: Epiphany is not celebrated in Ukraine on the 19th

 |alt=|official_name=|litcolor=|begins=|ends=|weekday=|month=|scheduling=|firsttime=|startedby=}}
 Traditional '''Ukrainian Christmas''' festivities start on [[Christmas Eve]], which is celebrated on 6 January, as reckoned by the [[Julian calendar]]. The Christmas celebrations end on 19 January, the date of the celebration of the Baptism of Jesus, known in Ukraine as Vodokhreschhe or Yordan.<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/ Christmas Traditions<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
 
-As of 2017, 25 December, Christmas Day by the [[Gregorian calendar|Gregorian]] calendar, became an official government holiday in Ukraine. [[Eastern Orthodox Church|The Eastern Orthodox Church]] and [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church|Ukrainian Greek Catholic Churches]] predominantly follow the [[Julian calendar|Julian Calendar]], and 7 January is also a [[Public holidays in Ukraine|public holiday in Ukraine]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://m.digitaljournal.com/news/world/ukraine-seeks-distance-from-moscow-with-new-christmas-holiday/article/507753|title=Ukraine seeks distance from Moscow with new Christmas holiday|website=m.digitaljournal.com|date=16 November 2017|access-date=2017-11-16}}</ref><ref>{{in lang|uk}} {{Cite news|url=http://www.bbc.com/ukrainian/news-42008437|title=Рада зробила 25 грудня вихідним днем|date=2017-11-16|work=BBC Україна|access-date=2017-11-16|language=en-GB}}</ref> In December 2020, the disputed and not universally recognised head of the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine]], [[Epiphanius I of Ukraine|Metropolitan Epiphanius]], said that changing the date of Christmas to 25 December in Ukraine is possible after both the church and the faithful are ready for such a decision, after conducting educational work. It was stated that the postponement of the Nativity of the Lord would entail a change in the dates of all fixed holidays to 13 days ago.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://news.rbc.ua/ukr/politics/epifaniy-nazval-uslovie-perenosa-prazdnovaniya-1608382147.html|title = Епіфаній назвав умову перенесення святкування Різдва на 25 грудня}}</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church|UGCC]], [[Sviatoslav Shevchuk|Patriarch Sviatoslav]], stated that the Greek Catholic Church would resolve this issue "together with our Orthodox brothers." He also noted that this issue is not dogmatic, it should overcome church divisions, not cause new ones, and in his opinion, the transition to celebrating Christmas in a new style — 25 December, should be initiated by the laity.
+As of 2017, 25 December, Christmas Day by the [[Gregorian calendar|Gregorian]] calendar, became an official government holiday in Ukraine. [[Eastern Orthodox Church|The Eastern Orthodox Church]] and [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church|Ukrainian Greek Catholic Churches]] predominantly follow the [[Julian calendar|Julian Calendar]], and 7 January is also a [[Public holidays in Ukraine|public holiday in Ukraine]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://m.digitaljournal.com/news/world/ukraine-seeks-distance-from-moscow-with-new-christmas-holiday/article/507753|title=Ukraine seeks distance from Moscow with new Christmas holiday|website=m.digitaljournal.com|date=16 November 2017|access-date=2017-11-16}}</ref><ref>{{in lang|uk}} {{Cite news|url=http://www.bbc.com/ukrainian/news-42008437|title=Рада зробила 25 грудня вихідним днем|date=2017-11-16|work=BBC Україна|access-date=2017-11-16|language=en-GB}}</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine]], [[Epiphanius I of Ukraine|Metropolitan Epiphanius]], said that changing the date of Christmas to 25 December in Ukraine is possible after both the church and the faithful are ready for such a decision, after conducting educational work. It was stated that the postponement of the Nativity of the Lord would entail a change in the dates of all fixed holidays to 13 days ago.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://news.rbc.ua/ukr/politics/epifaniy-nazval-uslovie-perenosa-prazdnovaniya-1608382147.html|title = Епіфаній назвав умову перенесення святкування Різдва на 25 грудня}}</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church|UGCC]], [[Sviatoslav Shevchuk|Patriarch Sviatoslav]], stated that the Greek Catholic Church would resolve this issue "together with our Orthodox brothers." He also noted that this issue is not dogmatic, it should overcome church divisions, not cause new ones, and in his opinion, the transition to celebrating Christmas in a new style — 25 December, should be initiated by the laity.
 
 ==Sviatyi Vechir (Holy Evening)==

initial_version:
The Ukrainian Christmas  festive days according to the Julian calendar, start on January 6th, Christmas Eve and ends with January 19th, "Jordan" or Epiphany.<ref>http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/</ref>

==Sviaty Vechir (Holy Evening)== 
<ref>http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html</ref>





==Koliadky - (Caroling)==


==Did Moroz - (Grandfather Frost)==



{{Reflist}}
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -26,7 +26,7 @@
 
 [[Christmas Eve]], or as its called ''Sviatyi Vechir'' or ''Sviatvechir'' in Ukrainian ("Holy Evening") is filled with numerous customs and rituals, most of which predate the introduction of christianity to Ukraine. Traditions include decorating house and dinner table with special attributes (a symbolic sheaf of wheat called the ''[[didukh]]'', [[garlic]], hay, and others), performing [[Koliada|koliadky]] ('carols') and so on.  Each ritual has its own meaning and purpose, as such a few wisps of hay on the embroidered tablecloth as a reminder of the manger in [[Bethlehem]]. One prominent custom of the night is a special supper, called ''[[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|Sviata Vecheria]]'' ("Holy Supper").<ref>{{Cite book|last=Inc|first=World Book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Nks04JbYUSgC&dq=sviata+vecheria&pg=PA33|title=Christmas in Ukraine|date=1997|publisher=World Book .com|isbn=978-0-7166-0897-4|language=en}}</ref>
 
-Ukrainians fast on Sviat vechir; only when the first star is seen in the evening sky, may the supper begin.  The family comes together to have a dinner which usually includes 12 dishes (the number can vary from 7-17). These [[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|twelve dishes]] are traditionally vegan plus fish, and do not contain meat, milk, or eggs. <ref>{{cite web |title=Christmas in Ukraine |url=https://www.whychristmas.com/cultures/ukraine.shtml |website=Why Christmas |access-date=14 December 2020}}</ref> While the dishes served can vary regionally, as well as from family to family, the two mandatory dishes are uzvar and kutia, both reckoned by ethnographer [[Вовк Федір Кіндратович|Khvedir Vovk]] to be remnants of ancient rituals which date back to the neolithic era.[[Kutia]] (a dish of grain, honey and poppy seeds) is traditionally served first at the meal, after being offered by the head of the household to the frost. A spoonful is tossed at the ceiling, and the number of poppy seeds which stick portends the fruitfulness of the fields and farm animals in the coming year. It is rarely served at other times of the year.<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html Sviat Vechir<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Uzvar is a beverage, made with cooked dried fruits and berries. It can be mixed in with the kutia, or served separately at the end of the meal.  Servings of both dishes are also set aside overnight in the pokuttia, the corner of the house with the icons, for the ancestors.
+Ukrainians fast on Sviat vechir; only when the first star is seen in the evening sky, may the supper begin.  The family comes together to have a dinner which usually includes 12 dishes (the number can vary from 7-17). These [[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|twelve dishes]] are traditionally vegan plus fish, and do not contain meat, milk, or eggs. <ref>{{cite web |title=Christmas in Ukraine |url=https://www.whychristmas.com/cultures/ukraine.shtml |website=Why Christmas |access-date=14 December 2020}}</ref> While the dishes served can vary regionally, as well as from family to family, the two mandatory dishes are uzvar and kutia, both reckoned by ethnographer [[Вовк Федір Кіндратович|Khvedir Vovk]] to be remnants of ancient rituals which date back to the neolithic era. [[Kutia]] (a dish of grain, honey and poppy seeds) is traditionally served first at the meal, after being offered by the head of the household to the frost. A spoonful is tossed at the ceiling, and the number of poppy seeds which stick portends the fruitfulness of the fields and farm animals in the coming year. It is rarely served at other times of the year.<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html Sviat Vechir<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Uzvar is a beverage, made with cooked dried fruits and berries. It can be mixed in with the kutia, or served separately at the end of the meal.  Servings of both dishes are also set aside overnight in the pokuttia, the corner of the house with the icons, for the ancestors.
 
 ==Koliadky (Caroling)==
 At the end of the Sviata Vechera the family often sings carols (''koliadky'', singular ''koliadka''). In many communities the ancient Ukrainian tradition of caroling is carried on by groups of young people and members of organizations and churches calling at homes and collecting donations. A well-known carol is "[[Boh predvičnyj narodivsja|Boh predvichnyi narodyvsia]]".<ref name=BLiturgy>{{cite web|title=Boh predvičnyj|url=http://mci.archpitt.org/legacy/songs/Slavonic/Boh_predvicnyj.html|website=Metropolitan Cantor Institute|publisher=Byzantine Catholic|access-date=12 August 2015|ref=Archeparchy of Pittsburgh|archive-date=4 March 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304235614/http://mci.archpitt.org/legacy/songs/Slavonic/Boh_predvicnyj.html|url-status=dead}}</ref>

initial_version:
The Ukrainian Christmas  festive days according to the Julian calendar, start on January 6th, Christmas Eve and ends with January 19th, "Jordan" or Epiphany.<ref>http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/</ref>

{{Reflist}}
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -26,7 +26,7 @@
 
 [[Christmas Eve]], or as its called ''Sviatyi Vechir'' or ''Sviatvechir'' in Ukrainian ("Holy Evening") is filled with numerous customs and rituals, most of which predate the introduction of christianity to Ukraine. Traditions include decorating house and dinner table with special attributes (a symbolic sheaf of wheat called the ''[[didukh]]'', [[garlic]], hay, and others), performing [[Koliada|koliadky]] ('carols') and so on.  Each ritual has its own meaning and purpose, as such a few wisps of hay on the embroidered tablecloth as a reminder of the manger in [[Bethlehem]]. One prominent custom of the night is a special supper, called ''[[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|Sviata Vecheria]]'' ("Holy Supper").<ref>{{Cite book|last=Inc|first=World Book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Nks04JbYUSgC&dq=sviata+vecheria&pg=PA33|title=Christmas in Ukraine|date=1997|publisher=World Book .com|isbn=978-0-7166-0897-4|language=en}}</ref>
 
-Ukrainians fast on Sviat vechir; only when the first star is seen in the evening sky, may the supper begin.  The family comes together to have a dinner which usually includes 12 dishes (the number can vary from 7-17). These [[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|twelve dishes]] are traditionally vegan plus fish, and do not contain meat, milk, or eggs. <ref>{{cite web |title=Christmas in Ukraine |url=https://www.whychristmas.com/cultures/ukraine.shtml |website=Why Christmas |access-date=14 December 2020}}</ref> While the dishes served can vary regionally, as well as from family to family, the two mandatory dishes are uzvar and kutia, both reckoned by ethnographer Khvedir Vovk to be remnants of ancient rituals which date back to the neolithic era.[[Kutia]] (a dish of grain, honey and poppy seeds) is traditionally served first at the meal, after being offered by the head of the household to the frost. A spoonful is tossed at the ceiling, and the number of poppy seeds which stick portends the fruitfulness of the fields and farm animals in the coming year. It is rarely served at other times of the year.<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html Sviat Vechir<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Uzvar is a beverage, made with cooked dried fruits and berries. It can be mixed in with the kutia, or served separately at the end of the meal.  Servings of both dishes are also set aside overnight in the pokuttia, the corner of the house with the icons, for the ancestors.
+Ukrainians fast on Sviat vechir; only when the first star is seen in the evening sky, may the supper begin.  The family comes together to have a dinner which usually includes 12 dishes (the number can vary from 7-17). These [[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|twelve dishes]] are traditionally vegan plus fish, and do not contain meat, milk, or eggs. <ref>{{cite web |title=Christmas in Ukraine |url=https://www.whychristmas.com/cultures/ukraine.shtml |website=Why Christmas |access-date=14 December 2020}}</ref> While the dishes served can vary regionally, as well as from family to family, the two mandatory dishes are uzvar and kutia, both reckoned by ethnographer [[Вовк Федір Кіндратович|Khvedir Vovk]] to be remnants of ancient rituals which date back to the neolithic era.[[Kutia]] (a dish of grain, honey and poppy seeds) is traditionally served first at the meal, after being offered by the head of the household to the frost. A spoonful is tossed at the ceiling, and the number of poppy seeds which stick portends the fruitfulness of the fields and farm animals in the coming year. It is rarely served at other times of the year.<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html Sviat Vechir<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Uzvar is a beverage, made with cooked dried fruits and berries. It can be mixed in with the kutia, or served separately at the end of the meal.  Servings of both dishes are also set aside overnight in the pokuttia, the corner of the house with the icons, for the ancestors.
 
 ==Koliadky (Caroling)==
 At the end of the Sviata Vechera the family often sings carols (''koliadky'', singular ''koliadka''). In many communities the ancient Ukrainian tradition of caroling is carried on by groups of young people and members of organizations and churches calling at homes and collecting donations. A well-known carol is "[[Boh predvičnyj narodivsja|Boh predvichnyi narodyvsia]]".<ref name=BLiturgy>{{cite web|title=Boh predvičnyj|url=http://mci.archpitt.org/legacy/songs/Slavonic/Boh_predvicnyj.html|website=Metropolitan Cantor Institute|publisher=Byzantine Catholic|access-date=12 August 2015|ref=Archeparchy of Pittsburgh|archive-date=4 March 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304235614/http://mci.archpitt.org/legacy/songs/Slavonic/Boh_predvicnyj.html|url-status=dead}}</ref>
llm_output:

**Weaponised**: The inclusion of the Ukrainian name in its original script emphasizes cultural identity and heritage, which can be seen as a response to narratives that seek to undermine or erase Ukrainian cultural contributions. This aligns with a broader context of asserting Ukrainian identity in the face of external pressures.

-Traditional '''Ukrainian Christmas''' festivities start on [[Christmas Eve]], which is celebrated on 6 January, as reckoned by the [[Julian calendar]]. The Christmas celebrations end on 19 January, the date of the celebration of the Baptism of Jesus, known in Ukraine as Vodokhreschhe or Yordan.<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/ Christmas Traditions<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
+Traditional '''Ukrainian Christmas''' festivities start on [[Christmas Eve]], which is celebrated on 6 January, as reckoned by the [[Julian calendar]]. The Christmas celebrations end on 19 January, the date of the celebration of the [[Baptism of Jesus]], known in [[Ukraine]] as Vodokhreschhe (''Водо́хреще'') or Yordan.<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/ Christmas Traditions<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
 
 As of 2017, 25 December, Christmas Day by the [[Gregorian calendar|Gregorian]] calendar, became an official government holiday in Ukraine. [[Eastern Orthodox Church|The Eastern Orthodox Church]] and [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church|Ukrainian Greek Catholic Churches]] predominantly follow the [[Julian calendar|Julian Calendar]], and 7 January is also a [[Public holidays in Ukraine|public holiday in Ukraine]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://m.digitaljournal.com/news/world/ukraine-seeks-distance-from-moscow-with-new-christmas-holiday/article/507753|title=Ukraine seeks distance from Moscow with new Christmas holiday|website=m.digitaljournal.com|date=16 November 2017|access-date=2017-11-16}}</ref><ref>{{in lang|uk}} {{Cite news|url=http://www.bbc.com/ukrainian/news-42008437|title=Рада зробила 25 грудня вихідним днем|date=2017-11-16|work=BBC Україна|access-date=2017-11-16|language=en-GB}}</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine]], [[Epiphanius I of Ukraine|Metropolitan Epiphanius]], said that changing the date of Christmas to 25 December in Ukraine is possible after both the church and the faithful are ready for such a decision, after conducting educational work. It was stated that the postponement of the Nativity of the Lord would entail a change in the dates of all fixed holidays to 13 days ago.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://news.rbc.ua/ukr/politics/epifaniy-nazval-uslovie-perenosa-prazdnovaniya-1608382147.html|title = Епіфаній назвав умову перенесення святкування Різдва на 25 грудня}}</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church|UGCC]], [[Sviatoslav Shevchuk|Patriarch Sviatoslav]], stated that the Greek Catholic Church would resolve this issue "together with our Orthodox brothers." He also noted that this issue is not dogmatic, it should overcome church divisions, not cause new ones, and in his opinion, the transition to celebrating Christmas in a new style — 25 December, should be initiated by the laity.

-[[Christmas Eve]] is called ''Sviatyi Vechir'' or ''Sviatvechir'' in Ukraine ("Holy Evening"), and has many customs and rituals, most of which predate the introduction of christianity to Ukraine. Traditions include decorating house and dinner table with special attributes (a symbolic sheaf of wheat called the ''[[didukh]]'', [[garlic]], hay, and others), performing [[Koliada|koliadky]] ('carols') and so on.  Each ritual has its own meaning and purpose, as such a few wisps of hay on the embroidered tablecloth as a reminder of the manger in [[Bethlehem]]. One prominent custom of the night is a special supper, called ''[[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|Sviata Vecheria]]'' ("Holy Supper").<ref>{{Cite book|last=Inc|first=World Book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Nks04JbYUSgC&dq=sviata+vecheria&pg=PA33|title=Christmas in Ukraine|date=1997|publisher=World Book .com|isbn=978-0-7166-0897-4|language=en}}</ref>
+[[Christmas Eve]] is called Sviatyi Vechir (''Святий вечір'') or Sviatvechir (''Святвечір'') in Ukraine ("Holy Evening"), and has many customs and rituals, most of which predate the introduction of christianity to Ukraine. Traditions include decorating house and dinner table with special attributes (a symbolic sheaf of wheat called the ''[[didukh]]'', [[garlic]], hay, and others), performing [[Koliada|koliadky]] ('carols') and so on.  Each ritual has its own meaning and purpose, as such a few wisps of hay on the embroidered tablecloth as a reminder of the manger in [[Bethlehem]]. One prominent custom of the night is a special supper, called ''[[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|Sviata Vecheria]]'' ("Holy Supper").<ref>{{Cite book|last=Inc|first=World Book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Nks04JbYUSgC&dq=sviata+vecheria&pg=PA33|title=Christmas in Ukraine|date=1997|publisher=World Book .com|isbn=978-0-7166-0897-4|language=en}}</ref>
 
 Ukrainians fast on Sviat vechir; only when the first star is seen in the evening sky, may the supper begin.  The family comes together to have a dinner which usually includes 12 dishes (the number can vary from 7-17). These [[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|twelve dishes]] are traditionally vegan plus fish, and do not contain meat, milk, or eggs. <ref>{{cite web |title=Christmas in Ukraine |url=https://www.whychristmas.com/cultures/ukraine.shtml |website=Why Christmas |access-date=14 December 2020}}</ref> While the dishes served can vary regionally, as well as from family to family, the two mandatory dishes are uzvar and kutia, both reckoned by ethnographer [[Fedir Vovk|Khvedir Vovk]] to be remnants of ancient rituals which date back to the neolithic era.<ref>{{cite web |title=Traditional Recipe of Ukrainian Kutia |url=https://etnocook.com/kutia/ |website=Ethnocook |access-date=27 November 2022}}</ref> [[Kutia]] (a dish of grain, honey and poppy seeds) is traditionally served first at the meal, after being offered by the head of the household to the frost. A spoonful is tossed at the ceiling, and the number of poppy seeds which stick portends the fruitfulness of the fields and farm animals in the coming year. It is rarely served at other times of the year.<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html Sviat Vechir<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Uzvar is a beverage, made with cooked dried fruits and berries. It can be mixed in with the kutia, or served separately at the end of the meal.  Servings of both dishes are also set aside overnight in the pokuttia, the corner of the house with the icons, for the ancestors.

It was stated that the postponement of the Nativity of the Lord would entail a change in the dates of all fixed holidays to 13 days ago.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://news.rbc.ua/ukr/politics/epifaniy-nazval-uslovie-perenosa-prazdnovaniya-1608382147.html|title = Епіфаній назвав умову перенесення святкування Різдва на 25 грудня}}</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church|UGCC]], [[Sviatoslav Shevchuk|Patriarch Sviatoslav]], stated that the Greek Catholic Church would resolve this issue "together with our Orthodox brothers." It was stated that the postponement of the Nativity of the Lord would entail a change in the dates of all fixed holidays to 13 days ago.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://news.rbc.ua/ukr/politics/epifaniy-nazval-uslovie-perenosa-prazdnovaniya-1608382147.html|title = Епіфаній назвав умову перенесення святкування Різдва на 25 грудня}}</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church|UGCC]], [[Sviatoslav Shevchuk|Patriarch Sviatoslav]], stated that the Greek Catholic Church would resolve this issue "together with our Orthodox brothers." He also noted that this issue is not dogmatic, it should overcome church divisions, not cause new ones, and in his opinion, the transition to celebrating Christmas in a new style — 25 December, should be initiated by the laity.

 As of 2017, 25 December, Christmas Day by the [[Gregorian calendar|Gregorian]] calendar, became an official government holiday in Ukraine. [[Eastern Orthodox Church|The Eastern Orthodox Church]] and [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church|Ukrainian Greek Catholic Churches]] predominantly follow the Julian calendar, and 7 January is also a [[Public holidays in Ukraine|public holiday in Ukraine]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://m.digitaljournal.com/news/world/ukraine-seeks-distance-from-moscow-with-new-christmas-holiday/article/507753|title=Ukraine seeks distance from Moscow with new Christmas holiday|website=m.digitaljournal.com|date=16 November 2017|access-date=2017-11-16}}</ref><ref>{{in lang|uk}} {{Cite news|url=http://www.bbc.com/ukrainian/news-42008437|title=Рада зробила 25 грудня вихідним днем|date=2017-11-16|work=BBC Україна|access-date=2017-11-16|language=en-GB}}</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine]], [[Epiphanius I of Ukraine|Metropolitan Epiphanius]], said that changing the date of Christmas to 25 December in Ukraine is possible after both the church and the faithful are ready for such a decision, after conducting educational work. It was stated that the postponement of the Nativity of the Lord would entail a change in the dates of all fixed holidays to 13 days ago.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://news.rbc.ua/ukr/politics/epifaniy-nazval-uslovie-perenosa-prazdnovaniya-1608382147.html|title = Епіфаній назвав умову перенесення святкування Різдва на 25 грудня}}</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church|UGCC]], [[Sviatoslav Shevchuk|Patriarch Sviatoslav]], stated that the Greek Catholic Church would resolve this issue "together with our Orthodox brothers." He also noted that this issue is not dogmatic, it should overcome church divisions, not cause new ones, and in his opinion, the transition to celebrating Christmas in a new style — 25 December, should be initiated by the laity.

 |alt=|official_name=|litcolor=|begins=|ends=|weekday=|month=|scheduling=|firsttime=|startedby=}}
 Traditional '''Ukrainian Christmas''' festivities start on [[Christmas Eve]], which is celebrated on 6 January, as reckoned by the [[Julian calendar]]. The Christmas celebrations end on 19 January, the date of the celebration of the [[Baptism of Jesus]], known in [[Ukraine]] as Vodokhreschhe (''Водо́хреще'') or Yordan.<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/ Christmas Traditions<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
 
+== Date of celebration ==
 As of 2017, 25 December, Christmas Day by the [[Gregorian calendar|Gregorian]] calendar, became an official government holiday in Ukraine. [[Eastern Orthodox Church|The Eastern Orthodox Church]] and [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church|Ukrainian Greek Catholic Churches]] predominantly follow the Julian calendar, and 7 January is also a [[Public holidays in Ukraine|public holiday in Ukraine]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://m.digitaljournal.com/news/world/ukraine-seeks-distance-from-moscow-with-new-christmas-holiday/article/507753|title=Ukraine seeks distance from Moscow with new Christmas holiday|website=m.digitaljournal.com|date=16 November 2017|access-date=2017-11-16}}</ref><ref>{{in lang|uk}} {{Cite news|url=http://www.bbc.com/ukrainian/news-42008437|title=Рада зробила 25 грудня вихідним днем|date=2017-11-16|work=BBC Україна|access-date=2017-11-16|language=en-GB}}</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine]], [[Epiphanius I of Ukraine|Metropolitan Epiphanius]], said that changing the date of Christmas to 25 December in Ukraine is possible after both the church and the faithful are ready for such a decision, after conducting educational work. It was stated that the postponement of the Nativity of the Lord would entail a change in the dates of all fixed holidays to 13 days ago.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://news.rbc.ua/ukr/politics/epifaniy-nazval-uslovie-perenosa-prazdnovaniya-1608382147.html|title = Епіфаній назвав умову перенесення святкування Різдва на 25 грудня}}</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church|UGCC]], [[Sviatoslav Shevchuk|Patriarch Sviatoslav]], stated that the Greek Catholic Church would resolve this issue "together with our Orthodox brothers." He also noted that this issue is not dogmatic, it should overcome church divisions, not cause new ones, and in his opinion, the transition to celebrating Christmas in a new style — 25 December, should be initiated by the laity.
 
 On October 18, 2022, the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine]] allowed dioceses to hold Christmas services according to the [[Revised Julian calendar]], i.e., December 25. In the case of a divine service, its participants are released from the restrictions of fasting on this day.<ref>{{Cite web |title=OCU allowed Christmas services on December 25 |url=https://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2022/10/18/7372478/ |accessdate=2022-10-18 |website=[[Ukrainian Pravda]] |language=uk}}</ref>
+
+On [[December 24]], [[2022]], during an [[audience]], [[Major archbishop]] [[Sviatoslav Shevchuk|Sviatoslav]] handed over to [[Metropolitan of Kyiv and All Ukraine|Metropolitan]] [[Epiphanius I of Ukraine|Epiphanius]] for review a letter outlining the considerations of the UGCC hierarchs regarding the {{ill|Calendar reform in Ukraine|lt=calendar reform|uk|Календарна реформа в Україні|display=1}}. The primates decided to create a joint working group on specific proposals for calendar reform. The joint group is initiated on the occasion of the celebration of the 1700th anniversary of the [[First Council of Nicaea|First Ecumenical Council]], held in [[Nicaea]] in 325. In this [[Ecumenical council|Council]], in particular, the calendar principles of church life were determined.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Heads of OCU, UGCC agree to set up working group to reform church calendar |url=https://www.ukrinform.net/rubric-society/3640576-heads-of-ocu-ugcc-agree-to-set-up-working-group-to-reform-church-calendar.html |access-date=2022-12-24 |website=www.ukrinform.net |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=During the meeting of His Beatitude Sviatoslav with His Beatitude Epiphanius, they talked about the reform of the church calendar |url=https://news.ugcc.ua/data/pid-chas-zustrichi-blazhennishogo-svyatoslava-z-blazhennishym-epifaniem-govoryly-pro-reformu-tserkovnogo-kalendarya-1713/ |access-date=2022-12-24 |website=Українська Греко-Католицька Церква |language=uk}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2022-12-24 |title=There was a meeting of the Primate of the OCU with the Father and the Primate of the UGCC |url=https://www.pomisna.info/uk/vsi-novyny/vidbulasya-zustrich-predstoyatelya-ptsu-z-ottsem-i-glavoyu-ugkts/ |access-date=2022-12-24 |website=OCU |language=uk}}</ref>
 
 ==Sviatyi Vechir (Holy Evening)==

 ==Sviatyi Vechir (Holy Evening)==
 
-[[Christmas Eve]] is called Sviatyi Vechir (''Святий вечір'') or Sviatvechir (''Святвечір'') in Ukraine ("Holy Evening"), and has many customs and rituals, most of which predate the introduction of christianity to Ukraine. Traditions include decorating house and dinner table with special attributes (a symbolic sheaf of wheat called the ''[[didukh]]'', [[garlic]], hay, and others), performing [[Koliada|koliadky]] ('carols') and so on.  Each ritual has its own meaning and purpose, as such a few wisps of hay on the embroidered tablecloth as a reminder of the manger in [[Bethlehem]]. One prominent custom of the night is a special supper, called ''[[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|Sviata Vecheria]]'' ("Holy Supper").<ref>{{Cite book|last=Inc|first=World Book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Nks04JbYUSgC&dq=sviata+vecheria&pg=PA33|title=Christmas in Ukraine|date=1997|publisher=World Book .com|isbn=978-0-7166-0897-4|language=en}}</ref>
+[[Christmas Eve]] is called Sviatyi Vechir (''Святий вечір'') or Sviatvechir (''Святвечір'') in Ukraine ("Holy Evening"), and has many customs and rituals, most of which predate the introduction of Christianity to Ukraine. Traditions include decorating house and dinner table with special attributes (a symbolic sheaf of wheat called the ''[[didukh]]'', [[garlic]], hay, and others), performing [[Koliada|koliadky]] ('carols') and so on.  Each ritual has its own meaning and purpose, as such a few wisps of hay on the embroidered tablecloth as a reminder of the manger in [[Bethlehem]]. One prominent custom of the night is a special supper, called ''[[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|Sviata Vecheria]]'' ("Holy Supper").<ref>{{Cite book|last=Inc|first=World Book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Nks04JbYUSgC&dq=sviata+vecheria&pg=PA33|title=Christmas in Ukraine|date=1997|publisher=World Book .com|isbn=978-0-7166-0897-4|language=en}}</ref>
 
-Ukrainians fast on Sviat vechir; only when the first star is seen in the evening sky, may the supper begin.  The family comes together to have a dinner which usually includes 12 dishes (the number can vary from 7-17). These [[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|twelve dishes]] are traditionally vegan plus fish, and do not contain meat, milk, or eggs. <ref>{{cite web |title=Christmas in Ukraine |url=https://www.whychristmas.com/cultures/ukraine.shtml |website=Why Christmas |access-date=14 December 2020}}</ref> While the dishes served can vary regionally, as well as from family to family, the two mandatory dishes are uzvar and kutia, both reckoned by ethnographer [[Fedir Vovk|Khvedir Vovk]] to be remnants of ancient rituals which date back to the neolithic era.<ref>{{cite web |title=Traditional Recipe of Ukrainian Kutia |url=https://etnocook.com/kutia/ |website=Ethnocook |access-date=27 November 2022}}</ref> [[Kutia]] (a dish of grain, honey and poppy seeds) is traditionally served first at the meal, after being offered by the head of the household to the frost. A spoonful is tossed at the ceiling, and the number of poppy seeds which stick portends the fruitfulness of the fields and farm animals in the coming year. It is rarely served at other times of the year.<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html Sviat Vechir<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Uzvar is a beverage, made with cooked dried fruits and berries. It can be mixed in with the kutia, or served separately at the end of the meal.  Servings of both dishes are also set aside overnight in the pokuttia, the corner of the house with the icons, for the ancestors.
+Ukrainians fast on Sviat vechir; only when the first star is seen in the evening sky, may the supper begin.  The family comes together to have a dinner which usually includes 12 dishes (the number can vary from 7–17). These [[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|twelve dishes]] are traditionally vegan plus fish, and do not contain meat, milk, or eggs.<ref>{{cite web |title=Christmas in Ukraine |url=https://www.whychristmas.com/cultures/ukraine.shtml |website=Why Christmas |access-date=14 December 2020}}</ref> While the dishes served can vary regionally, as well as from family to family, the two mandatory dishes are uzvar and kutia, both reckoned by ethnographer [[Fedir Vovk|Khvedir Vovk]] to be remnants of ancient rituals which date back to the neolithic era.<ref>{{cite web |title=Traditional Recipe of Ukrainian Kutia |url=https://etnocook.com/kutia/ |website=Ethnocook |access-date=27 November 2022}}</ref> [[Kutia]] (a dish of grain, honey and poppy seeds) is traditionally served first at the meal, after being offered by the head of the household to the frost. A spoonful is tossed at the ceiling, and the number of poppy seeds which stick portends the fruitfulness of the fields and farm animals in the coming year. It is rarely served at other times of the year.<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html Sviat Vechir<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Uzvar is a beverage, made with cooked dried fruits and berries. It can be mixed in with the kutia, or served separately at the end of the meal.  Servings of both dishes are also set aside overnight in the pokuttia, the corner of the house with the icons, for the ancestors.
 
 ==Koliadky (Caroling)==
-At the end of the Sviata Vechera the family often sings carols (''koliadky'', singular ''koliadka''). In many communities the ancient Ukrainian tradition of caroling is carried on by groups of young people and members of organizations and churches calling at homes and collecting donations. A well-known carol is ''{{ill|Nova radist stala|lt=|uk|Нова радість стала|display=1}}'', [[Boh predvičnyj narodivsja|''Boh predvichnyi narodyvsia'']],<ref name=BLiturgy>{{cite web|title=Boh predvičnyj|url=http://mci.archpitt.org/legacy/songs/Slavonic/Boh_predvicnyj.html|website=Metropolitan Cantor Institute|publisher=Byzantine Catholic|access-date=12 August 2015|ref=Archeparchy of Pittsburgh|archive-date=4 March 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304235614/http://mci.archpitt.org/legacy/songs/Slavonic/Boh_predvicnyj.html|url-status=dead}}</ref> ''{{ill|Dobryi vechir tobi, pane hospodariu|lt=|uk|Добрий вечір тобі, пане господарю|display=1}}'', ''{{ill|Vo Vyfleiemi nyni novyna|lt=|uk|Во Вифлеємі нині новина|display=1}}'', ''{{ill|Nebo i zemlia nyni torzhestvuiut|lt=|uk|Небо і земля нині торжествують|display=1}}'', ''{{ill|Boh sia rozhdaie|lt=|uk|Бог ся раджае|display=1}}'' ect.
+At the end of the Sviata Vechera the family often sings carols (''koliadky'', singular ''koliadka''). In many communities the ancient Ukrainian tradition of caroling is carried on by groups of young people and members of organizations and churches calling at homes and collecting donations. A well-known carol is ''{{ill|Nova radist stala|lt=|uk|Нова радість стала|display=1}}'', [[Boh predvičnyj narodivsja|''Boh predvichnyi narodyvsia'']],<ref name=BLiturgy>{{cite web|title=Boh predvičnyj|url=http://mci.archpitt.org/legacy/songs/Slavonic/Boh_predvicnyj.html|website=Metropolitan Cantor Institute|publisher=Byzantine Catholic|access-date=12 August 2015|ref=Archeparchy of Pittsburgh|archive-date=4 March 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304235614/http://mci.archpitt.org/legacy/songs/Slavonic/Boh_predvicnyj.html|url-status=dead}}</ref> ''{{ill|Dobryi vechir tobi, pane hospodariu|lt=|uk|Добрий вечір тобі, пане господарю|display=1}}'', ''{{ill|Vo Vyfleiemi nyni novyna|lt=|uk|Во Вифлеємі нині новина|display=1}}'', ''{{ill|Nebo i zemlia nyni torzhestvuiut|lt=|uk|Небо і земля нині торжествують|display=1}}'', ''{{ill|Boh sia rozhdaie|lt=|uk|Бог ся раджае|display=1}}'' etc.
 
 ==Didukh (Grandfather)==
 
-In villages (farming communities), the head of the household brings in a sheaf of grain called the ''[[didukh]]'' which represents the importance of the ancient and rich wheat crops of Ukraine, the staff of life through the centuries. Didukh means literally "grandfather spirit" so it symbolizes the family's ancestors. In Ukrainian city homes the didukh may be purchased, and is often three footed made of woven grain and dried grasses and flowers.{{fact|date=April 2022}}
+In villages (farming communities), the head of the household brings in a sheaf of grain called the ''[[didukh]]'' which represents the importance of the ancient and rich wheat crops of Ukraine, the staff of life through the centuries. Didukh means literally "grandfather spirit" so it symbolizes the family's ancestors. In Ukrainian city homes the didukh may be purchased, and is often three footed made of woven grain and dried grasses and flowers.{{citation needed|date=April 2022}}
 
 ==Shopka (Nativity scene)==
-A ''[[Nativity scene|shopka]] ([[vertep]])'' is a traditional portable [[Nativity of Jesus|nativity]] scene used to represent nativity and other figures in a [[Nativity play|puppet]] form.{{fact|date=April 2022}}
+A ''[[Nativity scene|shopka]] ([[vertep]])'' is a traditional portable [[Nativity of Jesus|nativity]] scene used to represent nativity and other figures in a [[Nativity play|puppet]] form.{{citation needed|date=April 2022}}

changed_version:

@@ -34,7 +34,7 @@
 Ukrainians fast on Sviat vechir; only when the first star is seen in the evening sky, may the supper begin.  The family comes together to have a dinner which usually includes 12 dishes (the number can vary from 7-17). These [[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|twelve dishes]] are traditionally vegan plus fish, and do not contain meat, milk, or eggs. <ref>{{cite web |title=Christmas in Ukraine |url=https://www.whychristmas.com/cultures/ukraine.shtml |website=Why Christmas |access-date=14 December 2020}}</ref> While the dishes served can vary regionally, as well as from family to family, the two mandatory dishes are uzvar and kutia, both reckoned by ethnographer [[Fedir Vovk|Khvedir Vovk]] to be remnants of ancient rituals which date back to the neolithic era.<ref>{{cite web |title=Traditional Recipe of Ukrainian Kutia |url=https://etnocook.com/kutia/ |website=Ethnocook |access-date=27 November 2022}}</ref> [[Kutia]] (a dish of grain, honey and poppy seeds) is traditionally served first at the meal, after being offered by the head of the household to the frost. A spoonful is tossed at the ceiling, and the number of poppy seeds which stick portends the fruitfulness of the fields and farm animals in the coming year. It is rarely served at other times of the year.<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html Sviat Vechir<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Uzvar is a beverage, made with cooked dried fruits and berries. It can be mixed in with the kutia, or served separately at the end of the meal.  Servings of both dishes are also set aside overnight in the pokuttia, the corner of the house with the icons, for the ancestors.
 
 ==Koliadky (Caroling)==
-At the end of the Sviata Vechera the family often sings carols (''koliadky'', singular ''koliadka''). In many communities the ancient Ukrainian tradition of caroling is carried on by groups of young people and members of organizations and churches calling at homes and collecting donations. @@ -25,9 +25,9 @@
 
 As of 2017, 25 December, Christmas Day by the [[Gregorian calendar|Gregorian]] calendar, became an official government holiday in Ukraine. [[Eastern Orthodox Church|The Eastern Orthodox Church]] and [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church]]es predominantly follow the Julian calendar, and 7 January is also a [[Public holidays in Ukraine|public holiday in Ukraine]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://m.digitaljournal.com/news/world/ukraine-seeks-distance-from-moscow-with-new-christmas-holiday/article/507753|title=Ukraine seeks distance from Moscow with new Christmas holiday|website=m.digitaljournal.com|date=16 November 2017|access-date=2017-11-16}}</ref><ref>{{in lang|uk}} {{Cite news|url=http://www.bbc.com/ukrainian/news-42008437|title=Рада зробила 25 грудня вихідним днем|date=2017-11-16|work=BBC Україна|access-date=2017-11-16|language=en-GB}}</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine]], [[Epiphanius I of Ukraine|Metropolitan Epiphanius]], said that changing the date of Christmas to 25 December in Ukraine is possible after both the church and the faithful are ready for such a decision, after conducting educational work. It was stated that the postponement of the Nativity of the Lord would entail a change in the dates of all fixed holidays to 13 days ago.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://news.rbc.ua/ukr/politics/epifaniy-nazval-uslovie-perenosa-prazdnovaniya-1608382147.html|title = Епіфаній назвав умову перенесення святкування Різдва на 25 грудня}}</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church|UGCC]], [[Sviatoslav Shevchuk|Patriarch Sviatoslav]], stated that the Greek Catholic Church would resolve this issue "together with our Orthodox brothers." He also noted that this issue is not dogmatic, it should overcome church divisions, not cause new ones, and in his opinion, the transition to celebrating Christmas in a new style — 25 December, should be initiated by the laity.
 
-On October 18, 2022, the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine]] allowed dioceses to hold Christmas services according to the [[Revised Julian calendar]], i.e., December 25. In the case of a divine service, its participants are released from the restrictions of fasting on this day.<ref>{{Cite web |title=OCU allowed Christmas services on December 25 |url=https://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2022/10/18/7372478/ |accessdate=2022-10-18 |website=[[Ukrainian Pravda]] |language=uk}}</ref>
+On 18 October 2022, the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine]] allowed dioceses to hold Christmas services according to the [[Revised Julian calendar]], i.e., 25 December. In the case of a divine service, its participants are released from the restrictions of fasting on this day.<ref>{{Cite web |title=OCU allowed Christmas services on December 25 |url=https://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2022/10/18/7372478/ |accessdate=2022-10-18 |website=[[Ukrainian Pravda]] |language=uk}}</ref>
 
-On December 24, 2022, during an [[audience]], [[Major archbishop]] [[Sviatoslav Shevchuk|Sviatoslav]] handed over to [[Metropolitan of Kyiv and All Ukraine|Metropolitan]] [[Epiphanius I of Ukraine|Epiphanius]] for review a letter outlining the considerations of the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church|UGCC]] hierarchs regarding the {{ill|Calendar reform in Ukraine|lt=calendar reform|uk|Календарна реформа в Україні|display=1}}. The primates decided to create a joint working group on specific proposals for calendar reform. The joint group is initiated on the occasion of the celebration of the 1700th anniversary of the [[First Council of Nicaea|First Ecumenical Council]], held in [[Nicaea]] in 325. In this [[Ecumenical council|Council]], in particular, the calendar principles of church life were determined.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Heads of OCU, UGCC agree to set up working group to reform church calendar |url=https://www.ukrinform.net/rubric-society/3640576-heads-of-ocu-ugcc-agree-to-set-up-working-group-to-reform-church-calendar.html |access-date=2022-12-24 |website=www.ukrinform.net |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=During the meeting of His Beatitude Sviatoslav with His Beatitude Epiphanius, they talked about the reform of the church calendar |url=https://news.ugcc.ua/data/pid-chas-zustrichi-blazhennishogo-svyatoslava-z-blazhennishym-epifaniem-govoryly-pro-reformu-tserkovnogo-kalendarya-1713/ |access-date=2022-12-24 |website=Українська Греко-Католицька Церква |language=uk}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2022-12-24 |title=There was a meeting of the Primate of the OCU with the Father and the Primate of the UGCC |url=https://www.pomisna.info/uk/vsi-novyny/vidbulasya-zustrich-predstoyatelya-ptsu-z-ottsem-i-glavoyu-ugkts/ |access-date=2022-12-24 |website=OCU |language=uk}}</ref>
+On 24 December 2022, during an [[audience]], [[Major archbishop]] [[Sviatoslav Shevchuk|Sviatoslav]] handed over to [[Metropolitan of Kyiv and All Ukraine|Metropolitan]] [[Epiphanius I of Ukraine|Epiphanius]] for review a letter outlining the considerations of the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church|UGCC]] hierarchs regarding the {{ill|Calendar reform in Ukraine|lt=calendar reform|uk|Календарна реформа в Україні|display=1}}. The primates decided to create a joint working group on specific proposals for calendar reform. The joint group is initiated on the occasion of the celebration of the 1700th anniversary of the [[First Council of Nicaea|First Ecumenical Council]], held in [[Nicaea]] in 325. In this [[Ecumenical council|Council]], in particular, the calendar principles of church life were determined.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Heads of OCU, UGCC agree to set up working group to reform church calendar |url=https://www.ukrinform.net/rubric-society/3640576-heads-of-ocu-ugcc-agree-to-set-up-working-group-to-reform-church-calendar.html |access-date=2022-12-24 |website=www.ukrinform.net |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=During the meeting of His Beatitude Sviatoslav with His Beatitude Epiphanius, they talked about the reform of the church calendar |url=https://news.ugcc.ua/data/pid-chas-zustrichi-blazhennishogo-svyatoslava-z-blazhennishym-epifaniem-govoryly-pro-reformu-tserkovnogo-kalendarya-1713/ |access-date=2022-12-24 |website=Українська Греко-Католицька Церква |language=uk}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2022-12-24 |title=There was a meeting of the Primate of the OCU with the Father and the Primate of the UGCC |url=https://www.pomisna.info/uk/vsi-novyny/vidbulasya-zustrich-predstoyatelya-ptsu-z-ottsem-i-glavoyu-ugkts/ |access-date=2022-12-24 |website=OCU |language=uk}}</ref>
 
 ==Sviatyi Vechir (Holy Evening)==

-Traditional '''Ukrainian Christmas''' festivities start on [[Christmas Eve]], which is celebrated on 24 December in the [[Julian calendar]] used by the [[Eastern Orthodox Church]], which falls on 6 January in the common [[Gregorian calendar]]. changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -31,7 +31,7 @@
 During the early [[History of the Soviet Union|Soviet period]], all religious celebrations were discouraged under the official state policy of [[atheism]]. The [[Bolsheviks]] argued that Christmas was a [[pagan]] [[sun-worship]]ping ritual with no basis in scientific fact and denounced the [[Christmas tree]] as a [[bourgeois]] German import.<ref name=":0" /> In 1929, all religious holidays, including Christmas, were abolished by a decree of the [[Stalinist regime]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|last=|first=|date=2019-12-29|title=How New Year was celebrated in the USSR (PHOTOS)|url=https://www.rbth.com/history/331458-soviet-new-year|url-status=live|access-date=2021-06-12|website=Beyond Russia|language=en-US|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191229111401/https://www.rbth.com/history/331458-soviet-new-year |archive-date=29 December 2019 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=Постановление СНК СССР от 24.09.1929|url=http://www.libussr.ru/doc_ussr/ussr_3594.htm|url-status=live|access-date=2021-06-12|website=www.libussr.ru|language=ru|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161229003241/http://www.libussr.ru:80/doc_ussr/ussr_3594.htm |archive-date=29 December 2016 }}</ref> However, in a surprising turn of state politics in 1935, many Ukrainian Christmas traditions were revived as part of a secular [[New Year's Eve|New Year's]] celebration after [[Joseph Stalin]]'s advisers convinced the [[Vozhd]] of the [[proletarians]]' need for a break from their hard work in the middle of a long, cold winter.<ref name=":1" /> The Christmas tree was repurposed as a "New Year's fir tree" (Russian: Новогодняя елка, ''Novogodnyaya yolka'') to be admired by all children throughout the [[Soviet Union]], including those in republics that had not historically celebrated Christmas due to their different religious traditions, such as the [[Soviet Central Asia|Central Asian ones]]. Other Ukrainian Christmas attributes and traditions, such as [[Christmas gift|gift-giving]], Did Moroz's visits and Christmas decorations, lost their religious significance and became associated with New Year's celebrations, which were secular in nature.<ref name=":0" />
 
 In 1991, after the dissolution of the Soviet Union, Christmas was reinstated alongside other religious holidays.<ref name=":0" /> 
-Especially in recent years, there has been a shift from Did Moroz, which came to be associated with the Soviet-era heritage, to the more traditional [[Saint Nicholas]] (Святий Миколай, ''Sviatyi Mykolai''), who used to be more popular in [[Western Ukraine]].<ref name=MT141120>{{cite news |url= http://www.themoscowtimes.com/news/article/kiev-brings-back-orthodox-santa-claus-instead-of-soviet-era-father-frost/511488.html |title= Kiev Brings Back Orthodox Santa Claus Instead of Soviet-Era Father Frost |work= [[The Moscow Times]] |date= 20 November 2014 }}</ref> There were rumors that Ded Moroz imagery was discouraged by the authorities due to [[Russo-Ukrainian war|conflict with Russia]]; however, the [[Ukrainian Ministry of Culture]] has refuted this.<ref>[https://comments.ua/society/604910-deda-moroza-snegurochku-ukraine.html "Деда Мороза и Снегурочку в Украине никто не запрещал - Минкульт"]</ref>

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -23,13 +23,15 @@
 Christmas was largely erased from the Ukrainian calendar for much of the [[20th century]] due to the [[Persecution of Christians in the Soviet Union|Soviet Union's anti-religious policies]], but many of its traditions survived, having been transplanted to [[Novy God|New Year's Day]].<ref>{{Cite web|last=Tamkin|first=Emily|title=How Soviets Came to Celebrate New Year’s Like Christmas (and Why Russians Still Do)|url=https://foreignpolicy.com/2016/12/30/how-soviets-came-to-celebrate-new-years-like-christmas-and-why-russians-still-do/|access-date=2022-01-13|website=Foreign Policy|language=en-US}}</ref> 
 
 ==History==
+[[File:Новогодние марки Украины Дед Мороз.jpg|thumbnail|Did Moroz on a Ukrainian postage stamp with New Year greeting]]
 In [[Ukraine]], the Christmas holiday became the official celebration with the [[baptism of Rus']] ordered by [[Prince Vladimir]] in the late [[10th century]]. However, given the early Christian community of [[Kievan Rus']], the celebration may have a longer history.
 
 In the [[19th century]], a lavishly decorated Christmas tree became central to the holiday, a tradition originally imported by [[Nicholas I of Russia|Nicholas I]]'s wife, [[Alexandra Feodorovna (Charlotte of Prussia)|Alexandra Feodorovna]], from her native [[Prussia]]. The tradition of giving gifts to children on Christmas took root around the same time.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|last=Weber|first=Hannah|date=25 December 2020|title=Yolka: the story of Russia's 'New Year tree', from pagan origins to Soviet celebrations|url=https://www.calvertjournal.com/articles/show/9424/yolka-russia-new-year-tree-pagan-soviet-christmas|url-status=live|access-date=2021-06-12|website=The Calvert Journal|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180113181107/http://www.calvertjournal.com/articles/show/9424/yolka-russia-new-year-tree-pagan-soviet-christmas |archive-date=13 January 2018 }}</ref> Christmas gifts were traditionally brought by [[Ded Moroz]] (Rus: Дед Мороз, or [[Grandfather Frost]]), the Russian counterpart of [[Santa Claus|Saint Nicholas]] or [[Father Christmas]], albeit a little taller and less stout. Rooted in Slavic folklore, Ded Moroz is accompanied by his beautiful granddaughter, [[Snegurochka]] (Rus: Снегурочка, [[Snegurochka|The Snowmaiden]]), who rides with him on a sleigh pulled by a trio of horses.<ref name=":0" />
 
 During the early [[History of the Soviet Union|Soviet period]], all religious celebrations were discouraged under the official state policy of [[atheism]]. The [[Bolsheviks]] argued that Christmas was a [[pagan]] [[sun-worship]]ping ritual with no basis in scientific fact and denounced the [[Christmas tree]] as a [[bourgeois]] German import.<ref name=":0" /> In 1929, all religious holidays, including Christmas, were abolished by a decree of the [[Stalinist regime]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|last=|first=|date=2019-12-29|title=How New Year was celebrated in the USSR (PHOTOS)|url=https://www.rbth.com/history/331458-soviet-new-year|url-status=live|access-date=2021-06-12|website=Beyond Russia|language=en-US|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191229111401/https://www.rbth.com/history/331458-soviet-new-year |archive-date=29 December 2019 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=Постановление СНК СССР от 24.09.1929|url=http://www.libussr.ru/doc_ussr/ussr_3594.htm|url-status=live|access-date=2021-06-12|website=www.libussr.ru|language=ru|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161229003241/http://www.libussr.ru:80/doc_ussr/ussr_3594.htm |archive-date=29 December 2016 }}</ref> However, in a surprising turn of state politics in 1935, many Christmas traditions were revived as part of a secular [[New Year's Eve|New Year's]] celebration after [[Joseph Stalin]]'s advisers convinced the [[Vozhd]] of the [[proletarians]]' need for a break from their hard work in the middle of a long, cold winter.<ref name=":1" /> The Christmas tree was repurposed as a "New Year's fir tree" (Russian: Новогодняя елка, ''Novogodnyaya yolka'') to be admired by all children throughout the [[Soviet Union]], including those in republics that had not historically celebrated Christmas due to their different religious traditions, such as the [[Soviet Central Asia|Central Asian ones]]. Other Christmas attributes and traditions, such as [[Christmas gift|gift-giving]], Ded Moroz's visits and Christmas decorations, lost their religious significance and became associated with New Year's celebrations, which were secular in nature.<ref name=":0" />
 
-In 1991, after the dissolution of the Soviet Union, Christmas was reinstated alongside other religious holidays.<ref name=":0" />
+In 1991, after the dissolution of the Soviet Union, Christmas was reinstated alongside other religious holidays.<ref name=":0" /> 
+Especially in recent years, there has been a shift from Ded Moroz/Did Moroz ({{lang-uk|Дід Мороз}}), which came to be associated with the Soviet-era heritage, to more traditional [[Saint Nicholas]] (Святий Миколай, ''Sviatyi Mykolai''), which used to be more popular in [[Western Ukraine]].<ref name=MT141120>{{cite news |url= http://www.themoscowtimes.com/news/article/kiev-brings-back-orthodox-santa-claus-instead-of-soviet-era-father-frost/511488.html |title= Kiev Brings Back Orthodox Santa Claus Instead of Soviet-Era Father Frost |work= [[The Moscow Times]] |date= 20 November 2014 }}</ref> There were rumors that Ded Moroz imagery was discouraged by the authorities due to conflict with Russia; the Ukrainian Ministry of Culture refuted this.<ref>[https://comments.ua/society/604910-deda-moroza-snegurochku-ukraine.html "Деда Мороза и Снегурочку в Украине никто не запрещал - Минкульт"]</ref>
 
 == Date of celebration ==
 {{hatnote|Further information: {{ill|Calendar reform in Ukraine|uk|Календарна реформа в Україні|display=1}}}}

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -21,6 +21,8 @@
 Traditional '''Ukrainian Christmas''' festivities start on [[Christmas Eve]], which is celebrated on 24 December in the [[Julian calendar]] used by the [[Eastern Orthodox Church]], which falls on 6 January in the common [[Gregorian calendar]]. Ukrainian Christmas celebrations end on {{OldStyleDate|19 January||6 January}}, the date of the celebration of the [[Baptism of Jesus]], known in [[Ukraine]] as Водо́хреще (Vodokhreschhe) or Yordan.<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/ Christmas Traditions<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
 
 == Date of celebration ==
+{{hatnote|Further information: {{ill|Calendar reform in Ukraine|uk|Календарна реформа в Україні|display=1}}}}
+
 As of 2017, 25 December, Christmas Day by the [[Gregorian calendar|Gregorian]] calendar, became an official government holiday in Ukraine. [[Eastern Orthodox Church|The Eastern Orthodox Church]] and [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church|Ukrainian Greek Catholic Churches]] predominantly follow the Julian calendar, and 7 January is also a [[Public holidays in Ukraine|public holiday in Ukraine]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://m.digitaljournal.com/news/world/ukraine-seeks-distance-from-moscow-with-new-christmas-holiday/article/507753|title=Ukraine seeks distance from Moscow with new Christmas holiday|website=m.digitaljournal.com|date=16 November 2017|access-date=2017-11-16}}</ref><ref>{{in lang|uk}} {{Cite news|url=http://www.bbc.com/ukrainian/news-42008437|title=Рада зробила 25 грудня вихідним днем|date=2017-11-16|work=BBC Україна|access-date=2017-11-16|language=en-GB}}</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine]], [[Epiphanius I of Ukraine|Metropolitan Epiphanius]], said that changing the date of Christmas to 25 December in Ukraine is possible after both the church and the faithful are ready for such a decision, after conducting educational work. It was stated that the postponement of the Nativity of the Lord would entail a change in the dates of all fixed holidays to 13 days ago.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://news.rbc.ua/ukr/politics/epifaniy-nazval-uslovie-perenosa-prazdnovaniya-1608382147.html|title = Епіфаній назвав умову перенесення святкування Різдва на 25 грудня}}</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church|UGCC]], [[Sviatoslav Shevchuk|Patriarch Sviatoslav]], stated that the Greek Catholic Church would resolve this issue "together with our Orthodox brothers." He also noted that this issue is not dogmatic, it should overcome church divisions, not cause new ones, and in his opinion, the transition to celebrating Christmas in a new style — 25 December, should be initiated by the laity.
 
 On October 18, 2022, the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine]] allowed dioceses to hold Christmas services according to the [[Revised Julian calendar]], i.e., December 25. In the case of a divine service, its participants are released from the restrictions of fasting on this day.<ref>{{Cite web |title=OCU allowed Christmas services on December 25 |url=https://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2022/10/18/7372478/ |accessdate=2022-10-18 |website=[[Ukrainian Pravda]] |language=uk}}</ref>
llm_output:
Added a hatnote regarding further information on the calendar reform in Ukraine.

Not Weaponised. The addition of a hatnote for further information is a neutral editorial change that does not carry any political or cultural implications.

-Especially in recent years, there has been a shift from Ded Moroz/Did Moroz ({{lang-uk|Дід Мороз}}), which came to be associated with the Soviet-era heritage, to more traditional [[Saint Nicholas]] (Святий Миколай, ''Sviatyi Mykolai''), which used to be more popular in [[Western Ukraine]].<ref name=MT141120>{{cite news |url= http://www.themoscowtimes.com/news/article/kiev-brings-back-orthodox-santa-claus-instead-of-soviet-era-father-frost/511488.html |title= Kiev Brings Back Orthodox Santa Claus Instead of Soviet-Era Father Frost |work= [[The Moscow Times]] |date= 20 November 2014 }}</ref> There were rumors that Ded Moroz imagery was discouraged by the authorities due to conflict with Russia; the Ukrainian Ministry of Culture refuted this.<ref>[https://comments.ua/society/604910-deda-moroza-snegurochku-ukraine.html "Деда Мороза и Снегурочку в Украине никто не запрещал - Минкульт"]</ref>
+Especially in recent years, there has been a shift from Did Moroz, which came to be associated with the Soviet-era heritage, to the more traditional [[Saint Nicholas]] (Святий Миколай, ''Sviatyi Mykolai''), who used to be more popular in [[Western Ukraine]].<ref name=MT141120>{{cite news |url= http://www.themoscowtimes.com/news/article/kiev-brings-back-orthodox-santa-claus-instead-of-soviet-era-father-frost/511488.html |title= Kiev Brings Back Orthodox Santa Claus Instead of Soviet-Era Father Frost |work= [[The Moscow Times]] |date= 20 November 2014 }}</ref> There were rumors that Ded Moroz imagery was discouraged by the authorities due to [[Russo-Ukrainian war|conflict with Russia]]; however, the [[Ukrainian Ministry of Culture]] has refuted this.<ref>[https://comments.ua/society/604910-deda-moroza-snegurochku-ukraine.html "Деда Мороза и Снегурочку в Украине никто не запрещал - Минкульт"]</ref>

The Ukrainian Christmas  festive days according to the Julian calendar, start on January 6th, Christmas Eve and ends with January 19th, "Jordan" or Epiphany.<ref>http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/</ref>

==Sviaty Vechir (Holy Evening)== 
<ref>http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html</ref>





==Koliadky - (Caroling)==


==Did Moroz - (Grandfather Frost)==



{{Reflist}}
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -20,9 +20,19 @@
 |alt=|official_name=|litcolor=|begins=|ends=|weekday=|month=|scheduling=|firsttime=|startedby=}}
 Traditional '''Ukrainian Christmas''' festivities start on [[Christmas Eve]], which is celebrated on 24 December in the [[Julian calendar]] used by the [[Eastern Orthodox Church]], or is celebrated on 6 January by those who follow the common [[Gregorian calendar]]. Ukrainian Christmas celebrations end on {{OldStyleDate|19 January||6 January}}, the date of the celebration of the [[Baptism of Jesus]], known in [[Ukraine]] as Водо́хреще (Vodokhreshche) or Yordan.<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/ Christmas Traditions<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
 
+Christmas was largely erased from the Ukrainian calendar for much of the [[20th century]] due to the [[Persecution of Christians in the Soviet Union|Soviet Union's anti-religious policies]], but many of its traditions survived, having been transplanted to [[Novy God|New Year's Day]].<ref>{{Cite web|last=Tamkin|first=Emily|title=How Soviets Came to Celebrate New Year’s Like Christmas (and Why Russians Still Do)|url=https://foreignpolicy.com/2016/12/30/how-soviets-came-to-celebrate-new-years-like-christmas-and-why-russians-still-do/|access-date=2022-01-13|website=Foreign Policy|language=en-US}}</ref> 
+
+==History==
+In [[Ukraine]], the Christmas holiday became the official celebration with the [[baptism of Rus']] ordered by [[Prince Vladimir]] in the late [[10th century]]. However, given the early Christian community of [[Kievan Rus']], the celebration may have a longer history.
+
+In the [[19th century]], a lavishly decorated Christmas tree became central to the holiday, a tradition originally imported by [[Nicholas I of Russia|Nicholas I]]'s wife, [[Alexandra Feodorovna (Charlotte of Prussia)|Alexandra Feodorovna]], from her native [[Prussia]]. The tradition of giving gifts to children on Christmas took root around the same time.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|last=Weber|first=Hannah|date=25 December 2020|title=Yolka: the story of Russia's 'New Year tree', from pagan origins to Soviet celebrations|url=https://www.calvertjournal.com/articles/show/9424/yolka-russia-new-year-tree-pagan-soviet-christmas|url-status=live|access-date=2021-06-12|website=The Calvert Journal|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180113181107/http://www.calvertjournal.com/articles/show/9424/yolka-russia-new-year-tree-pagan-soviet-christmas |archive-date=13 January 2018 }}</ref> Christmas gifts were traditionally brought by [[Ded Moroz]] (Rus: Дед Мороз, or [[Grandfather Frost]]), the Russian counterpart of [[Santa Claus|Saint Nicholas]] or [[Father Christmas]], albeit a little taller and less stout. Rooted in Slavic folklore, Ded Moroz is accompanied by his beautiful granddaughter, [[Snegurochka]] (Rus: Снегурочка, [[Snegurochka|The Snowmaiden]]), who rides with him on a sleigh pulled by a trio of horses.<ref name=":0" />
+
+During the early [[History of the Soviet Union|Soviet period]], all religious celebrations were discouraged under the official state policy of [[atheism]]. The [[Bolsheviks]] argued that Christmas was a [[pagan]] [[sun-worship]]ping ritual with no basis in scientific fact and denounced the [[Christmas tree]] as a [[bourgeois]] German import.<ref name=":0" /> In 1929, all religious holidays, including Christmas, were abolished by a decree of the [[Stalinist regime]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|last=|first=|date=2019-12-29|title=How New Year was celebrated in the USSR (PHOTOS)|url=https://www.rbth.com/history/331458-soviet-new-year|url-status=live|access-date=2021-06-12|website=Beyond Russia|language=en-US|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191229111401/https://www.rbth.com/history/331458-soviet-new-year |archive-date=29 December 2019 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=Постановление СНК СССР от 24.09.1929|url=http://www.libussr.ru/doc_ussr/ussr_3594.htm|url-status=live|access-date=2021-06-12|website=www.libussr.ru|language=ru|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161229003241/http://www.libussr.ru:80/doc_ussr/ussr_3594.htm |archive-date=29 December 2016 }}</ref> However, in a surprising turn of state politics in 1935, many Christmas traditions were revived as part of a secular [[New Year's Eve|New Year's]] celebration after [[Joseph Stalin]]'s advisers convinced the [[Vozhd]] of the [[proletarians]]' need for a break from their hard work in the middle of a long, cold winter.<ref name=":1" /> The Christmas tree was repurposed as a "New Year's fir tree" (Russian: Новогодняя елка, ''Novogodnyaya yolka'') to be admired by all children throughout the [[Soviet Union]], including those in republics that had not historically celebrated Christmas due to their different religious traditions, such as the [[Soviet Central Asia|Central Asian ones]]. Other Christmas attributes and traditions, such as [[Christmas gift|gift-giving]], Ded Moroz's visits and Christmas decorations, lost their religious significance and became associated with New Year's celebrations, which were secular in nature.<ref name=":0" />
+
+In 1991, after the dissolution of the Soviet Union, Christmas was reinstated alongside other religious holidays.<ref name=":0" />
+
 == Date of celebration ==
 {{hatnote|Further information: {{ill|Calendar reform in Ukraine|uk|Календарна реформа в Україні|display=1}}}}
-
 As of 2017, 25 December, Christmas Day by the [[Gregorian calendar|Gregorian]] calendar, became an official government holiday in Ukraine. [[Eastern Orthodox Church|The Eastern Orthodox Church]] and [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church]]es predominantly follow the Julian calendar, and 7 January is also a [[Public holidays in Ukraine|public holiday in Ukraine]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://m.digitaljournal.com/news/world/ukraine-seeks-distance-from-moscow-with-new-christmas-holiday/article/507753|title=Ukraine seeks distance from Moscow with new Christmas holiday|website=m.digitaljournal.com|date=16 November 2017|access-date=2017-11-16}}</ref><ref>{{in lang|uk}} {{Cite news|url=http://www.bbc.com/ukrainian/news-42008437|title=Рада зробила 25 грудня вихідним днем|date=2017-11-16|work=BBC Україна|access-date=2017-11-16|language=en-GB}}</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine]], [[Epiphanius I of Ukraine|Metropolitan Epiphanius]], said that changing the date of Christmas to 25 December in Ukraine is possible after both the church and the faithful are ready for such a decision, after conducting educational work. It was stated that the postponement of the Nativity of the Lord would entail a change in the dates of all fixed holidays to 13 days ago.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://news.rbc.ua/ukr/politics/epifaniy-nazval-uslovie-perenosa-prazdnovaniya-1608382147.html|title = Епіфаній назвав умову перенесення святкування Різдва на 25 грудня}}</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church|UGCC]], [[Sviatoslav Shevchuk|Patriarch Sviatoslav]], stated that the Greek Catholic Church would resolve this issue "together with our Orthodox brothers." He also noted that this issue is not dogmatic, it should overcome church divisions, not cause new ones, and in his opinion, the transition to celebrating Christmas in a new style — 25 December, should be initiated by the laity.
 
 On 18 October 2022, the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine]] allowed dioceses to hold Christmas services according to the [[Revised Julian calendar]], i.e., 25 December. In the case of a divine service, its participants are released from the restrictions of fasting on this day.<ref>{{Cite web |title=OCU allowed Christmas services on December 25 |url=https://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2022/10/18/7372478/ |accessdate=2022-10-18 |website=[[Ukrainian Pravda]] |language=uk}}</ref>
@@ -30,7 +40,6 @@
 On 24 December 2022, during an [[audience]], [[Major archbishop]] [[Sviatoslav Shevchuk|Sviatoslav]] handed over to [[Metropolitan of Kyiv and All Ukraine|Metropolitan]] [[Epiphanius I of Ukraine|Epiphanius]] for review a letter outlining the considerations of the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church|UGCC]] hierarchs regarding the {{ill|Calendar reform in Ukraine|lt=calendar reform|uk|Календарна реформа в Україні|display=1}}. The primates decided to create a joint working group on specific proposals for calendar reform. The joint group is initiated on the occasion of the celebration of the 1700th anniversary of the [[First Council of Nicaea|First Ecumenical Council]], held in [[Nicaea]] in 325. In this [[Ecumenical council|Council]], in particular, the calendar principles of church life were determined.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Heads of OCU, UGCC agree to set up working group to reform church calendar |url=https://www.ukrinform.net/rubric-society/3640576-heads-of-ocu-ugcc-agree-to-set-up-working-group-to-reform-church-calendar.html |access-date=2022-12-24 |website=www.ukrinform.net |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=During the meeting of His Beatitude Sviatoslav with His Beatitude Epiphanius, they talked about the reform of the church calendar |url=https://news.ugcc.ua/data/pid-chas-zustrichi-blazhennishogo-svyatoslava-z-blazhennishym-epifaniem-govoryly-pro-reformu-tserkovnogo-kalendarya-1713/ |access-date=2022-12-24 |website=Українська Греко-Католицька Церква |language=uk}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2022-12-24 |title=There was a meeting of the Primate of the OCU with the Father and the Primate of the UGCC |url=https://www.pomisna.info/uk/vsi-novyny/vidbulasya-zustrich-predstoyatelya-ptsu-z-ottsem-i-glavoyu-ugkts/ |access-date=2022-12-24 |website=OCU |language=uk}}</ref>
 
 ==Sviatyi Vechir (Holy Evening)==
-
 [[Christmas Eve]] is called Sviatyi Vechir (''Святий вечір'') or Sviatvechir (''Святвечір'') in Ukraine ("Holy Evening"), and has many customs and rituals, most of which predate the introduction of Christianity to Ukraine. Traditions include decorating house and dinner table with special attributes (a symbolic sheaf of wheat called the ''[[didukh]]'', [[garlic]], hay, and others), performing [[Koliada|koliadky]] ('carols') and so on.  Each ritual has its own meaning and purpose, as such a few wisps of hay on the embroidered tablecloth as a reminder of the manger in [[Bethlehem]]. One prominent custom of the night is a special supper, called ''[[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|Sviata Vecheria]]'' ("Holy Supper").<ref>{{Cite book|last=Inc|first=World Book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Nks04JbYUSgC&dq=sviata+vecheria&pg=PA33|title=Christmas in Ukraine|date=1997|publisher=World Book .com|isbn=978-0-7166-0897-4|language=en}}</ref>
 
 Ukrainians fast on Sviat vechir; only when the first star is seen in the evening sky, may the supper begin.  The family comes together to have a dinner which usually includes 12 dishes (the number can vary from 7–17). These [[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|twelve dishes]] are traditionally vegan plus fish, and do not contain meat, milk, or eggs.<ref>{{cite web |title=Christmas in Ukraine |url=https://www.whychristmas.com/cultures/ukraine.shtml |website=Why Christmas |access-date=14 December 2020}}</ref> While the dishes served can vary regionally, as well as from family to family, the two mandatory dishes are uzvar and kutia, both reckoned by ethnographer [[Fedir Vovk|Khvedir Vovk]] to be remnants of ancient rituals which date back to the neolithic era.<ref>{{cite web |title=Traditional Recipe of Ukrainian Kutia |url=https://etnocook.com/kutia/ |website=Ethnocook |access-date=27 November 2022}}</ref> [[Kutia]] (a dish of grain, honey and poppy seeds) is traditionally served first at the meal, after being offered by the head of the household to the frost. A spoonful is tossed at the ceiling, and the number of poppy seeds which stick portends the fruitfulness of the fields and farm animals in the coming year. It is rarely served at other times of the year.<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html Sviat Vechir<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Uzvar is a beverage, made with cooked dried fruits and berries. It can be mixed in with the kutia, or served separately at the end of the meal.  Servings of both dishes are also set aside overnight in the pokuttia, the corner of the house with the icons, for the ancestors.
@@ -39,7 +48,6 @@
 At the end of the Sviata Vechera the family often sings carols (''koliadky'', singular ''koliadka''). In many communities the ancient Ukrainian tradition of caroling is carried on by groups of young people and members of organizations and churches calling at homes and collecting donations. A well-known carol is ''{{ill|Nova radist stala|lt=|uk|Нова радість стала|display=1}}'', [[Boh predvičnyj narodivsja|''Boh predvichnyi narodyvsia'']],<ref name=BLiturgy>{{cite web|title=Boh predvičnyj|url=http://mci.archpitt.org/legacy/songs/Slavonic/Boh_predvicnyj.html|website=Metropolitan Cantor Institute|publisher=Byzantine Catholic|access-date=12 August 2015|ref=Archeparchy of Pittsburgh|archive-date=4 March 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304235614/http://mci.archpitt.org/legacy/songs/Slavonic/Boh_predvicnyj.html|url-status=dead}}</ref> ''{{ill|Dobryi vechir tobi, pane hospodariu|lt=|uk|Добрий вечір тобі, пане господарю|display=1}}'', ''{{ill|Vo Vyfleiemi nyni novyna|lt=|uk|Во Вифлеємі нині новина|display=1}}'', ''{{ill|Nebo i zemlia nyni torzhestvuiut|lt=|uk|Небо і земля нині торжествують|display=1}}'', ''{{ill|Boh sia rozhdaie|lt=|uk|Бог ся раджае|display=1}}'' etc.
 
 ==Didukh (Grandfather)==
-
 In villages (farming communities), the head of the household brings in a sheaf of grain called the ''[[didukh]]'' which represents the importance of the ancient and rich wheat crops of Ukraine, the staff of life through the centuries. Didukh means literally "grandfather spirit" so it symbolizes the family's ancestors. In Ukrainian city homes the didukh may be purchased, and is often three footed made of woven grain and dried grasses and flowers.{{citation needed|date=April 2022}}
 
 ==Shopka (Nativity scene)==
