 Christmas was largely erased from the Ukrainian calendar for much of the [[20th century]] due to the [[Persecution of Christians in the Soviet Union|Soviet Union's anti-religious policies]], but many of its traditions survived, having been transplanted to [[Novy God|New Year's Day]].<ref>{{Cite web|last=Tamkin|first=Emily|title=How Soviets Came to Celebrate New Year’s Like Christmas (and Why Russians Still Do)|url=https://foreignpolicy.com/2016/12/30/how-soviets-came-to-celebrate-new-years-like-christmas-and-why-russians-still-do/|access-date=2022-01-13|website=Foreign Policy|language=en-US}}</ref> 
 
 ==History==
-[[File:Новогодние марки Украины Дед Мороз.jpg|thumbnail|Did Moroz on a Ukrainian postage stamp with New Year greeting]]
-In [[Ukraine]], the Christmas holiday became the official celebration with the [[baptism of Rus']] ordered by [[Prince Vladimir]] in the late [[10th century]]. However, given the early Christian community of [[Kievan Rus']], the celebration may have a longer history.
-
-In the [[19th century]], a lavishly decorated Christmas tree became central to the holiday, a tradition originally imported by [[Nicholas I of Russia|Nicholas I]]'s wife, [[Alexandra Feodorovna (Charlotte of Prussia)|Alexandra Feodorovna]], from her native [[Prussia]]. The tradition of giving gifts to children on Christmas took root around the same time.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|last=Weber|first=Hannah|date=25 December 2020|title=Yolka: the story of Russia's 'New Year tree', from pagan origins to Soviet celebrations|url=https://www.calvertjournal.com/articles/show/9424/yolka-russia-new-year-tree-pagan-soviet-christmas|url-status=live|access-date=2021-06-12|website=The Calvert Journal|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180113181107/http://www.calvertjournal.com/articles/show/9424/yolka-russia-new-year-tree-pagan-soviet-christmas |archive-date=13 January 2018 }}</ref> Christmas gifts were traditionally brought by [[Did Moroz]] ({{lang-uk|Дід Мороз}}) or [[Grandfather Frost]], the Ukrainian counterpart of [[Santa Claus|Saint Nicholas]] or [[Father Christmas]], albeit a little taller and less stout. Rooted in Slavic folklore, Ded Moroz is accompanied by his beautiful granddaughter, [[Snegurka]] ({{lang-uk|Снігурка|Snihurka}}, [[Snegurochka|The Snowmaiden]]), who rides with him on a sleigh pulled by a trio of horses.<ref name=":0" />
+In [[Ukraine]], the Christmas holiday became the official celebration with the [[baptism of Rus']] ordered by [[Prince Vladimir]] in the late [[10th century]]. However, given the early Christian community of [[Kievan Rus']], the celebration may have a longer history.[[File:Новогодние марки Украины Дед Мороз.jpg|thumbnail|Did Moroz on a Ukrainian postage stamp with New Year greeting]]In the [[19th century]], a lavishly decorated Christmas tree became central to the holiday, a tradition originally imported by [[Nicholas I of Russia|Nicholas I]]'s wife, [[Alexandra Feodorovna (Charlotte of Prussia)|Alexandra Feodorovna]], from her native [[Prussia]]. The tradition of giving gifts to children on Christmas took root around the same time.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|last=Weber|first=Hannah|date=25 December 2020|title=Yolka: the story of Russia's 'New Year tree', from pagan origins to Soviet celebrations|url=https://www.calvertjournal.com/articles/show/9424/yolka-russia-new-year-tree-pagan-soviet-christmas|url-status=live|access-date=2021-06-12|website=The Calvert Journal|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180113181107/http://www.calvertjournal.com/articles/show/9424/yolka-russia-new-year-tree-pagan-soviet-christmas |archive-date=13 January 2018 }}</ref> Christmas gifts were traditionally brought by [[Did Moroz]] ({{lang-uk|Дід Мороз}}) or [[Grandfather Frost]], the Ukrainian counterpart of [[Santa Claus|Saint Nicholas]] or [[Father Christmas]], albeit a little taller and less stout. Rooted in Slavic folklore, Ded Moroz is accompanied by his beautiful granddaughter, [[Snegurka]] ({{lang-uk|Снігурка|Snihurka}}, [[Snegurochka|The Snowmaiden]]), who rides with him on a sleigh pulled by a trio of horses.<ref name=":0" />
 
 During the early [[History of the Soviet Union|Soviet period]], all religious celebrations were discouraged under the official state policy of [[atheism]]. The [[Bolsheviks]] argued that Christmas was a [[pagan]] [[sun-worship]]ping ritual with no basis in scientific fact and denounced the [[Christmas tree]] as a [[bourgeois]] German import.<ref name=":0" /> In 1929, all religious holidays, including Christmas, were abolished by a decree of the [[Stalinist regime]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|last=|first=|date=2019-12-29|title=How New Year was celebrated in the USSR (PHOTOS)|url=https://www.rbth.com/history/331458-soviet-new-year|url-status=live|access-date=2021-06-12|website=Beyond Russia|language=en-US|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191229111401/https://www.rbth.com/history/331458-soviet-new-year |archive-date=29 December 2019 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=Постановление СНК СССР от 24.09.1929|url=http://www.libussr.ru/doc_ussr/ussr_3594.htm|url-status=live|access-date=2021-06-12|website=www.libussr.ru|language=ru|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161229003241/http://www.libussr.ru:80/doc_ussr/ussr_3594.htm |archive-date=29 December 2016 }}</ref> However, in a surprising turn of state politics in 1935, many Ukrainian Christmas traditions were revived as part of a secular [[New Year's Eve|New Year's]] celebration after [[Joseph Stalin]]'s advisers convinced the [[Vozhd]] of the [[proletarians]]' need for a break from their hard work in the middle of a long, cold winter.<ref name=":1" /> The Christmas tree was repurposed as a "New Year's fir tree" ({{lang-uk|Новорічна ялинка|Novorichna yalynka}}) to be admired by all children throughout the [[Soviet Union]], including those in republics that had not historically celebrated Christmas due to their different religious traditions, such as the [[Soviet Central Asia|Central Asian ones]]. Other Ukrainian Christmas attributes and traditions, such as [[Christmas gift|gift-giving]], Did Moroz's visits and Christmas decorations, lost their religious significance and became associated with New Year's celebrations, which were secular in nature.<ref name=":0" />
 
-In 1991, after the dissolution of the Soviet Union, Christmas was reinstated alongside other religious holidays.<ref name=":0" /> 
-Especially in recent years, there has been a shift from Did Moroz, who came to be associated with the Soviet-era heritage, to the more traditional [[Saint Nicholas]] ({{lang-uk|Святий Миколай|Sviatyi Mykolai}}), who used to be more popular in [[Western Ukraine]].<ref name=MT141120>{{cite news |url= http://www.themoscowtimes.com/news/article/kiev-brings-back-orthodox-santa-claus-instead-of-soviet-era-father-frost/511488.html |title= Kiev Brings Back Orthodox Santa Claus Instead of Soviet-Era Father Frost |work= [[The Moscow Times]] |date= 20 November 2014 }}</ref> There were rumors that Ded Moroz imagery was discouraged by the authorities due to [[Russo-Ukrainian war|conflict with Russia]]; however, the [[Ukrainian Ministry of Culture]] has refuted this.<ref>[https://comments.ua/society/604910-deda-moroza-snegurochku-ukraine.html "Деда Мороза и Снегурочку в Украине никто не запрещал - Минкульт"]</ref>
+In 1991, after the dissolution of the Soviet Union, Christmas was reinstated alongside other religious holidays.<ref name=":0" /> Especially in recent years, there has been a shift from Did Moroz, who came to be associated with the Soviet-era heritage, to the more traditional [[Saint Nicholas]] ({{lang-uk|Святий Миколай|Sviatyi Mykolai}}), who used to be more popular in [[Western Ukraine]].<ref name=MT141120>{{cite news |url= http://www.themoscowtimes.com/news/article/kiev-brings-back-orthodox-santa-claus-instead-of-soviet-era-father-frost/511488.html |title= Kiev Brings Back Orthodox Santa Claus Instead of Soviet-Era Father Frost |work= [[The Moscow Times]] |date= 20 November 2014 }}</ref> There were rumors that Ded Moroz imagery was discouraged by the authorities due to the [[Russo-Ukrainian War]]; however, the [[Ukrainian Ministry of Culture]] has refuted this.<ref>[https://comments.ua/society/604910-deda-moroza-snegurochku-ukraine.html "Деда Мороза и Снегурочку в Украине никто не запрещал - Минкульт"]</ref>
 
 == Date of celebration ==
 {{hatnote|Further information: {{ill|Calendar reform in Ukraine|uk|Календарна реформа в Україні|display=1}}}}
+[[File:Diduch-Lviv.jpg|thumb|A [[didukh]] in [[Lviv]].]]
 As of 2017, 25 December, Christmas Day by the [[Gregorian calendar|Gregorian]] calendar, became an official government holiday in Ukraine. [[Eastern Orthodox Church|The Eastern Orthodox Church]]es predominantly follow the Julian calendar, and 7 January is also a [[Public holidays in Ukraine|public holiday in Ukraine]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://m.digitaljournal.com/news/world/ukraine-seeks-distance-from-moscow-with-new-christmas-holiday/article/507753|title=Ukraine seeks distance from Moscow with new Christmas holiday|website=m.digitaljournal.com|date=16 November 2017|access-date=2017-11-16}}</ref><ref>{{in lang|uk}} {{Cite news|url=http://www.bbc.com/ukrainian/news-42008437|title=Рада зробила 25 грудня вихідним днем|date=2017-11-16|work=BBC Україна|access-date=2017-11-16|language=en-GB}}</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine]], [[Epiphanius I of Ukraine|Metropolitan Epiphanius]], said that changing the date of Christmas to 25 December in Ukraine is possible after both the church and the faithful are ready for such a decision, after conducting educational work. It was stated that the postponement of the Nativity of the Lord would entail a change in the dates of all fixed holidays to 13 days ago.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://news.rbc.ua/ukr/politics/epifaniy-nazval-uslovie-perenosa-prazdnovaniya-1608382147.html|title = Епіфаній назвав умову перенесення святкування Різдва на 25 грудня}}</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church]] (UGCC), [[Sviatoslav Shevchuk|Patriarch Sviatoslav]], stated that the Greek Catholic Church would resolve this issue "together with our Orthodox brothers." He also noted that this issue is not dogmatic, it should overcome church divisions, not cause new ones, and in his opinion, the transition to celebrating Christmas in a new style — 25 December, should be initiated by the laity.
+
+About a hundred parishes of the Romanian national minority in Ukraine, which are part of the [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)|Ukrainian Orthodox Church of the Moscow Patriarchate]], have always celebrated Christmas on December 25 according to the [[Revised Julian calendar]].<ref>{{Cite news |last=Кралюк |first=Петро |date=2023-01-02 |title=«Є сподівання, що ПЦУ і УГКЦ перейдуть на святкування Різдва 25 грудня» – професор Петро Кралюк |language=uk |work=Радіо Свобода |url=https://www.radiosvoboda.org/a/rizdvo-tserkovnyy-kalendar/32201163.html |access-date=2023-03-27}}</ref>
 
 On 18 October 2022, the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine]] allowed dioceses to hold Christmas services according to the [[Revised Julian calendar]], i.e., 25 December. In the case of a divine service, its participants are released from the restrictions of fasting on this day.<ref>{{Cite web |title=OCU allowed Christmas services on December 25 |url=https://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2022/10/18/7372478/ |accessdate=2022-10-18 |website=[[Ukrainian Pravda]] |language=uk}}</ref>
 
@@ -56,6 +55,7 @@
 In February 2023 the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church|UGCC]] decided to switch to a new style ([[Revised Julian calendar]]) for fixed holidays (і.e., except for [[Date of Easter|Easter]]) from September 2023.<ref>{{Cite web|language=uk|url=https://ugcc.ua/data/istorychne-rishennya-ugkts-v-ukrayni-perehodyt-na-novyy-kalendar-2056/|title=Історичне рішення: УГКЦ в Україні переходить на новий календар|website=Українська Греко-Католицька Церква|accessdate=2023-02-06}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|language=uk|url=https://tsn.ua/ukrayina/ukrayinska-greko-katolicka-cerkva-perehodit-na-noviy-kalendar-podrobici-istorichnogo-rishennya-2259325.html|title=Українська греко-католицька церква переходить на новий календар: подробиці історичного рішення|website=ТСН.ua|date=2023-02-06|accessdate=2023-02-06}}</ref> [[Parish|Parishes]] of the UGCC that are not ready to switch to the new style in 2023 have a transition period until September 1, 2025 to make the change.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-02-06 |title=Ukraine Catholic Church moves from Russian-affiliated Julian calendar |url=https://www.pillarcatholic.com/ukraine-catholic-church-moves-from-russian/ |access-date=2023-02-06 |website=The Pillar |language=en}}</ref>
 
 ==Sviatyi Vechir (Holy Evening)==
+[[File:Шопка_перед_львівською_ратушою.jpg|thumb|[[Nativity scene]].]]
 [[Christmas Eve]] is called Sviatyi Vechir (''Святий вечір'') or Sviatvechir (''Святвечір'') in Ukraine ("Holy Evening"), and has many customs and rituals, most of which predate the introduction of Christianity to Ukraine. Traditions include decorating house and dinner table with special attributes (a symbolic sheaf of wheat called the ''[[didukh]]'', [[garlic]], hay, and others), performing [[Koliada|koliadky]] ('carols') and so on.  Each ritual has its own meaning and purpose, as such a few wisps of hay on the embroidered tablecloth as a reminder of the manger in [[Bethlehem]]. One prominent custom of the night is a special supper, called ''[[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|Sviata Vecheria]]'' ("Holy Supper").<ref>{{Cite book|last=Inc|first=World Book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Nks04JbYUSgC&dq=sviata+vecheria&pg=PA33|title=Christmas in Ukraine|date=1997|publisher=World Book .com|isbn=978-0-7166-0897-4|language=en}}</ref>
 
 Ukrainians fast on Sviat vechir; only when the first star is seen in the evening sky, may the supper begin.  The family comes together to have a dinner which usually includes 12 dishes (the number can vary from 7–17). These [[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|twelve dishes]] are traditionally vegan plus fish, and do not contain meat, milk, or eggs.<ref>{{cite web |title=Christmas in Ukraine |url=https://www.whychristmas.com/cultures/ukraine.shtml |website=Why Christmas |access-date=14 December 2020}}</ref> While the dishes served can vary regionally, as well as from family to family, the two mandatory dishes are uzvar and kutia, both reckoned by ethnographer [[Fedir Vovk|Khvedir Vovk]] to be remnants of ancient rituals which date back to the neolithic era.<ref>{{cite web |title=Traditional Recipe of Ukrainian Kutia |url=https://etnocook.com/kutia/ |website=Ethnocook |access-date=27 November 2022}}</ref> [[Kutia]] (a dish of grain, honey and poppy seeds) is traditionally served first at the meal, after being offered by the head of the household to the frost. A spoonful is tossed at the ceiling, and the number of poppy seeds which stick portends the fruitfulness of the fields and farm animals in the coming year. It is rarely served at other times of the year.<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html Sviat Vechir<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Uzvar is a beverage, made with cooked dried fruits and berries. It can be mixed in with the kutia, or served separately at the end of the meal.  Servings of both dishes are also set aside overnight in the pokuttia, the corner of the house with the icons, for the ancestors.

+Christmas was largely erased from the Ukrainian calendar for much of the 20th century due to the [[Persecution of Christians in the Soviet Union|Soviet Union's anti-religious policies]], but many of its traditions survived and are being revived again.
 
 ==History==
 In Ukraine, the Christmas holiday became the official celebration with the [[baptism of Rus']] ordered by [[Prince Vladimir]] in the late 10th century. However, given the early Christian community of [[Kievan Rus']], the celebration may have a longer history.[[File:Новогодние марки Украины Дед Мороз.jpg|thumbnail|Did Moroz on a Ukrainian postage stamp with New Year greeting]]In the 19th century, a lavishly decorated Christmas tree became central to the holiday, a tradition originally imported by [[Nicholas I of Russia|Nicholas I]]'s wife, [[Alexandra Feodorovna (Charlotte of Prussia)|Alexandra Feodorovna]], from her native [[Prussia]]. The tradition of giving gifts to children on Christmas took root around the same time.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|last=Weber|first=Hannah|date=25 December 2020|title=Yolka: the story of Russia's 'New Year tree', from pagan origins to Soviet celebrations|url=https://www.calvertjournal.com/articles/show/9424/yolka-russia-new-year-tree-pagan-soviet-christmas|url-status=live|access-date=2021-06-12|website=The Calvert Journal|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180113181107/http://www.calvertjournal.com/articles/show/9424/yolka-russia-new-year-tree-pagan-soviet-christmas |archive-date=13 January 2018 }}</ref> Christmas gifts were traditionally brought by [[Did Moroz]] ({{lang-uk|Дід Мороз}}) or [[Grandfather Frost]], the Ukrainian counterpart of [[Santa Claus|Saint Nicholas]] or [[Father Christmas]], albeit a little taller and less stout. Rooted in Slavic folklore, Ded Moroz is accompanied by his beautiful granddaughter, [[Snegurka]] ({{lang-uk|Снігурка|Snihurka}}, the snowmaiden), who rides with him on a sleigh pulled by a trio of horses.<ref name=":0" />
comment: Ukrainian Christmas traditions have not been transplanted to the New Year's Day.

 [[File:Шопка_перед_львівською_ратушою.jpg|thumb|[[Nativity scene]].]]
 [[Christmas Eve]] (24 December/6 January) is called Sviatyi Vechir (''Святий вечір'') or Sviatvechir (''Святвечір'') in Ukraine ("Holy Evening"), and has many customs and rituals, most of which predate the introduction of Christianity to Ukraine. Traditions include decorating house and dinner table with special attributes (a symbolic sheaf of wheat called the ''[[didukh]]'', [[garlic]], hay, and others), performing [[Koliada|koliadky]] ('carols') and so on.  Each ritual has its own meaning and purpose, as such a few wisps of hay on the embroidered tablecloth as a reminder of the manger in [[Bethlehem]]. One prominent custom of the night is a special supper, called ''[[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|Sviata Vecheria]]'' ("Holy Supper").<ref>{{Cite book|last=Inc|first=World Book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Nks04JbYUSgC&dq=sviata+vecheria&pg=PA33|title=Christmas in Ukraine|date=1997|publisher=World Book .com|isbn=978-0-7166-0897-4|language=en}}</ref>
 
-Ukrainians fast on Sviat vechir; only when the first star is seen in the evening sky, may the supper begin.  The family comes together to have a dinner which usually includes 12 dishes (the number can vary from 7–17). These [[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|twelve dishes]] are traditionally vegan plus fish, and do not contain meat, milk, or eggs.<ref>{{cite web |title=Christmas in Ukraine |url=https://www.whychristmas.com/cultures/ukraine.shtml |website=Why Christmas |access-date=14 December 2020}}</ref> While the dishes served can vary regionally, as well as from family to family, the two mandatory dishes are uzvar and kutia, both reckoned by ethnographer [[Fedir Vovk|Khvedir Vovk]] to be remnants of ancient rituals which date back to the neolithic era.<ref>{{cite web |title=Traditional Recipe of Ukrainian Kutia |url=https://etnocook.com/kutia/ |website=Ethnocook |access-date=27 November 2022}}</ref> [[Kutia]] (a dish of grain, honey and poppy seeds) is traditionally served first at the meal, after being offered by the head of the household to the frost. A spoonful is tossed at the ceiling, and the number of poppy seeds which stick portends the fruitfulness of the fields and farm animals in the coming year. It is rarely served at other times of the year.<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html Sviat Vechir<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Uzvar is a beverage, made with cooked dried fruits and berries. It can be mixed in with the kutia, or served separately at the end of the meal.  Servings of both dishes are also set aside overnight in the pokuttia, the corner of the house with the icons, for the ancestors.

The family comes together to have a dinner which usually includes 12 dishes (the number can vary from 7–17). These [[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|twelve dishes]] are traditionally vegan plus fish, and do not contain meat, milk, or eggs.<ref>{{cite web |title=Christmas in Ukraine |url=https://www.whychristmas.com/cultures/ukraine.shtml |website=Why Christmas |access-date=14 December 2020}}</ref> While the dishes served can vary regionally, as well as from family to family, the two mandatory dishes are uzvar and kutia, both reckoned by ethnographer [[Fedir Vovk|Khvedir Vovk]] to be remnants of ancient rituals which date back to the neolithic era.<ref>{{cite web |title=Traditional Recipe of Ukrainian Kutia |url=https://etnocook.com/kutia/ |website=Ethnocook |access-date=27 November 2022}}</ref> [[Kutia]] (a dish of grain, honey and poppy seeds) is traditionally served first at the meal, after being offered by the head of the household to the frost. A spoonful is tossed at the ceiling, and in rural townships the number of poppy seeds which stick portends the fruitfulness of the fields and farm animals in the coming year. It is rarely served at other times of the year.<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html Sviat Vechir<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Uzvar is a beverage, made with cooked dried fruits and berries. It can be mixed in with the kutia, or served separately at the end of the meal.  Servings of both dishes are also set aside overnight in the pokuttia, the corner of the house with the Orthodox icons or Catholic images of saints, for deceased ancestors within the family.
 
 ==''Koliadky'' (caroling)==
 At the end of the Sviata Vechera the family often sings carols (''koliadky'', singular ''koliadka''). In many communities the ancient Ukrainian tradition of caroling is carried on by groups of young people and members of organizations and churches calling at homes and collecting donations. A well-known carol is ''{{ill|Nova radist stala|lt=|uk|Нова радість стала|display=1}}'', [[Boh predvičnyj narodivsja|''Boh predvichnyi narodyvsia'']],<ref name=BLiturgy>{{cite web|title=Boh predvičnyj|url=http://mci.archpitt.org/legacy/songs/Slavonic/Boh_predvicnyj.html|website=Metropolitan Cantor Institute|publisher=Byzantine Catholic|access-date=12 August 2015|ref=Archeparchy of Pittsburgh|archive-date=4 March 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304235614/http://mci.archpitt.org/legacy/songs/Slavonic/Boh_predvicnyj.html|url-status=dead}}</ref> ''{{ill|Dobryi vechir tobi, pane hospodariu|lt=|uk|Добрий вечір тобі, пане господарю|display=1}}'', ''{{ill|Vo Vyfleiemi nyni novyna|lt=|uk|Во Вифлеємі нині новина|display=1}}'', ''{{ill|Nebo i zemlia nyni torzhestvuiut|lt=|uk|Небо і земля нині торжествують|display=1}}'', ''{{ill|Boh sia rozhdaie|lt=|uk|Бог ся раджае|display=1}}'' etc.

-Traditional '''Ukrainian Christmas''' festivities start on [[Christmas Eve]], which is celebrated from December 24 to January 6, the date of the celebration of the [[baptism of Jesus]], known in [[Ukraine]] as ''[[Epiphany (holiday)|Vodokhreshche]]'' or ''Yordan'',<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/ Christmas Traditions<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> according to the [[Gregorian calendar]] and [[Revised Julian calendar]] by the [[Latin Church in Ukraine|Latin]] and [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church|Greek]]<ref name=":3" /> [[Catholic Church in Ukraine|Catholics]], most [[Protestantism in Ukraine|Protestant churches]] and some parishes of the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine]]. The Orthodox Church of Ukraine, the [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)|Ukrainian Orthodox Church of the Moscow Patriarchate]] (except for the [[Romanians in Ukraine|Romanian parishes]]<ref name=":2" />) and some Protestant churches celebrate Christmas according to the [[Julian calendar]], so the Gregorian holidays last from January 6 to January 19.
+
+Traditional '''Ukrainian Christmas''' festivities start on [[Christmas Eve]], which is celebrated from December 24 to January 6, the date of the celebration of the [[baptism of Jesus]], known in [[Ukraine]] as ''[[Epiphany (holiday)|Vodokhreshche]]'' or ''Yordan'',<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/ Christmas Traditions<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> according to the [[Gregorian calendar]] and [[Revised Julian calendar]] by the [[Latin Church in Ukraine|Latin]] and [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church|Greek]]<ref name=":3" /> [[Catholic Church in Ukraine|Catholics]], [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine]] and most [[Protestantism in Ukraine|Protestant churches]]. 
+
+The [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)|Ukrainian Orthodox Church of the Moscow Patriarchate]] (except for the [[Romanians in Ukraine|Romanian parishes]]<ref name=":2" />), some parishes of the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine]] and Protestant churches celebrate Christmas according to the [[Julian calendar]], so the Gregorian holidays last from January 6 to January 19. The {{ill|Armenian Diocese of Ukraine|hy|Ուկրաինայի հայոց թեմ|display=1}} of the [[Armenian Apostolic Church]] and [[Armenian Catholic Church in Ukraine]] celebrates Christmas from January 5 to January 6 along with [[Epiphany (holiday)|Epiphany]] according to the Gregorian calendar.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Do Lvivians know that Armenians celebrate Christmas on January 6? |url=https://tvoemisto.tv/blogs/shche_odna_data_rizdva_hto_u_lvovi_maie_svyatu_vecheryu_5_sichnya_141904.html |access-date=2023-06-18 |website=tvoemisto.tv}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |last=Терещук |first=Галина |date=2020-01-06 |title=Christmas in Lviv: three dates of the family holiday |language=uk |work=Радіо Свобода |url=https://www.radiosvoboda.org/a/30362341.html |access-date=2023-06-18}}</ref>
 
 Christmas was largely erased from the Ukrainian calendar for much of the 20th century due to the [[Persecution of Christians in the Soviet Union|Soviet Union's anti-religious policies]], but many of its traditions survived, having been transplanted to [[Novy God|New Year's Day]].<ref>{{Cite web|last=Tamkin|first=Emily|title=How Soviets Came to Celebrate New Year’s Like Christmas (and Why Russians Still Do)|url=https://foreignpolicy.com/2016/12/30/how-soviets-came-to-celebrate-new-years-like-christmas-and-why-russians-still-do/|access-date=2022-01-13|website=Foreign Policy|language=en-US}}</ref> 
 
@@ -52,7 +56,7 @@
 
 On February 2, 2023, the Holy Synod of the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine|OCU]] allowed and approved the procedure for blessing parishes and monasteries for the full use of the [[Revised Julian calendar]],<ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-02-02 |title=Decree of the Holy Synod on the procedure for blessing parishes and monasteries for the use of the Revised Julian calendar |url=https://www.pomisna.info/uk/vsi-novyny/postanova-svyashhennogo-synodu-pro-poryadok-nadannya-blagoslovennya-parafiyam-ta-monastyryam-na-vykorystannya-novoyulianskogo-kalendarya/ |access-date=2023-02-03 |website=OCU |language=uk}}</ref> and on May 24, 2023, to hold a meeting of the Council of Bishops, where the issue of calendar reform will be raised.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-02-02 |title=Official notice of the meeting of the Holy Synod on February 2, 2023. |url=https://www.pomisna.info/uk/vsi-novyny/ofitsijne-povidomlennya-pro-zasidannya-svyashhennogo-synodu-2-lyutogo-2023-r/ |access-date=2023-02-03 |website=OCU |language=uk}}</ref> 
 
-Effective 24 May 2023, the OCU officially declared that 25 December will be the permanent date for Christmas commemorations and festivities for the Ukrainian Orthodox faithful, as the Church officially formalized the adoption of the Revised Julian calendar for fixed feasts and solemnities in line with the other Orthodox churches of the world, with Easter kept in the old Julian Calendar.
+Effective 24 May 2023, the OCU officially declared that 25 December will be the permanent date for Christmas commemorations and festivities for the Ukrainian Orthodox faithful, as the Church officially formalized the adoption of the Revised Julian calendar for fixed feasts and solemnities in line with the other Orthodox churches of the world, with Easter kept in the old Julian Calendar.<ref>{{Cite news |last=RFE/RL |title=Orthodox Church Of Ukraine Approves Calendar Switch In Widening Diversion From Russia |language=en |work=RadioFreeEurope/RadioLiberty |url=https://www.rferl.org/a/orthodox-church-ukraine-approves-calendar-switch-russia/32426292.html |access-date=2023-06-18}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-05-24 |title=Orthodox Church of Ukraine to switch to Revised Julian calendar, celebrate Christmas on Dec. 25 |url=https://kyivindependent.com/orthodox-church-of-ukraine-to-switch-to-revised-julian-calendar-celebrate-christmas-on-dec-25/ |access-date=2023-06-18 |website=The Kyiv Independent |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Orthodox Church of Ukraine Decides to Celebrate Christmas on Dec. 25 |url=https://www.kyivpost.com/post/17460 |access-date=2023-06-18 |website=Get the Latest Ukraine News Today - KyivPost |language=en}}</ref>
 
 In February 2023 the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church|UGCC]] decided to switch to a new style ([[Revised Julian calendar]]) for fixed holidays (і.e., except for [[Date of Easter|Easter]]) from September 2023.<ref>{{Cite web|language=uk|url=https://ugcc.ua/data/istorychne-rishennya-ugkts-v-ukrayni-perehodyt-na-novyy-kalendar-2056/|title=Історичне рішення: УГКЦ в Україні переходить на новий календар|website=Українська Греко-Католицька Церква|accessdate=2023-02-06}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|language=uk|url=https://tsn.ua/ukrayina/ukrayinska-greko-katolicka-cerkva-perehodit-na-noviy-kalendar-podrobici-istorichnogo-rishennya-2259325.html|title=Українська греко-католицька церква переходить на новий календар: подробиці історичного рішення|website=ТСН.ua|date=2023-02-06|accessdate=2023-02-06}}</ref> TUGCC's Eparchy of Saints Peter and Paul of Melbourne (Australia/Oceania), in March 2023, declared itself to be the first UGCC diocese to formally adopt the Gregorian rather than Revised Julian for both movable and fixed feasts for its region. [[Parish|Parishes]] of the UGCC that are not ready to switch to the new style in 2023 have a transition period until September 1, 2025 to make the change.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web |date=2023-02-06 |title=Ukraine Catholic Church moves from Russian-affiliated Julian calendar |url=https://www.pillarcatholic.com/ukraine-catholic-church-moves-from-russian/ |access-date=2023-02-06 |website=The Pillar |language=en}}</ref>

The primates decided to create a joint working group on specific proposals for calendar reform. The joint group is initiated on the occasion of the celebration of the 1700th anniversary of the [[First Council of Nicaea|First Ecumenical Council]], held in [[Nicaea]] in 325. In this [[Ecumenical council|Council]], in particular, the calendar principles of church life were determined.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Heads of OCU, UGCC agree to set up working group to reform church calendar |url=https://www.ukrinform.net/rubric-society/3640576-heads-of-ocu-ugcc-agree-to-set-up-working-group-to-reform-church-calendar.html |access-date=2022-12-24 |website=www.ukrinform.net |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=During the meeting of His Beatitude Sviatoslav with His Beatitude Epiphanius, they talked about the reform of the church calendar |url=https://news.ugcc.ua/data/pid-chas-zustrichi-blazhennishogo-svyatoslava-z-blazhennishym-epifaniem-govoryly-pro-reformu-tserkovnogo-kalendarya-1713/ |access-date=2022-12-24 |website=Українська Греко-Католицька Церква |language=uk}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2022-12-24 |title=There was a meeting of the Primate of the OCU with the Father and the Primate of the UGCC |url=https://www.pomisna.info/uk/vsi-novyny/vidbulasya-zustrich-predstoyatelya-ptsu-z-ottsem-i-glavoyu-ugkts/ |access-date=2022-12-24 |website=OCU |language=uk}}</ref>

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -33,38 +33,38 @@
 Christmas was largely erased from the Ukrainian calendar for much of the [[20th century]] due to the [[Persecution of Christians in the Soviet Union|Soviet Union's anti-religious policies]], but many of its traditions survived, having been transplanted to [[Novy God|New Year's Day]].<ref>{{Cite web|last=Tamkin|first=Emily|title=How Soviets Came to Celebrate New Year’s Like Christmas (and Why Russians Still Do)|url=https://foreignpolicy.com/2016/12/30/how-soviets-came-to-celebrate-new-years-like-christmas-and-why-russians-still-do/|access-date=2022-01-13|website=Foreign Policy|language=en-US}}</ref> 
 
 ==History==
-In [[Ukraine]], the Christmas holiday became the official celebration with the [[baptism of Rus']] ordered by [[Prince Vladimir]] in the late [[10th century]]. However, given the early Christian community of [[Kievan Rus']], the celebration may have a long history.[[File:Новогодние марки Украины Дед Мороз.jpg|thumbnail|Did Moroz on a Ukrainian postage stamp with New Year greeting]]In the [[19th century]], a lavishly decorated Christmas tree became central to the holiday, a tradition originally imported by [[Nicholas I of Russia|Nicholas I]]'s wife, [[Alexandra Feodorovna (Charlotte of Prussia)|Alexandra Feodorovna]], from her native [[Prussia]]. The tradition of giving gifts to children on Christmas took root around the same time.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|last=Weber|first=Hannah|date=25 December 2020|title=Yolka: the story of Russia's 'New Year tree', from pagan origins to Soviet celebrations|url=https://www.calvertjournal.com/articles/show/9424/yolka-russia-new-year-tree-pagan-soviet-christmas|url-status=live|access-date=2021-06-12|website=The Calvert Journal|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180113181107/http://www.calvertjournal.com/articles/show/9424/yolka-russia-new-year-tree-pagan-soviet-christmas |archive-date=13 January 2018 }}</ref> Christmas gifts were traditionally brought by [[Did Moroz]] ({{lang-uk|Дід Мороз}}) or [[Grandfather Frost]], the Ukrainian counterpart of [[Santa Claus|Saint Nicholas]] or [[Father Christmas]], albeit a little taller and less stout. Rooted in Slavic folklore, Ded Moroz is accompanied by his beautiful granddaughter, [[Snegurka]] ({{lang-uk|Снігурка|Snihurka}}, [[Snegurochka|The Snowmaiden]]), who rides with him on a sleigh pulled by a trio of horses.<ref name=":0" />
+In [[Ukraine]], the Christmas holiday became the official celebration with the [[baptism of Rus']] ordered by [[Prince Vladimir]] in the late [[10th century]]. However, given the early Christian community of [[Kievan Rus']], the celebration may have a longer history.[[File:Новогодние марки Украины Дед Мороз.jpg|thumbnail|Did Moroz on a Ukrainian postage stamp with New Year greeting]]In the [[19th century]], a lavishly decorated Christmas tree became central to the holiday, a tradition originally imported by [[Nicholas I of Russia|Nicholas I]]'s wife, [[Alexandra Feodorovna (Charlotte of Prussia)|Alexandra Feodorovna]], from her native [[Prussia]]. The tradition of giving gifts to children on Christmas took root around the same time.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|last=Weber|first=Hannah|date=25 December 2020|title=Yolka: the story of Russia's 'New Year tree', from pagan origins to Soviet celebrations|url=https://www.calvertjournal.com/articles/show/9424/yolka-russia-new-year-tree-pagan-soviet-christmas|url-status=live|access-date=2021-06-12|website=The Calvert Journal|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180113181107/http://www.calvertjournal.com/articles/show/9424/yolka-russia-new-year-tree-pagan-soviet-christmas |archive-date=13 January 2018 }}</ref> Christmas gifts were traditionally brought by [[Did Moroz]] ({{lang-uk|Дід Мороз}}) or [[Grandfather Frost]], the Ukrainian counterpart of [[Santa Claus|Saint Nicholas]] or [[Father Christmas]], albeit a little taller and less stout. Rooted in Slavic folklore, Ded Moroz is accompanied by his beautiful granddaughter, [[Snegurka]] ({{lang-uk|Снігурка|Snihurka}}, [[Snegurochka|The Snowmaiden]]), who rides with him on a sleigh pulled by a trio of horses.<ref name=":0" />
 
-During the early [[History of the Soviet Union|Soviet period]], all religious celebrations were discouraged under the official state policy of [[atheism]]. The [[Bolsheviks]] argued that Christmas was a [[pagan]] [[sun-worship]]ping ritual with no basis in scientific fact and denounced the [[Christmas tree]] as a [[bourgeois]] German import.<ref name=":0" /> In 1929, all religious holidays, including Christmas, were abolished by a decree of the [[Stalinist regime]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|last=|first=|date=2019-12-29|title=How New Year was celebrated in the USSR (PHOTOS)|url=https://www.rbth.com/history/331458-soviet-new-year|url-status=live|access-date=2021-06-12|website=Beyond Russia|language=en-US|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191229111401/https://www.rbth.com/history/331458-soviet-new-year |archive-date=29 December 2019 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=Постановление СНК СССР от 24.09.1929|url=http://www.libussr.ru/doc_ussr/ussr_3594.htm|url-status=live|access-date=2021-06-12|website=www.libussr.ru|language=ru|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161229003241/http://www.libussr.ru:80/doc_ussr/ussr_3594.htm |archive-date=29 December 2016 }}</ref> However, in a surprising turn of state politics in 1935, many Ukrainian Christmas traditions were revived as part of a secular [[New Year's Eve|New Year's]] celebration after [[Joseph Stalin]]'s advisers convinced the [[Vozhd]] of the [[proletarians]]' need for a break from their hard work in the middle of a long, cold winter.<ref name=":1" /> The Christmas tree was repurposed as a "New Year's fir tree" ({{lang-uk|Новорічна ялинка|Novorichna yalynka}}) to be admired by all children throughout the [[Soviet Union]], including those in republics that had not historically celebrated Christmas due to their different religious traditions, such as the [[Soviet Central Asia|Central Asian ones]]. Other Ukrainian Christmas attributes and traditions, such as [[Christmas gift|gift-giving]], Did Moroz's visits and Christmas decorations, lost their religious significance and became associated with New Year's secular celebrations.<ref name=":0" />
+During the early [[History of the Soviet Union|Soviet period]], all religious celebrations were discouraged under the official state policy of [[atheism]]. The [[Bolsheviks]] argued that Christmas was a [[pagan]] [[sun-worship]]ping ritual with no basis in scientific fact and denounced the [[Christmas tree]] as a [[bourgeois]] German import.<ref name=":0" /> In 1929, all religious holidays, including Christmas, were abolished by a decree of the [[Stalinist regime]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|last=|first=|date=2019-12-29|title=How New Year was celebrated in the USSR (PHOTOS)|url=https://www.rbth.com/history/331458-soviet-new-year|url-status=live|access-date=2021-06-12|website=Beyond Russia|language=en-US|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191229111401/https://www.rbth.com/history/331458-soviet-new-year |archive-date=29 December 2019 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=Постановление СНК СССР от 24.09.1929|url=http://www.libussr.ru/doc_ussr/ussr_3594.htm|url-status=live|access-date=2021-06-12|website=www.libussr.ru|language=ru|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161229003241/http://www.libussr.ru:80/doc_ussr/ussr_3594.htm |archive-date=29 December 2016 }}</ref> However, in a surprising turn of state politics in 1935, many Ukrainian Christmas traditions were revived as part of a secular [[New Year's Eve|New Year's]] celebration after [[Joseph Stalin]]'s advisers convinced the [[Vozhd]] of the [[proletarians]]' need for a break from their hard work in the middle of a long, cold winter.<ref name=":1" /> The Christmas tree was repurposed as a "New Year's fir tree" ({{lang-uk|Новорічна ялинка|Novorichna yalynka}}) to be admired by all children throughout the [[Soviet Union]], including those in republics that had not historically celebrated Christmas due to their different religious traditions, such as the [[Soviet Central Asia|Central Asian ones]]. Other Ukrainian Christmas attributes and traditions, such as [[Christmas gift|gift-giving]], Did Moroz's visits and Christmas decorations, lost their religious significance and became associated with New Year's celebrations, which were secular in nature.<ref name=":0" />
 
-In 1991, after the dissolution of the Soviet Union, Christmas was reinstated alongside other religious holidays.<ref name=":0" /> Especially in recent years, there has been a shift from Did Moroz, who came to be associated with the Soviet-era heritage, to the more traditional [[Saint Nicholas]] ({{lang-uk|Святий Миколай|Sviatyi Mykolai}}), who used to be more popular in [[Western Ukraine]].<ref name=MT141120>{{cite news |url= http://www.themoscowtimes.com/news/article/kiev-brings-back-orthodox-santa-claus-instead-of-soviet-era-father-frost/511488.html |title= Kyiv Brings Back Orthodox Santa Claus Instead of Soviet-Era Father Frost |work= [[The Moscow Times]] |date= 20 November 2014 }}</ref> There were rumours that Ded Moroz imagery was discouraged by the authorities due to the [[Russo-Ukrainian War]]; however, the [[Ukrainian Ministry of Culture]] has refuted this.<ref>[https://comments.ua/society/604910-deda-moroza-snegurochku-ukraine.html "Деда Мороза и Снегурочку в Украине никто не запрещал - Минкульт"]</ref>
+In 1991, after the dissolution of the Soviet Union, Christmas was reinstated alongside other religious holidays.<ref name=":0" /> Especially in recent years, there has been a shift from Did Moroz, who came to be associated with the Soviet-era heritage, to the more traditional [[Saint Nicholas]] ({{lang-uk|Святий Миколай|Sviatyi Mykolai}}), who used to be more popular in [[Western Ukraine]].<ref name=MT141120>{{cite news |url= http://www.themoscowtimes.com/news/article/kiev-brings-back-orthodox-santa-claus-instead-of-soviet-era-father-frost/511488.html |title= Kiev Brings Back Orthodox Santa Claus Instead of Soviet-Era Father Frost |work= [[The Moscow Times]] |date= 20 November 2014 }}</ref> There were rumors that Ded Moroz imagery was discouraged by the authorities due to the [[Russo-Ukrainian War]]; however, the [[Ukrainian Ministry of Culture]] has refuted this.<ref>[https://comments.ua/society/604910-deda-moroza-snegurochku-ukraine.html "Деда Мороза и Снегурочку в Украине никто не запрещал - Минкульт"]</ref>
 
 == Date of celebration ==
 {{hatnote|Further information: {{ill|Calendar reform in Ukraine|uk|Календарна реформа в Україні|display=1}}}}
 [[File:Diduch-Lviv.jpg|thumb|A [[didukh]] in [[Lviv]].]]
-As of 2017, 25 December, Christmas Day by the [[Gregorian calendar|Gregorian]] calendar, became an official government holiday in Ukraine. [[Eastern Orthodox Church|The Eastern Orthodox Church]]es predominantly follow the Julian calendar, and 7 January is also a [[Public holidays in Ukraine|public holiday in Ukraine]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://m.digitaljournal.com/news/world/ukraine-seeks-distance-from-moscow-with-new-christmas-holiday/article/507753|title=Ukraine seeks distance from Moscow with new Christmas holiday|website=m.digitaljournal.com|date=16 November 2017|access-date=2017-11-16}}</ref><ref>{{in lang|uk}} {{Cite news|url=http://www.bbc.com/ukrainian/news-42008437|title=Рада зробила 25 грудня вихідним днем|date=2017-11-16|work=BBC Україна|access-date=2017-11-16|language=en-GB}}</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine]], [[Epiphanius I of Ukraine|Metropolitan Epiphanius]], said that changing the date of Christmas to 25 December in Ukraine is possible after both the church and the faithful are ready for such a decision, after conducting educational work. It was stated that the postponement of the Nativity of the Lord would entail a change in the dates of all fixed holidays to 13 days ago.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://news.rbc.ua/ukr/politics/epifaniy-nazval-uslovie-perenosa-prazdnovaniya-1608382147.html|title = Епіфаній назвав умову перенесення святкування Різдва на 25 грудня}}</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church]] (UGCC), [[Sviatoslav Shevchuk|Patriarch Sviatoslav]], stated that the Greek Catholic Church would resolve this issue "together with our Orthodox brothers." He also noted that this issue is not dogmatic; it should overcome church divisions, not cause new ones, and in his opinion, the laity should initiate the transition to celebrating Christmas in a new style — 25 December.
+As of 2017, 25 December, Christmas Day by the [[Gregorian calendar|Gregorian]] calendar, became an official government holiday in Ukraine. [[Eastern Orthodox Church|The Eastern Orthodox Church]]es predominantly follow the Julian calendar, and 7 January is also a [[Public holidays in Ukraine|public holiday in Ukraine]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://m.digitaljournal.com/news/world/ukraine-seeks-distance-from-moscow-with-new-christmas-holiday/article/507753|title=Ukraine seeks distance from Moscow with new Christmas holiday|website=m.digitaljournal.com|date=16 November 2017|access-date=2017-11-16}}</ref><ref>{{in lang|uk}} {{Cite news|url=http://www.bbc.com/ukrainian/news-42008437|title=Рада зробила 25 грудня вихідним днем|date=2017-11-16|work=BBC Україна|access-date=2017-11-16|language=en-GB}}</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine]], [[Epiphanius I of Ukraine|Metropolitan Epiphanius]], said that changing the date of Christmas to 25 December in Ukraine is possible after both the church and the faithful are ready for such a decision, after conducting educational work. It was stated that the postponement of the Nativity of the Lord would entail a change in the dates of all fixed holidays to 13 days ago.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://news.rbc.ua/ukr/politics/epifaniy-nazval-uslovie-perenosa-prazdnovaniya-1608382147.html|title = Епіфаній назвав умову перенесення святкування Різдва на 25 грудня}}</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church]] (UGCC), [[Sviatoslav Shevchuk|Patriarch Sviatoslav]], stated that the Greek Catholic Church would resolve this issue "together with our Orthodox brothers." He also noted that this issue is not dogmatic, it should overcome church divisions, not cause new ones, and in his opinion, the transition to celebrating Christmas in a new style — 25 December, should be initiated by the laity.
 
 About a hundred parishes of the [[Romanians in Ukraine|Romanian national minority in Ukraine]], which are part of the [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)|Ukrainian Orthodox Church of the Moscow Patriarchate]], have always celebrated Christmas on December 25 according to the [[Revised Julian calendar]], just like the [[Romanian Orthodox Church]].<ref name=":2">{{Cite news |last=Кралюк |first=Петро |date=2023-01-02 |title=«Є сподівання, що ПЦУ і УГКЦ перейдуть на святкування Різдва 25 грудня» – професор Петро Кралюк |language=uk |work=Радіо Свобода |url=https://www.radiosvoboda.org/a/rizdvo-tserkovnyy-kalendar/32201163.html |access-date=2023-03-27}}</ref>
 
-On 18 October 2022, the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine]] allowed dioceses to hold Christmas services according to the [[Revised Julian calendar]], i.e., 25 December. In the case of divine service, its participants are released from fasting restrictions on this day.<ref>{{Cite web |title=OCU allowed Christmas services on December 25 |url=https://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2022/10/18/7372478/ |accessdate=2022-10-18 |website=[[Ukrainian Pravda]] |language=uk}}</ref>
+On 18 October 2022, the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine]] allowed dioceses to hold Christmas services according to the [[Revised Julian calendar]], i.e., 25 December. In the case of a divine service, its participants are released from the restrictions of fasting on this day.<ref>{{Cite web |title=OCU allowed Christmas services on December 25 |url=https://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2022/10/18/7372478/ |accessdate=2022-10-18 |website=[[Ukrainian Pravda]] |language=uk}}</ref>
 
 On 24 December 2022, during an [[audience]], [[Major archbishop]] Sviatoslav handed over to [[Metropolitan of Kyiv and All Ukraine|Metropolitan]] [[Epiphanius I of Ukraine|Epiphanius]] for review a letter outlining the considerations of the UGCC hierarchs regarding the {{ill|Calendar reform in Ukraine|lt=calendar reform|uk|Календарна реформа в Україні|display=1}}. The primates decided to create a joint working group on specific proposals for calendar reform. The joint group is initiated on the occasion of the celebration of the 1700th anniversary of the [[First Council of Nicaea|First Ecumenical Council]], held in [[Nicaea]] in 325. In this [[Ecumenical council|Council]], in particular, the calendar principles of church life were determined.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Heads of OCU, UGCC agree to set up working group to reform church calendar |url=https://www.ukrinform.net/rubric-society/3640576-heads-of-ocu-ugcc-agree-to-set-up-working-group-to-reform-church-calendar.html |access-date=2022-12-24 |website=www.ukrinform.net |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=During the meeting of His Beatitude Sviatoslav with His Beatitude Epiphanius, they talked about the reform of the church calendar |url=https://news.ugcc.ua/data/pid-chas-zustrichi-blazhennishogo-svyatoslava-z-blazhennishym-epifaniem-govoryly-pro-reformu-tserkovnogo-kalendarya-1713/ |access-date=2022-12-24 |website=Українська Греко-Католицька Церква |language=uk}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2022-12-24 |title=There was a meeting of the Primate of the OCU with the Father and the Primate of the UGCC |url=https://www.pomisna.info/uk/vsi-novyny/vidbulasya-zustrich-predstoyatelya-ptsu-z-ottsem-i-glavoyu-ugkts/ |access-date=2022-12-24 |website=OCU |language=uk}}</ref>
 
 On February 2, 2023, the Holy Synod of the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine|OCU]] allowed and approved the procedure for blessing parishes and monasteries for the full use of the [[Revised Julian calendar]],<ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-02-02 |title=Decree of the Holy Synod on the procedure for blessing parishes and monasteries for the use of the Revised Julian calendar |url=https://www.pomisna.info/uk/vsi-novyny/postanova-svyashhennogo-synodu-pro-poryadok-nadannya-blagoslovennya-parafiyam-ta-monastyryam-na-vykorystannya-novoyulianskogo-kalendarya/ |access-date=2023-02-03 |website=OCU |language=uk}}</ref> and on May 24, 2023, to hold a meeting of the Council of Bishops, where the issue of calendar reform will be raised.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-02-02 |title=Official notice of the meeting of the Holy Synod on February 2, 2023. |url=https://www.pomisna.info/uk/vsi-novyny/ofitsijne-povidomlennya-pro-zasidannya-svyashhennogo-synodu-2-lyutogo-2023-r/ |access-date=2023-02-03 |website=OCU |language=uk}}</ref>
 
-In February 2023, the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church|UGCC]] decided to switch to a new style ([[Revised Julian calendar]]) for fixed holidays (і.e., except for [[Date of Easter|Easter]]) from September 2023.<ref>{{Cite web|language=uk|url=https://ugcc.ua/data/istorychne-rishennya-ugkts-v-ukrayni-perehodyt-na-novyy-kalendar-2056/|title=Історичне рішення: УГКЦ в Україні переходить на новий календар|website=Українська Греко-Католицька Церква|accessdate=2023-02-06}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|language=uk|url=https://tsn.ua/ukrayina/ukrayinska-greko-katolicka-cerkva-perehodit-na-noviy-kalendar-podrobici-istorichnogo-rishennya-2259325.html|title=Українська греко-католицька церква переходить на новий календар: подробиці історичного рішення|website=ТСН.ua|date=2023-02-06|accessdate=2023-02-06}}</ref> [[Parish|Parishes]] of the UGCC that are not ready to switch to the new style in 2023 have a transition period until September 1, 2025, to make the change.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web |date=2023-02-06 |title=Ukraine Catholic Church moves from Russian-affiliated Julian calendar |url=https://www.pillarcatholic.com/ukraine-catholic-church-moves-from-russian/ |access-date=2023-02-06 |website=The Pillar |language=en}}</ref>
+In February 2023 the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church|UGCC]] decided to switch to a new style ([[Revised Julian calendar]]) for fixed holidays (і.e., except for [[Date of Easter|Easter]]) from September 2023.<ref>{{Cite web|language=uk|url=https://ugcc.ua/data/istorychne-rishennya-ugkts-v-ukrayni-perehodyt-na-novyy-kalendar-2056/|title=Історичне рішення: УГКЦ в Україні переходить на новий календар|website=Українська Греко-Католицька Церква|accessdate=2023-02-06}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|language=uk|url=https://tsn.ua/ukrayina/ukrayinska-greko-katolicka-cerkva-perehodit-na-noviy-kalendar-podrobici-istorichnogo-rishennya-2259325.html|title=Українська греко-католицька церква переходить на новий календар: подробиці історичного рішення|website=ТСН.ua|date=2023-02-06|accessdate=2023-02-06}}</ref> [[Parish|Parishes]] of the UGCC that are not ready to switch to the new style in 2023 have a transition period until September 1, 2025 to make the change.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web |date=2023-02-06 |title=Ukraine Catholic Church moves from Russian-affiliated Julian calendar |url=https://www.pillarcatholic.com/ukraine-catholic-church-moves-from-russian/ |access-date=2023-02-06 |website=The Pillar |language=en}}</ref>
 
 ==Sviatyi Vechir (Holy Evening)==
 [[File:Шопка_перед_львівською_ратушою.jpg|thumb|[[Nativity scene]].]]
-[[Christmas Eve]] is called Sviatyi Vechir (''Святий вечір'') or Sviatvechir (''Святвечір'') in Ukraine ("Holy Evening"), and has many customs and rituals, most of which predate the introduction of Christianity to Ukraine. Traditions include decorating house and dinner tables with special attributes (a symbolic sheaf of wheat called the ''[[didukh]]'', [[garlic]], hay, and others), performing [[Koliada|koliadky]] ('carols') and so on.  Each ritual has its meaning and purpose; a few wisps of hay on the embroidered tablecloth is a reminder of the manger in [[Bethlehem]]. One prominent custom of the night is a special supper, called ''[[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|Sviata Vecheria]]'' ("Holy Supper").<ref>{{Cite book|last=Inc|first=World Book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Nks04JbYUSgC&dq=sviata+vecheria&pg=PA33|title=Christmas in Ukraine|date=1997|publisher=World Book .com|isbn=978-0-7166-0897-4|language=en}}</ref>
+[[Christmas Eve]] is called Sviatyi Vechir (''Святий вечір'') or Sviatvechir (''Святвечір'') in Ukraine ("Holy Evening"), and has many customs and rituals, most of which predate the introduction of Christianity to Ukraine. Traditions include decorating house and dinner table with special attributes (a symbolic sheaf of wheat called the ''[[didukh]]'', [[garlic]], hay, and others), performing [[Koliada|koliadky]] ('carols') and so on.  Each ritual has its own meaning and purpose, as such a few wisps of hay on the embroidered tablecloth as a reminder of the manger in [[Bethlehem]]. One prominent custom of the night is a special supper, called ''[[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|Sviata Vecheria]]'' ("Holy Supper").<ref>{{Cite book|last=Inc|first=World Book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Nks04JbYUSgC&dq=sviata+vecheria&pg=PA33|title=Christmas in Ukraine|date=1997|publisher=World Book .com|isbn=978-0-7166-0897-4|language=en}}</ref>
 
-Ukrainians fast on Sviat vechir; only when the first star is seen in the evening sky may the supper begin.  The family comes together to have a dinner which usually includes 12 dishes (the number can vary from 7–17). These [[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|twelve dishes]] are traditionally vegan plus fish and do not contain meat, milk, or eggs.<ref>{{cite web |title=Christmas in Ukraine |url=https://www.whychristmas.com/cultures/ukraine.shtml |website=Why Christmas |access-date=14 December 2020}}</ref> While the dishes served can vary regionally, as well as from family to family, the two mandatory dishes are uzvar and kutia, both reckoned by ethnographer [[Fedir Vovk|Khvedir Vovk]] to be remnants of ancient rituals which date back to the Neolithic era.<ref>{{cite web |title=Traditional Recipe of Ukrainian Kutia |url=https://etnocook.com/kutia/ |website=Ethnocook |access-date=27 November 2022}}</ref> [[Kutia]] (a dish of grain, honey and poppy seeds) is traditionally served first at the meal, after being offered by the head of the household to the frost. A spoonful is tossed at the ceiling, and the number of poppy seeds which stick portends the fruitfulness of the fields and farm animals in the coming year. It is rarely served at other times of the year.<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html Sviat Vechir<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Uzvar is a beverage made with cooked dried fruits and berries. It can be mixed in with the kutia or served separately at the end of the meal.  Servings of both dishes are also set aside overnight in the porketta, the corner of the house with the icons for the ancestors.
+Ukrainians fast on Sviat vechir; only when the first star is seen in the evening sky, may the supper begin.  The family comes together to have a dinner which usually includes 12 dishes (the number can vary from 7–17). These [[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|twelve dishes]] are traditionally vegan plus fish, and do not contain meat, milk, or eggs.<ref>{{cite web |title=Christmas in Ukraine |url=https://www.whychristmas.com/cultures/ukraine.shtml |website=Why Christmas |access-date=14 December 2020}}</ref> While the dishes served can vary regionally, as well as from family to family, the two mandatory dishes are uzvar and kutia, both reckoned by ethnographer [[Fedir Vovk|Khvedir Vovk]] to be remnants of ancient rituals which date back to the neolithic era.<ref>{{cite web |title=Traditional Recipe of Ukrainian Kutia |url=https://etnocook.com/kutia/ |website=Ethnocook |access-date=27 November 2022}}</ref> [[Kutia]] (a dish of grain, honey and poppy seeds) is traditionally served first at the meal, after being offered by the head of the household to the frost. A spoonful is tossed at the ceiling, and the number of poppy seeds which stick portends the fruitfulness of the fields and farm animals in the coming year. It is rarely served at other times of the year.<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html Sviat Vechir<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Uzvar is a beverage, made with cooked dried fruits and berries. It can be mixed in with the kutia, or served separately at the end of the meal.  Servings of both dishes are also set aside overnight in the pokuttia, the corner of the house with the icons, for the ancestors.
 
 ==Koliadky (Caroling)==
-At the end of the Sviata Vechera, the family often sings carols (''koliadky'', singular ''koliadka''). In many communities, the ancient Ukrainian tradition of carolling is carried on by groups of young people and members of organizations and churches calling at homes and collecting donations. A well-known carol is ''{{ill|Nova radist stala|lt=|uk|Нова радість стала|display=1}}'', [[Boh predvičnyj narodivsja|''Boh predvichnyi narodyvsia'']],<ref name=BLiturgy>{{cite web|title=Boh predvičnyj|url=http://mci.archpitt.org/legacy/songs/Slavonic/Boh_predvicnyj.html|website=Metropolitan Cantor Institute|publisher=Byzantine Catholic|access-date=12 August 2015|ref=Archeparchy of Pittsburgh|archive-date=4 March 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304235614/http://mci.archpitt.org/legacy/songs/Slavonic/Boh_predvicnyj.html|url-status=dead}}</ref> ''{{ill|Dobryi vechir tobi, pane hospodariu|lt=|uk|Добрий вечір тобі, пане господарю|display=1}}'', ''{{ill|Vo Vyfleiemi nyni novyna|lt=|uk|Во Вифлеємі нині новина|display=1}}'', ''{{ill|Nebo i zemlia nyni torzhestvuiut|lt=|uk|Небо і земля нині торжествують|display=1}}'', ''{{ill|Boh sia rozhdaie|lt=|uk|Бог ся раджае|display=1}}'' etc.
+At the end of the Sviata Vechera the family often sings carols (''koliadky'', singular ''koliadka''). In many communities the ancient Ukrainian tradition of caroling is carried on by groups of young people and members of organizations and churches calling at homes and collecting donations. A well-known carol is ''{{ill|Nova radist stala|lt=|uk|Нова радість стала|display=1}}'', [[Boh predvičnyj narodivsja|''Boh predvichnyi narodyvsia'']],<ref name=BLiturgy>{{cite web|title=Boh predvičnyj|url=http://mci.archpitt.org/legacy/songs/Slavonic/Boh_predvicnyj.html|website=Metropolitan Cantor Institute|publisher=Byzantine Catholic|access-date=12 August 2015|ref=Archeparchy of Pittsburgh|archive-date=4 March 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304235614/http://mci.archpitt.org/legacy/songs/Slavonic/Boh_predvicnyj.html|url-status=dead}}</ref> ''{{ill|Dobryi vechir tobi, pane hospodariu|lt=|uk|Добрий вечір тобі, пане господарю|display=1}}'', ''{{ill|Vo Vyfleiemi nyni novyna|lt=|uk|Во Вифлеємі нині новина|display=1}}'', ''{{ill|Nebo i zemlia nyni torzhestvuiut|lt=|uk|Небо і земля нині торжествують|display=1}}'', ''{{ill|Boh sia rozhdaie|lt=|uk|Бог ся раджае|display=1}}'' etc.
 
 ==Didukh (Grandfather)==
-In villages (farming communities), the head of the household brings in a sheaf of grain called the ''[[didukh]]'', which represents the importance of the ancient and rich wheat crops of Ukraine, the staff of life through the centuries. Didukh means "grandfather spirit," symbolizing the family's ancestors. In Ukrainian city homes, the didukh may be purchased and is often three-footed and made of woven grain and dried grasses and flowers.{{citation needed|date=April 2022}}
+In villages (farming communities), the head of the household brings in a sheaf of grain called the ''[[didukh]]'' which represents the importance of the ancient and rich wheat crops of Ukraine, the staff of life through the centuries. Didukh means literally "grandfather spirit" so it symbolizes the family's ancestors. In Ukrainian city homes the didukh may be purchased, and is often three footed made of woven grain and dried grasses and flowers.{{citation needed|date=April 2022}}
 
 ==Shopka (Nativity scene)==
 A ''[[Nativity scene|shopka]] ([[vertep]])'' is a traditional portable [[Nativity of Jesus|nativity]] scene used to represent nativity and other figures in a [[Nativity play|puppet]] form.{{citation needed|date=April 2022}}

 The All-Night Christmas Vigil then follows, families then troop to their local parish churches or Protestant chruches to attend as thanksgiving for the Savior's birth in a stable.
 
 ==''Koliadky'' (caroling)==
-At the end of the Sviata Vechera the family often sings carols (''koliadky'', singular ''koliadka''). In many communities the ancient Ukrainian tradition of caroling is carried on by groups of young people and members of organizations and churches calling at homes and collecting donations. A well-known carol is ''{{ill|Nova radist stala|lt=|uk|Нова радість стала|display=1}}'', [[Boh predvičnyj narodivsja|''Boh predvichnyi narodyvsia'']],<ref name=BLiturgy>{{cite web|title=Boh predvičnyj|url=http://mci.archpitt.org/legacy/songs/Slavonic/Boh_predvicnyj.html|website=Metropolitan Cantor Institute|publisher=Byzantine Catholic|access-date=12 August 2015|ref=Archeparchy of Pittsburgh|archive-date=4 March 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304235614/http://mci.archpitt.org/legacy/songs/Slavonic/Boh_predvicnyj.html|url-status=dead}}</ref> ''{{ill|Dobryi vechir tobi, pane hospodariu|lt=|uk|Добрий вечір тобі, пане господарю|display=1}}'', ''{{ill|Vo Vyfleiemi nyni novyna|lt=|uk|Во Вифлеємі нині новина|display=1}}'', ''{{ill|Nebo i zemlia nyni torzhestvuiut|lt=|uk|Небо і земля нині торжествують|display=1}}'', ''{{ill|Boh sia rozhdaie|lt=|uk|Бог ся раджае|display=1}}'' etc.
+At the end of the Sviata Vechera dinner, and the vigil that follows, the family often sings carols (''koliadky'', singular ''koliadka''). In many communities the ancient Ukrainian tradition of caroling is carried on by groups of young people and members of organizations and churches calling at homes and collecting donations. A well-known carol is ''{{ill|Nova radist stala|lt=|uk|Нова радість стала|display=1}}'', [[Boh predvičnyj narodivsja|''Boh predvichnyi narodyvsia'']],<ref name=BLiturgy>{{cite web|title=Boh predvičnyj|url=http://mci.archpitt.org/legacy/songs/Slavonic/Boh_predvicnyj.html|website=Metropolitan Cantor Institute|publisher=Byzantine Catholic|access-date=12 August 2015|ref=Archeparchy of Pittsburgh|archive-date=4 March 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304235614/http://mci.archpitt.org/legacy/songs/Slavonic/Boh_predvicnyj.html|url-status=dead}}</ref> ''{{ill|Dobryi vechir tobi, pane hospodariu|lt=|uk|Добрий вечір тобі, пане господарю|display=1}}'', ''{{ill|Vo Vyfleiemi nyni novyna|lt=|uk|Во Вифлеємі нині новина|display=1}}'', ''{{ill|Nebo i zemlia nyni torzhestvuiut|lt=|uk|Небо і земля нині торжествують|display=1}}'', ''{{ill|Boh sia rozhdaie|lt=|uk|Бог ся раджае|display=1}}'' etc.
 
 ==''Didukh'' (grandfather)==
 In villages (farming communities), the head of the household brings in a sheaf of grain called the ''[[didukh]]'' which represents the importance of the ancient and rich wheat crops of Ukraine, the staff of life through the centuries. Didukh means literally "grandfather spirit" so it symbolizes the family's ancestors. In Ukrainian city homes the didukh may be purchased, and is often three footed made of woven grain and dried grasses and flowers.{{citation needed|date=April 2022}}

+Effective 24 May 2023, the OCU officially declared that 25 December will be the permanent date for Christmas commemorations and festivities for the Ukrainian Orthodox faithful, as the Church officially formalized the adoption of the Revised Julian calendar for fixed feasts and solemnities in line with the other Orthodox churches of the world, with Easter kept in the old Julian Calendar.<ref>{{Cite news |last=RFE/RL |title=Orthodox Church Of Ukraine Approves Calendar Switch In Widening Diversion From Russia |language=en |work=RadioFreeEurope/RadioLiberty |url=https://www.rferl.org/a/orthodox-church-ukraine-approves-calendar-switch-russia/32426292.html |access-date=2023-06-18}}</ref><ref name=":4">{{Cite web |date=2023-05-24 |title=Orthodox Church of Ukraine to switch to Revised Julian calendar, celebrate Christmas on Dec. 25 |url=https://kyivindependent.com/orthodox-church-of-ukraine-to-switch-to-revised-julian-calendar-celebrate-christmas-on-dec-25/ |access-date=2023-06-18 |website=The Kyiv Independent |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Orthodox Church of Ukraine Decides to Celebrate Christmas on Dec. 25 |url=https://www.kyivpost.com/post/17460 |access-date=2023-06-18 |website=Get the Latest Ukraine News Today - KyivPost |language=en}}</ref>

 ==Sviatyi Vechir (Holy Evening)==
 [[File:Шопка_перед_львівською_ратушою.jpg|thumb|[[Nativity scene]].]]
-[[Christmas Eve]] (24 December/6 January) is called Sviatyi Vechir (''Святий вечір'') or Sviatvechir (''Святвечір'') in Ukraine ("Holy Evening"), and has many customs and rituals, most of which predate the introduction of Christianity to Ukraine. Traditions include decorating house and dinner table with special attributes (a symbolic sheaf of wheat called the ''[[didukh]]'', [[garlic]], hay, and others), performing [[Koliada|koliadky]] ('carols') and so on.  Each ritual has its own meaning and purpose, as such a few wisps of hay on the embroidered tablecloth as a reminder of the manger in [[Bethlehem]]. One prominent custom of the night is a special supper, called ''[[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|Sviata Vecheria]]'' ("Holy Supper").<ref>{{Cite book|last=Inc|first=World Book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Nks04JbYUSgC&dq=sviata+vecheria&pg=PA33|title=Christmas in Ukraine|date=1997|publisher=World Book .com|isbn=978-0-7166-0897-4|language=en}}</ref>
+[[Christmas Eve]] on December 24 is called Sviatyi Vechir (''Святий вечір'') or Sviatvechir (''Святвечір'') in Ukraine ("Holy Evening"), and has many customs and rituals, most of which predate the introduction of Christianity to Ukraine. Traditions include decorating house and dinner table with special attributes (a symbolic sheaf of wheat called the ''[[didukh]]'', [[garlic]], hay, and others), performing [[Koliada|koliadky]] ('carols') and so on.  Each ritual has its own meaning and purpose, as such a few wisps of hay on the embroidered tablecloth as a reminder of the manger in [[Bethlehem]]. One prominent custom of the night is a special supper, called ''[[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|Sviata Vecheria]]'' ("Holy Supper").<ref>{{Cite book|last=Inc|first=World Book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Nks04JbYUSgC&dq=sviata+vecheria&pg=PA33|title=Christmas in Ukraine|date=1997|publisher=World Book .com|isbn=978-0-7166-0897-4|language=en}}</ref>
 
-Ukrainians fast on Sviat vechir; only when the first star is seen in the evening sky, may the supper begin.  The family comes together to have a dinner which usually includes 12 dishes (the number can vary from 7–17). These [[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|twelve dishes]] are traditionally vegan plus fish, and do not contain meat, milk, or eggs.<ref>{{cite web |title=Christmas in Ukraine |url=https://www.whychristmas.com/cultures/ukraine.shtml |website=Why Christmas |access-date=14 December 2020}}</ref> While the dishes served can vary regionally, as well as from family to family, the two mandatory dishes are uzvar and kutia, both reckoned by ethnographer [[Fedir Vovk|Khvedir Vovk]] to be remnants of ancient rituals which date back to the neolithic era.<ref>{{cite web |title=Traditional Recipe of Ukrainian Kutia |url=https://etnocook.com/kutia/ |website=Ethnocook |access-date=27 November 2022}}</ref> [[Kutia]] (a dish of grain, honey and poppy seeds) is traditionally served first at the meal, after being offered by the head of the household to the frost. A spoonful is tossed at the ceiling, and in rural townships the number of poppy seeds which stick portends the fruitfulness of the fields and farm animals in the coming year. It is rarely served at other times of the year.<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html Sviat Vechir<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Uzvar is a beverage, made with cooked dried fruits and berries. It can be mixed in with the kutia, or served separately at the end of the meal.  Servings of both dishes are also set aside overnight in the pokuttia, the corner of the house with the Orthodox icons or Catholic images of saints, for deceased ancestors within the family.
+Ukrainians of the OCU and UGCC fast on Sviatyi Vechir (Latin Rite Catholics and Protestants may choose also to follow tradition on said day); only when the first star is seen in the evening sky, may the supper begin.  The family comes together to have a dinner which usually includes 12 dishes (the number can vary from 7–17). These [[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|twelve dishes]] are traditionally vegan plus fish, and do not contain meat, milk, or eggs.<ref>{{cite web |title=Christmas in Ukraine |url=https://www.whychristmas.com/cultures/ukraine.shtml |website=Why Christmas |access-date=14 December 2020}}</ref> While the dishes served can vary regionally, as well as from family to family, the two mandatory dishes are uzvar and kutia, both reckoned by ethnographer [[Fedir Vovk|Khvedir Vovk]] to be remnants of ancient rituals which date back to the neolithic era.<ref>{{cite web |title=Traditional Recipe of Ukrainian Kutia |url=https://etnocook.com/kutia/ |website=Ethnocook |access-date=27 November 2022}}</ref> [[Kutia]] (a dish of grain, honey and poppy seeds) is traditionally served first at the meal, after being offered by the head of the household to the frost. A spoonful is tossed at the ceiling, and in rural townships the number of poppy seeds which stick portends the fruitfulness of the fields and farm animals in the coming year. It is rarely served at other times of the year.<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html Sviat Vechir<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Uzvar is a beverage, made with cooked dried fruits and berries. It can be mixed in with the kutia, or served separately at the end of the meal.  Servings of both dishes are also set aside overnight in the pokuttia, the corner of the house with the Orthodox icons or Catholic images of saints, for deceased ancestors within the family.
+
+The All-Night Christmas Vigil then follows, families then troop to their local parish churches or Protestant chruches to attend as thanksgiving for the Savior's birth in a stable.
 
 ==''Koliadky'' (caroling)==
 At the end of the Sviata Vechera the family often sings carols (''koliadky'', singular ''koliadka''). In many communities the ancient Ukrainian tradition of caroling is carried on by groups of young people and members of organizations and churches calling at homes and collecting donations. A well-known carol is ''{{ill|Nova radist stala|lt=|uk|Нова радість стала|display=1}}'', [[Boh predvičnyj narodivsja|''Boh predvichnyi narodyvsia'']],<ref name=BLiturgy>{{cite web|title=Boh predvičnyj|url=http://mci.archpitt.org/legacy/songs/Slavonic/Boh_predvicnyj.html|website=Metropolitan Cantor Institute|publisher=Byzantine Catholic|access-date=12 August 2015|ref=Archeparchy of Pittsburgh|archive-date=4 March 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304235614/http://mci.archpitt.org/legacy/songs/Slavonic/Boh_predvicnyj.html|url-status=dead}}</ref> ''{{ill|Dobryi vechir tobi, pane hospodariu|lt=|uk|Добрий вечір тобі, пане господарю|display=1}}'', ''{{ill|Vo Vyfleiemi nyni novyna|lt=|uk|Во Вифлеємі нині новина|display=1}}'', ''{{ill|Nebo i zemlia nyni torzhestvuiut|lt=|uk|Небо і земля нині торжествують|display=1}}'', ''{{ill|Boh sia rozhdaie|lt=|uk|Бог ся раджае|display=1}}'' etc.

 In 1991, after the dissolution of the Soviet Union, Christmas was reinstated alongside other religious holidays.<ref name=":0" /> Especially in recent years, there has been a shift from Did Moroz, who came to be associated with the Soviet-era heritage, to the more traditional [[Saint Nicholas]] ({{lang-uk|Святий Миколай|Sviatyi Mykolai}}), who used to be more popular in [[Western Ukraine]].<ref name=MT141120>{{cite news |url= http://www.themoscowtimes.com/news/article/kiev-brings-back-orthodox-santa-claus-instead-of-soviet-era-father-frost/511488.html |title= Kiev Brings Back Orthodox Santa Claus Instead of Soviet-Era Father Frost |work= [[The Moscow Times]] |date= 20 November 2014 }}</ref> There were rumors that Ded Moroz imagery was discouraged by the authorities due to the [[Russo-Ukrainian War]]; however, the [[Ukrainian Ministry of Culture]] has refuted this.<ref>[https://comments.ua/society/604910-deda-moroza-snegurochku-ukraine.html "Деда Мороза и Снегурочку в Украине никто не запрещал - Минкульт"]</ref>
 
 == Date of celebration ==
-{{hatnote|Further information: {{ill|Calendar reform in Ukraine|uk|Календарна реформа в Україні|display=1}}}}
 [[File:Diduch-Lviv.jpg|thumb|A [[didukh]] in [[Lviv]]]]
 As of 2017, 25 December, Christmas Day by the [[Gregorian calendar|Gregorian]] calendar, became an official government holiday in Ukraine. The [[Eastern Orthodox Church]]es predominantly follow the Julian calendar, and 7 January is also a [[Public holidays in Ukraine|public holiday in Ukraine]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://m.digitaljournal.com/news/world/ukraine-seeks-distance-from-moscow-with-new-christmas-holiday/article/507753|title=Ukraine seeks distance from Moscow with new Christmas holiday|website=m.digitaljournal.com|date=16 November 2017|access-date=2017-11-16}}</ref><ref>{{in lang|uk}} {{Cite news|url=http://www.bbc.com/ukrainian/news-42008437|title=Рада зробила 25 грудня вихідним днем|date=2017-11-16|work=BBC Україна|access-date=2017-11-16|language=en-GB}}</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine]], [[Epiphanius I of Ukraine|Metropolitan Epiphanius]], said that changing the date of Christmas to 25 December in Ukraine is possible after both the church and the faithful are ready for such a decision, after conducting educational work. It was stated that the postponement of the celebration of the nativity of the lord would entail a change in the dates of all fixed holidays to 13 days ago.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://news.rbc.ua/ukr/politics/epifaniy-nazval-uslovie-perenosa-prazdnovaniya-1608382147.html|title = Епіфаній назвав умову перенесення святкування Різдва на 25 грудня}}</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church]] (UGCC), [[Sviatoslav Shevchuk|Patriarch Sviatoslav]], stated that the Greek Catholic Church would resolve this issue "together with our Orthodox brothers". He also noted that this issue is not dogmatic, it should overcome church divisions, not cause new ones, and in his opinion, the transition to celebrating Christmas in a new style — 25 December, should be initiated by the laity.
