@@ -45,7 +45,7 @@
 
 == Date of celebration ==
 [[File:Diduch-Lviv.jpg|thumb|A [[didukh]] in [[Lviv]]]]
-As of 2017, 25 December, Christmas Day by the [[Gregorian calendar|Gregorian]] calendar, became an official government holiday in Ukraine. The [[Eastern Orthodox Church]]es predominantly follow the Julian calendar, and 7 January is also a [[Public holidays in Ukraine|public holiday in Ukraine]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://m.digitaljournal.com/news/world/ukraine-seeks-distance-from-moscow-with-new-christmas-holiday/article/507753|title=Ukraine seeks distance from Moscow with new Christmas holiday|website=m.digitaljournal.com|date=16 November 2017|access-date=2017-11-16|archive-date=17 November 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171117065016/http://m.digitaljournal.com/news/world/ukraine-seeks-distance-from-moscow-with-new-christmas-holiday/article/507753|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref>{{in lang|uk}} {{Cite news|url=http://www.bbc.com/ukrainian/news-42008437|title=Рада зробила 25 грудня вихідним днем|date=2017-11-16|work=BBC Україна|access-date=2017-11-16|language=en-GB}}</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine]], [[Epiphanius I of Ukraine|Metropolitan Epiphanius]], said that changing the date of Christmas to 25 December in Ukraine is possible after both the church and the faithful are ready for such a decision, after conducting educational work. It was stated that the postponement of the celebration of the nativity of the lord would entail a change in the dates of all fixed holidays to 13 days ago.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://news.rbc.ua/ukr/politics/epifaniy-nazval-uslovie-perenosa-prazdnovaniya-1608382147.html|title = Епіфаній назвав умову перенесення святкування Різдва на 25 грудня}}</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church]] (UGCC), [[Sviatoslav Shevchuk|Patriarch Sviatoslav]], stated that the Greek Catholic Church would resolve this issue "together with our Orthodox brothers". He also noted that this issue is not dogmatic, it should overcome church divisions, not cause new ones, and in his opinion, the transition to celebrating Christmas in a new style — 25 December, should be initiated by the laity.
+As of 2017, 25 December, Christmas Day by the [[Gregorian calendar|Gregorian]] calendar, became an official government holiday in Ukraine. The [[Eastern Orthodox Church]]es predominantly follow the Julian calendar, and 7 January is also a [[Public holidays in Ukraine|public holiday in Ukraine]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://m.digitaljournal.com/news/world/ukraine-seeks-distance-from-moscow-with-new-christmas-holiday/article/507753|title=Ukraine seeks distance from Moscow with new Christmas holiday|website=m.digitaljournal.com|date=16 November 2017|access-date=2017-11-16|archive-date=17 November 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171117065016/http://m.digitaljournal.com/news/world/ukraine-seeks-distance-from-moscow-with-new-christmas-holiday/article/507753|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref>{{in lang|uk}} {{Cite news|url=http://www.bbc.com/ukrainian/news-42008437|title=Рада зробила 25 грудня вихідним днем|date=2017-11-16|work=BBC Україна|access-date=2017-11-16|language=en-GB}}</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine]], [[Epiphanius I of Ukraine|Metropolitan Epiphanius]], said that changing the date of Christmas to 25 December in Ukraine is possible after both the church and the faithful are ready for such a decision, after conducting educational work. It was stated that the postponement of the celebration of the nativity of The Lord would entail a change in the dates of all fixed holidays to 13 days ago.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://news.rbc.ua/ukr/politics/epifaniy-nazval-uslovie-perenosa-prazdnovaniya-1608382147.html|title = Епіфаній назвав умову перенесення святкування Різдва на 25 грудня}}</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church]] (UGCC), [[Sviatoslav Shevchuk|Patriarch Sviatoslav]], stated that the Greek Catholic Church would resolve this issue "together with our Orthodox brothers". He also noted that this issue is not dogmatic, it should overcome church divisions, not cause new ones, and in his opinion, the transition to celebrating Christmas in a new style — 25 December, should be initiated by the laity.
 
 About a hundred parishes of the [[Romanians in Ukraine|Romanian national minority in Ukraine]], which are part of the [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)|Ukrainian Orthodox Church of the Moscow Patriarchate]], have always celebrated Christmas on December 25 according to the [[Revised Julian calendar]], just like the [[Romanian Orthodox Church]].<ref name=":2">{{Cite news |last=Кралюк |first=Петро |date=2023-01-02 |title=«Є сподівання, що ПЦУ і УГКЦ перейдуть на святкування Різдва 25 грудня» – професор Петро Кралюк |language=uk |work=Радіо Свобода |url=https://www.radiosvoboda.org/a/rizdvo-tserkovnyy-kalendar/32201163.html |access-date=2023-03-27}}</ref>

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -61,7 +61,7 @@
 
 On 28 June 2023 [[President of Ukraine]], [[Volodymyr Zelenskyy]], submitted to the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (Ukraine's national parliament) a draft law removing the Julian Calendar Christmas holiday on January 7 and confirming the December 25 date as the sole day of celebrations, reflecting changes in the OCU and UGCC calendars.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Zelensky Introduces Proposed Draft Law to Change Holiday Dates |url=https://www.kyivpost.com/post/18846 |access-date=2023-06-29 |website=Get the Latest Ukraine News Today - KyivPost |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-06-28 |title=Zelensky submitted to the Verkhovna Rada a law on changing holiday dates |url=https://babel.ua/en/news/95649-zelensky-submitted-to-the-verkhovna-rada-a-law-on-changing-holiday-dates |access-date=2023-06-29 |website=babel.ua |language=en}}</ref> Parliament passed this law on 14 July 2023 with 241 deputies voting in the affirmative.<ref name="3735767ChristmasUA">{{Cite web |date=2023-07-14 |title=Parliament changes dates of Christmas, Statehood Day, Day of Defenders |url=https://www.ukrinform.net/rubric-society/3735767-parliament-changes-dates-of-three-holidays-christmas-statehood-day-day-of-defenders-of-ukraine.html |access-date=2023-07-14 |website=[[Ukrinform]] |language=en}}</ref> Zelensky signed the law on 28 July 2023.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cnn.com/2023/07/29/europe/ukraine-christmas-date-change-intl/index.html|last1 = Toropin | first1 = Konstantin | last2 = Stambaugh | first2 = Alex | title = Ukraine moves Christmas to December 25, distancing itself from Russian tradition | website = Cable News Network | date = 29 July 2023 | accessdate = 1 August 2023}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-07-29 |title=Ukraine moves official Christmas Day holiday to Dec. 25, denouncing Russian-imposed traditions |url=https://apnews.com/article/russia-ukraine-war-christmas-orthodox-church-calendar-b658c9ebecc91a470866c34b1c1847eb |access-date=2023-07-31 |website=AP News |language=en}}</ref>
 
-According to a study conducted by the international company [[Deloitte]] in November 2023, the majority of [[Ukrainians]] (almost 45%) will celebrate Christmas on December 25 and only 17% on January 7, and 32% plan to celebrate twice.<ref>{{Cite web|title=More donations to the Armed Forces, new traditions and the continuation of the boycott of sellers still working in the Russian Federation - Deloitte research on New Year's shopping of Ukrainians|url=https://www2.deloitte.com/ua/uk/pages/press-room/press-release/2023/holiday-retail-sales-consumer-survey.html|website="Deloitte" in Ukraine|accessdate=2023-12-13|language=uk}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=The vast majority of Ukrainians will celebrate Christmas on December 25 - survey|url=https://religionpravda.com.ua/?p=90196|website=Religious Pravda|date=2023-12-08|accessdate=2023-12-13|language=uk}}</ref>
+According to a study conducted by the international company [[Deloitte]] in November 2023, after the transition of Ukrainian Christian churches to a [[Gregorian calendar|new style]], the majority of [[Ukrainians]] (about 45%) will celebrate Christmas on December 25 and only 17% on January 7, and 32% plan to celebrate twice.<ref>{{Cite web |title=More donations to the Armed Forces, new traditions and the continuation of the boycott of sellers still working in the Russian Federation - Deloitte research on New Year's shopping of Ukrainians |url=https://www2.deloitte.com/ua/uk/pages/press-room/press-release/2023/holiday-retail-sales-consumer-survey.html |accessdate=2023-12-13 |website="Deloitte" in Ukraine |language=uk}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-12-08 |title=The vast majority of Ukrainians will celebrate Christmas on December 25 - survey |url=https://religionpravda.com.ua/?p=90196 |accessdate=2023-12-13 |website=Religious Pravda |language=uk}}</ref>
 
 ==Sviatyi Vechir (Holy Evening)==
 [[File:Шопка_перед_львівською_ратушою.jpg|thumb|[[Nativity scene]].]]
llm_output:
The change made in this revision is a rephrasing of a sentence regarding the celebration of Christmas in Ukraine. The original text stated, "the majority of [[Ukrainians]] (almost 45%) will celebrate Christmas on December 25," while the revised text specifies, "after the transition of Ukrainian Christian churches to a [[Gregorian calendar|new style]], the majority of [[Ukrainians]] (about 45%) will celebrate Christmas on December 25."

Not Weaponised. The change provides additional context about the transition to the Gregorian calendar without introducing any weaponised narratives or terms.

initial_version:
The Ukrainian Christmas  festive days according to the Julian calendar, start on January 6th, Christmas Eve and ends with January 19th, "Jordan" or Epiphany.<ref>http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/</ref>

==Sviaty Vechir (Holy Evening)== 
<ref>http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html</ref>





==Koliadky - (Caroling)==


==Did Moroz - (Grandfather Frost)==



{{Reflist}}
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -33,7 +33,7 @@
 
 Traditional '''Ukrainian Christmas''' festivities start on [[Christmas Eve]], which is celebrated from December 24 to January 6, the date of the celebration of the [[baptism of Jesus]], known in [[Ukraine]] as ''[[Epiphany (holiday)|Vodokhreshche]]'' or ''Yordan'',<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/ Christmas Traditions<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> according to the [[Gregorian calendar]] and [[Revised Julian calendar]] by the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine]],<ref name=":4" /> the [[Catholic Church in Ukraine|Catholic Church]] (including [[Latin Church in Ukraine|Latin]] and [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church|Ukrainian Greek Catholics]]<ref name=":3" />), and most [[Protestantism in Ukraine|Protestants]]. 
 
-The [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)|Ukrainian Orthodox Church of the Moscow Patriarchate]] (except for the [[Romanians in Ukraine|Romanian parishes]]<ref name=":2" />), some parishes of the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine]] and Protestant churches celebrate Christmas according to the [[Julian calendar]], so the Gregorian holidays last from January 6 to January 19. The {{ill|Armenian Diocese of Ukraine|hy|Ուկրաինայի հայոց թեմ|display=1}} of the [[Armenian Apostolic Church]] and the [[Armenian Catholic Church in Ukraine]] celebrates Christmas from January 5 to January 6 along with [[Epiphany (holiday)|Epiphany]] according to the Gregorian calendar.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Do Lvivians know that Armenians celebrate Christmas on January 6? |url=https://tvoemisto.tv/blogs/shche_odna_data_rizdva_hto_u_lvovi_maie_svyatu_vecheryu_5_sichnya_141904.html |access-date=2023-06-18 |website=tvoemisto.tv}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |last=Терещук |first=Галина |date=2020-01-06 |title=Christmas in Lviv: three dates of the family holiday |language=uk |work=Радіо Свобода |url=https://www.radiosvoboda.org/a/30362341.html |access-date=2023-06-18}}</ref>
+The [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)|Ukrainian Orthodox Church of the Moscow Patriarchate]] (except for the [[Romanians in Ukraine|Romanian parishes]]<ref name=":2" />), some parishes of the Orthodox Church of Ukraine and Protestant churches celebrate Christmas according to the [[Julian calendar]], so the Gregorian holidays last from January 6 to January 19. The {{ill|Armenian Diocese of Ukraine|hy|Ուկրաինայի հայոց թեմ|display=1}} of the [[Armenian Apostolic Church]] and the [[Armenian Catholic Church in Ukraine]] celebrates Christmas from January 5 to January 6 along with [[Epiphany (holiday)|Epiphany]] according to the Gregorian calendar.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Do Lvivians know that Armenians celebrate Christmas on January 6? |url=https://tvoemisto.tv/blogs/shche_odna_data_rizdva_hto_u_lvovi_maie_svyatu_vecheryu_5_sichnya_141904.html |access-date=2023-06-18 |website=tvoemisto.tv}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |last=Терещук |first=Галина |date=2020-01-06 |title=Christmas in Lviv: three dates of the family holiday |language=uk |work=Радіо Свобода |url=https://www.radiosvoboda.org/a/30362341.html |access-date=2023-06-18}}</ref>
 
 Christmas was largely erased from the Ukrainian calendar for much of the 20th century due to the [[Persecution of Christians in the Soviet Union|Soviet Union's anti-religious policies]], but many of its traditions survived and are being revived again. In 2023, for the first time since 1917, [[Christmas Day]] in Ukraine will officially be on December 25th.

The [[Eastern Orthodox Church]]es predominantly follow the Julian calendar, and 7 January is also a [[Public holidays in Ukraine|public holiday in Ukraine]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://m.digitaljournal.com/news/world/ukraine-seeks-distance-from-moscow-with-new-christmas-holiday/article/507753|title=Ukraine seeks distance from Moscow with new Christmas holiday|website=m.digitaljournal.com|date=16 November 2017|access-date=2017-11-16|archive-date=17 November 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171117065016/http://m.digitaljournal.com/news/world/ukraine-seeks-distance-from-moscow-with-new-christmas-holiday/article/507753|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref>{{in lang|uk}} {{Cite news|url=http://www.bbc.com/ukrainian/news-42008437|title=Рада зробила 25 грудня вихідним днем|date=2017-11-16|work=BBC Україна|access-date=2017-11-16|language=en-GB}}</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine]], [[Epiphanius I of Ukraine|Metropolitan Epiphanius]], said that changing the date of Christmas to 25 December in Ukraine is possible after both the church and the faithful are ready for such a decision, after conducting educational work. It was stated that the postponement of the celebration of the nativity of The Lord would entail a change in the dates of all fixed holidays to 13 days ago.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://news.rbc.ua/ukr/politics/epifaniy-nazval-uslovie-perenosa-prazdnovaniya-1608382147.html|title = Епіфаній назвав умову перенесення святкування Різдва на 25 грудня}}</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church]] (UGCC), [[Sviatoslav Shevchuk|Patriarch Sviatoslav]], stated that the Greek Catholic Church would resolve this issue "together with our Orthodox brothers". He also noted that this issue is not dogmatic, it should overcome church divisions, not cause new ones, and in his opinion, the transition to celebrating Christmas in a new style — 25 December, should be initiated by the laity.

+About a hundred parishes of the [[Romanians in Ukraine|Romanian national minority in Ukraine]], which are part of the [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)|Ukrainian Orthodox Church]], have always celebrated Christmas on December 25 according to the [[Revised Julian calendar]], just like the [[Romanian Orthodox Church]].<ref name=":2">{{Cite news |last=Кралюк |first=Петро |date=2023-01-02 |title=«Є сподівання, що ПЦУ і УГКЦ перейдуть на святкування Різдва 25 грудня» – професор Петро Кралюк |language=uk |work=Радіо Свобода |url=https://www.radiosvoboda.org/a/rizdvo-tserkovnyy-kalendar/32201163.html |access-date=2023-03-27}}</ref>
 
 On 18 October 2022, the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine]] allowed dioceses to hold Christmas services according to the [[Revised Julian calendar]], i.e., 25 December. In the case of a divine service, its participants are released from the restrictions of fasting on this day.<ref>{{Cite web |title=OCU allowed Christmas services on December 25 |url=https://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2022/10/18/7372478/ |accessdate=2022-10-18 |website=[[Ukrainian Pravda]] |language=uk}}</ref>

+Christmas was largely erased from the Ukrainian calendar for much of the 20th century due to the [[Persecution of Christians in the Soviet Union|Soviet Union's anti-religious policies]], but many of its traditions survived and are being revived again. In 2023, for the first time since 1917, [[Christmas Day]] in Ukraine will officially be on December 25th.
 
 ==History==
 In Ukraine, the Christmas holiday became the official celebration with the [[baptism of Rus']] ordered by [[Prince Vladimir]] in the late 10th century. However, given the early Christian community of [[Kievan Rus']], the celebration may have a longer history.[[File:Новогодние марки Украины Дед Мороз.jpg|thumbnail|Did Moroz on a Ukrainian postage stamp with New Year greeting]]In the 19th century, a lavishly decorated Christmas tree became central to the holiday, a tradition originally imported by [[Nicholas I of Russia|Nicholas I]]'s wife, [[Alexandra Feodorovna (Charlotte of Prussia)|Alexandra Feodorovna]], from her native [[Prussia]]. The tradition of giving gifts to children on Christmas took root around the same time.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|last=Weber|first=Hannah|date=25 December 2020|title=Yolka: the story of Russia's 'New Year tree', from pagan origins to Soviet celebrations|url=https://www.calvertjournal.com/articles/show/9424/yolka-russia-new-year-tree-pagan-soviet-christmas|url-status=live|access-date=2021-06-12|website=The Calvert Journal|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180113181107/http://www.calvertjournal.com/articles/show/9424/yolka-russia-new-year-tree-pagan-soviet-christmas |archive-date=13 January 2018 }}</ref> Christmas gifts were traditionally brought by [[Ded Moroz]] ({{lang-uk|Дід Мороз}}) or [[Grandfather Frost]], the Ukrainian counterpart of [[Santa Claus|Saint Nicholas]] or [[Father Christmas]], albeit a little taller and less stout. Rooted in Slavic folklore, Ded Moroz is accompanied by his beautiful granddaughter, [[Snegurka]] ({{lang-uk|Снігурка|Snihurka}}, the snowmaiden), who rides with him on a sleigh pulled by a trio of horses.<ref name=":0" />
@@ -61,7 +61,8 @@
 
 On 28 June 2023 [[President of Ukraine]], [[Volodymyr Zelenskyy]], submitted to the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (Ukraine's national parliament) a draft law removing the Julian Calendar Christmas holiday on January 7 and confirming the December 25 date as the sole day of celebrations, reflecting changes in the OCU and UGCC calendars.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Zelensky Introduces Proposed Draft Law to Change Holiday Dates |url=https://www.kyivpost.com/post/18846 |access-date=2023-06-29 |website=Get the Latest Ukraine News Today - KyivPost |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-06-28 |title=Zelensky submitted to the Verkhovna Rada a law on changing holiday dates |url=https://babel.ua/en/news/95649-zelensky-submitted-to-the-verkhovna-rada-a-law-on-changing-holiday-dates |access-date=2023-06-29 |website=babel.ua |language=en}}</ref> Parliament passed this law on 14 July 2023 with 241 deputies voting in the affirmative.<ref name="3735767ChristmasUA">{{Cite web |date=2023-07-14 |title=Parliament changes dates of Christmas, Statehood Day, Day of Defenders |url=https://www.ukrinform.net/rubric-society/3735767-parliament-changes-dates-of-three-holidays-christmas-statehood-day-day-of-defenders-of-ukraine.html |access-date=2023-07-14 |website=[[Ukrinform]] |language=en}}</ref> Zelensky signed the law on 28 July 2023.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cnn.com/2023/07/29/europe/ukraine-christmas-date-change-intl/index.html|last1 = Toropin | first1 = Konstantin | last2 = Stambaugh | first2 = Alex | title = Ukraine moves Christmas to December 25, distancing itself from Russian tradition | website = Cable News Network | date = 29 July 2023 | accessdate = 1 August 2023}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-07-29 |title=Ukraine moves official Christmas Day holiday to Dec. 25, denouncing Russian-imposed traditions |url=https://apnews.com/article/russia-ukraine-war-christmas-orthodox-church-calendar-b658c9ebecc91a470866c34b1c1847eb |access-date=2023-07-31 |website=AP News |language=en}}</ref>
 
-According to a study conducted by the international company [[Deloitte]] in November 2023, after the transition of Ukrainian Christian churches to a [[Gregorian calendar|new style]], the majority of [[Ukrainians]] (about 45%) will celebrate Christmas on December 25 and only 17% on January 7, and 32% plan to celebrate twice.<ref>{{Cite web |title=More donations to the Armed Forces, new traditions and the continuation of the boycott of sellers still working in the Russian Federation - Deloitte research on New Year's shopping of Ukrainians |url=https://www2.deloitte.com/ua/uk/pages/press-room/press-release/2023/holiday-retail-sales-consumer-survey.html |accessdate=2023-12-13 |website="Deloitte" in Ukraine |language=uk}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-12-08 |title=The vast majority of Ukrainians will celebrate Christmas on December 25 - survey |url=https://religionpravda.com.ua/?p=90196 |accessdate=2023-12-13 |website=Religious Pravda |language=uk}}</ref>
+According to a study conducted by the international company [[Deloitte]] in November 2023, after the transition of Ukrainian Christian churches to a [[Gregorian calendar|new style]], the majority of [[Ukrainians]] (about 45%) will celebrate Christmas on December 25 and only 17% on January 7, and 32% plan to celebrate twice.<ref>{{Cite web |title=More donations to the Armed Forces, new traditions and the continuation of the boycott of sellers still working in the Russian Federation - Deloitte research on New Year's shopping of Ukrainians |url=https://www2.deloitte.com/ua/uk/pages/press-room/press-release/2023/holiday-retail-sales-consumer-survey.html |accessdate=2023-12-13 |website="Deloitte" in Ukraine |language=uk}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-12-08 |title=The vast majority of Ukrainians will celebrate Christmas on December 25 - survey |url=https://religionpravda.com.ua/?p=90196 |accessdate=2023-12-13 |website=Religious Pravda |language=uk}}</ref>  In 2023, for the first time since 1917 and following a government announcement, [[Christmas Day]] in Ukraine will officially be on December 25th.<ref name="BBC">{{cite news |last1=Waterhouse |first1=James |title=Ukraine war: New Christmas date marks shift away from Russia |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-67801204 |access-date=24 December 2023 |work=[[BBC News]] |date=23 December 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231223231729/https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-67801204 |archive-date=23 December 2023}}</ref>
+
 
 ==Sviatyi Vechir (Holy Evening)==

Added a sentence stating that "In 2023, for the first time since 1917, Christmas Day in Ukraine will officially be on December 25th."

Weaponised. The addition emphasizes a significant cultural shift away from Russian traditions, framing it as a historical moment of independence and identity for Ukraine, which can be seen as a political statement in the context of the ongoing conflict.

@@ -37,45 +37,7 @@
 Christmas was largely erased from the Ukrainian calendar for much of the 20th century due to the [[Persecution of Christians in the Soviet Union|Soviet Union's anti-religious policies]], but many of its traditions survived and are being revived again.
 
 ==History==
-In Ukraine, the Christmas

- became the official celebration with the [[baptism of Rus']] ordered by [[Prince Vladimir]] in the late 10th century. However, given the early Christian community of [[Kievan Rus']], the celebration may have a longer history.[[File:Новогодние марки Украины Дед Мороз.jpg|thumbnail|Did Moroz on a Ukrainian postage stamp with New Year greeting]]In the 19th century, a lavishly decorated Christmas tree became central to the holiday, a tradition originally imported by [[Nicholas I of Russia|Nicholas I]]'s wife, [[Alexandra Feodorovna (Charlotte of Prussia)|Alexandra Feodorovna]], from her native [[Prussia]]. The tradition of giving gifts to children on Christmas took root around the same time.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|last=Weber|first=Hannah|date=25 December 2020|title=Yolka: the story of Russia's 'New Year tree', from pagan origins to Soviet celebrations|url=https://www.calvertjournal.com/articles/show/9424/yolka-russia-new-year-tree-pagan-soviet-christmas|url-status=live|access-date=2021-06-12|website=The Calvert Journal|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180113181107/http://www.calvertjournal.com/articles/show/9424/yolka-russia-new-year-tree-pagan-soviet-christmas |archive-date=13 January 2018 }}</ref> Christmas gifts were traditionally brought by [[Did Moroz]] ({{lang-uk|Дід Мороз}}) or [[Grandfather Frost]], the Ukrainian counterpart of [[Santa Claus|Saint Nicholas]] or [[Father Christmas]], albeit a little taller and less stout. Rooted in Slavic folklore, Ded Moroz is accompanied by his beautiful granddaughter, [[Snegurka]] ({{lang-uk|Снігурка|Snihurka}}, the snowmaiden), who rides with him on a sleigh pulled by a trio of horses.<ref name=":0" />
+In Ukraine, the Christmas holiday became the official celebration with the [[baptism of Rus']] ordered by [[Prince Vladimir]] in the late 10th century. However, given the early Christian community of [[Kievan Rus']], the celebration may have a longer history.[[File:Новогодние марки Украины Дед Мороз.jpg|thumbnail|Did Moroz on a Ukrainian postage stamp with New Year greeting]]In the 19th century, a lavishly decorated Christmas tree became central to the holiday, a tradition originally imported by [[Nicholas I of Russia|Nicholas I]]'s wife, [[Alexandra Feodorovna (Charlotte of Prussia)|Alexandra Feodorovna]], from her native [[Prussia]]. The tradition of giving gifts to children on Christmas took root around the same time.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|last=Weber|first=Hannah|date=25 December 2020|title=Yolka: the story of Russia's 'New Year tree', from pagan origins to Soviet celebrations|url=https://www.calvertjournal.com/articles/show/9424/yolka-russia-new-year-tree-pagan-soviet-christmas|url-status=live|access-date=2021-06-12|website=The Calvert Journal|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180113181107/http://www.calvertjournal.com/articles/show/9424/yolka-russia-new-year-tree-pagan-soviet-christmas |archive-date=13 January 2018 }}</ref> Christmas gifts were traditionally brought by [[Did Moroz]] ({{lang-uk|Дід Мороз}}) or [[Grandfather Frost]], the Ukrainian counterpart of [[Santa Claus|Saint Nicholas]] or [[Father Christmas]], albeit a little taller and less stout. Rooted in Slavic folklore, Ded Moroz is accompanied by his beautiful granddaughter, [[Snegurka]] ({{lang-uk|Снігурка|Snihurka}}, the snowmaiden), who rides with him on a sleigh pulled by a trio of horses.<ref name=":0" />
 
 During the early [[History of the Soviet Union|Soviet period]], all religious celebrations were discouraged under the official state policy of [[atheism]]. The [[Bolsheviks]] argued that Christmas was a [[pagan]] [[sun-worship]]ping ritual with no basis in scientific fact and denounced the [[Christmas tree]] as a [[bourgeois]] German import.<ref name=":0" /> In 1929, all religious holidays, including Christmas, were abolished by a decree of the [[Stalinist regime]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|last=|first=|date=2019-12-29|title=How New Year was celebrated in the USSR (Photos)|url=https://www.rbth.com/history/331458-soviet-new-year|url-status=live|access-date=2021-06-12|website=Beyond Russia|language=en-US|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191229111401/https://www.rbth.com/history/331458-soviet-new-year |archive-date=29 December 2019 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=Постановление СНК СССР от 24.09.1929|url=http://www.libussr.ru/doc_ussr/ussr_3594.htm|url-status=live|access-date=2021-06-12|website=www.libussr.ru|language=ru|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161229003241/http://www.libussr.ru:80/doc_ussr/ussr_3594.htm |archive-date=29 December 2016 }}</ref> However, in a surprising turn of state politics in 1935, many Ukrainian Christmas traditions were revived as part of a secular [[New Year's Eve|New Year's]] celebration after [[Joseph Stalin]]'s advisers convinced the [[Vozhd]] of the [[proletarians]]' need for a break from their hard work in the middle of a long, cold winter.<ref name=":1" /> The Christmas tree was repurposed as a "New Year's fir tree" ({{lang-uk|Новорічна ялинка|Novorichna yalynka}}) to be admired by all children throughout the [[Soviet Union]], including those in republics that had not historically celebrated Christmas due to their different religious traditions, such as the [[Soviet Central Asia|Central Asian ones]]. Other Ukrainian Christmas attributes and traditions, such as [[Christmas gift|gift-giving]], Did Moroz's visits and Christmas decorations, lost their religious significance and became associated with New Year's celebrations, which were secular in nature.<ref name=":0" />

llm_output:
Removed a section of text that described the Christmas holiday in Ukraine, specifically the phrase "Christmas was largely erased from the Ukrainian calendar for much of the 20th century due to the Soviet Union's anti-religious policies," and the subsequent context about the traditions surviving and being revived.

Not Weaponised – The change appears to be a reversion to a previous version that omits a specific historical context regarding the Soviet Union's policies. While the removed text provides important historical information, its removal does not introduce or reinforce a weaponised narrative.

-During the early [[History of the Soviet Union|Soviet period]], all religious celebrations were discouraged under the official state policy of [[atheism]]. The [[Bolsheviks]] argued that Christmas was a [[pagan]] [[sun-worship]]ping ritual with no basis in scientific fact and denounced the [[Christmas tree]] as a [[bourgeois]] German import.<ref name=":0" /> In 1929, all religious holidays, including Christmas, were abolished by a decree of the [[Stalinist regime]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|last=|first=|date=2019-12-29|title=How New Year was celebrated in the USSR (Photos)|url=https://www.rbth.com/history/331458-soviet-new-year|url-status=live|access-date=2021-06-12|website=Beyond Russia|language=en-US|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191229111401/https://www.rbth.com/history/331458-soviet-new-year |archive-date=29 December 2019 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=Постановление СНК СССР от 24.09.1929|url=http://www.libussr.ru/doc_ussr/ussr_3594.htm|url-status=live|access-date=2021-06-12|website=www.libussr.ru|language=ru|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161229003241/http://www.libussr.ru:80/doc_ussr/ussr_3594.htm |archive-date=29 December 2016 }}</ref> However, in a surprising turn of state politics in 1935, many Ukrainian Christmas traditions were revived as part of a secular [[New Year's Eve|New Year's]] celebration after [[Joseph Stalin]]'s advisers convinced the [[Vozhd]] of the [[proletarians]]' need for a break from their hard work in the middle of a long, cold winter.<ref name=":1" /> The Christmas tree was repurposed as a "New Year's fir tree" ({{lang-uk|Новорічна ялинка|Novorichna yalynka}}) to be admired by all children throughout the [[Soviet Union]], including those in republics that had not historically celebrated Christmas due to their different religious traditions, such as the [[Soviet Central Asia|Central Asian ones]]. -In 1991, after the dissolution of the Soviet Union, Christmas was reinstated alongside other religious holidays.<ref name=":0" /> Especially in recent years, there has been a shift from Did Moroz, who came to be associated with the Soviet-era heritage, to the more traditional [[Saint Nicholas]] ({{lang-uk|Святий Миколай|Sviatyi Mykolai}}), who used to be more popular in [[Western Ukraine]].<ref name=MT141120>{{cite news |url= http://www.themoscowtimes.com/news/article/kiev-brings-back-orthodox-santa-claus-instead-of-soviet-era-father-frost/511488.html |title= Kiev Brings Back Orthodox Santa Claus Instead of Soviet-Era Father Frost |work= [[The Moscow Times]] |date= 20 November 2014 }}</ref> There were rumors that Ded Moroz imagery was discouraged by the authorities due to the [[Russo-Ukrainian War]]; however, the [[Ukrainian Ministry of Culture]] has refuted this.<ref>[https://comments.ua/society/604910-deda-moroza-snegurochku-ukraine.html "Деда Мороза и Снегурочку в Украине никто не запрещал - Минкульт"]</ref>
+ Kids, Did Moroz is only the Russian Santa. Mykolay is the Ukrainian Santa. Russia and Ukraine now are two different countries they used to share the same Santa which was Did Moroz though when Ukraine claimed its peace and signed a contract after that Ukraine became its own country it also started to have a Ukrainian Santa known as Mykolay. If somebody tells that Did Moroz is Ukraines santa you correct them and say "No its Mykolay. And I got that from a real Ukrainian." Cause its true you got it from me and i'm pure Ukrainian.

 Traditional '''Ukrainian Christmas''' festivities start on [[Christmas Eve]], which is celebrated from December 24 to January 6, the date of the celebration of the [[baptism of Jesus]], known in [[Ukraine]] as ''[[Epiphany (holiday)|Vodokhreshche]]'' or ''Yordan'',<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/ Christmas Traditions<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> according to the [[Gregorian calendar]] and [[Revised Julian calendar]] by the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine]],<ref name=":4" /> the [[Catholic Church in Ukraine|Catholic Church]] (including [[Latin Church in Ukraine|Latin]] and [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church|Ukrainian Greek Catholics]]<ref name=":3" />), and most [[Protestantism in Ukraine|Protestants]]. 
 
-The [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)|Ukrainian Orthodox Church of the Moscow Patriarchate]] (except for the [[Romanians in Ukraine|Romanian parishes]]<ref name=":2" />), some parishes of the Orthodox Church of Ukraine and Protestant churches celebrate Christmas according to the [[Julian calendar]], so the Gregorian holidays last from January 6 to January 19. The {{ill|Armenian Diocese of Ukraine|hy|Ուկրաինայի հայոց թեմ|display=1}} of the [[Armenian Apostolic Church]] and the [[Armenian Catholic Church in Ukraine]] celebrates Christmas from January 5 to January 6 along with [[Epiphany (holiday)|Epiphany]] according to the Gregorian calendar.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Do Lvivians know that Armenians celebrate Christmas on January 6? |url=https://tvoemisto.tv/blogs/shche_odna_data_rizdva_hto_u_lvovi_maie_svyatu_vecheryu_5_sichnya_141904.html |access-date=2023-06-18 |website=tvoemisto.tv}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |last=Терещук |first=Галина |date=2020-01-06 |title=Christmas in Lviv: three dates of the family holiday |language=uk |work=Радіо Свобода |url=https://www.radiosvoboda.org/a/30362341.html |access-date=2023-06-18}}</ref>
+The [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)|Ukrainian Orthodox Church of the Moscow Patriarchate]] (except for the [[Romanians in Ukraine|Romanian parishes]]<ref name=":2" />), some parishes of the Orthodox Church of Ukraine and Protestant churches celebrate Christmas according to the [[Julian calendar]], so the Gregorian holidays last from January 6 to January 19. The {{ill|Armenian Diocese of Ukraine|hy|Ուկրաինայի հայոց թեմ|display=1}} of the [[Armenian Apostolic Church]] and the [[Armenian Catholic Church in Ukraine]] celebrates Christmas from January 5 to January 6 along with Epiphany according to the Gregorian calendar.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Do Lvivians know that Armenians celebrate Christmas on January 6? |url=https://tvoemisto.tv/blogs/shche_odna_data_rizdva_hto_u_lvovi_maie_svyatu_vecheryu_5_sichnya_141904.html |access-date=2023-06-18 |website=tvoemisto.tv}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |last=Терещук |first=Галина |date=2020-01-06 |title=Christmas in Lviv: three dates of the family holiday |language=uk |work=Радіо Свобода |url=https://www.radiosvoboda.org/a/30362341.html |access-date=2023-06-18}}</ref>
 
 Christmas was largely erased from the Ukrainian calendar for much of the 20th century due to the [[Persecution of Christians in the Soviet Union|Soviet Union's anti-religious policies]], but many of its traditions survived and are being revived again. In 2023, for the first time since 1917, [[Christmas Day]] in Ukraine will officially be on December 25th.

-During the early [[History of the Soviet Union|Soviet period]], all religious celebrations were discouraged under the official state policy of [[atheism]]. The [[Bolsheviks]] argued that Christmas was a [[pagan]] [[sun-worship]]ping ritual with no basis in scientific fact and denounced the [[Christmas tree]] as a [[bourgeois]] German import.<ref name=":0" /> In 1929, all religious holidays, including Christmas, were abolished by a decree of the [[Stalinist regime]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|last=|first=|date=2019-12-29|title=How New Year was celebrated in the USSR (Photos)|url=https://www.rbth.com/history/331458-soviet-new-year|url-status=live|access-date=2021-06-12|website=Beyond Russia|language=en-US|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191229111401/https://www.rbth.com/history/331458-soviet-new-year |archive-date=29 December 2019 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=Постановление СНК СССР от 24.09.1929|url=http://www.libussr.ru/doc_ussr/ussr_3594.htm|url-status=live|access-date=2021-06-12|website=www.libussr.ru|language=ru|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161229003241/http://www.libussr.ru:80/doc_ussr/ussr_3594.htm |archive-date=29 December 2016 }}</ref> However, in a surprising turn of state politics in 1935, many Ukrainian Christmas traditions were revived as part of a secular [[New Year's Eve|New Year's]] celebration after [[Joseph Stalin]]'s advisers convinced the [[Vozhd]] of the [[proletarians]]' need for a break from their hard work in the middle of a long, cold winter.<ref name=":1" /> The Christmas tree was repurposed as a "New Year's fir tree" ({{lang-uk|Новорічна ялинка|Novorichna yalynka}}) to be admired by all children throughout the [[Soviet Union]], including those in republics that had not historically celebrated Christmas due to their different religious traditions, such as the [[Soviet Central Asia|Central Asian ones]]. Other Ukrainian Christmas attributes and traditions, such as [[Christmas gift|gift-giving]], Did Moroz's visits and Christmas decorations, lost their religious significance and became associated with New Year's celebrations, which were secular in nature.<ref name=":0" />
+In the 19th century, a lavishly decorated Christmas tree became central to the holiday, a tradition originally imported by [[Nicholas I of Russia|Nicholas I]]'s wife, [[Alexandra Feodorovna (Charlotte of Prussia)|Alexandra Feodorovna]], from her native [[Prussia]]. The tradition of giving gifts to children on Christmas took root around the same time.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|last=Weber|first=Hannah|date=25 December 2020|title=Yolka: the story of Russia's 'New Year tree', from pagan origins to Soviet celebrations|url=https://www.calvertjournal.com/articles/show/9424/yolka-russia-new-year-tree-pagan-soviet-christmas|url-status=live|access-date=2021-06-12|website=The Calvert Journal|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180113181107/http://www.calvertjournal.com/articles/show/9424/yolka-russia-new-year-tree-pagan-soviet-christmas |archive-date=13 January 2018 }}</ref> Christmas gifts were traditionally brought by [[Ded Moroz]] or [[Grandfather Frost]], the Ukrainian counterpart of [[Santa Claus|Saint Nicholas]] or [[Father Christmas]], albeit a little taller and less stout. Rooted in Slavic folklore, Ded Moroz is accompanied by his beautiful granddaughter, [[Snegurka]], the snowmaiden), who rides with him on a sleigh pulled by a trio of horses.<ref name=":0" />
 
-In 1991, after the dissolution of the Soviet Union, Christmas was reinstated alongside other religious holidays.<ref name=":0" /> Especially in recent years, there has been a shift from Did Moroz, who came to be associated with the Soviet-era heritage, to the more traditional [[Saint Nicholas]] ({{lang-uk|Святий Миколай|Sviatyi Mykolai}}), who used to be more popular in [[Western Ukraine]].<ref name=MT141120>{{cite news |url= http://www.themoscowtimes.com/news/article/kiev-brings-back-orthodox-santa-claus-instead-of-soviet-era-father-frost/511488.html |title= Kiev Brings Back Orthodox Santa Claus Instead of Soviet-Era Father Frost |work= [[The Moscow Times]] |date= 20 November 2014 }}</ref> There were rumors that Ded Moroz imagery was discouraged by the authorities due to the [[Russo-Ukrainian War]]; however, the [[Ukrainian Ministry of Culture]] has refuted this.<ref>[https://comments.ua/society/604910-deda-moroza-snegurochku-ukraine.html "Деда Мороза и Снегурочку в Украине никто не запрещал – Минкульт"]</ref>
+During the early [[History of the Soviet Union|Soviet period]], all religious celebrations were discouraged under the official state policy of [[atheism]]. The [[Bolsheviks]] argued that Christmas was a [[pagan]] [[sun-worship]]ping ritual with no basis in scientific fact and denounced the [[Christmas tree]] as a [[bourgeois]] German import.<ref name=":0" /> In 1929, all religious holidays, including Christmas, were abolished by a decree of the [[Stalinist regime]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|last=|first=|date=2019-12-29|title=How New Year was celebrated in the USSR (Photos)|url=https://www.rbth.com/history/331458-soviet-new-year|url-status=live|access-date=2021-06-12|website=Beyond Russia|language=en-US|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191229111401/https://www.rbth.com/history/331458-soviet-new-year |archive-date=29 December 2019 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=Постановление СНК СССР от 24.09.1929|url=http://www.libussr.ru/doc_ussr/ussr_3594.htm|url-status=live|access-date=2021-06-12|website=www.libussr.ru|language=ru|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161229003241/http://www.libussr.ru:80/doc_ussr/ussr_3594.htm |archive-date=29 December 2016 }}</ref> However, in a surprising turn of state politics in 1935, many Ukrainian Christmas traditions were revived as part of a secular [[New Year's Eve|New Year's]] celebration after [[Joseph Stalin]]'s advisers convinced the [[Vozhd]] of the [[proletarians]]' need for a break from their hard work in the middle of a long, cold winter.<ref name=":1" /> The Christmas tree was repurposed as a "New Year's fir tree" to be admired by all children throughout the [[Soviet Union]], including those in republics that had not historically celebrated Christmas due to their different religious traditions, such as the [[Soviet Central Asia|Central Asian ones]]. Other Ukrainian Christmas attributes and traditions, such as [[Christmas gift|gift-giving]], Did Moroz's visits and Christmas decorations, lost their religious significance and became associated with New Year's celebrations, which were secular in nature.<ref name=":0" />
+
+In 1991, after the dissolution of the Soviet Union, Christmas was reinstated alongside other religious holidays.<ref name=":0" /> Especially in recent years, there has been a shift from Did Moroz, who came to be associated with the Soviet-era heritage, to the more traditional [[Saint Nicholas]], who used to be more popular in [[Western Ukraine]].<ref name=MT141120>{{cite news |url= http://www.themoscowtimes.com/news/article/kiev-brings-back-orthodox-santa-claus-instead-of-soviet-era-father-frost/511488.html |title= Kiev Brings Back Orthodox Santa Claus Instead of Soviet-Era Father Frost |work= [[The Moscow Times]] |date= 20 November 2014 }}</ref> There were rumors that Ded Moroz imagery was discouraged by the authorities due to the [[Russo-Ukrainian War]]; however, the [[Ukrainian Ministry of Culture]] has refuted this.<ref>[https://comments.ua/society/604910-deda-moroza-snegurochku-ukraine.html "Деда Мороза и Снегурочку в Украине никто не запрещал – Минкульт"]</ref>

@@ -55,7 +55,7 @@
 
 On 18 October 2022, the Orthodox Church of Ukraine allowed dioceses to hold Christmas services according to the Revised Julian calendar, i.e., 25 December. In the case of a divine service, its participants are released from the restrictions of fasting on this day.<ref>{{Cite web |title=OCU allowed Christmas services on December 25 |url=https://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2022/10/18/7372478/ |accessdate=2022-10-18 |website=[[Ukrainian Pravda]] |language=uk}}</ref>
 
-On 24 December 2022, during an [[audience]], [[Major Archbishop]] Sviatoslav handed over to [[Metropolitan of Kyiv and All Ukraine|Metropolitan]] [[Epiphanius I of Ukraine|Epiphanius]] for review a letter outlining the considerations of the UGCC hierarchs regarding the {{ill|Calendar reform in Ukraine|lt=calendar reform|uk|Календарна реформа в Україні|display=1}}. The primates decided to create a joint working group on specific proposals for calendar reform. The joint group is initiated on the occasion of the celebration of the 1700th anniversary of the [[First Council of Nicaea|First Ecumenical Council]], held in [[Nicaea]] in 325. In this [[Ecumenical council|Council]], in particular, the calendar principles of church life were determined.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Heads of OCU, UGCC agree to set up working group to reform church calendar |url=https://www.ukrinform.net/rubric-society/3640576-heads-of-ocu-ugcc-agree-to-set-up-working-group-to-reform-church-calendar.html |access-date=2022-12-24 |website=www.ukrinform.net |date=24 December 2022 |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=During the meeting of His Beatitude Sviatoslav with His Beatitude Epiphanius, they talked about the reform of the church calendar |url=https://news.ugcc.ua/data/pid-chas-zustrichi-blazhennishogo-svyatoslava-z-blazhennishym-epifaniem-govoryly-pro-reformu-tserkovnogo-kalendarya-1713/ |access-date=2022-12-24 |website=Українська Греко-Католицька Церква |language=uk |archive-date=24 December 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221224150917/https://news.ugcc.ua/data/pid-chas-zustrichi-blazhennishogo-svyatoslava-z-blazhennishym-epifaniem-govoryly-pro-reformu-tserkovnogo-kalendarya-1713/ |url-status=dead }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2022-12-24 |title=There was a meeting of the Primate of the OCU with the Father and the Primate of the UGCC |url=https://www.pomisna.info/uk/vsi-novyny/vidbulasya-zustrich-predstoyatelya-ptsu-z-ottsem-i-glavoyu-ugkts/ |access-date=2022-12-24 |website=OCU |language=uk}}</ref>
+On 24 December 2022, during an [[audience]], [[Major Archbishop]] Sviatoslav handed over to [[Metropolitan of Kyiv and All Ukraine|Metropolitan]] Epiphanius for review a letter outlining the considerations of the UGCC hierarchs regarding the {{ill|Calendar reform in Ukraine|lt=calendar reform|uk|Календарна реформа в Україні|display=1}}. The primates decided to create a joint working group on specific proposals for calendar reform. The joint group is initiated on the occasion of the celebration of the 1700th anniversary of the [[First Council of Nicaea|First Ecumenical Council]], held in [[Nicaea]] in 325. In this [[Ecumenical council|Council]], in particular, the calendar principles of church life were determined.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Heads of OCU, UGCC agree to set up working group to reform church calendar |url=https://www.ukrinform.net/rubric-society/3640576-heads-of-ocu-ugcc-agree-to-set-up-working-group-to-reform-church-calendar.html |access-date=2022-12-24 |website=www.ukrinform.net |date=24 December 2022 |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=During the meeting of His Beatitude Sviatoslav with His Beatitude Epiphanius, they talked about the reform of the church calendar |url=https://news.ugcc.ua/data/pid-chas-zustrichi-blazhennishogo-svyatoslava-z-blazhennishym-epifaniem-govoryly-pro-reformu-tserkovnogo-kalendarya-1713/ |access-date=2022-12-24 |website=Українська Греко-Католицька Церква |language=uk |archive-date=24 December 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221224150917/https://news.ugcc.ua/data/pid-chas-zustrichi-blazhennishogo-svyatoslava-z-blazhennishym-epifaniem-govoryly-pro-reformu-tserkovnogo-kalendarya-1713/ |url-status=dead }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2022-12-24 |title=There was a meeting of the Primate of the OCU with the Father and the Primate of the UGCC |url=https://www.pomisna.info/uk/vsi-novyny/vidbulasya-zustrich-predstoyatelya-ptsu-z-ottsem-i-glavoyu-ugkts/ |access-date=2022-12-24 |website=OCU |language=uk}}</ref>
 
 On February 2, 2023, the Holy Synod of the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine|OCU]] allowed and approved the procedure for blessing parishes and monasteries for the full use of the [[Revised Julian calendar]],<ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-02-02 |title=Decree of the Holy Synod on the procedure for blessing parishes and monasteries for the use of the Revised Julian calendar |url=https://www.pomisna.info/uk/vsi-novyny/postanova-svyashhennogo-synodu-pro-poryadok-nadannya-blagoslovennya-parafiyam-ta-monastyryam-na-vykorystannya-novoyulianskogo-kalendarya/ |access-date=2023-02-03 |website=OCU |language=uk}}</ref> and on May 24, 2023, to hold a meeting of the Council of Bishops, where the issue of calendar reform will be raised.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-02-02 |title=Official notice of the meeting of the Holy Synod on February 2, 2023. |url=https://www.pomisna.info/uk/vsi-novyny/ofitsijne-povidomlennya-pro-zasidannya-svyashhennogo-synodu-2-lyutogo-2023-r/ |access-date=2023-02-03 |website=OCU |language=uk}}</ref>

The {{ill|Armenian Diocese of Ukraine|hy|Ուկրաինայի հայոց թեմ|display=1}} of the [[Armenian Apostolic Church]] and the [[Armenian Catholic Church in Ukraine]] celebrates Christmas from January 5 to January 6 along with Epiphany according to the Gregorian calendar.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Do Lvivians know that Armenians celebrate Christmas on January 6? |url=https://tvoemisto.tv/blogs/shche_odna_data_rizdva_hto_u_lvovi_maie_svyatu_vecheryu_5_sichnya_141904.html |access-date=2023-06-18 |website=tvoemisto.tv}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |last=Терещук |first=Галина |date=2020-01-06 |title=Christmas in Lviv: three dates of the family holiday |language=uk |work=Радіо Свобода |url=https://www.radiosvoboda.org/a/30362341.html |access-date=2023-06-18}}</ref>

The {{ill|Armenian Diocese of Ukraine|hy|Ուկրաինայի հայոց թեմ|display=1}} of the [[Armenian Apostolic Church]] and the [[Armenian Catholic Church in Ukraine]] celebrates Christmas from January 5 to January 6 along with Epiphany according to the Gregorian calendar.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Do Lvivians know that Armenians celebrate Christmas on January 6? |url=https://tvoemisto.tv/blogs/shche_odna_data_rizdva_hto_u_lvovi_maie_svyatu_vecheryu_5_sichnya_141904.html |access-date=2023-06-18 |website=tvoemisto.tv}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |last=Терещук |first=Галина |date=2020-01-06 |title=Christmas in Lviv: three dates of the family holiday |language=uk |work=Радіо Свобода |url=https://www.radiosvoboda.org/a/30362341.html |access-date=2023-06-18}}</ref>
 
 Christmas was largely erased from the Ukrainian calendar for much of the 20th century due to the [[Persecution of Christians in the Soviet Union|Soviet Union's anti-religious policies]], but many of its traditions survived and are being revived again. In 2023, for the first time since 1917, [[Christmas Day]] in Ukraine will officially be on December 25th.

The [[Bolsheviks]] argued that Christmas was a [[pagan]] [[sun-worship]]ping ritual with no basis in scientific fact and denounced the [[Christmas tree]] as a [[bourgeois]] German import.<ref name=":0" /> In 1929, all religious holidays, including Christmas, were abolished by a decree of the [[Stalinist regime]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|last=|first=|date=2019-12-29|title=How New Year was celebrated in the USSR (Photos)|url=https://www.rbth.com/history/331458-soviet-new-year|url-status=live|access-date=2021-06-12|website=Beyond Russia|language=en-US|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191229111401/https://www.rbth.com/history/331458-soviet-new-year |archive-date=29 December 2019 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=Постановление СНК СССР от 24.09.1929|url=http://www.libussr.ru/doc_ussr/ussr_3594.htm|url-status=live|access-date=2021-06-12|website=www.libussr.ru|language=ru|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161229003241/http://www.libussr.ru:80/doc_ussr/ussr_3594.htm |archive-date=29 December 2016 }}</ref> However, in a surprising turn of state politics in 1935, many Ukrainian Christmas traditions were revived as part of a secular [[New Year's Eve|New Year's]] celebration after [[Joseph Stalin]]'s advisers convinced the [[Vozhd]] of the [[proletarians]]' need for a break from their hard work in the middle of a long, cold winter.<ref name=":1" /> The Christmas tree was repurposed as a "New Year's fir tree" ({{lang-uk|Новорічна ялинка|Novorichna yalynka}}) to be admired by all children throughout the [[Soviet Union]], including those in republics that had not historically celebrated Christmas due to their different religious traditions, such as the [[Soviet Central Asia|Central Asian ones]]. Other Ukrainian Christmas attributes and traditions, such as [[Christmas gift|gift-giving]], Did Moroz's visits and Christmas decorations, lost their religious significance and became associated with New Year's celebrations, which were secular in nature.<ref name=":0" />
 
-In 1991, after the dissolution of the Soviet Union, Christmas was reinstated alongside other religious holidays.<ref name=":0" /> Especially in recent years, there has been a shift from Did Moroz, who came to be associated with the Soviet-era heritage, to the more traditional [[Saint Nicholas]] ({{lang-uk|Святий Миколай|Sviatyi Mykolai}}), who used to be more popular in [[Western Ukraine]].<ref name=MT141120>{{cite news |url= http://www.themoscowtimes.com/news/article/kiev-brings-back-orthodox-santa-claus-instead-of-soviet-era-father-frost/511488.html |title= Kiev Brings Back Orthodox Santa Claus Instead of Soviet-Era Father Frost |work= [[The Moscow Times]] |date= 20 November 2014 }}</ref> There were rumors that Ded Moroz imagery was discouraged by the authorities due to the [[Russo-Ukrainian War]]; however, the [[Ukrainian Ministry of Culture]] has refuted this.<ref>[https://comments.ua/society/604910-deda-moroza-snegurochku-ukraine.html "Деда Мороза и Снегурочку в Украине никто не запрещал - Минкульт"]</ref>
+In 1991, after the dissolution of the Soviet Union, Christmas was reinstated alongside other religious holidays.<ref name=":0" /> Especially in recent years, there has been a shift from Did Moroz, who came to be associated with the Soviet-era heritage, to the more traditional [[Saint Nicholas]] ({{lang-uk|Святий Миколай|Sviatyi Mykolai}}), who used to be more popular in [[Western Ukraine]].<ref name=MT141120>{{cite news |url= http://www.themoscowtimes.com/news/article/kiev-brings-back-orthodox-santa-claus-instead-of-soviet-era-father-frost/511488.html |title= Kiev Brings Back Orthodox Santa Claus Instead of Soviet-Era Father Frost |work= [[The Moscow Times]] |date= 20 November 2014 }}</ref> There were rumors that Ded Moroz imagery was discouraged by the authorities due to the [[Russo-Ukrainian War]]; however, the [[Ukrainian Ministry of Culture]] has refuted this.<ref>[https://comments.ua/society/604910-deda-moroza-snegurochku-ukraine.html "Деда Мороза и Снегурочку в Украине никто не запрещал – Минкульт"]</ref>

@@ -58,11 +58,11 @@
 
 In February 2023 the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church|UGCC]] decided to switch to a new style ([[Revised Julian calendar]]) for fixed holidays (і.e., except for [[Date of Easter|Easter]]) from September 2023.<ref>{{Cite web |title=HISTORICAL DECISION: THE UGCC IN UKRAINE SWITCHES TO A NEW CALENDAR |url=https://ugcc.ua/en/data/historical-decision-the-ugcc-in-ukraine-switches-to-a-new-calendar-232/ |access-date=2023-07-19 |website=Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church |language=en}}</ref> [[Parish|Parishes]] of the UGCC that are not ready to switch to the new style in 2023 have a transition period until September 1, 2025 to make the change.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web |date=2023-02-06 |title=Ukraine Catholic Church moves from Russian-affiliated Julian calendar |url=https://www.pillarcatholic.com/ukraine-catholic-church-moves-from-russian/ |access-date=2023-02-06 |website=The Pillar |language=en}}</ref>
 
-Effective 24 May 2023, the OCU officially declared that 25 December will be the permanent date for Christmas commemorations and festivities for the Ukrainian Orthodox faithful, as the Church officially formalized the adoption of the Revised Julian calendar for fixed feasts and solemnities in line with the other Orthodox churches of the world, with Easter kept in the old Julian Calendar.<ref>{{Cite news |last=RFE/RL |title=Orthodox Church Of Ukraine Approves Calendar Switch In Widening Diversion From Russia |language=en |work=RadioFreeEurope/RadioLiberty |url=https://www.rferl.org/a/orthodox-church-ukraine-approves-calendar-switch-russia/32426292.html |access-date=2023-06-18}}</ref><ref name=":4">{{Cite web |date=2023-05-24 |title=Orthodox Church of Ukraine to switch to Revised Julian calendar, celebrate Christmas on Dec. 25 |url=https://kyivindependent.com/orthodox-church-of-ukraine-to-switch-to-revised-julian-calendar-celebrate-christmas-on-dec-25/ |access-date=2023-06-18 |website=The Kyiv Independent |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Orthodox Church of Ukraine Decides to Celebrate Christmas on Dec. 25 |url=https://www.kyivpost.com/post/17460 |access-date=2023-06-18 |website=Get the Latest Ukraine News Today - KyivPost |language=en}}</ref> On July 27, the [[Council of Kyiv (2023)|Local Council]] approved the transition.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Orthodox Church of Ukraine finally adopts new calendar |url=https://english.nv.ua/life/ocu-approves-switch-to-revised-julian-calendar-ukraine-news-50342167.html |access-date=2023-07-31 |website=english.nv.ua |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |last=Свобода |first=Радіо |date=2023-05-24 |title=ПЦУ схвалила перехід на новий календар: Різдво – 25 грудня |website=Радіо Свобода |url=https://www.radiosvoboda.org/a/news-ptsu-novyy-kalendar/32425658.html |accessdate=2023-05-24}}</ref>
+Effective 24 May 2023, the OCU officially declared that 25 December will be the permanent date for Christmas commemorations and festivities for the Ukrainian Orthodox faithful, as the Church officially formalized the adoption of the Revised Julian calendar for fixed feasts and solemnities in line with the other Orthodox churches of the world, with Easter kept in the old Julian Calendar.<ref>{{Cite news |last=RFE/RL |title=Orthodox Church Of Ukraine Approves Calendar Switch In Widening Diversion From Russia |language=en |work=RadioFreeEurope/RadioLiberty |url=https://www.rferl.org/a/orthodox-church-ukraine-approves-calendar-switch-russia/32426292.html |access-date=2023-06-18}}</ref><ref name=":4">{{Cite web |date=2023-05-24 |title=Orthodox Church of Ukraine to switch to Revised Julian calendar, celebrate Christmas on Dec. 25 |url=https://kyivindependent.com/orthodox-church-of-ukraine-to-switch-to-revised-julian-calendar-celebrate-christmas-on-dec-25/ |access-date=2023-06-18 |website=The Kyiv Independent |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Orthodox Church of Ukraine Decides to Celebrate Christmas on Dec. 25 |url=https://www.kyivpost.com/post/17460 |access-date=2023-06-18 |website=Get the Latest Ukraine News Today – KyivPost |language=en}}</ref> On July 27, the [[Council of Kyiv (2023)|Local Council]] approved the transition.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Orthodox Church of Ukraine finally adopts new calendar |url=https://english.nv.ua/life/ocu-approves-switch-to-revised-julian-calendar-ukraine-news-50342167.html |access-date=2023-07-31 |website=english.nv.ua |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |last=Свобода |first=Радіо |date=2023-05-24 |title=ПЦУ схвалила перехід на новий календар: Різдво – 25 грудня |website=Радіо Свобода |url=https://www.radiosvoboda.org/a/news-ptsu-novyy-kalendar/32425658.html |accessdate=2023-05-24}}</ref>
 
-On 28 June 2023 [[President of Ukraine]], [[Volodymyr Zelenskyy]], submitted to the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (Ukraine's national parliament) a draft law removing the Julian Calendar Christmas holiday on January 7 and confirming the December 25 date as the sole day of celebrations, reflecting changes in the OCU and UGCC calendars.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Zelensky Introduces Proposed Draft Law to Change Holiday Dates |url=https://www.kyivpost.com/post/18846 |access-date=2023-06-29 |website=Get the Latest Ukraine News Today - KyivPost |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-06-28 |title=Zelensky submitted to the Verkhovna Rada a law on changing holiday dates |url=https://babel.ua/en/news/95649-zelensky-submitted-to-the-verkhovna-rada-a-law-on-changing-holiday-dates |access-date=2023-06-29 |website=babel.ua |language=en}}</ref> Parliament passed this law on 14 July 2023 with 241 deputies voting in the affirmative.<ref name="3735767ChristmasUA">{{Cite web |date=2023-07-14 |title=Parliament changes dates of Christmas, Statehood Day, Day of Defenders |url=https://www.ukrinform.net/rubric-society/3735767-parliament-changes-dates-of-three-holidays-christmas-statehood-day-day-of-defenders-of-ukraine.html |access-date=2023-07-14 |website=[[Ukrinform]] |language=en}}</ref> Zelensky signed the law on 28 July 2023.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cnn.com/2023/07/29/europe/ukraine-christmas-date-change-intl/index.html|last1 = Toropin | first1 = Konstantin | last2 = Stambaugh | first2 = Alex | title = Ukraine moves Christmas to December 25, distancing itself from Russian tradition | website = Cable News Network | date = 29 July 2023 | accessdate = 1 August 2023}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-07-29 |title=Ukraine moves official Christmas Day holiday to Dec. 25, denouncing Russian-imposed traditions |url=https://apnews.com/article/russia-ukraine-war-christmas-orthodox-church-calendar-b658c9ebecc91a470866c34b1c1847eb |access-date=2023-07-31 |website=AP News |language=en}}</ref>
+On 28 June 2023 [[President of Ukraine]], [[Volodymyr Zelenskyy]], submitted to the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (Ukraine's national parliament) a draft law removing the Julian Calendar Christmas holiday on January 7 and confirming the December 25 date as the sole day of celebrations, reflecting changes in the OCU and UGCC calendars.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Zelensky Introduces Proposed Draft Law to Change Holiday Dates |url=https://www.kyivpost.com/post/18846 |access-date=2023-06-29 |website=Get the Latest Ukraine News Today – KyivPost |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-06-28 |title=Zelensky submitted to the Verkhovna Rada a law on changing holiday dates |url=https://babel.ua/en/news/95649-zelensky-submitted-to-the-verkhovna-rada-a-law-on-changing-holiday-dates |access-date=2023-06-29 |website=babel.ua |language=en}}</ref> Parliament passed this law on 14 July 2023 with 241 deputies voting in the affirmative.<ref name="3735767ChristmasUA">{{Cite web |date=2023-07-14 |title=Parliament changes dates of Christmas, Statehood Day, Day of Defenders |url=https://www.ukrinform.net/rubric-society/3735767-parliament-changes-dates-of-three-holidays-christmas-statehood-day-day-of-defenders-of-ukraine.html |access-date=2023-07-14 |website=[[Ukrinform]] |language=en}}</ref> Zelensky signed the law on 28 July 2023.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cnn.com/2023/07/29/europe/ukraine-christmas-date-change-intl/index.html|last1 = Toropin | first1 = Konstantin | last2 = Stambaugh | first2 = Alex | title = Ukraine moves Christmas to December 25, distancing itself from Russian tradition | website = Cable News Network | date = 29 July 2023 | accessdate = 1 August 2023}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-07-29 |title=Ukraine moves official Christmas Day holiday to Dec. 25, denouncing Russian-imposed traditions |url=https://apnews.com/article/russia-ukraine-war-christmas-orthodox-church-calendar-b658c9ebecc91a470866c34b1c1847eb |access-date=2023-07-31 |website=AP News |language=en}}</ref>
 
-According to a study conducted by the international company [[Deloitte]] in November 2023, after the transition of Ukrainian Christian churches to a [[Gregorian calendar|new style]], the majority of [[Ukrainians]] (about 45%) will celebrate Christmas on December 25 and only 17% on January 7, and 32% plan to celebrate twice.<ref>{{Cite web |title=More donations to the Armed Forces, new traditions and the continuation of the boycott of sellers still working in the Russian Federation - Deloitte research on New Year's shopping of Ukrainians |url=https://www2.deloitte.com/ua/uk/pages/press-room/press-release/2023/holiday-retail-sales-consumer-survey.html |accessdate=2023-12-13 |website="Deloitte" in Ukraine |language=uk}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-12-08 |title=The vast majority of Ukrainians will celebrate Christmas on December 25 - survey |url=https://religionpravda.com.ua/?p=90196 |accessdate=2023-12-13 |website=Religious Pravda |language=uk}}</ref>  In 2023, for the first time since 1917 and following a government announcement, [[Christmas Day]] in Ukraine will officially be on December 25th.<ref name="BBC">{{cite news |last1=Waterhouse |first1=James |title=Ukraine war: New Christmas date marks shift away from Russia |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-67801204 |access-date=24 December 2023 |work=[[BBC News]] |date=23 December 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231223231729/https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-67801204 |archive-date=23 December 2023}}</ref>
+According to a study conducted by the international company [[Deloitte]] in November 2023, after the transition of Ukrainian Christian churches to a [[Gregorian calendar|new style]], the majority of [[Ukrainians]] (about 45%) will celebrate Christmas on December 25 and only 17% on January 7, and 32% plan to celebrate twice.<ref>{{Cite web |title=More donations to the Armed Forces, new traditions and the continuation of the boycott of sellers still working in the Russian Federation – Deloitte research on New Year's shopping of Ukrainians |url=https://www2.deloitte.com/ua/uk/pages/press-room/press-release/2023/holiday-retail-sales-consumer-survey.html |accessdate=2023-12-13 |website="Deloitte" in Ukraine |language=uk}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-12-08 |title=The vast majority of Ukrainians will celebrate Christmas on December 25 – survey |url=https://religionpravda.com.ua/?p=90196 |accessdate=2023-12-13 |website=Religious Pravda |language=uk}}</ref>  In 2023, for the first time since 1917 and following a government announcement, [[Christmas Day]] in Ukraine will officially be on December 25th.<ref name="BBC">{{cite news |last1=Waterhouse |first1=James |title=Ukraine war: New Christmas date marks shift away from Russia |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-67801204 |access-date=24 December 2023 |work=[[BBC News]] |date=23 December 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231223231729/https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-67801204 |archive-date=23 December 2023}}</ref>
 
 
 ==Sviatyi Vechir (Holy Evening)==

@@ -30,7 +30,7 @@

-Traditional '''Ukrainian Christmas''' festivities start on [[Christmas Eve]], which is celebrated from December 24 to January 6, the date of the celebration of the [[baptism of Jesus]], known in [[Ukraine]] as ''[[Epiphany (holiday)|Vodokhreshche]]'' or ''Yordan'',<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/ Christmas Traditions<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> according to the [[Gregorian calendar]] and [[Revised Julian calendar]] by the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine]],<ref name=":4" /> [[Latin Church in Ukraine|Latin]] and [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church|Greek]]<ref name=":3" /> [[Catholic Church in Ukraine|Catholics]], and most [[Protestantism in Ukraine|Protestant churches]]. 
+Traditional '''Ukrainian Christmas''' festivities start on [[Christmas Eve]], which is celebrated from December 24 to January 6, the date of the celebration of the [[baptism of Jesus]], known in [[Ukraine]] as ''[[Epiphany (holiday)|Vodokhreshche]]'' or ''Yordan'',<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/ Christmas Traditions<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> according to the [[Gregorian calendar]] and [[Revised Julian calendar]] by the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine]],<ref name=":4" /> the [[Catholic Church in Ukraine|Catholic Church]] (including [[Latin Church in Ukraine|Latin]] and [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church|Ukrainian Greek Catholics]]<ref name=":3" />), and most [[Protestantism in Ukraine|Protestants]]. 
 
 The [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)|Ukrainian Orthodox Church of the Moscow Patriarchate]] (except for the [[Romanians in Ukraine|Romanian parishes]]<ref name=":2" />), some parishes of the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine]] and Protestant churches celebrate Christmas according to the [[Julian calendar]], so the Gregorian holidays last from January 6 to January 19. The {{ill|Armenian Diocese of Ukraine|hy|Ուկրաինայի հայոց թեմ|display=1}} of the [[Armenian Apostolic Church]] and the [[Armenian Catholic Church in Ukraine]] celebrates Christmas from January 5 to January 6 along with [[Epiphany (holiday)|Epiphany]] according to the Gregorian calendar.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Do Lvivians know that Armenians celebrate Christmas on January 6? |url=https://tvoemisto.tv/blogs/shche_odna_data_rizdva_hto_u_lvovi_maie_svyatu_vecheryu_5_sichnya_141904.html |access-date=2023-06-18 |website=tvoemisto.tv}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |last=Терещук |first=Галина |date=2020-01-06 |title=Christmas in Lviv: three dates of the family holiday |language=uk |work=Радіо Свобода |url=https://www.radiosvoboda.org/a/30362341.html |access-date=2023-06-18}}</ref>
 
@@ -65,7 +65,7 @@
 [[File:Шопка_перед_львівською_ратушою.jpg|thumb|[[Nativity scene]].]]
 [[Christmas Eve]] on December 24 is called Sviatyi Vechir (''Святий вечір'') or Sviatvechir (''Святвечір'') in Ukraine ("Holy Evening"), and has many customs and rituals, most of which predate the introduction of Christianity to Ukraine. Traditions include decorating house and dinner table with special attributes (a symbolic sheaf of wheat called the ''[[didukh]]'', [[garlic]], hay, and others), performing [[Koliada|koliadky]] ('carols') and so on.  Each ritual has its own meaning and purpose, as such a few wisps of hay on the embroidered tablecloth as a reminder of the manger in [[Bethlehem]]. One prominent custom of the night is a special supper, called ''[[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|Sviata Vecheria]]'' ("Holy Supper").<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Nks04JbYUSgC&dq=sviata+vecheria&pg=PA33|last=World Book Inc.|title=Christmas in Ukraine|date=1997|location=Chicago|isbn=978-0-7166-0897-4|language=en}}</ref>
 
-Ukrainians of the OCU and UGCC fast on Sviatyi Vechir (Latin Rite Catholics and Protestants may choose also to follow tradition on said day); only when the first star is seen in the evening sky, may the supper begin.  The family comes together to have a dinner which usually includes 12 dishes (the number can vary from 7–17). These [[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|twelve dishes]] are traditionally vegan plus fish, and do not contain meat, milk, or eggs.<ref>{{cite web |title=Christmas in Ukraine |url=https://www.whychristmas.com/cultures/ukraine.shtml |website=Why Christmas |access-date=14 December 2020}}</ref> While the dishes served can vary regionally, as well as from family to family, the two mandatory dishes are uzvar and kutia, both reckoned by ethnographer [[Fedir Vovk|Khvedir Vovk]] to be remnants of ancient rituals which date back to the neolithic era.<ref>{{cite web |title=Traditional Recipe of Ukrainian Kutia |url=https://etnocook.com/kutia/ |website=Ethnocook |access-date=27 November 2022}}</ref> [[Kutia]] (a dish of grain, honey and poppy seeds) is traditionally served first at the meal, after being offered by the head of the household to the frost. A spoonful is tossed at the ceiling, and in rural townships the number of poppy seeds which stick portends the bountyfulness of the fields, orchards and farm animals in the coming year. It is rarely served at other times of the year.<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html Sviat Vechir<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Uzvar is a beverage, made with cooked dried fruits and berries. It can be mixed in with the kutia, or served separately at the end of the meal.  Servings of both dishes are also set aside overnight in the pokuttia, the corner of the house with the Orthodox/Eastern Rite Catholic icons or Latin Rite Catholic images of saints, for deceased ancestors within the family or, in recent cases, for family members killed during the Russo-Ukrainian War (especially those who were KIA in the Armed Forces of Ukraine and other uniformed organizations).
+Ukrainians of the OCU and UGCC fast on Sviatyi Vechir ([[Latin Church]] Catholics and Protestants may choose also to follow tradition on said day); only when the first star is seen in the evening sky, may the supper begin.  The family comes together to have a dinner which usually includes 12 dishes (the number can vary from 7–17). These [[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|twelve dishes]] are traditionally vegan plus fish, and do not contain meat, milk, or eggs.<ref>{{cite web |title=Christmas in Ukraine |url=https://www.whychristmas.com/cultures/ukraine.shtml |website=Why Christmas |access-date=14 December 2020}}</ref> While the dishes served can vary regionally, as well as from family to family, the two mandatory dishes are uzvar and kutia, both reckoned by ethnographer [[Fedir Vovk|Khvedir Vovk]] to be remnants of ancient rituals which date back to the neolithic era.<ref>{{cite web |title=Traditional Recipe of Ukrainian Kutia |url=https://etnocook.com/kutia/ |website=Ethnocook |access-date=27 November 2022}}</ref> [[Kutia]] (a dish of grain, honey and poppy seeds) is traditionally served first at the meal, after being offered by the head of the household to the frost. A spoonful is tossed at the ceiling, and in rural townships the number of poppy seeds which stick portends the bountyfulness of the fields, orchards and farm animals in the coming year. It is rarely served at other times of the year.<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html Sviat Vechir<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Uzvar is a beverage, made with cooked dried fruits and berries. It can be mixed in with the kutia, or served separately at the end of the meal.  Servings of both dishes are also set aside overnight in the pokuttia, the corner of the house with the Orthodox/Eastern Catholic icons or Latin Catholic images of saints, for deceased ancestors within the family or, in recent cases, for family members killed during the Russo-Ukrainian War (especially those who were KIA in the Armed Forces of Ukraine and other uniformed organizations).
 
 The All-Night Christmas Vigil then follows, families then troop to their local parish churches or Protestant chruches to attend as thanksgiving for the Savior's birth in a stable.

 On February 2, 2023, the Holy Synod of the OCU allowed and approved the procedure for blessing parishes and monasteries for the full use of the Revised Julian calendar,<ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-02-02 |title=Decree of the Holy Synod on the procedure for blessing parishes and monasteries for the use of the Revised Julian calendar |url=https://www.pomisna.info/uk/vsi-novyny/postanova-svyashhennogo-synodu-pro-poryadok-nadannya-blagoslovennya-parafiyam-ta-monastyryam-na-vykorystannya-novoyulianskogo-kalendarya/ |access-date=2023-02-03 |website=OCU |language=uk}}</ref> and on May 24, 2023, to hold a meeting of the Council of Bishops, where the issue of calendar reform will be raised.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-02-02 |title=Official notice of the meeting of the Holy Synod on February 2, 2023. |url=https://www.pomisna.info/uk/vsi-novyny/ofitsijne-povidomlennya-pro-zasidannya-svyashhennogo-synodu-2-lyutogo-2023-r/ |access-date=2023-02-03 |website=OCU |language=uk}}</ref>

+In February 2023 the UGCC decided to switch to the Revised Julian calendar for fixed holidays (і.e., except for [[Date of Easter|Easter]]) from September 2023.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Historical decision: the UGCC in Ukraine switches to a new calendar|url=https://ugcc.ua/en/data/historical-decision-the-ugcc-in-ukraine-switches-to-a-new-calendar-232/ |access-date=2023-07-19 |website=Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church |language=en}}</ref> [[Parish|Parishes]] of the UGCC that are not ready to switch to the new style in 2023 have a transition period until September 1, 2025 to make the change.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web |date=2023-02-06 |title=Ukraine Catholic Church moves from Russian-affiliated Julian calendar |url=https://www.pillarcatholic.com/ukraine-catholic-church-moves-from-russian/ |access-date=2023-02-06 |website=The Pillar |language=en}}</ref>
 
 Effective 24 May 2023, the OCU officially declared that 25 December will be the permanent date for Christmas commemorations and festivities for the Ukrainian Orthodox faithful, as the Church officially formalized the adoption of the Revised Julian calendar for fixed feasts and solemnities in line with the other Orthodox churches of the world, with Easter kept in the old Julian Calendar.<ref>{{Cite news |last=RFE/RL |title=Orthodox Church Of Ukraine Approves Calendar Switch In Widening Diversion From Russia |language=en |work=RadioFreeEurope/RadioLiberty |url=https://www.rferl.org/a/orthodox-church-ukraine-approves-calendar-switch-russia/32426292.html |access-date=2023-06-18}}</ref><ref name=":4">{{Cite web |date=2023-05-24 |title=Orthodox Church of Ukraine to switch to Revised Julian calendar, celebrate Christmas on Dec. 25 |url=https://kyivindependent.com/orthodox-church-of-ukraine-to-switch-to-revised-julian-calendar-celebrate-christmas-on-dec-25/ |access-date=2023-06-18 |website=The Kyiv Independent |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Orthodox Church of Ukraine Decides to Celebrate Christmas on Dec. 25 |url=https://www.kyivpost.com/post/17460 |access-date=2023-06-18 |website=Get the Latest Ukraine News Today – KyivPost |language=en}}</ref> On July 27, the [[Council of Kyiv (2023)|Local Council]] approved the transition.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Orthodox Church of Ukraine finally adopts new calendar |url=https://english.nv.ua/life/ocu-approves-switch-to-revised-julian-calendar-ukraine-news-50342167.html |access-date=2023-07-31 |website=english.nv.ua |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |last=Свобода |first=Радіо |date=2023-05-24 |title=ПЦУ схвалила перехід на новий календар: Різдво – 25 грудня |website=Радіо Свобода |url=https://www.radiosvoboda.org/a/news-ptsu-novyy-kalendar/32425658.html |accessdate=2023-05-24}}</ref>
