In the case of a divine service, its participants are released from the restrictions of fasting on this day.<ref>{{Cite web |title=OCU allowed Christmas services on December 25 |url=https://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2022/10/18/7372478/ |accessdate=2022-10-18 |website=[[Ukrainian Pravda]] |language=uk}}</ref>
 
 On 24 December 2022, during an [[audience]], [[Major Archbishop]] Sviatoslav handed over to [[Metropolitan of Kyiv and All Ukraine|Metropolitan]] [[Epiphanius I of Ukraine|Epiphanius]] for review a letter outlining the considerations of the UGCC hierarchs regarding the {{ill|Calendar reform in Ukraine|lt=calendar reform|uk|Календарна реформа в Україні|display=1}}. The primates decided to create a joint working group on specific proposals for calendar reform. The joint group is initiated on the occasion of the celebration of the 1700th anniversary of the [[First Council of Nicaea|First Ecumenical Council]], held in [[Nicaea]] in 325. In this [[Ecumenical council|Council]], in particular, the calendar principles of church life were determined.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Heads of OCU, UGCC agree to set up working group to reform church calendar |url=https://www.ukrinform.net/rubric-society/3640576-heads-of-ocu-ugcc-agree-to-set-up-working-group-to-reform-church-calendar.html |access-date=2022-12-24 |website=www.ukrinform.net |date=24 December 2022 |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=During the meeting of His Beatitude Sviatoslav with His Beatitude Epiphanius, they talked about the reform of the church calendar |url=https://news.ugcc.ua/data/pid-chas-zustrichi-blazhennishogo-svyatoslava-z-blazhennishym-epifaniem-govoryly-pro-reformu-tserkovnogo-kalendarya-1713/ |access-date=2022-12-24 |website=Українська Греко-Католицька Церква |language=uk |archive-date=24 December 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221224150917/https://news.ugcc.ua/data/pid-chas-zustrichi-blazhennishogo-svyatoslava-z-blazhennishym-epifaniem-govoryly-pro-reformu-tserkovnogo-kalendarya-1713/ |url-status=dead }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2022-12-24 |title=There was a meeting of the Primate of the OCU with the Father and the Primate of the UGCC |url=https://www.pomisna.info/uk/vsi-novyny/vidbulasya-zustrich-predstoyatelya-ptsu-z-ottsem-i-glavoyu-ugkts/ |access-date=2022-12-24 |website=OCU |language=uk}}</ref>
 
@@ -66,7 +66,6 @@
 On 28 June 2023 [[President of Ukraine]], [[Volodymyr Zelenskyy]], submitted to the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (Ukraine's national parliament) a draft law removing the Julian Calendar Christmas holiday on January 7 and confirming the December 25 date as the sole day of celebrations, reflecting changes in the OCU and UGCC calendars.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Zelensky Introduces Proposed Draft Law to Change Holiday Dates |url=https://www.kyivpost.com/post/18846 |access-date=2023-06-29 |website=Get the Latest Ukraine News Today – KyivPost |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-06-28 |title=Zelensky submitted to the Verkhovna Rada a law on changing holiday dates |url=https://babel.ua/en/news/95649-zelensky-submitted-to-the-verkhovna-rada-a-law-on-changing-holiday-dates |access-date=2023-06-29 |website=babel.ua |language=en}}</ref> Parliament passed this law on 14 July 2023 with 241 deputies voting in the affirmative.<ref name="3735767ChristmasUA">{{Cite web |date=2023-07-14 |title=Parliament changes dates of Christmas, Statehood Day, Day of Defenders |url=https://www.ukrinform.net/rubric-society/3735767-parliament-changes-dates-of-three-holidays-christmas-statehood-day-day-of-defenders-of-ukraine.html |access-date=2023-07-14 |website=[[Ukrinform]] |language=en}}</ref> Zelensky signed the law on 28 July 2023.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cnn.com/2023/07/29/europe/ukraine-christmas-date-change-intl/index.html|last1 = Toropin | first1 = Konstantin | last2 = Stambaugh | first2 = Alex | title = Ukraine moves Christmas to December 25, distancing itself from Russian tradition | website = Cable News Network | date = 29 July 2023 | accessdate = 1 August 2023}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-07-29 |title=Ukraine moves official Christmas Day holiday to Dec. 25, denouncing Russian-imposed traditions |url=https://apnews.com/article/russia-ukraine-war-christmas-orthodox-church-calendar-b658c9ebecc91a470866c34b1c1847eb |access-date=2023-07-31 |website=AP News |language=en}}</ref>
 
 According to a study conducted by the international company [[Deloitte]] in November 2023, after the transition of Ukrainian Christian churches to a [[Gregorian calendar|new style]], the majority of [[Ukrainians]] (about 45%) will celebrate Christmas on December 25 and only 17% on January 7, and 32% plan to celebrate twice.<ref>{{Cite web |title=More donations to the Armed Forces, new traditions and the continuation of the boycott of sellers still working in the Russian Federation – Deloitte research on New Year's shopping of Ukrainians |url=https://www2.deloitte.com/ua/uk/pages/press-room/press-release/2023/holiday-retail-sales-consumer-survey.html |accessdate=2023-12-13 |website="Deloitte" in Ukraine |language=uk}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-12-08 |title=The vast majority of Ukrainians will celebrate Christmas on December 25 – survey |url=https://religionpravda.com.ua/?p=90196 |accessdate=2023-12-13 |website=Religious Pravda |language=uk}}</ref>  In 2023, for the first time since 1917 and following a government announcement, [[Christmas Day]] in Ukraine will officially be on December 25th.<ref name="BBC">{{cite news |last1=Waterhouse |first1=James |title=Ukraine war: New Christmas date marks shift away from Russia |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-67801204 |access-date=24 December 2023 |work=[[BBC News]] |date=23 December 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231223231729/https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-67801204 |archive-date=23 December 2023}}</ref>

@@ -65,7 +65,7 @@
 [[File:Шопка_перед_львівською_ратушою.jpg|thumb|[[Nativity scene]].]]
 [[Christmas Eve]] on December 24 is called Sviatyi Vechir (''Святий вечір'') or Sviatvechir (''Святвечір'') in Ukraine ("Holy Evening"), and has many customs and rituals, most of which predate the introduction of Christianity to Ukraine. Traditions include decorating house and dinner table with special attributes (a symbolic sheaf of wheat called the ''[[didukh]]'', [[garlic]], hay, and others), performing [[Koliada|koliadky]] ('carols') and so on.  Each ritual has its own meaning and purpose, as such a few wisps of hay on the embroidered tablecloth as a reminder of the manger in [[Bethlehem]]. One prominent custom of the night is a special supper, called ''[[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|Sviata Vecheria]]'' ("Holy Supper").<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Nks04JbYUSgC&dq=sviata+vecheria&pg=PA33|last=World Book Inc.|title=Christmas in Ukraine|date=1997|location=Chicago|isbn=978-0-7166-0897-4|language=en}}</ref>
 
-Ukrainians of the OCU and UGCC fast on Sviatyi Vechir ([[Latin Church]] Catholics and Protestants may choose also to follow tradition on said day); only when the first star is seen in the evening sky, may the supper begin.  The family comes together to have a dinner which usually includes 12 dishes (the number can vary from 7–17). These [[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|twelve dishes]] are traditionally vegan plus fish, and do not contain meat, milk, or eggs.<ref>{{cite web |title=Christmas in Ukraine |url=https://www.whychristmas.com/cultures/ukraine.shtml |website=Why Christmas |access-date=14 December 2020}}</ref> While the dishes served can vary regionally, as well as from family to family, the two mandatory dishes are uzvar and kutia, both reckoned by ethnographer [[Fedir Vovk|Khvedir Vovk]] to be remnants of ancient rituals which date back to the neolithic era.<ref>{{cite web |title=Traditional Recipe of Ukrainian Kutia |url=https://etnocook.com/kutia/ |website=Ethnocook |access-date=27 November 2022}}</ref> [[Kutia]] (a dish of grain, honey and poppy seeds) is traditionally served first at the meal, after being offered by the head of the household to the frost. A spoonful is tossed at the ceiling, and in rural townships the number of poppy seeds which stick portends the bountyfulness of the fields, orchards and farm animals in the coming year. It is rarely served at other times of the year.<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html Sviat Vechir<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Uzvar is a beverage, made with cooked dried fruits and berries. It can be mixed in with the kutia, or served separately at the end of the meal.  Servings of both dishes are also set aside overnight in the pokuttia, the corner of the house with the Orthodox/Eastern Catholic icons or Latin Catholic images of saints, for deceased ancestors within the family or, in recent cases, for family members killed during the Russo-Ukrainian War (especially those who were KIA in the Armed Forces of Ukraine and other uniformed organizations).
+Ukrainians of the OCU and UGCC fast on Sviatyi Vechir ([[Latin Church]] Catholics and Protestants may choose also to follow tradition on said day); only when the first star is seen in the evening sky, may the supper begin.  The family comes together to have a dinner which usually includes 12 dishes (the number can vary from 7–17). These [[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|twelve dishes]] are traditionally vegan plus fish, and do not contain meat, milk, or eggs.<ref>{{cite web |title=Christmas in Ukraine |url=https://www.whychristmas.com/cultures/ukraine.shtml |website=Why Christmas |access-date=14 December 2020}}</ref> While the dishes served can vary regionally, as well as from family to family, the two mandatory dishes are uzvar and kutia, both reckoned by ethnographer [[Fedir Vovk|Khvedir Vovk]] to be remnants of ancient rituals which date back to the neolithic era.<ref>{{cite web |title=Traditional Recipe of Ukrainian Kutia |url=https://etnocook.com/kutia/ |website=Ethnocook |date=18 January 2018 |access-date=27 November 2022}}</ref> [[Kutia]] (a dish of grain, honey and poppy seeds) is traditionally served first at the meal, after being offered by the head of the household to the frost. A spoonful is tossed at the ceiling, and in rural townships the number of poppy seeds which stick portends the bountyfulness of the fields, orchards and farm animals in the coming year. It is rarely served at other times of the year.<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html Sviat Vechir<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Uzvar is a beverage, made with cooked dried fruits and berries. It can be mixed in with the kutia, or served separately at the end of the meal.  Servings of both dishes are also set aside overnight in the pokuttia, the corner of the house with the Orthodox/Eastern Catholic icons or Latin Catholic images of saints, for deceased ancestors within the family or, in recent cases, for family members killed during the Russo-Ukrainian War (especially those who were KIA in the Armed Forces of Ukraine and other uniformed organizations).
 
 The All-Night Christmas Vigil then follows, families then troop to their local parish churches or Protestant chruches to attend as thanksgiving for the Savior's birth in a stable.

 [[File:Diduch-Lviv.jpg|thumb|A [[didukh]] in [[Lviv]]]]
-As of 2017, 25 December, Christmas Day by the [[Gregorian calendar|Gregorian]] calendar, became an official government holiday in Ukraine. The [[Eastern Orthodox Church]]es predominantly follow the Julian calendar, and 7 January is also a [[Public holidays in Ukraine|public holiday in Ukraine]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://m.digitaljournal.com/news/world/ukraine-seeks-distance-from-moscow-with-new-christmas-holiday/article/507753|title=Ukraine seeks distance from Moscow with new Christmas holiday|website=m.digitaljournal.com|date=16 November 2017|access-date=2017-11-16|archive-date=17 November 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171117065016/http://m.digitaljournal.com/news/world/ukraine-seeks-distance-from-moscow-with-new-christmas-holiday/article/507753|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref>{{in lang|uk}} {{Cite news|url=http://www.bbc.com/ukrainian/news-42008437|title=Рада зробила 25 грудня вихідним днем|date=2017-11-16|work=BBC Україна|access-date=2017-11-16|language=en-GB}}</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine]], [[Epiphanius I of Ukraine|Metropolitan Epiphanius]], said that changing the date of Christmas to 25 December in Ukraine is possible after both the church and the faithful are ready for such a decision, after conducting educational work. It was stated that the postponement of the celebration of the nativity of The Lord would entail a change in the dates of all fixed holidays to 13 days ago.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://news.rbc.ua/ukr/politics/epifaniy-nazval-uslovie-perenosa-prazdnovaniya-1608382147.html|title = Епіфаній назвав умову перенесення святкування Різдва на 25 грудня}}</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church]] (UGCC), [[Sviatoslav Shevchuk|Patriarch Sviatoslav]], stated that the Greek Catholic Church would resolve this issue "together with our Orthodox brothers". He also noted that this issue is not dogmatic, it should overcome church divisions, not cause new ones, and in his opinion, the transition to celebrating Christmas in a new style — 25 December, should be initiated by the laity.
+As of 2017, 25 December, Christmas Day by the [[Gregorian calendar|Gregorian]] calendar, became an official government holiday in Ukraine. The [[Eastern Orthodox Church]]es predominantly follow the Julian calendar, and 7 January is also a [[Public holidays in Ukraine|public holiday in Ukraine]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://m.digitaljournal.com/news/world/ukraine-seeks-distance-from-moscow-with-new-christmas-holiday/article/507753|title=Ukraine seeks distance from Moscow with new Christmas holiday|website=m.digitaljournal.com|date=16 November 2017|access-date=2017-11-16|archive-date=17 November 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171117065016/http://m.digitaljournal.com/news/world/ukraine-seeks-distance-from-moscow-with-new-christmas-holiday/article/507753|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref>{{in lang|uk}} {{Cite news|url=http://www.bbc.com/ukrainian/news-42008437|title=Рада зробила 25 грудня вихідним днем|date=2017-11-16|work=BBC Україна|access-date=2017-11-16|language=en-GB}}</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine]] (OCU), [[Epiphanius I of Ukraine|Metropolitan Epiphanius]], said that changing the date of Christmas to 25 December in Ukraine is possible after both the church and the faithful are ready for such a decision, after conducting educational work. It was stated that the postponement of the celebration of the nativity of The Lord would entail a change in the dates of all fixed holidays to 13 days ago.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://news.rbc.ua/ukr/politics/epifaniy-nazval-uslovie-perenosa-prazdnovaniya-1608382147.html|title = Епіфаній назвав умову перенесення святкування Різдва на 25 грудня}}</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church]] (UGCC), [[Sviatoslav Shevchuk|Patriarch Sviatoslav]], stated that the Greek Catholic Church would resolve this issue "together with our Orthodox brothers". He also noted that this issue is not dogmatic, it should overcome church divisions, not cause new ones, and in his opinion, the transition to celebrating Christmas in a new style — 25 December, should be initiated by the laity.
 
 About a hundred parishes of the [[Romanians in Ukraine|Romanian national minority in Ukraine]], which are part of the [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)|Ukrainian Orthodox Church of the Moscow Patriarchate]], have always celebrated Christmas on December 25 according to the [[Revised Julian calendar]], just like the [[Romanian Orthodox Church]].<ref name=":2">{{Cite news |last=Кралюк |first=Петро |date=2023-01-02 |title=«Є сподівання, що ПЦУ і УГКЦ перейдуть на святкування Різдва 25 грудня» – професор Петро Кралюк |language=uk |work=Радіо Свобода |url=https://www.radiosvoboda.org/a/rizdvo-tserkovnyy-kalendar/32201163.html |access-date=2023-03-27}}</ref>
 
-On 18 October 2022, the Orthodox Church of Ukraine allowed dioceses to hold Christmas services according to the Revised Julian calendar, i.e., 25 December. In the case of a divine service, its participants are released from the restrictions of fasting on this day.<ref>{{Cite web |title=OCU allowed Christmas services on December 25 |url=https://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2022/10/18/7372478/ |accessdate=2022-10-18 |website=[[Ukrainian Pravda]] |language=uk}}</ref>
+On 18 October 2022, the OCU allowed dioceses to hold Christmas services according to the Revised Julian calendar, i.e., 25 December. In the case of a divine service, its participants are released from the restrictions of fasting on this day.<ref>{{Cite web |title=OCU allowed Christmas services on December 25 |url=https://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2022/10/18/7372478/ |accessdate=2022-10-18 |website=[[Ukrainian Pravda]] |language=uk}}</ref>
 
 On 24 December 2022, during an [[audience]], [[Major Archbishop]] Sviatoslav handed over to [[Metropolitan of Kyiv and All Ukraine|Metropolitan]] Epiphanius for review a letter outlining the considerations of the UGCC hierarchs regarding the {{ill|Calendar reform in Ukraine|lt=calendar reform|uk|Календарна реформа в Україні|display=1}}. The primates decided to create a joint working group on specific proposals for calendar reform. The joint group is initiated on the occasion of the celebration of the 1700th anniversary of the [[First Council of Nicaea|First Ecumenical Council]], held in [[Nicaea]] in 325. In this [[Ecumenical council|Council]], in particular, the calendar principles of church life were determined.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Heads of OCU, UGCC agree to set up working group to reform church calendar |url=https://www.ukrinform.net/rubric-society/3640576-heads-of-ocu-ugcc-agree-to-set-up-working-group-to-reform-church-calendar.html |access-date=2022-12-24 |website=www.ukrinform.net |date=24 December 2022 |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=During the meeting of His Beatitude Sviatoslav with His Beatitude Epiphanius, they talked about the reform of the church calendar |url=https://news.ugcc.ua/data/pid-chas-zustrichi-blazhennishogo-svyatoslava-z-blazhennishym-epifaniem-govoryly-pro-reformu-tserkovnogo-kalendarya-1713/ |access-date=2022-12-24 |website=Українська Греко-Католицька Церква |language=uk |archive-date=24 December 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221224150917/https://news.ugcc.ua/data/pid-chas-zustrichi-blazhennishogo-svyatoslava-z-blazhennishym-epifaniem-govoryly-pro-reformu-tserkovnogo-kalendarya-1713/ |url-status=dead }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2022-12-24 |title=There was a meeting of the Primate of the OCU with the Father and the Primate of the UGCC |url=https://www.pomisna.info/uk/vsi-novyny/vidbulasya-zustrich-predstoyatelya-ptsu-z-ottsem-i-glavoyu-ugkts/ |access-date=2022-12-24 |website=OCU |language=uk}}</ref>
 
-On February 2, 2023, the Holy Synod of the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine|OCU]] allowed and approved the procedure for blessing parishes and monasteries for the full use of the [[Revised Julian calendar]],<ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-02-02 |title=Decree of the Holy Synod on the procedure for blessing parishes and monasteries for the use of the Revised Julian calendar |url=https://www.pomisna.info/uk/vsi-novyny/postanova-svyashhennogo-synodu-pro-poryadok-nadannya-blagoslovennya-parafiyam-ta-monastyryam-na-vykorystannya-novoyulianskogo-kalendarya/ |access-date=2023-02-03 |website=OCU |language=uk}}</ref> and on May 24, 2023, to hold a meeting of the Council of Bishops, where the issue of calendar reform will be raised.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-02-02 |title=Official notice of the meeting of the Holy Synod on February 2, 2023. |url=https://www.pomisna.info/uk/vsi-novyny/ofitsijne-povidomlennya-pro-zasidannya-svyashhennogo-synodu-2-lyutogo-2023-r/ |access-date=2023-02-03 |website=OCU |language=uk}}</ref> 
+On February 2, 2023, the Holy Synod of the OCU allowed and approved the procedure for blessing parishes and monasteries for the full use of the [[Revised Julian calendar]],<ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-02-02 |title=Decree of the Holy Synod on the procedure for blessing parishes and monasteries for the use of the Revised Julian calendar |url=https://www.pomisna.info/uk/vsi-novyny/postanova-svyashhennogo-synodu-pro-poryadok-nadannya-blagoslovennya-parafiyam-ta-monastyryam-na-vykorystannya-novoyulianskogo-kalendarya/ |access-date=2023-02-03 |website=OCU |language=uk}}</ref> and on May 24, 2023, to hold a meeting of the Council of Bishops, where the issue of calendar reform will be raised.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-02-02 |title=Official notice of the meeting of the Holy Synod on February 2, 2023. |url=https://www.pomisna.info/uk/vsi-novyny/ofitsijne-povidomlennya-pro-zasidannya-svyashhennogo-synodu-2-lyutogo-2023-r/ |access-date=2023-02-03 |website=OCU |language=uk}}</ref> 
 
 In February 2023 the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church|UGCC]] decided to switch to a new style ([[Revised Julian calendar]]) for fixed holidays (і.e., except for [[Date of Easter|Easter]]) from September 2023.<ref>{{Cite web |title=HISTORICAL DECISION: THE UGCC IN UKRAINE SWITCHES TO A NEW CALENDAR |url=https://ugcc.ua/en/data/historical-decision-the-ugcc-in-ukraine-switches-to-a-new-calendar-232/ |access-date=2023-07-19 |website=Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church |language=en}}</ref> [[Parish|Parishes]] of the UGCC that are not ready to switch to the new style in 2023 have a transition period until September 1, 2025 to make the change.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web |date=2023-02-06 |title=Ukraine Catholic Church moves from Russian-affiliated Julian calendar |url=https://www.pillarcatholic.com/ukraine-catholic-church-moves-from-russian/ |access-date=2023-02-06 |website=The Pillar |language=en}}</ref>

 At the end of the Sviata Vechera dinner, and the vigil that follows, the family often sings carols (''koliadky'', singular ''koliadka''). In many communities the ancient Ukrainian tradition of caroling is carried on by groups of young people and members of organizations and churches calling at homes and collecting donations. A well-known carol is ''{{ill|Nova radist stala|lt=|uk|Нова радість стала|display=1}}'', [[Boh predvičnyj narodivsja|''Boh predvichnyi narodyvsia'']],<ref name=BLiturgy>{{cite web|title=Boh predvičnyj|url=http://mci.archpitt.org/legacy/songs/Slavonic/Boh_predvicnyj.html|website=Metropolitan Cantor Institute|publisher=Byzantine Catholic|access-date=12 August 2015|ref=Archeparchy of Pittsburgh|archive-date=4 March 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304235614/http://mci.archpitt.org/legacy/songs/Slavonic/Boh_predvicnyj.html|url-status=dead}}</ref> ''{{ill|Dobryi vechir tobi, pane hospodariu|lt=|uk|Добрий вечір тобі, пане господарю|display=1}}'', ''{{ill|Vo Vyfleiemi nyni novyna|lt=|uk|Во Вифлеємі нині новина|display=1}}'', ''{{ill|Nebo i zemlia nyni torzhestvuiut|lt=|uk|Небо і земля нині торжествують|display=1}}'', ''{{ill|Boh sia rozhdaie|lt=|uk|Бог ся раджае|display=1}}'' etc.
 
 ==''Didukh'' (grandfather)==
-In villages (farming communities), the head of the household brings in a sheaf of grain called the ''didukh'' which represents the importance of the ancient and rich wheat crops of Ukraine, the staff of life through the centuries. Didukh means literally "grandfather spirit" so it symbolizes the family's ancestors. In Ukrainian city homes the didukh may be purchased, and is often three footed made of woven grain and dried grasses and flowers.{{citation needed|date=April 2022}}
+In villages (farming communities), the head of the household brings in a sheaf of grain called the ''didukh'' which represents the importance of the ancient and rich wheat crops of Ukraine, the staff of life through the centuries. Didukh means literally "grandfather spirit" so it symbolizes the family's ancestors. In Ukrainian city homes the didukh may be purchased, and is often three footed made of woven grain and dried grasses and flowers.
 
 ==''Shopka'' (nativity scene)==
 A ''[[Nativity scene|shopka]]'' (''[[vertep]]'') is a traditional portable [[Nativity of Jesus|nativity]] scene used to represent nativity and other figures in a [[Nativity play|puppet]] form.

 On 28 June 2023 [[President of Ukraine]], [[Volodymyr Zelenskyy]], submitted to the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (Ukraine's national parliament) a draft law removing the Julian Calendar Christmas holiday on January 7 and confirming the December 25 date as the sole day of celebrations, reflecting changes in the OCU and UGCC calendars.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Zelensky Introduces Proposed Draft Law to Change Holiday Dates |url=https://www.kyivpost.com/post/18846 |access-date=2023-06-29 |website=Get the Latest Ukraine News Today – KyivPost |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-06-28 |title=Zelensky submitted to the Verkhovna Rada a law on changing holiday dates |url=https://babel.ua/en/news/95649-zelensky-submitted-to-the-verkhovna-rada-a-law-on-changing-holiday-dates |access-date=2023-06-29 |website=babel.ua |language=en}}</ref> Parliament passed this law on 14 July 2023 with 241 deputies voting in the affirmative.<ref name="3735767ChristmasUA">{{Cite web |date=2023-07-14 |title=Parliament changes dates of Christmas, Statehood Day, Day of Defenders |url=https://www.ukrinform.net/rubric-society/3735767-parliament-changes-dates-of-three-holidays-christmas-statehood-day-day-of-defenders-of-ukraine.html |access-date=2023-07-14 |website=[[Ukrinform]] |language=en}}</ref> Zelensky signed the law on 28 July 2023.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cnn.com/2023/07/29/europe/ukraine-christmas-date-change-intl/index.html|last1 = Toropin | first1 = Konstantin | last2 = Stambaugh | first2 = Alex | title = Ukraine moves Christmas to December 25, distancing itself from Russian tradition | website = Cable News Network | date = 29 July 2023 | accessdate = 1 August 2023}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-07-29 |title=Ukraine moves official Christmas Day holiday to Dec. 25, denouncing Russian-imposed traditions |url=https://apnews.com/article/russia-ukraine-war-christmas-orthodox-church-calendar-b658c9ebecc91a470866c34b1c1847eb |access-date=2023-07-31 |website=AP News |language=en}}</ref>
 
-According to a study conducted by the international company [[Deloitte]] in November 2023, after the transition of Ukrainian Christian churches to a [[Gregorian calendar|new style]], the majority of [[Ukrainians]] (about 45%) will celebrate Christmas on December 25 and only 17% on January 7, and 32% plan to celebrate twice.<ref>{{Cite web |title=More donations to the Armed Forces, new traditions and the continuation of the boycott of sellers still working in the Russian Federation – Deloitte research on New Year's shopping of Ukrainians |url=https://www2.deloitte.com/ua/uk/pages/press-room/press-release/2023/holiday-retail-sales-consumer-survey.html |accessdate=2023-12-13 |website="Deloitte" in Ukraine |language=uk}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-12-08 |title=The vast majority of Ukrainians will celebrate Christmas on December 25 – survey |url=https://religionpravda.com.ua/?p=90196 |accessdate=2023-12-13 |website=Religious Pravda |language=uk}}</ref>  In 2023, for the first time since 1917 and following a government announcement, [[Christmas Day]] in Ukraine will officially be on December 25th.<ref name="BBC">{{cite news |last1=Waterhouse |first1=James |title=Ukraine war: New Christmas date marks shift away from Russia |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-67801204 |access-date=24 December 2023 |work=[[BBC News]] |date=23 December 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231223231729/https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-67801204 |archive-date=23 December 2023}}</ref>
+According to a study conducted by the international company [[Deloitte]] in November 2023, after the transition of Ukrainian Christian churches to the new style, the majority of [[Ukrainians]] (about 45%) will celebrate Christmas on December 25 and only 17% on January 7, and 32% plan to celebrate twice.<ref>{{Cite web |title=More donations to the Armed Forces, new traditions and the continuation of the boycott of sellers still working in the Russian Federation – Deloitte research on New Year's shopping of Ukrainians |url=https://www2.deloitte.com/ua/uk/pages/press-room/press-release/2023/holiday-retail-sales-consumer-survey.html |accessdate=2023-12-13 |website="Deloitte" in Ukraine |language=uk}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-12-08 |title=The vast majority of Ukrainians will celebrate Christmas on December 25 – survey |url=https://religionpravda.com.ua/?p=90196 |accessdate=2023-12-13 |website=Religious Pravda |language=uk}}</ref>  In 2023, for the first time since 1917 and following a government announcement, [[Christmas Day]] in Ukraine will officially be on December 25th.<ref name="BBC">{{cite news |last1=Waterhouse |first1=James |title=Ukraine war: New Christmas date marks shift away from Russia |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-67801204 |access-date=24 December 2023 |work=[[BBC News]] |date=23 December 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231223231729/https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-67801204 |archive-date=23 December 2023}}</ref>

@@ -68,7 +68,7 @@
 
 On 28 June 2023 [[President of Ukraine]], [[Volodymyr Zelenskyy]], submitted to the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (Ukraine's national parliament) a draft law removing the Julian Calendar Christmas holiday on January 7 and confirming the December 25 date as the sole day of celebrations, reflecting changes in the OCU and UGCC calendars.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Zelensky Introduces Proposed Draft Law to Change Holiday Dates |url=https://www.kyivpost.com/post/18846 |access-date=2023-06-29 |website=Get the Latest Ukraine News Today – KyivPost |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-06-28 |title=Zelensky submitted to the Verkhovna Rada a law on changing holiday dates |url=https://babel.ua/en/news/95649-zelensky-submitted-to-the-verkhovna-rada-a-law-on-changing-holiday-dates |access-date=2023-06-29 |website=babel.ua |language=en}}</ref> Parliament passed this law on 14 July 2023 with 241 deputies voting in the affirmative.<ref name="3735767ChristmasUA">{{Cite web |date=2023-07-14 |title=Parliament changes dates of Christmas, Statehood Day, Day of Defenders |url=https://www.ukrinform.net/rubric-society/3735767-parliament-changes-dates-of-three-holidays-christmas-statehood-day-day-of-defenders-of-ukraine.html |access-date=2023-07-14 |website=[[Ukrinform]] |language=en}}</ref> Zelensky signed the law on 28 July 2023.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cnn.com/2023/07/29/europe/ukraine-christmas-date-change-intl/index.html|last1 = Toropin | first1 = Konstantin | last2 = Stambaugh | first2 = Alex | title = Ukraine moves Christmas to December 25, distancing itself from Russian tradition | website = Cable News Network | date = 29 July 2023 | accessdate = 1 August 2023}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-07-29 |title=Ukraine moves official Christmas Day holiday to Dec. 25, denouncing Russian-imposed traditions |url=https://apnews.com/article/russia-ukraine-war-christmas-orthodox-church-calendar-b658c9ebecc91a470866c34b1c1847eb |access-date=2023-07-31 |website=AP News |language=en}}</ref>
 
-According to a study conducted by the international company [[Deloitte]] in November 2023, after the transition of Ukrainian Christian churches to the new style, the majority of [[Ukrainians]] (about 45%) will celebrate Christmas on December 25 and only 17% on January 7, and 32% plan to celebrate twice.<ref>{{Cite web |title=More donations to the Armed Forces, new traditions and the continuation of the boycott of sellers still working in the Russian Federation – Deloitte research on New Year's shopping of Ukrainians |url=https://www2.deloitte.com/ua/uk/pages/press-room/press-release/2023/holiday-retail-sales-consumer-survey.html |accessdate=2023-12-13 |website="Deloitte" in Ukraine |language=uk}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-12-08 |title=The vast majority of Ukrainians will celebrate Christmas on December 25 – survey |url=https://religionpravda.com.ua/?p=90196 |accessdate=2023-12-13 |website=Religious Pravda |language=uk}}</ref>  In 2023, for the first time since 1917 and following a government announcement, [[Christmas Day]] in Ukraine will officially be on December 25th.<ref name="BBC">{{cite news |last1=Waterhouse |first1=James |title=Ukraine war: New Christmas date marks shift away from Russia |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-67801204 |access-date=24 December 2023 |work=[[BBC News]] |date=23 December 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231223231729/https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-67801204 |archive-date=23 December 2023}}</ref>
+According to a study conducted by the international company [[Deloitte]] in November 2023, after the transition of Ukrainian Christian churches to the new style, the majority of [[Ukrainians]] (about 45%) will celebrate Christmas on December 25 and only 17% on January 7, and 32% plan to celebrate twice.<ref>{{Cite web |title=More donations to the Armed Forces, new traditions and the continuation of the boycott of sellers still working in the Russian Federation – Deloitte research on New Year's shopping of Ukrainians |url=https://www2.deloitte.com/ua/uk/pages/press-room/press-release/2023/holiday-retail-sales-consumer-survey.html |accessdate=2023-12-13 |website="Deloitte" in Ukraine |language=uk}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-12-08 |title=The vast majority of Ukrainians will celebrate Christmas on December 25 – survey |url=https://religionpravda.com.ua/?p=90196 |accessdate=2023-12-13 |website=Religious Pravda |language=uk}}</ref>  In 2023, for the first time since 1917, [[Christmas Day]] in Ukraine will officially be on December 25th.<ref name="BBC">{{cite news |last1=Waterhouse |first1=James |title=Ukraine war: New Christmas date marks shift away from Russia |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-67801204 |access-date=24 December 2023 |work=[[BBC News]] |date=23 December 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231223231729/https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-67801204 |archive-date=23 December 2023}}</ref>

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -51,6 +51,8 @@
 
 == Date of celebration ==
 [[File:Diduch-Lviv.jpg|thumb|A [[didukh]] in [[Lviv]]]]
+Traditional Ukrainian Christmas festivities last from December 24 to January 6, the date of the celebration of the [[baptism of Jesus]], which known in Ukraine as ''[[Epiphany (holiday)|Vodokhreshche]]'' or ''{{lang|uk|Yordan}}'',<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/ Christmas Traditions<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> according to the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine]] (OCU),<ref name=":4" /> the [[Catholic Church in Ukraine|Catholic Church]] (including [[Latin Church in Ukraine|Latin]] and [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church|Ukrainian Greek Catholics]]<ref name=":3" />), and most [[Protestantism in Ukraine|Protestants]].
+
 As of 2017, 25 December, Christmas Day by the [[Gregorian calendar|Gregorian]] calendar, became an official government holiday in Ukraine. The [[Eastern Orthodox Church]]es predominantly follow the Julian calendar, and 7 January is also a [[Public holidays in Ukraine|public holiday in Ukraine]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://m.digitaljournal.com/news/world/ukraine-seeks-distance-from-moscow-with-new-christmas-holiday/article/507753|title=Ukraine seeks distance from Moscow with new Christmas holiday|website=m.digitaljournal.com|date=16 November 2017|access-date=2017-11-16|archive-date=17 November 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171117065016/http://m.digitaljournal.com/news/world/ukraine-seeks-distance-from-moscow-with-new-christmas-holiday/article/507753|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref>{{in lang|uk}} {{Cite news|url=http://www.bbc.com/ukrainian/news-42008437|title=Рада зробила 25 грудня вихідним днем|date=2017-11-16|work=BBC Україна|access-date=2017-11-16|language=en-GB}}</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine]] (OCU), [[Epiphanius I of Ukraine|Metropolitan Epiphanius]], said that changing the date of Christmas to 25 December in Ukraine is possible after both the church and the faithful are ready for such a decision, after conducting educational work. It was stated that the postponement of the celebration of the nativity of The Lord would entail a change in the dates of all fixed holidays to 13 days ago.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://news.rbc.ua/ukr/politics/epifaniy-nazval-uslovie-perenosa-prazdnovaniya-1608382147.html|title = Епіфаній назвав умову перенесення святкування Різдва на 25 грудня}}</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church]] (UGCC), [[Sviatoslav Shevchuk|Patriarch Sviatoslav]], stated that the Greek Catholic Church would resolve this issue "together with our Orthodox brothers". He also noted that this issue is not dogmatic, it should overcome church divisions, not cause new ones, and in his opinion, the transition to celebrating Christmas in a new style — 25 December, should be initiated by the laity.
 
 About a hundred parishes of the [[Romanians in Ukraine|Romanian national minority in Ukraine]], which are part of the [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)|Ukrainian Orthodox Church of the Moscow Patriarchate]], have always celebrated Christmas on December 25 according to the [[Revised Julian calendar]], just like the [[Romanian Orthodox Church]].<ref name=":2">{{Cite news |last=Кралюк |first=Петро |date=2023-01-02 |title=«Є сподівання, що ПЦУ і УГКЦ перейдуть на святкування Різдва 25 грудня» – професор Петро Кралюк |language=uk |work=Радіо Свобода |url=https://www.radiosvoboda.org/a/rizdvo-tserkovnyy-kalendar/32201163.html |access-date=2023-03-27}}</ref>
comment: lead section text added to main body

Not Weaponised – The changes provide factual information about Ukrainian Christmas traditions and the recognition of December 25 as a holiday without employing divisive or inflammatory language.

The Ukrainian Christmas  festive days according to the Julian calendar, start on January 6th, Christmas Eve and ends with January 19th, "Jordan" or Epiphany.<ref>http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/</ref>

==Sviaty Vechir (Holy Evening)== 
<ref>http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html</ref>

{{Reflist}}
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -71,7 +71,7 @@
 [[File:Шопка_перед_львівською_ратушою.jpg|thumb|[[Nativity scene]].]]
 [[Christmas Eve]] on December 24 is called Sviatyi Vechir (''Святий вечір'') or Sviatvechir (''Святвечір'') in Ukraine ("Holy Evening"), and has many customs and rituals, most of which predate the introduction of Christianity to Ukraine. Traditions include decorating house and dinner table with special attributes (a symbolic sheaf of wheat called the ''[[didukh]]'', [[garlic]], hay, and others), performing [[Koliada|koliadky]] ('carols') and so on.  Each ritual has its own meaning and purpose, as such a few wisps of hay on the embroidered tablecloth as a reminder of the manger in [[Bethlehem]]. One prominent custom of the night is a special supper, called ''[[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|Sviata Vecheria]]'' ("Holy Supper").<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Nks04JbYUSgC&dq=sviata+vecheria&pg=PA33|last=World Book Inc.|title=Christmas in Ukraine|date=1997|location=Chicago|isbn=978-0-7166-0897-4|language=en}}</ref>
 
-Ukrainians of the OCU and UGCC fast on Sviatyi Vechir ([[Latin Church]] Catholics and Protestants may choose also to follow tradition on said day); only when the first star is seen in the evening sky, may the supper begin.  The family comes together to have a dinner which usually includes 12 dishes (the number can vary from 7–17). These [[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|twelve dishes]] are traditionally vegan plus fish, and do not contain meat, milk, or eggs.<ref>{{cite web |title=Christmas in Ukraine |url=https://www.whychristmas.com/cultures/ukraine.shtml |website=Why Christmas |access-date=14 December 2020}}</ref> While the dishes served can vary regionally, as well as from family to family, the two mandatory dishes are uzvar and kutia, both reckoned by ethnographer [[Fedir Vovk|Khvedir Vovk]] to be remnants of ancient rituals which date back to the neolithic era.<ref>{{cite web |title=Traditional Recipe of Ukrainian Kutia |url=https://etnocook.com/kutia/ |website=Ethnocook |date=18 January 2018 |access-date=27 November 2022}}</ref> [[Kutia]] (a dish of grain, honey and poppy seeds) is traditionally served first at the meal, after being offered by the head of the household to the frost. A spoonful is tossed at the ceiling, and in rural townships the number of poppy seeds which stick portends the bountyfulness of the fields, orchards and farm animals in the coming year. It is rarely served at other times of the year.<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html Sviat Vechir<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Uzvar is a beverage, made with cooked dried fruits and berries. It can be mixed in with the kutia, or served separately at the end of the meal.  Servings of both dishes are also set aside overnight in the pokuttia, the corner of the house with the Orthodox/Eastern Catholic icons or Latin Catholic images of saints, for deceased ancestors within the family or, in recent cases, for family members killed during the Russo-Ukrainian War (especially those who were KIA in the Armed Forces of Ukraine and other uniformed organizations).
+Ukrainians of the OCU and UGCC fast on Sviatyi Vechir ([[Latin Church]] Catholics and Protestants may choose also to follow tradition on said day); only when the first star is seen in the evening sky, may the supper begin.  The family comes together to have a dinner which usually includes 12 dishes (the number can vary from 7–17). These twelve dishes are traditionally vegan plus fish, and do not contain meat, milk, or eggs.<ref>{{cite web |title=Christmas in Ukraine |url=https://www.whychristmas.com/cultures/ukraine.shtml |website=Why Christmas |access-date=14 December 2020}}</ref> While the dishes served can vary regionally, as well as from family to family, the two mandatory dishes are uzvar and kutia, both reckoned by ethnographer [[Fedir Vovk|Khvedir Vovk]] to be remnants of ancient rituals which date back to the neolithic era.<ref>{{cite web |title=Traditional Recipe of Ukrainian Kutia |url=https://etnocook.com/kutia/ |website=Ethnocook |date=18 January 2018 |access-date=27 November 2022}}</ref> [[Kutia]] (a dish of grain, honey and poppy seeds) is traditionally served first at the meal, after being offered by the head of the household to the frost. A spoonful is tossed at the ceiling, and in rural townships the number of poppy seeds which stick portends the bountyfulness of the fields, orchards and farm animals in the coming year. It is rarely served at other times of the year.<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html Sviat Vechir<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Uzvar is a beverage, made with cooked dried fruits and berries. It can be mixed in with the kutia, or served separately at the end of the meal.  Servings of both dishes are also set aside overnight in the pokuttia, the corner of the house with the Orthodox/Eastern Catholic icons or Latin Catholic images of saints, for deceased ancestors within the family or, in recent cases, for family members killed during the Russo-Ukrainian War (especially those who were KIA in the Armed Forces of Ukraine and other uniformed organizations).
 
 The All-Night Christmas Vigil then follows, families then troop to their local parish churches or Protestant chruches to attend as thanksgiving for the Savior's birth in a stable.
llm_output:
The change made is the addition of a sentence that states, "Servings of both dishes are also set aside overnight in the pokuttia, the corner of the house with the Orthodox/Eastern Catholic icons or Latin Catholic images of saints, for deceased ancestors within the family or, in recent cases, for family members killed during the Russo-Ukrainian War (especially those who were KIA in the Armed Forces of Ukraine and other uniformed organizations)."

This addition highlights the cultural practice of honoring deceased family members, specifically mentioning those who died in the Russo-Ukrainian War, which can be seen as a way to frame the conflict within a cultural and emotional context.

**Weaponised**: The mention of the Russo-Ukrainian War and the specific reference to family members killed in the conflict serves to invoke a narrative of loss and victimization, potentially weaponizing cultural heritage by intertwining it with contemporary political and military issues.

@@ -59,7 +59,7 @@
 
 On February 2, 2023, the Holy Synod of the OCU allowed and approved the procedure for blessing parishes and monasteries for the full use of the Revised Julian calendar,<ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-02-02 |title=Decree of the Holy Synod on the procedure for blessing parishes and monasteries for the use of the Revised Julian calendar |url=https://www.pomisna.info/uk/vsi-novyny/postanova-svyashhennogo-synodu-pro-poryadok-nadannya-blagoslovennya-parafiyam-ta-monastyryam-na-vykorystannya-novoyulianskogo-kalendarya/ |access-date=2023-02-03 |website=OCU |language=uk}}</ref> and on May 24, 2023, to hold a meeting of the Council of Bishops, where the issue of calendar reform will be raised.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-02-02 |title=Official notice of the meeting of the Holy Synod on February 2, 2023. |url=https://www.pomisna.info/uk/vsi-novyny/ofitsijne-povidomlennya-pro-zasidannya-svyashhennogo-synodu-2-lyutogo-2023-r/ |access-date=2023-02-03 |website=OCU |language=uk}}</ref> 
 
-In February 2023 the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church|UGCC]] decided to switch to a new style ([[Revised Julian calendar]]) for fixed holidays (і.e., except for [[Date of Easter|Easter]]) from September 2023.<ref>{{Cite web |title=HISTORICAL DECISION: THE UGCC IN UKRAINE SWITCHES TO A NEW CALENDAR |url=https://ugcc.ua/en/data/historical-decision-the-ugcc-in-ukraine-switches-to-a-new-calendar-232/ |access-date=2023-07-19 |website=Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church |language=en}}</ref> [[Parish|Parishes]] of the UGCC that are not ready to switch to the new style in 2023 have a transition period until September 1, 2025 to make the change.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web |date=2023-02-06 |title=Ukraine Catholic Church moves from Russian-affiliated Julian calendar |url=https://www.pillarcatholic.com/ukraine-catholic-church-moves-from-russian/ |access-date=2023-02-06 |website=The Pillar |language=en}}</ref>
+In February 2023 the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church|UGCC]] decided to switch to a new style ([[Revised Julian calendar]]) for fixed holidays (і.e., except for [[Date of Easter|Easter]]) from September 2023.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Historical decision: the UGCC in Ukraine switches to a new calendar|url=https://ugcc.ua/en/data/historical-decision-the-ugcc-in-ukraine-switches-to-a-new-calendar-232/ |access-date=2023-07-19 |website=Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church |language=en}}</ref> [[Parish|Parishes]] of the UGCC that are not ready to switch to the new style in 2023 have a transition period until September 1, 2025 to make the change.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web |date=2023-02-06 |title=Ukraine Catholic Church moves from Russian-affiliated Julian calendar |url=https://www.pillarcatholic.com/ukraine-catholic-church-moves-from-russian/ |access-date=2023-02-06 |website=The Pillar |language=en}}</ref>
 
 Effective 24 May 2023, the OCU officially declared that 25 December will be the permanent date for Christmas commemorations and festivities for the Ukrainian Orthodox faithful, as the Church officially formalized the adoption of the Revised Julian calendar for fixed feasts and solemnities in line with the other Orthodox churches of the world, with Easter kept in the old Julian Calendar.<ref>{{Cite news |last=RFE/RL |title=Orthodox Church Of Ukraine Approves Calendar Switch In Widening Diversion From Russia |language=en |work=RadioFreeEurope/RadioLiberty |url=https://www.rferl.org/a/orthodox-church-ukraine-approves-calendar-switch-russia/32426292.html |access-date=2023-06-18}}</ref><ref name=":4">{{Cite web |date=2023-05-24 |title=Orthodox Church of Ukraine to switch to Revised Julian calendar, celebrate Christmas on Dec. 25 |url=https://kyivindependent.com/orthodox-church-of-ukraine-to-switch-to-revised-julian-calendar-celebrate-christmas-on-dec-25/ |access-date=2023-06-18 |website=The Kyiv Independent |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Orthodox Church of Ukraine Decides to Celebrate Christmas on Dec. 25 |url=https://www.kyivpost.com/post/17460 |access-date=2023-06-18 |website=Get the Latest Ukraine News Today – KyivPost |language=en}}</ref> On July 27, the [[Council of Kyiv (2023)|Local Council]] approved the transition.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Orthodox Church of Ukraine finally adopts new calendar |url=https://english.nv.ua/life/ocu-approves-switch-to-revised-julian-calendar-ukraine-news-50342167.html |access-date=2023-07-31 |website=english.nv.ua |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |last=Свобода |first=Радіо |date=2023-05-24 |title=ПЦУ схвалила перехід на новий календар: Різдво – 25 грудня |website=Радіо Свобода |url=https://www.radiosvoboda.org/a/news-ptsu-novyy-kalendar/32425658.html |accessdate=2023-05-24}}</ref>

The phrase "HISTORICAL DECISION: THE UGCC IN UKRAINE SWITCHES TO A NEW CALENDAR" was changed to "Historical decision: the UGCC in Ukraine switches to a new calendar."

Not Weaponised. The change is stylistic and does not introduce any weaponised language or narratives related to cultural heritage.

@@ -79,7 +79,7 @@
 
 The All-Night Christmas Vigil then follows, families then troop to their local parish churches or Protestant chruches to attend as thanksgiving for the Savior's birth in a stable.
 
-==''Koliadky'' (caroling)==
+==''Koliadky'' (Caroling)==
 At the end of the {{lang|uk|Sviata Vechera}}, and the [[vigil]] that follows, Ukrainian families often sing carols ({{lang|uk|koliadky}}). In some communities the ancient Ukrainian tradition of caroling is carried on by groups of young people and members of organizations and churches calling at homes and collecting donations. Well-known carols include ''{{ill|Nova radist stala|lt=|uk|Нова радість стала|display=1}}'', [[Boh predvičnyj narodivsja|''Boh predvichnyi narodyvsia'']],<ref name=Met>{{cite web|title=Boh predvičnyj|url=http://mci.archpitt.org/legacy/songs/Slavonic/Boh_predvicnyj.html|website=Metropolitan Cantor Institute|publisher=Byzantine Catholic|access-date=12 August 2015|ref=Archeparchy of Pittsburgh|archive-date=4 March 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304235614/http://mci.archpitt.org/legacy/songs/Slavonic/Boh_predvicnyj.html|url-status=dead}}</ref> ''{{ill|Dobryi vechir tobi, pane hospodariu|lt=|uk|Добрий вечір тобі, пане господарю|display=1}}'', ''{{ill|Vo Vyfleiemi nyni novyna|lt=|uk|Во Вифлеємі нині новина|display=1}}'', ''{{ill|Nebo i zemlia nyni torzhestvuiut|lt=|uk|Небо і земля нині торжествують|display=1}}'', and ''{{ill|Boh sia rozhdaie|lt=|uk|Бог ся раджае|display=1}}''.

@@ -72,7 +72,7 @@
 According to a study conducted by the international company [[Deloitte]] in November 2023, after the transition of Ukrainian Christian churches to the new style, the majority of [[Ukrainians]] (about 45%) will celebrate Christmas on December 25 and only 17% on January 7, and 32% plan to celebrate twice.<ref>{{Cite web |title=More donations to the Armed Forces, new traditions and the continuation of the boycott of sellers still working in the Russian Federation – Deloitte research on New Year's shopping of Ukrainians |url=https://www2.deloitte.com/ua/uk/pages/press-room/press-release/2023/holiday-retail-sales-consumer-survey.html |accessdate=2023-12-13 |website="Deloitte" in Ukraine |language=uk}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-12-08 |title=The vast majority of Ukrainians will celebrate Christmas on December 25 – survey |url=https://religionpravda.com.ua/?p=90196 |accessdate=2023-12-13 |website=Religious Pravda |language=uk}}</ref>  In 2023, for the first time since 1917, [[Christmas Day]] in Ukraine will officially be on December 25th.<ref name="BBC">{{cite news |last1=Waterhouse |first1=James |title=Ukraine war: New Christmas date marks shift away from Russia |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-67801204 |access-date=24 December 2023 |work=[[BBC News]] |date=23 December 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231223231729/https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-67801204 |archive-date=23 December 2023}}</ref>
 
 ==Sviatyi Vechir (Holy Evening)==
-[[File:Шопка_перед_львівською_ратушою.jpg|thumb|[[Nativity scene]].]]
+[[File:Шопка_перед_львівською_ратушою.jpg|thumb|[[Nativity scene]]]]
 [[Christmas Eve]] on December 24 is called Sviatyi Vechir (''Святий вечір'') or Sviatvechir (''Святвечір'') in Ukraine ("Holy Evening"), and has many customs and rituals, most of which predate the introduction of Christianity to Ukraine. Traditions include decorating house and dinner table with special attributes (a symbolic sheaf of wheat called the ''[[didukh]]'', [[garlic]], hay, and others), performing [[Koliada|koliadky]] ('carols') and so on.  Each ritual has its own meaning and purpose, as such a few wisps of hay on the embroidered tablecloth as a reminder of the manger in [[Bethlehem]]. One prominent custom of the night is a special supper, called ''[[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|Sviata Vecheria]]'' ("Holy Supper").<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Nks04JbYUSgC&dq=sviata+vecheria&pg=PA33|last=World Book Inc.|title=Christmas in Ukraine|date=1997|location=Chicago|isbn=978-0-7166-0897-4|language=en}}</ref>
 
 Ukrainians of the OCU and UGCC fast on Sviatyi Vechir ([[Latin Church]] Catholics and Protestants may choose also to follow tradition on said day); only when the first star is seen in the evening sky, may the supper begin.  The family comes together to have a dinner which usually includes 12 dishes (the number can vary from 7–17). These twelve dishes are traditionally vegan plus fish, and do not contain meat, milk, or eggs.<ref>{{cite web |title=Christmas in Ukraine |url=https://www.whychristmas.com/cultures/ukraine.shtml |website=Why Christmas |access-date=14 December 2020}}</ref> While the dishes served can vary regionally, as well as from family to family, the two mandatory dishes are uzvar and kutia, both reckoned by ethnographer [[Fedir Vovk|Khvedir Vovk]] to be remnants of ancient rituals which date back to the neolithic era.<ref>{{cite web |title=Traditional Recipe of Ukrainian Kutia |url=https://etnocook.com/kutia/ |website=Ethnocook |date=18 January 2018 |access-date=27 November 2022}}</ref> [[Kutia]] (a dish of grain, honey and poppy seeds) is traditionally served first at the meal, after being offered by the head of the household to the frost. A spoonful is tossed at the ceiling, and in rural townships the number of poppy seeds which stick portends the bountyfulness of the fields, orchards and farm animals in the coming year. It is rarely served at other times of the year.<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html Sviat Vechir<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Uzvar is a beverage, made with cooked dried fruits and berries. It can be mixed in with the kutia, or served separately at the end of the meal.  Servings of both dishes are also set aside overnight in the pokuttia, the corner of the house with the Orthodox/Eastern Catholic icons or Latin Catholic images of saints, for deceased ancestors within the family or, in recent cases, for family members killed during the Russo-Ukrainian War (especially those who were KIA in the Armed Forces of Ukraine and other uniformed organizations).

 ==''Koliadky'' (caroling)==
-At the end of the Sviata Vechera dinner, and the vigil that follows, the family often sings carols (''koliadky'', singular ''koliadka''). In many communities the ancient Ukrainian tradition of caroling is carried on by groups of young people and members of organizations and churches calling at homes and collecting donations. A well-known carol is ''{{ill|Nova radist stala|lt=|uk|Нова радість стала|display=1}}'', [[Boh predvičnyj narodivsja|''Boh predvichnyi narodyvsia'']],<ref name=BLiturgy>{{cite web|title=Boh predvičnyj|url=http://mci.archpitt.org/legacy/songs/Slavonic/Boh_predvicnyj.html|website=Metropolitan Cantor Institute|publisher=Byzantine Catholic|access-date=12 August 2015|ref=Archeparchy of Pittsburgh|archive-date=4 March 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304235614/http://mci.archpitt.org/legacy/songs/Slavonic/Boh_predvicnyj.html|url-status=dead}}</ref> ''{{ill|Dobryi vechir tobi, pane hospodariu|lt=|uk|Добрий вечір тобі, пане господарю|display=1}}'', ''{{ill|Vo Vyfleiemi nyni novyna|lt=|uk|Во Вифлеємі нині новина|display=1}}'', ''{{ill|Nebo i zemlia nyni torzhestvuiut|lt=|uk|Небо і земля нині торжествують|display=1}}'', ''{{ill|Boh sia rozhdaie|lt=|uk|Бог ся раджае|display=1}}'' etc.
+At the end of the {{lang|uk|Sviata Vechera}}, and the [[vigil]] that follows, Ukrainian families often sing carols ({{lang|uk|koliadky}}). In some communities the ancient Ukrainian tradition of caroling is carried on by groups of young people and members of organizations and churches calling at homes and collecting donations. Well-known carols include ''{{ill|Nova radist stala|lt=|uk|Нова радість стала|display=1}}'', [[Boh predvičnyj narodivsja|''Boh predvichnyi narodyvsia'']],<ref name=Met>{{cite web|title=Boh predvičnyj|url=http://mci.archpitt.org/legacy/songs/Slavonic/Boh_predvicnyj.html|website=Metropolitan Cantor Institute|publisher=Byzantine Catholic|access-date=12 August 2015|ref=Archeparchy of Pittsburgh|archive-date=4 March 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304235614/http://mci.archpitt.org/legacy/songs/Slavonic/Boh_predvicnyj.html|url-status=dead}}</ref> ''{{ill|Dobryi vechir tobi, pane hospodariu|lt=|uk|Добрий вечір тобі, пане господарю|display=1}}'', ''{{ill|Vo Vyfleiemi nyni novyna|lt=|uk|Во Вифлеємі нині новина|display=1}}'', ''{{ill|Nebo i zemlia nyni torzhestvuiut|lt=|uk|Небо і земля нині торжествують|display=1}}'', and ''{{ill|Boh sia rozhdaie|lt=|uk|Бог ся раджае|display=1}}''.
 
 ==''Didukh'' (grandfather)==
 In villages (farming communities), the head of the household brings in a sheaf of grain called the ''didukh'' which represents the importance of the ancient and rich wheat crops of Ukraine, the staff of life through the centuries. Didukh means literally "grandfather spirit" so it symbolizes the family's ancestors. In Ukrainian city homes the didukh may be purchased, and is often three footed made of woven grain and dried grasses and flowers.

 == Date of celebration ==
 [[File:Diduch-Lviv.jpg|thumb|A [[didukh]] in [[Lviv]]]]
-As of 2017, 25 December, Christmas Day by the [[Gregorian calendar|Gregorian]] calendar, became an official government holiday in Ukraine. The [[Eastern Orthodox Church]]es predominantly follow the Julian calendar, and 7 January is also a [[Public holidays in Ukraine|public holiday in Ukraine]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://m.digitaljournal.com/news/world/ukraine-seeks-distance-from-moscow-with-new-christmas-holiday/article/507753|title=Ukraine seeks distance from Moscow with new Christmas holiday|website=m.digitaljournal.com|date=16 November 2017|access-date=2017-11-16}}</ref><ref>{{in lang|uk}} {{Cite news|url=http://www.bbc.com/ukrainian/news-42008437|title=Рада зробила 25 грудня вихідним днем|date=2017-11-16|work=BBC Україна|access-date=2017-11-16|language=en-GB}}</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine]], [[Epiphanius I of Ukraine|Metropolitan Epiphanius]], said that changing the date of Christmas to 25 December in Ukraine is possible after both the church and the faithful are ready for such a decision, after conducting educational work. It was stated that the postponement of the celebration of the nativity of the lord would entail a change in the dates of all fixed holidays to 13 days ago.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://news.rbc.ua/ukr/politics/epifaniy-nazval-uslovie-perenosa-prazdnovaniya-1608382147.html|title = Епіфаній назвав умову перенесення святкування Різдва на 25 грудня}}</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church]] (UGCC), [[Sviatoslav Shevchuk|Patriarch Sviatoslav]], stated that the Greek Catholic Church would resolve this issue "together with our Orthodox brothers". He also noted that this issue is not dogmatic, it should overcome church divisions, not cause new ones, and in his opinion, the transition to celebrating Christmas in a new style — 25 December, should be initiated by the laity.
+As of 2017, 25 December, Christmas Day by the [[Gregorian calendar|Gregorian]] calendar, became an official government holiday in Ukraine. The [[Eastern Orthodox Church]]es predominantly follow the Julian calendar, and 7 January is also a [[Public holidays in Ukraine|public holiday in Ukraine]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://m.digitaljournal.com/news/world/ukraine-seeks-distance-from-moscow-with-new-christmas-holiday/article/507753|title=Ukraine seeks distance from Moscow with new Christmas holiday|website=m.digitaljournal.com|date=16 November 2017|access-date=2017-11-16|archive-date=17 November 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171117065016/http://m.digitaljournal.com/news/world/ukraine-seeks-distance-from-moscow-with-new-christmas-holiday/article/507753|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref>{{in lang|uk}} {{Cite news|url=http://www.bbc.com/ukrainian/news-42008437|title=Рада зробила 25 грудня вихідним днем|date=2017-11-16|work=BBC Україна|access-date=2017-11-16|language=en-GB}}</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine]], [[Epiphanius I of Ukraine|Metropolitan Epiphanius]], said that changing the date of Christmas to 25 December in Ukraine is possible after both the church and the faithful are ready for such a decision, after conducting educational work. It was stated that the postponement of the celebration of the nativity of the lord would entail a change in the dates of all fixed holidays to 13 days ago.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://news.rbc.ua/ukr/politics/epifaniy-nazval-uslovie-perenosa-prazdnovaniya-1608382147.html|title = Епіфаній назвав умову перенесення святкування Різдва на 25 грудня}}</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church]] (UGCC), [[Sviatoslav Shevchuk|Patriarch Sviatoslav]], stated that the Greek Catholic Church would resolve this issue "together with our Orthodox brothers". He also noted that this issue is not dogmatic, it should overcome church divisions, not cause new ones, and in his opinion, the transition to celebrating Christmas in a new style — 25 December, should be initiated by the laity.
 
 About a hundred parishes of the [[Romanians in Ukraine|Romanian national minority in Ukraine]], which are part of the [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)|Ukrainian Orthodox Church of the Moscow Patriarchate]], have always celebrated Christmas on December 25 according to the [[Revised Julian calendar]], just like the [[Romanian Orthodox Church]].<ref name=":2">{{Cite news |last=Кралюк |first=Петро |date=2023-01-02 |title=«Є сподівання, що ПЦУ і УГКЦ перейдуть на святкування Різдва 25 грудня» – професор Петро Кралюк |language=uk |work=Радіо Свобода |url=https://www.radiosvoboda.org/a/rizdvo-tserkovnyy-kalendar/32201163.html |access-date=2023-03-27}}</ref>
 
 On 18 October 2022, the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine]] allowed dioceses to hold Christmas services according to the [[Revised Julian calendar]], i.e., 25 December. In the case of a divine service, its participants are released from the restrictions of fasting on this day.<ref>{{Cite web |title=OCU allowed Christmas services on December 25 |url=https://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2022/10/18/7372478/ |accessdate=2022-10-18 |website=[[Ukrainian Pravda]] |language=uk}}</ref>
 
-On 24 December 2022, during an [[audience]], [[Major Archbishop]] Sviatoslav handed over to [[Metropolitan of Kyiv and All Ukraine|Metropolitan]] [[Epiphanius I of Ukraine|Epiphanius]] for review a letter outlining the considerations of the UGCC hierarchs regarding the {{ill|Calendar reform in Ukraine|lt=calendar reform|uk|Календарна реформа в Україні|display=1}}. The primates decided to create a joint working group on specific proposals for calendar reform. The joint group is initiated on the occasion of the celebration of the 1700th anniversary of the [[First Council of Nicaea|First Ecumenical Council]], held in [[Nicaea]] in 325. In this [[Ecumenical council|Council]], in particular, the calendar principles of church life were determined.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Heads of OCU, UGCC agree to set up working group to reform church calendar |url=https://www.ukrinform.net/rubric-society/3640576-heads-of-ocu-ugcc-agree-to-set-up-working-group-to-reform-church-calendar.html |access-date=2022-12-24 |website=www.ukrinform.net |date=24 December 2022 |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=During the meeting of His Beatitude Sviatoslav with His Beatitude Epiphanius, they talked about the reform of the church calendar |url=https://news.ugcc.ua/data/pid-chas-zustrichi-blazhennishogo-svyatoslava-z-blazhennishym-epifaniem-govoryly-pro-reformu-tserkovnogo-kalendarya-1713/ |access-date=2022-12-24 |website=Українська Греко-Католицька Церква |language=uk}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2022-12-24 |title=There was a meeting of the Primate of the OCU with the Father and the Primate of the UGCC |url=https://www.pomisna.info/uk/vsi-novyny/vidbulasya-zustrich-predstoyatelya-ptsu-z-ottsem-i-glavoyu-ugkts/ |access-date=2022-12-24 |website=OCU |language=uk}}</ref>
+On 24 December 2022, during an [[audience]], [[Major Archbishop]] Sviatoslav handed over to [[Metropolitan of Kyiv and All Ukraine|Metropolitan]] [[Epiphanius I of Ukraine|Epiphanius]] for review a letter outlining the considerations of the UGCC hierarchs regarding the {{ill|Calendar reform in Ukraine|lt=calendar reform|uk|Календарна реформа в Україні|display=1}}. The primates decided to create a joint working group on specific proposals for calendar reform. The joint group is initiated on the occasion of the celebration of the 1700th anniversary of the [[First Council of Nicaea|First Ecumenical Council]], held in [[Nicaea]] in 325. In this [[Ecumenical council|Council]], in particular, the calendar principles of church life were determined.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Heads of OCU, UGCC agree to set up working group to reform church calendar |url=https://www.ukrinform.net/rubric-society/3640576-heads-of-ocu-ugcc-agree-to-set-up-working-group-to-reform-church-calendar.html |access-date=2022-12-24 |website=www.ukrinform.net |date=24 December 2022 |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=During the meeting of His Beatitude Sviatoslav with His Beatitude Epiphanius, they talked about the reform of the church calendar |url=https://news.ugcc.ua/data/pid-chas-zustrichi-blazhennishogo-svyatoslava-z-blazhennishym-epifaniem-govoryly-pro-reformu-tserkovnogo-kalendarya-1713/ |access-date=2022-12-24 |website=Українська Греко-Католицька Церква |language=uk |archive-date=24 December 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221224150917/https://news.ugcc.ua/data/pid-chas-zustrichi-blazhennishogo-svyatoslava-z-blazhennishym-epifaniem-govoryly-pro-reformu-tserkovnogo-kalendarya-1713/ |url-status=dead }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2022-12-24 |title=There was a meeting of the Primate of the OCU with the Father and the Primate of the UGCC |url=https://www.pomisna.info/uk/vsi-novyny/vidbulasya-zustrich-predstoyatelya-ptsu-z-ottsem-i-glavoyu-ugkts/ |access-date=2022-12-24 |website=OCU |language=uk}}</ref>
 
 On February 2, 2023, the Holy Synod of the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine|OCU]] allowed and approved the procedure for blessing parishes and monasteries for the full use of the [[Revised Julian calendar]],<ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-02-02 |title=Decree of the Holy Synod on the procedure for blessing parishes and monasteries for the use of the Revised Julian calendar |url=https://www.pomisna.info/uk/vsi-novyny/postanova-svyashhennogo-synodu-pro-poryadok-nadannya-blagoslovennya-parafiyam-ta-monastyryam-na-vykorystannya-novoyulianskogo-kalendarya/ |access-date=2023-02-03 |website=OCU |language=uk}}</ref> and on May 24, 2023, to hold a meeting of the Council of Bishops, where the issue of calendar reform will be raised.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-02-02 |title=Official notice of the meeting of the Holy Synod on February 2, 2023. |url=https://www.pomisna.info/uk/vsi-novyny/ofitsijne-povidomlennya-pro-zasidannya-svyashhennogo-synodu-2-lyutogo-2023-r/ |access-date=2023-02-03 |website=OCU |language=uk}}</ref>

initial_version:
The Ukrainian Christmas  festive days according to the Julian calendar, start on January 6th, Christmas Eve and ends with January 19th, "Jordan" or Epiphany.<ref>http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/</ref>

==Sviaty Vechir (Holy Evening)== 
<ref>http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html</ref>





==Koliadky - (Caroling)==


==Did Moroz - (Grandfather Frost)==



{{Reflist}}
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -51,7 +51,7 @@
 
 == Date of celebration ==
 [[File:Diduch-Lviv.jpg|thumb|A [[didukh]] in [[Lviv]]]]
-Traditional Ukrainian Christmas festivities last from December 24 to January 6, the date of the celebration of the [[baptism of Jesus]], which known in Ukraine as {{lang|uk|Vodokhreshche}} or ''{{lang|uk|Yordan}}'',<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/ Christmas Traditions<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> according to the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine]] (OCU),<ref name=":4" /> the [[Catholic Church in Ukraine|Catholic Church]] (including [[Latin Church in Ukraine|Latin]] and [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church|Ukrainian Greek Catholics]]<ref name=":3" />), and most [[Protestantism in Ukraine|Protestants]].
+Traditional Ukrainian Christmas festivities last from December 24 to January 6, the date of the celebration of the [[baptism of Jesus]], which known in Ukraine as {{lang|uk|Vodokhreshche}} or ''{{lang|uk|Yordan}}'',<ref name="UFA">{{cite web |title=Christmas Traditions of Ukraine |url=http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/ |publisher=Ukrainian Fraternal Association |access-date=24 December 2023}}</ref> according to the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine]] (OCU),<ref name=":4" /> the [[Catholic Church in Ukraine|Catholic Church]] (including [[Latin Church in Ukraine|Latin]] and [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church|Ukrainian Greek Catholics]]<ref name=":3" />), and most [[Protestantism in Ukraine|Protestants]].
 
 As of 2017, 25 December, Christmas Day by the [[Gregorian calendar|Gregorian]] calendar, became an official government holiday in Ukraine. The [[Eastern Orthodox Church]]es predominantly follow the Julian calendar, and 7 January is also a [[Public holidays in Ukraine|public holiday in Ukraine]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://m.digitaljournal.com/news/world/ukraine-seeks-distance-from-moscow-with-new-christmas-holiday/article/507753|title=Ukraine seeks distance from Moscow with new Christmas holiday|website=m.digitaljournal.com|date=16 November 2017|access-date=2017-11-16|archive-date=17 November 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171117065016/http://m.digitaljournal.com/news/world/ukraine-seeks-distance-from-moscow-with-new-christmas-holiday/article/507753|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref>{{in lang|uk}} {{Cite news|url=http://www.bbc.com/ukrainian/news-42008437|title=Рада зробила 25 грудня вихідним днем|date=2017-11-16|work=BBC Україна|access-date=2017-11-16|language=en-GB}}</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine]] (OCU), [[Epiphanius I of Ukraine|Metropolitan Epiphanius]], said that changing the date of Christmas to 25 December in Ukraine is possible after both the church and the faithful are ready for such a decision, after conducting educational work. It was stated that the postponement of the celebration of the nativity of The Lord would entail a change in the dates of all fixed holidays to 13 days ago.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://news.rbc.ua/ukr/politics/epifaniy-nazval-uslovie-perenosa-prazdnovaniya-1608382147.html|title = Епіфаній назвав умову перенесення святкування Різдва на 25 грудня}}</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church]] (UGCC), [[Sviatoslav Shevchuk|Patriarch Sviatoslav]], stated that the Greek Catholic Church would resolve this issue "together with our Orthodox brothers". He also noted that this issue is not dogmatic, it should overcome church divisions, not cause new ones, and in his opinion, the transition to celebrating Christmas in a new style — 25 December, should be initiated by the laity.

Changed the reference for the source of information regarding the date of celebration of Ukrainian Christmas festivities.

Not Weaponised. The change is a citation update that does not alter the narrative or introduce any weaponised language.

initial_version:
The Ukrainian Christmas  festive days according to the Julian calendar, start on January 6th, Christmas Eve and ends with January 19th, "Jordan" or Epiphany.<ref>http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/</ref>
