{{Reflist}}
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -65,7 +65,7 @@
 
 In February 2023 the UGCC decided to switch to the Revised Julian calendar for fixed holidays (і.e., except for [[Date of Easter|Easter]]) from September 2023.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Historical decision: the UGCC in Ukraine switches to a new calendar|url=https://ugcc.ua/en/data/historical-decision-the-ugcc-in-ukraine-switches-to-a-new-calendar-232/ |access-date=2023-07-19 |website=Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church |language=en}}</ref> [[Parish|Parishes]] of the UGCC that are not ready to switch to the new style in 2023 have a transition period until September 1, 2025 to make the change.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web |date=2023-02-06 |title=Ukraine Catholic Church moves from Russian-affiliated Julian calendar |url=https://www.pillarcatholic.com/ukraine-catholic-church-moves-from-russian/ |access-date=2023-02-06 |website=The Pillar |language=en}}</ref>
 
-Effective 24 May 2023, the OCU officially declared that 25 December will be the permanent date for Christmas commemorations and festivities for the Ukrainian Orthodox faithful, as the Church officially formalized the adoption of the Revised Julian calendar for fixed feasts and solemnities in line with the other Orthodox churches of the world, with Easter kept in the old Julian Calendar.<ref>{{Cite news |last=RFE/RL |title=Orthodox Church Of Ukraine Approves Calendar Switch In Widening Diversion From Russia |language=en |work=RadioFreeEurope/RadioLiberty |url=https://www.rferl.org/a/orthodox-church-ukraine-approves-calendar-switch-russia/32426292.html |access-date=2023-06-18}}</ref><ref name=":4">{{Cite web |date=2023-05-24 |title=Orthodox Church of Ukraine to switch to Revised Julian calendar, celebrate Christmas on Dec. 25 |url=https://kyivindependent.com/orthodox-church-of-ukraine-to-switch-to-revised-julian-calendar-celebrate-christmas-on-dec-25/ |access-date=2023-06-18 |website=The Kyiv Independent |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Orthodox Church of Ukraine Decides to Celebrate Christmas on Dec. 25 |url=https://www.kyivpost.com/post/17460 |access-date=2023-06-18 |website=Get the Latest Ukraine News Today – KyivPost |language=en}}</ref> On July 27, the [[Council of Kyiv (2023)|Local Council]] approved the transition.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Orthodox Church of Ukraine finally adopts new calendar |url=https://english.nv.ua/life/ocu-approves-switch-to-revised-julian-calendar-ukraine-news-50342167.html |access-date=2023-07-31 |website=english.nv.ua |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |last=Свобода |first=Радіо |date=2023-05-24 |title=ПЦУ схвалила перехід на новий календар: Різдво – 25 грудня |website=Радіо Свобода |url=https://www.radiosvoboda.org/a/news-ptsu-novyy-kalendar/32425658.html |accessdate=2023-05-24}}</ref>
+Effective 24 May 2023, the OCU officially declared that 25 December will be the permanent date for Christmas commemorations and festivities for the Ukrainian Orthodox faithful, as the Church officially formalized the adoption of the Revised Julian calendar for fixed feasts and solemnities in line with the other Orthodox churches of the world, with Easter kept in the old Julian Calendar.<ref>{{Cite news |last=RFE/RL |title=Orthodox Church Of Ukraine Approves Calendar Switch In Widening Diversion From Russia |language=en |work=RadioFreeEurope/RadioLiberty |url=https://www.rferl.org/a/orthodox-church-ukraine-approves-calendar-switch-russia/32426292.html |access-date=2023-06-18}}</ref><ref name=":4">{{Cite web |date=2023-05-24 |title=Orthodox Church of Ukraine to switch to Revised Julian calendar, celebrate Christmas on Dec. 25 |url=https://kyivindependent.com/orthodox-church-of-ukraine-to-switch-to-revised-julian-calendar-celebrate-christmas-on-dec-25/ |access-date=2023-06-18 |website=The Kyiv Independent |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Orthodox Church of Ukraine Decides to Celebrate Christmas on Dec. 25 |url=https://www.kyivpost.com/post/17460 |access-date=2023-06-18 |website=Get the Latest Ukraine News Today – KyivPost |language=en}}</ref> On July 27, the [[Council of Kyiv (2023)|Local Council]] approved the transition.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Orthodox Church of Ukraine finally adopts new calendar |url=https://english.nv.ua/life/ocu-approves-switch-to-revised-julian-calendar-ukraine-news-50342167.html |access-date=2023-07-31 |website=english.nv.ua |language=en}}</ref>
 
 On 28 June 2023 [[President of Ukraine]], [[Volodymyr Zelenskyy]], submitted to the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (Ukraine's national parliament) a draft law removing the Julian Calendar Christmas holiday on January 7 and confirming the December 25 date as the sole day of celebrations, reflecting changes in the OCU and UGCC calendars.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Zelensky Introduces Proposed Draft Law to Change Holiday Dates |url=https://www.kyivpost.com/post/18846 |access-date=2023-06-29 |website=Get the Latest Ukraine News Today – KyivPost |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-06-28 |title=Zelensky submitted to the Verkhovna Rada a law on changing holiday dates |url=https://babel.ua/en/news/95649-zelensky-submitted-to-the-verkhovna-rada-a-law-on-changing-holiday-dates |access-date=2023-06-29 |website=babel.ua |language=en}}</ref> Parliament passed this law on 14 July 2023 with 241 deputies voting in the affirmative.<ref name="3735767ChristmasUA">{{Cite web |date=2023-07-14 |title=Parliament changes dates of Christmas, Statehood Day, Day of Defenders |url=https://www.ukrinform.net/rubric-society/3735767-parliament-changes-dates-of-three-holidays-christmas-statehood-day-day-of-defenders-of-ukraine.html |access-date=2023-07-14 |website=[[Ukrinform]] |language=en}}</ref> Zelensky signed the law on 28 July 2023.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cnn.com/2023/07/29/europe/ukraine-christmas-date-change-intl/index.html|last1 = Toropin | first1 = Konstantin | last2 = Stambaugh | first2 = Alex | title = Ukraine moves Christmas to December 25, distancing itself from Russian tradition | website = Cable News Network | date = 29 July 2023 | accessdate = 1 August 2023}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-07-29 |title=Ukraine moves official Christmas Day holiday to Dec. 25, denouncing Russian-imposed traditions |url=https://apnews.com/article/russia-ukraine-war-christmas-orthodox-church-calendar-b658c9ebecc91a470866c34b1c1847eb |access-date=2023-07-31 |website=AP News |language=en}}</ref>

 On 28 June 2023 [[President of Ukraine]], [[Volodymyr Zelenskyy]], submitted to the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (Ukraine's national parliament) a draft law removing the Julian Calendar Christmas holiday on January 7 and confirming the December 25 date as the sole day of celebrations, reflecting changes in the OCU and UGCC calendars.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Zelensky Introduces Proposed Draft Law to Change Holiday Dates |url=https://www.kyivpost.com/post/18846 |access-date=2023-06-29 |website=Get the Latest Ukraine News Today – KyivPost |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-06-28 |title=Zelensky submitted to the Verkhovna Rada a law on changing holiday dates |url=https://babel.ua/en/news/95649-zelensky-submitted-to-the-verkhovna-rada-a-law-on-changing-holiday-dates |access-date=2023-06-29 |website=babel.ua |language=en}}</ref> Parliament passed this law on 14 July 2023 with 241 deputies voting in the affirmative.<ref name="3735767ChristmasUA">{{Cite web |date=2023-07-14 |title=Parliament changes dates of Christmas, Statehood Day, Day of Defenders |url=https://www.ukrinform.net/rubric-society/3735767-parliament-changes-dates-of-three-holidays-christmas-statehood-day-day-of-defenders-of-ukraine.html |access-date=2023-07-14 |website=[[Ukrinform]] |language=en}}</ref> Zelensky signed the law on 28 July 2023.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cnn.com/2023/07/29/europe/ukraine-christmas-date-change-intl/index.html|last1 = Toropin | first1 = Konstantin | last2 = Stambaugh | first2 = Alex | title = Ukraine moves Christmas to December 25, distancing itself from Russian tradition | website = Cable News Network | date = 29 July 2023 | accessdate = 1 August 2023}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-07-29 |title=Ukraine moves official Christmas Day holiday to Dec. 25, denouncing Russian-imposed traditions |url=https://apnews.com/article/russia-ukraine-war-christmas-orthodox-church-calendar-b658c9ebecc91a470866c34b1c1847eb |access-date=2023-07-31 |website=AP News |language=en}}</ref>

changed_version:

@@ -53,7 +53,7 @@
 [[File:Diduch-Lviv.jpg|thumb|A [[didukh]] in [[Lviv]]]]
 Traditional Ukrainian Christmas festivities last from December 24 to January 6, the date of the celebration of the [[baptism of Jesus]], which known in Ukraine as {{lang|uk|Vodokhreshche}} or ''{{lang|uk|Yordan}}'',<ref name="UFA">{{cite web |title=Christmas Traditions of Ukraine |url=http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/ |publisher=Ukrainian Fraternal Association |access-date=24 December 2023}}</ref> according to the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine]] (OCU),<ref name=":4" /> the [[Catholic Church in Ukraine|Catholic Church]] (including [[Latin Church in Ukraine|Latin]] and [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church|Ukrainian Greek Catholics]]<ref name=":3" />), and most [[Protestantism in Ukraine|Protestants]].
 
-As of 2017, 25 December, Christmas Day by the [[Gregorian calendar|Gregorian]] calendar, became an official government holiday in Ukraine. The [[Eastern Orthodox Church]]es predominantly follow the Julian calendar, and 7 January is also a [[Public holidays in Ukraine|public holiday in Ukraine]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://m.digitaljournal.com/news/world/ukraine-seeks-distance-from-moscow-with-new-christmas-holiday/article/507753|title=Ukraine seeks distance from Moscow with new Christmas holiday|website=m.digitaljournal.com|date=16 November 2017|access-date=2017-11-16|archive-date=17 November 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171117065016/http://m.digitaljournal.com/news/world/ukraine-seeks-distance-from-moscow-with-new-christmas-holiday/article/507753|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref>{{in lang|uk}} {{Cite news|url=http://www.bbc.com/ukrainian/news-42008437|title=Рада зробила 25 грудня вихідним днем|date=2017-11-16|work=BBC Україна|access-date=2017-11-16|language=en-GB}}</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine]] (OCU), [[Epiphanius I of Ukraine|Metropolitan Epiphanius]], said that changing the date of Christmas to 25 December in Ukraine is possible after both the church and the faithful are ready for such a decision, after conducting educational work. It was stated that the postponement of the celebration of the nativity of The Lord would entail a change in the dates of all fixed holidays to 13 days ago.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://news.rbc.ua/ukr/politics/epifaniy-nazval-uslovie-perenosa-prazdnovaniya-1608382147.html|title = Епіфаній назвав умову перенесення святкування Різдва на 25 грудня}}</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church]] (UGCC), [[Sviatoslav Shevchuk|Patriarch Sviatoslav]], stated that the Greek Catholic Church would resolve this issue "together with our Orthodox brothers". He also noted that this issue is not dogmatic, it should overcome church divisions, not cause new ones, and in his opinion, the transition to celebrating Christmas in a new style — 25 December, should be initiated by the laity.
+As of 2017, 25 December, Christmas Day by the [[Gregorian calendar|Gregorian]] calendar, became an official government holiday in Ukraine. The [[Eastern Orthodox Church]]es predominantly follow the Julian calendar, and 7 January is also a [[Public holidays in Ukraine|public holiday in Ukraine]].<ref>{{in lang|uk}} {{Cite news|url=http://www.bbc.com/ukrainian/news-42008437|title=Рада зробила 25 грудня вихідним днем|date=2017-11-16|work=BBC Україна|access-date=2017-11-16|language=en-GB}}</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine]] (OCU), [[Epiphanius I of Ukraine|Metropolitan Epiphanius]], said that changing the date of Christmas to 25 December in Ukraine is possible after both the church and the faithful are ready for such a decision, after conducting educational work. It was stated that the postponement of the celebration of the nativity of The Lord would entail a change in the dates of all fixed holidays to 13 days ago.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://news.rbc.ua/ukr/politics/epifaniy-nazval-uslovie-perenosa-prazdnovaniya-1608382147.html|title = Епіфаній назвав умову перенесення святкування Різдва на 25 грудня}}</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church]] (UGCC), [[Sviatoslav Shevchuk|Patriarch Sviatoslav]], stated that the Greek Catholic Church would resolve this issue "together with our Orthodox brothers". He also noted that this issue is not dogmatic, it should overcome church divisions, not cause new ones, and in his opinion, the transition to celebrating Christmas in a new style — 25 December, should be initiated by the laity.
 
 About a hundred parishes of the [[Romanians in Ukraine|Romanian national minority in Ukraine]], which are part of the [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)|Ukrainian Orthodox Church of the Moscow Patriarchate]], have always celebrated Christmas on December 25 according to the [[Revised Julian calendar]], just like the [[Romanian Orthodox Church]].<ref name=":2">{{Cite news |last=Кралюк |first=Петро |date=2023-01-02 |title=«Є сподівання, що ПЦУ і УГКЦ перейдуть на святкування Різдва 25 грудня» – професор Петро Кралюк |language=uk |work=Радіо Свобода |url=https://www.radiosvoboda.org/a/rizdvo-tserkovnyy-kalendar/32201163.html |access-date=2023-03-27}}</ref>

@@ -47,7 +47,7 @@
 
 During the early [[History of the Soviet Union|Soviet period]], all religious celebrations were discouraged under the official state policy of [[atheism]]. The [[Bolsheviks]] argued that Christmas was a [[pagan]] [[sun-worship]]ping ritual with no basis in scientific fact and denounced the [[Christmas tree]] as a [[bourgeois]] German import.<ref name=":0" /> In 1929, all religious holidays, including Christmas, were abolished by a decree of the [[Stalinist regime]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|last=|first=|date=2019-12-29|title=How New Year was celebrated in the USSR (Photos)|url=https://www.rbth.com/history/331458-soviet-new-year|url-status=live|access-date=2021-06-12|website=Beyond Russia|language=en-US|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191229111401/https://www.rbth.com/history/331458-soviet-new-year |archive-date=29 December 2019 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=Постановление СНК СССР от 24.09.1929|url=http://www.libussr.ru/doc_ussr/ussr_3594.htm|url-status=live|access-date=2021-06-12|website=www.libussr.ru|language=ru|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161229003241/http://www.libussr.ru:80/doc_ussr/ussr_3594.htm |archive-date=29 December 2016 }}</ref> However, in a surprising turn of state politics in 1935, many Ukrainian Christmas traditions were revived as part of a secular [[New Year's Eve|New Year's]] celebration after [[Joseph Stalin]]'s advisers convinced the [[Vozhd]] of the [[proletarians]]' need for a break from their hard work in the middle of a long, cold winter.<ref name=":1" /> The Christmas tree was repurposed as a "New Year's fir tree" to be admired by all children throughout the [[Soviet Union]], including those in republics that had not historically celebrated Christmas due to their different religious traditions, such as the [[Soviet Central Asia|Central Asian ones]]. Other Ukrainian Christmas attributes and traditions, such as [[Christmas gift|gift-giving]], Did Moroz's visits and Christmas decorations, lost their religious significance and became associated with New Year's celebrations, which were secular in nature.<ref name=":0" />
 
-In 1991, after the dissolution of the Soviet Union, Christmas was reinstated alongside other religious holidays.<ref name=":0" /> Especially in recent years, there has been a shift from Did Moroz, who came to be associated with the Soviet-era heritage, to the more traditional [[Saint Nicholas]], who used to be more popular in [[Western Ukraine]].<ref name="Mos">{{cite news |title=Kiev Brings Back Orthodox Santa Claus Instead of Soviet-Era Father Frost |work= |url=http://www.themoscowtimes.com/news/article/kiev-brings-back-orthodox-santa-claus-instead-of-soviet-era-father-frost/511488.html |access-date=24 December 2023 |work=[[The Moscow Times]] |date=20 November 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141120231116/http://www.themoscowtimes.com/news/article/kiev-brings-back-orthodox-santa-claus-instead-of-soviet-era-father-frost/511488.html |archive-date=20 November 2014}}</ref> There were rumours that Ded Moroz imagery was discouraged by the authorities due to the [[Russo-Ukrainian War]]; however, the [[Ukrainian Ministry of Culture]] has refuted this.<ref>[https://comments.ua/society/604910-deda-moroza-snegurochku-ukraine.html "Деда Мороза и Снегурочку в Украине никто не запрещал – Минкульт"]</ref>

The [[Bolsheviks]] argued that Christmas was a [[pagan]] [[sun-worship]]ping ritual with no basis in scientific fact and denounced the [[Christmas tree]] as a [[bourgeois]] German import.<ref name=":0" /> In 1929, all religious holidays, including Christmas, were abolished by a decree of the [[Stalinist regime]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|last=|first=|date=2019-12-29|title=How New Year was celebrated in the USSR (Photos)|url=https://www.rbth.com/history/331458-soviet-new-year|url-status=live|access-date=2021-06-12|website=Beyond Russia|language=en-US|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191229111401/https://www.rbth.com/history/331458-soviet-new-year |archive-date=29 December 2019 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=Постановление СНК СССР от 24.09.1929|url=http://www.libussr.ru/doc_ussr/ussr_3594.htm|url-status=live|access-date=2021-06-12|website=www.libussr.ru|language=ru|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161229003241/http://www.libussr.ru:80/doc_ussr/ussr_3594.htm |archive-date=29 December 2016 }}</ref> However, in a surprising turn of state politics in 1935, many Ukrainian Christmas traditions were revived as part of a secular [[New Year's Eve|New Year's]] celebration after [[Joseph Stalin]]'s advisers convinced the [[Vozhd]] of the [[proletarians]]' need for a break from their hard work in the middle of a long, cold winter.<ref name=":1" /> The Christmas tree was repurposed as a "New Year's fir tree" to be admired by all children throughout the [[Soviet Union]], including those in republics that had not historically celebrated Christmas due to their different religious traditions, such as the [[Soviet Central Asia|Central Asian ones]]. Other Ukrainian Christmas attributes and traditions, such as [[Christmas gift|gift-giving]], Did Moroz's visits and Christmas decorations, lost their religious significance and became associated with New Year's celebrations, which were secular in nature.<ref name=":0" />

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -73,7 +73,7 @@
 
 ==Sviatyi Vechir (Holy Evening)==
 [[File:Шопка_перед_львівською_ратушою.jpg|thumb|[[Nativity scene]]]]
-[[Christmas Eve]] on December 24 is called Sviatyi Vechir (''Святий вечір'') or Sviatvechir (''Святвечір'') in Ukraine ("Holy Evening"), and has many customs and rituals, most of which predate the introduction of Christianity to Ukraine. Traditions include decorating house and dinner table with special attributes (a symbolic sheaf of wheat called the ''[[didukh]]'', [[garlic]], hay, and others), performing [[Koliada|koliadky]] ('carols') and so on.  Each ritual has its own meaning and purpose, as such a few wisps of hay on the embroidered tablecloth as a reminder of the manger in [[Bethlehem]]. One prominent custom of the night is a special supper, called ''[[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|Sviata Vecheria]]'' ("Holy Supper").<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Nks04JbYUSgC&dq=sviata+vecheria&pg=PA33|last=World Book Inc.|title=Christmas in Ukraine|date=1997|location=Chicago|isbn=978-0-7166-0897-4|language=en}}</ref>
+[[Christmas Eve]] on December 24 is called Sviatyi Vechir (''Святий вечір'') or Sviatvechir (''Святвечір'') in Ukraine ("Holy Evening"), and has many customs and rituals, most of which predate the introduction of Christianity to Ukraine. Traditions include decorating house and dinner table with special attributes (a symbolic sheaf of wheat called the ''[[didukh]]'', [[garlic]], hay, and others), performing [[Koliada|koliadky]] ('carols') and so on.  Each ritual has its own meaning and purpose, as such a few wisps of hay on the embroidered tablecloth as a reminder of the manger in [[Bethlehem]]. One prominent custom of the night is a special supper, called ''[[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|Sviata Vecheria]]'' ("Holy Supper").{{sfn|Hughes|1997|pp=32{{ndash}}47}}
 
 Ukrainians of the OCU and UGCC fast on Sviatyi Vechir ([[Latin Church]] Catholics and Protestants may choose also to follow tradition on said day); only when the first star is seen in the evening sky, may the supper begin.  The family comes together to have a dinner which usually includes 12 dishes (the number can vary from 7–17). These twelve dishes are traditionally vegan plus fish, and do not contain meat, milk, or eggs.<ref>{{cite web |title=Christmas in Ukraine |url=https://www.whychristmas.com/cultures/ukraine.shtml |website=Why Christmas |access-date=14 December 2020}}</ref> While the dishes served can vary regionally, as well as from family to family, the two mandatory dishes are uzvar and kutia, both reckoned by ethnographer [[Fedir Vovk|Khvedir Vovk]] to be remnants of ancient rituals which date back to the neolithic era.<ref>{{cite web |title=Traditional Recipe of Ukrainian Kutia |url=https://etnocook.com/kutia/ |website=Ethnocook |date=18 January 2018 |access-date=27 November 2022}}</ref> [[Kutia]] (a dish of grain, honey and poppy seeds) is traditionally served first at the meal, after being offered by the head of the household to the frost. A spoonful is tossed at the ceiling, and in rural townships the number of poppy seeds which stick portends the bountyfulness of the fields, orchards and farm animals in the coming year. It is rarely served at other times of the year.<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html Sviat Vechir<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Uzvar is a beverage, made with cooked dried fruits and berries. It can be mixed in with the kutia, or served separately at the end of the meal.  Servings of both dishes are also set aside overnight in the pokuttia, the corner of the house with the Orthodox/Eastern Catholic icons or Latin Catholic images of saints, for deceased ancestors within the family or, in recent cases, for family members killed during the Russo-Ukrainian War (especially those who were KIA in the Armed Forces of Ukraine and other uniformed organizations).

@@ -35,7 +35,7 @@
 
 Traditional '''Ukrainian Christmas''' festivities start on [[Christmas Eve]], which is celebrated from December 24 to January 6, the date of the celebration of the [[baptism of Jesus]], known in [[Ukraine]] as ''[[Epiphany (holiday)|Vodokhreshche]]'' or ''Yordan'', according to the [[Gregorian calendar]] and [[Revised Julian calendar]] by the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine]] (OCU), the [[Catholic Church in Ukraine]] (including the [[Latin Church in Ukraine|Latin]] and [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church|Ukrainian Greek Catholics]]), and most [[Protestantism in Ukraine|Ukrainian Protestants]]. 
 
-The [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)|Ukrainian Orthodox Church of the Moscow Patriarchate]] (except for the [[Romanians in Ukraine|Romanian parishes]]<ref name=":2" />), some parishes of the OCU and Protestant churches celebrate Christmas according to the [[Julian calendar]], so the Gregorian holidays last from January 6 to January 19. 
+The [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)|Ukrainian Orthodox Church of the Moscow Patriarchate]] (except for the [[Romanians in Ukraine|Romanian parishes]]),<ref name=":2" /> some parishes of the OCU and Protestant churches celebrate Christmas according to the [[Julian calendar]], so the Gregorian holidays last from January 6 to January 19. 
 
 Christmas was largely erased from the Ukrainian calendar for much of the 20th century due to the [[Persecution of Christians in the Soviet Union|Soviet Union's anti-religious policies]], but many of its traditions survived and are being revived again. In 2023, for the first time since 1917, [[Christmas Day]] in Ukraine will officially be on December 25th.

@@ -45,7 +45,7 @@
 
 In the 19th century, a lavishly decorated Christmas tree became central to the holiday, a tradition originally imported by [[Nicholas I of Russia|Nicholas I]]'s wife, [[Alexandra Feodorovna (Charlotte of Prussia)|Alexandra Feodorovna]], from her native [[Prussia]]. The tradition of giving gifts to children on Christmas took root around the same time.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|last=Weber|first=Hannah|date=25 December 2020|title=Yolka: the story of Russia's 'New Year tree', from pagan origins to Soviet celebrations|url=https://www.calvertjournal.com/articles/show/9424/yolka-russia-new-year-tree-pagan-soviet-christmas|url-status=live|access-date=2021-06-12|website=The Calvert Journal|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180113181107/http://www.calvertjournal.com/articles/show/9424/yolka-russia-new-year-tree-pagan-soviet-christmas |archive-date=13 January 2018 }}</ref> Christmas gifts were traditionally brought by [[Ded Moroz]] or [[Grandfather Frost]], the Ukrainian counterpart of [[Santa Claus|Saint Nicholas]] or [[Father Christmas]], albeit a little taller and less stout. Rooted in Slavic folklore, Ded Moroz is accompanied by his beautiful granddaughter, [[Snegurka]], the snowmaiden), who rides with him on a sleigh pulled by a trio of horses.<ref name=":0" />
 
-During the early [[History of the Soviet Union|Soviet period]], all religious celebrations were discouraged under the official state policy of [[atheism]]. The [[Bolsheviks]] argued that Christmas was a [[pagan]] [[sun-worship]]ping ritual with no basis in scientific fact and denounced the [[Christmas tree]] as a [[bourgeois]] German import.<ref name=":0" /> In 1929, all religious holidays, including Christmas, were abolished by a decree of the [[Stalinist regime]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|last=|first=|date=2019-12-29|title=How New Year was celebrated in the USSR (Photos)|url=https://www.rbth.com/history/331458-soviet-new-year|url-status=live|access-date=2021-06-12|website=Beyond Russia|language=en-US|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191229111401/https://www.rbth.com/history/331458-soviet-new-year |archive-date=29 December 2019 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=Постановление СНК СССР от 24.09.1929|url=http://www.libussr.ru/doc_ussr/ussr_3594.htm|url-status=live|access-date=2021-06-12|website=www.libussr.ru|language=ru|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161229003241/http://www.libussr.ru:80/doc_ussr/ussr_3594.htm |archive-date=29 December 2016 }}</ref> However, in a surprising turn of state politics in 1935, many Ukrainian Christmas traditions were revived as part of a secular [[New Year's Eve|New Year's]] celebration after [[Joseph Stalin]]'s advisers convinced the [[Vozhd]] of the [[proletarians]]' need for a break from their hard work in the middle of a long, cold winter.<ref name=":1" /> The Christmas tree was repurposed as a "New Year's fir tree" to be admired by all children throughout the [[Soviet Union]], including those in republics that had not historically celebrated Christmas due to their different religious traditions, such as the [[Soviet Central Asia|Central Asian ones]]. Other Ukrainian Christmas attributes and traditions, such as [[Christmas gift|gift-giving]], Did Moroz's visits and Christmas decorations, lost their religious significance and became associated with New Year's celebrations, which were secular in nature.<ref name=":0" />
+During the early [[History of the Soviet Union|Soviet period]], all religious celebrations were discouraged under the official state policy of [[atheism]]. The [[Bolsheviks]] argued that Christmas was a [[pagan]] [[sun-worship]]ping ritual with no basis in scientific fact and denounced the [[Christmas tree]] as a [[bourgeois]] German import.<ref name=":0" /> In 1929, all religious holidays, including Christmas, were abolished by a decree of the [[Stalinist regime]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|last=|first=|date=2019-12-29|title=How New Year was celebrated in the USSR (Photos)|url=https://www.rbth.com/history/331458-soviet-new-year|url-status=live|access-date=2021-06-12|website=Beyond Russia|language=en-US|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191229111401/https://www.rbth.com/history/331458-soviet-new-year |archive-date=29 December 2019 }}</ref> However, in a surprising turn of state politics in 1935, many Ukrainian Christmas traditions were revived as part of a secular [[New Year's Eve|New Year's]] celebration after [[Joseph Stalin]]'s advisers convinced the [[Vozhd]] of the [[proletarians]]' need for a break from their hard work in the middle of a long, cold winter.<ref name=":1" /> The Christmas tree was repurposed as a "New Year's fir tree" to be admired by all children throughout the [[Soviet Union]], including those in republics that had not historically celebrated Christmas due to their different religious traditions, such as the [[Soviet Central Asia|Central Asian ones]]. Other Ukrainian Christmas attributes and traditions, such as [[Christmas gift|gift-giving]], Did Moroz's visits and Christmas decorations, lost their religious significance and became associated with New Year's celebrations, which were secular in nature.<ref name=":0" />
 
 In 1991, after the dissolution of the Soviet Union, Christmas was reinstated alongside other religious holidays.<ref name=":0" /> Especially in recent years, there has been a shift from Did Moroz, who came to be associated with the Soviet-era heritage, to the more traditional [[Saint Nicholas]], who used to be more popular in [[Western Ukraine]].<ref name="Mos">{{cite news |title=Kiev Brings Back Orthodox Santa Claus Instead of Soviet-Era Father Frost |url=http://www.themoscowtimes.com/news/article/kiev-brings-back-orthodox-santa-claus-instead-of-soviet-era-father-frost/511488.html |access-date=24 December 2023 |work=[[The Moscow Times]] |date=20 November 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141120231116/http://www.themoscowtimes.com/news/article/kiev-brings-back-orthodox-santa-claus-instead-of-soviet-era-father-frost/511488.html |archive-date=20 November 2014}}</ref>

 [[File:Diduch-Lviv.jpg|thumb|A [[didukh]] in [[Lviv]]]]
 Traditional Ukrainian Christmas festivities last from December 24 to January 6, the date of the celebration of the [[baptism of Jesus]], which known in Ukraine as {{lang|uk|Vodokhreshche}} or ''{{lang|uk|Yordan}}'',<ref name="UFA">{{cite web |title=Christmas Traditions of Ukraine |url=http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/ |publisher=Ukrainian Fraternal Association |access-date=24 December 2023}}</ref> according to the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine]] (OCU),<ref name=":4" /> the [[Catholic Church in Ukraine|Catholic Church]] (including [[Latin Church in Ukraine|Latin]] and [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church|Ukrainian Greek Catholics]]<ref name=":3" />), and most [[Protestantism in Ukraine|Protestants]].
 
-As of 2017, 25 December, Christmas Day by the [[Gregorian calendar|Gregorian]] calendar, became an official government holiday in Ukraine. The [[Eastern Orthodox Church]]es predominantly follow the Julian calendar, and 7 January is also a [[Public holidays in Ukraine|public holiday in Ukraine]].<ref name="BBC1">{{cite news |title=Рада зробила 25 грудня вихідним днем |url=http://www.bbc.com/ukrainian/news-42008437 |access-date=18 November 2017 |work=[[BBC News Україна]] |date=16 November 2017 |page=|trans-title=The council made December 25 a day off |language=uk}}</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine]] (OCU), [[Epiphanius I of Ukraine|Metropolitan Epiphanius]], said that changing the date of Christmas to 25 December in Ukraine is possible after both the church and the faithful are ready for such a decision, after conducting educational work. It was stated that the postponement of the celebration of the nativity of The Lord would entail a change in the dates of all fixed holidays to 13 days ago.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://news.rbc.ua/ukr/politics/epifaniy-nazval-uslovie-perenosa-prazdnovaniya-1608382147.html|title = Епіфаній назвав умову перенесення святкування Різдва на 25 грудня}}</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church]] (UGCC), [[Sviatoslav Shevchuk|Patriarch Sviatoslav]], stated that the Greek Catholic Church would resolve this issue "together with our Orthodox brothers". He also noted that this issue is not dogmatic, it should overcome church divisions, not cause new ones, and in his opinion, the transition to celebrating Christmas in a new style — 25 December, should be initiated by the laity.
+As of 2017, 25 December, Christmas Day by the [[Gregorian calendar|Gregorian]] calendar, became an official government holiday in Ukraine. The [[Eastern Orthodox Church]]es predominantly follow the Julian calendar, and 7 January is also a [[Public holidays in Ukraine|public holiday in Ukraine]].<ref name="BBC1">{{cite news |title=Рада зробила 25 грудня вихідним днем |url=http://www.bbc.com/ukrainian/news-42008437 |access-date=18 November 2017 |work=[[BBC News Україна]] |date=16 November 2017 |page=|trans-title=The council made December 25 a day off |language=uk}}</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine]] (OCU), [[Epiphanius I of Ukraine|Metropolitan Epiphanius]], said that changing the date of Christmas to 25 December in Ukraine is possible after both the church and the faithful are ready for such a decision, after conducting educational work. It was stated that the postponement of the celebration of the nativity of The Lord would entail a change in the dates of all fixed holidays to 13 days ago.<ref name="Rok">{{cite news |last1=Rokitna |first1=Anastasia |title=Епифаний назвал условие переноса празднования Рождества на 25 декабря |url=https://news.rbc.ua/ukr/politics/epifaniy-nazval-uslovie-perenosa-prazdnovaniya-1608382147.html|title = Епіфаній назвав умову перенесення святкування Різдва на 25 грудня |access-date=25 December 2023 |work=RBC - Ukraine |publisher=UBT |date=19 December 2020 |page=|trans-title=Epiphany named the move of the Holy Day of Resurrection to the 25th birthday |language=uk}}</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church]] (UGCC), [[Sviatoslav Shevchuk|Patriarch Sviatoslav]], stated that the Greek Catholic Church would resolve this issue "together with our Orthodox brothers". He also noted that this issue is not dogmatic, it should overcome church divisions, not cause new ones, and in his opinion, the transition to celebrating Christmas in a new style — 25 December, should be initiated by the laity.
 
 About a hundred parishes of the [[Romanians in Ukraine|Romanian national minority in Ukraine]], which are part of the [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)|Ukrainian Orthodox Church of the Moscow Patriarchate]], have always celebrated Christmas on December 25 according to the [[Revised Julian calendar]], just like the [[Romanian Orthodox Church]].<ref name=":2">{{Cite news |last=Kralyuk |first=Petro |date=2 January 2023 |title=«Є сподівання, що ПЦУ і УГКЦ перейдуть на святкування Різдва 25 грудня» – професор Петро Кралюк |trans-title="There is hope that OCU and UGCC will celebrate Christmas on December 25" - Professor Petro Kralyuk
  |language=uk |work=[[Radio Svoboda]] |url=https://www.radiosvoboda.org/a/rizdvo-tserkovnyy-kalendar/32201163.html |access-date=27 March 2023}}</ref>

changed_version:
---

@@ -35,7 +35,7 @@
 
 Traditional '''Ukrainian Christmas''' festivities start on [[Christmas Eve]], which is celebrated from December 24 to January 6, the date of the celebration of the [[baptism of Jesus]], known in [[Ukraine]] as ''[[Epiphany (holiday)|Vodokhreshche]]'' or ''Yordan'', according to the [[Gregorian calendar]] and [[Revised Julian calendar]] by the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine]] (OCU), the [[Catholic Church in Ukraine]] (including the [[Latin Church in Ukraine|Latin]] and [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church|Ukrainian Greek Catholics]]), and most [[Protestantism in Ukraine|Ukrainian Protestants]]. 
 
-The [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)|Ukrainian Orthodox Church of the Moscow Patriarchate]] (except for the [[Romanians in Ukraine|Romanian parishes]]<ref name=":2" />), some parishes of the OCU and Protestant churches celebrate Christmas according to the [[Julian calendar]], so the Gregorian holidays last from January 6 to January 19. The {{ill|Armenian Diocese of Ukraine|hy|Ուկրաինայի հայոց թեմ|display=1}} of the [[Armenian Apostolic Church]] and the [[Armenian Catholic Church in Ukraine]] celebrates Christmas from January 5 to January 6 along with Epiphany according to the Gregorian calendar.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Do Lvivians know that Armenians celebrate Christmas on January 6? |url=https://tvoemisto.tv/blogs/shche_odna_data_rizdva_hto_u_lvovi_maie_svyatu_vecheryu_5_sichnya_141904.html |access-date=2023-06-18 |website=tvoemisto.tv}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |last=Терещук |first=Галина |date=2020-01-06 |title=Christmas in Lviv: three dates of the family holiday |language=uk |work=Радіо Свобода |url=https://www.radiosvoboda.org/a/30362341.html |access-date=2023-06-18}}</ref>
+The [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)|Ukrainian Orthodox Church of the Moscow Patriarchate]] (except for the [[Romanians in Ukraine|Romanian parishes]]<ref name=":2" />), some parishes of the OCU and Protestant churches celebrate Christmas according to the [[Julian calendar]], so the Gregorian holidays last from January 6 to January 19. 
 
 Christmas was largely erased from the Ukrainian calendar for much of the 20th century due to the [[Persecution of Christians in the Soviet Union|Soviet Union's anti-religious policies]], but many of its traditions survived and are being revived again. In 2023, for the first time since 1917, [[Christmas Day]] in Ukraine will officially be on December 25th.

The Ukrainian Christmas  festive days according to the Julian calendar, start on January 6th, Christmas Eve and ends with January 19th, "Jordan" or Epiphany.<ref>http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/</ref>

==Sviaty Vechir (Holy Evening)== 
<ref>http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html</ref>





==Koliadky - (Caroling)==


==Did Moroz - (Grandfather Frost)==



{{Reflist}}
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -79,7 +79,7 @@
 
 Ukrainians of the OCU and UGCC fast on Sviatyi Vechir ([[Latin Church]] Catholics and Protestants may choose also to follow tradition on said day); only when the first star is seen in the evening sky, may the supper begin.  The family comes together to have a dinner which usually includes 12 dishes (the number can vary from 7–17). These twelve dishes are traditionally vegan plus fish, and do not contain meat, milk, or eggs.<ref>{{cite web |title=Christmas in Ukraine |url=https://www.whychristmas.com/cultures/ukraine.shtml |website=Why Christmas |access-date=14 December 2020}}</ref> While the dishes served can vary regionally, as well as from family to family, the two mandatory dishes are uzvar and kutia, both reckoned by ethnographer [[Fedir Vovk|Khvedir Vovk]] to be remnants of ancient rituals which date back to the neolithic era.<ref>{{cite web |title=Traditional Recipe of Ukrainian Kutia |url=https://etnocook.com/kutia/ |website=Ethnocook |date=18 January 2018 |access-date=27 November 2022}}</ref> [[Kutia]] (a dish of grain, honey and poppy seeds) is traditionally served first at the meal, after being offered by the head of the household to the frost. A spoonful is tossed at the ceiling, and in rural townships the number of poppy seeds which stick portends the bountyfulness of the fields, orchards and farm animals in the coming year. It is rarely served at other times of the year.<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html Sviat Vechir<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Uzvar is a beverage, made with cooked dried fruits and berries. It can be mixed in with the kutia, or served separately at the end of the meal.  Servings of both dishes are also set aside overnight in the pokuttia, the corner of the house with the Orthodox/Eastern Catholic icons or Latin Catholic images of saints, for deceased ancestors within the family or, in recent cases, for family members killed during the Russo-Ukrainian War (especially those who were KIA in the Armed Forces of Ukraine and other uniformed organizations).
 
-The All-Night Christmas Vigil then follows, families then troop to their local parish churches or Protestant chruches to attend as thanksgiving for the Savior's birth in a stable.
+The All-Night Christmas Vigil then follows, families then troop to their local parish churches or Protestant chruches to attend as thanksgiving for the Savior's birth in a stable.  A ''[[Nativity scene|shopka]]'' (''[[vertep]]'') is a traditional portable [[Nativity of Jesus|nativity]] scene used to represent nativity and other figures in a [[Nativity play|puppet]] form.
 
 ==''Koliadky'' (Caroling)==
 At the end of the {{lang|uk|Sviata Vechera}}, and the [[vigil]] that follows, Ukrainian families often sing carols ({{lang|uk|koliadky}}). In some communities the ancient Ukrainian tradition of caroling is carried on by groups of young people and members of organizations and churches calling at homes and collecting donations. Well-known carols include ''{{ill|Nova radist stala|lt=|uk|Нова радість стала|display=1}}'', [[Boh predvičnyj narodivsja|''Boh predvichnyi narodyvsia'']],<ref name=Met>{{cite web|title=Boh predvičnyj|url=http://mci.archpitt.org/legacy/songs/Slavonic/Boh_predvicnyj.html|website=Metropolitan Cantor Institute|publisher=Byzantine Catholic|access-date=12 August 2015|ref=Archeparchy of Pittsburgh|archive-date=4 March 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304235614/http://mci.archpitt.org/legacy/songs/Slavonic/Boh_predvicnyj.html|url-status=dead}}</ref> ''{{ill|Dobryi vechir tobi, pane hospodariu|lt=|uk|Добрий вечір тобі, пане господарю|display=1}}'', ''{{ill|Vo Vyfleiemi nyni novyna|lt=|uk|Во Вифлеємі нині новина|display=1}}'', ''{{ill|Nebo i zemlia nyni torzhestvuiut|lt=|uk|Небо і земля нині торжествують|display=1}}'', and ''{{ill|Boh sia rozhdaie|lt=|uk|Бог ся раджае|display=1}}''.
llm_output:
Changed the text by adding a description of a traditional portable nativity scene, known as "shopka" or "vertep".

Not Weaponised – The addition provides cultural context about Ukrainian traditions without promoting a specific political narrative or agenda.

 On 18 October 2022, the OCU allowed dioceses to hold Christmas services according to the Revised Julian calendar, i.e., 25 December. In the case of a divine service, its participants are released from the restrictions of fasting on this day.<ref>{{Cite web |title=OCU allowed Christmas services on December 25 |url=https://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2022/10/18/7372478/ |accessdate=2022-10-18 |website=[[Ukrainian Pravda]] |language=uk}}</ref>

The Ukrainian Christmas  festive days according to the Julian calendar, start on January 6th, Christmas Eve and ends with January 19th, "Jordan" or Epiphany.<ref>http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/</ref>

==Sviaty Vechir (Holy Evening)== 
<ref>http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html</ref>





==Koliadky - (Caroling)==


==Did Moroz - (Grandfather Frost)==



{{Reflist}}
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -1,7 +1,6 @@
 {{Short description|Overview of Christmas in Ukraine}}
 {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2014}}
 {{Use British English|date=December 2023}}
-{{more citations needed|date=December 2023}}
 {{Infobox holiday
 | holiday_name  = Christmas in Ukraine
 | image         = Hnizdovsky Rizdvo3.gif
@@ -40,7 +39,7 @@
 Christmas was largely erased from the Ukrainian calendar for much of the 20th century due to the [[Persecution of Christians in the Soviet Union|Soviet Union's anti-religious policies]], but many of its traditions survived and are being revived again. In 2023, for the first time since 1917, [[Christmas Day]] in Ukraine will officially be on December 25th.
 
 ==History==
-In Ukraine, the Christmas holiday became the official celebration with the [[baptism of Rus']] ordered by [[Prince Vladimir]] in the late 10th century. However, given the early Christian community of [[Kievan Rus']], the celebration may have a longer history.
+In Ukraine, the Christmas holiday became the official celebration with the [[baptism of Rus']] ordered by [[Prince Vladimir]] in the year 988.<ref>{{citation |last=Moreau |first=A. Scott |page=102 |title=Introducing World Missions: A Biblical, Historical, and Practical Survey |last2=Corwin |first2=Gary R. |last3=Corwin |first3=Gary |last4=McGee |first4=Gary B. |date=2004 |publisher=Baker Academic |isbn=978-0-8010-2648-5 |language=en}}</ref> However, given the early Christian community of [[Kievan Rus']], the celebration may have a longer history.
 [[File:Новогодние марки Украины Дед Мороз.jpg|thumbnail|Did Moroz on a Ukrainian postage stamp with New Year greeting]]
 
 In the 19th century, a lavishly decorated Christmas tree became central to the holiday, a tradition originally imported by [[Nicholas I of Russia|Nicholas I]]'s wife, [[Alexandra Feodorovna (Charlotte of Prussia)|Alexandra Feodorovna]], from her native [[Prussia]]. The tradition of giving gifts to children on Christmas took root around the same time.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|last=Weber|first=Hannah|date=25 December 2020|title=Yolka: the story of Russia's 'New Year tree', from pagan origins to Soviet celebrations|url=https://www.calvertjournal.com/articles/show/9424/yolka-russia-new-year-tree-pagan-soviet-christmas|url-status=live|access-date=2021-06-12|website=The Calvert Journal|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180113181107/http://www.calvertjournal.com/articles/show/9424/yolka-russia-new-year-tree-pagan-soviet-christmas |archive-date=13 January 2018 }}</ref> Christmas gifts were traditionally brought by [[Ded Moroz]] or [[Grandfather Frost]], the Ukrainian counterpart of [[Santa Claus|Saint Nicholas]] or [[Father Christmas]], albeit a little taller and less stout. Rooted in Slavic folklore, Ded Moroz is accompanied by his beautiful granddaughter, [[Snegurka]], the snowmaiden), who rides with him on a sleigh pulled by a trio of horses.<ref name=":0" />
llm_output:
Removed the tag "{{more citations needed|date=December 2023}}" and added a citation for the year 988 regarding the baptism of Rus'.

Not Weaponised. The changes made are factual and do not employ language that could be interpreted as weaponising cultural heritage.

The Ukrainian Christmas  festive days according to the Julian calendar, start on January 6th, Christmas Eve and ends with January 19th, "Jordan" or Epiphany.<ref>http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/</ref>

{{Reflist}}
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -79,7 +79,7 @@
 
 Ukrainians of the OCU and UGCC fast on Sviatyi Vechir ([[Latin Church]] Catholics and Protestants may choose also to follow tradition on said day); only when the first star is seen in the evening sky, may the supper begin.  The family comes together to have a dinner which usually includes 12 dishes (the number can vary from 7–17). These twelve dishes are traditionally vegan plus fish, and do not contain meat, milk, or eggs.<ref>{{cite web |title=Christmas in Ukraine |url=https://www.whychristmas.com/cultures/ukraine.shtml |website=Why Christmas |access-date=14 December 2020}}</ref> While the dishes served can vary regionally, as well as from family to family, the two mandatory dishes are uzvar and kutia, both reckoned by ethnographer [[Fedir Vovk|Khvedir Vovk]] to be remnants of ancient rituals which date back to the neolithic era.<ref>{{cite web |title=Traditional Recipe of Ukrainian Kutia |url=https://etnocook.com/kutia/ |website=Ethnocook |date=18 January 2018 |access-date=27 November 2022}}</ref> [[Kutia]] (a dish of grain, honey and poppy seeds) is traditionally served first at the meal, after being offered by the head of the household to the frost. A spoonful is tossed at the ceiling, and in rural townships the number of poppy seeds which stick portends the bountyfulness of the fields, orchards and farm animals in the coming year. It is rarely served at other times of the year.<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html Sviat Vechir<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Uzvar is a beverage, made with cooked dried fruits and berries. It can be mixed in with the kutia, or served separately at the end of the meal.  Servings of both dishes are also set aside overnight in the pokuttia, the corner of the house with the Orthodox/Eastern Catholic icons or Latin Catholic images of saints, for deceased ancestors within the family or, in recent cases, for family members killed during the Russo-Ukrainian War (especially those who were KIA in the Armed Forces of Ukraine and other uniformed organizations).
 
-The All-Night Christmas Vigil then follows, families then troop to their local parish churches or Protestant chruches to attend as thanksgiving for the Savior's birth in a stable.  A ''[[Nativity scene|shopka]]'' (''[[vertep]]'') is a traditional portable [[Nativity of Jesus|nativity]] scene used to represent nativity and other figures in a [[Nativity play|puppet]] form.
+The All-Night Christmas Vigil then follows, families then troop to their local parish churches or Protestant chruches to attend as thanksgiving for the Savior's birth in a stable.  A ''[[Nativity scene|shopka]]'' (''[[vertep]]'') is a traditional portable [[Nativity of Jesus|nativity]] scene used to represent nativity and other figures in a [[Nativity play|puppet]] form.<ref>{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=G_8pAQAAIAAJ&newbks=0&printsec=frontcover&dq=shopka+ukraine+christmas+eve&q=shopka+ukraine+christmas+eve&hl=en |title=Soviet Studies in Literature |date=1990 |publisher=International Arts and Science Press |language=en}}</ref>
 
 ==''Koliadky'' (Caroling)==
 At the end of the {{lang|uk|Sviata Vechera}}, and the [[vigil]] that follows, Ukrainian families often sing carols ({{lang|uk|koliadky}}). In some communities the ancient Ukrainian tradition of caroling is carried on by groups of young people and members of organizations and churches calling at homes and collecting donations. Well-known carols include ''{{ill|Nova radist stala|lt=|uk|Нова радість стала|display=1}}'', [[Boh predvičnyj narodivsja|''Boh predvichnyi narodyvsia'']],<ref name=Met>{{cite web|title=Boh predvičnyj|url=http://mci.archpitt.org/legacy/songs/Slavonic/Boh_predvicnyj.html|website=Metropolitan Cantor Institute|publisher=Byzantine Catholic|access-date=12 August 2015|ref=Archeparchy of Pittsburgh|archive-date=4 March 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304235614/http://mci.archpitt.org/legacy/songs/Slavonic/Boh_predvicnyj.html|url-status=dead}}</ref> ''{{ill|Dobryi vechir tobi, pane hospodariu|lt=|uk|Добрий вечір тобі, пане господарю|display=1}}'', ''{{ill|Vo Vyfleiemi nyni novyna|lt=|uk|Во Вифлеємі нині новина|display=1}}'', ''{{ill|Nebo i zemlia nyni torzhestvuiut|lt=|uk|Небо і земля нині торжествують|display=1}}'', and ''{{ill|Boh sia rozhdaie|lt=|uk|Бог ся раджае|display=1}}''.
llm_output:
Added a citation for the description of the All-Night Christmas Vigil and the traditional nativity scene (shopka).

Not Weaponised – The change is a neutral addition of a citation that enhances the article's credibility without introducing any politically charged language or narratives.

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -65,7 +65,7 @@
 
 In February 2023 the UGCC decided to switch to the Revised Julian calendar for fixed holidays (і.e., except for [[Date of Easter|Easter]]) from September 2023.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Historical decision: the UGCC in Ukraine switches to a new calendar|url=https://ugcc.ua/en/data/historical-decision-the-ugcc-in-ukraine-switches-to-a-new-calendar-232/ |access-date=2023-07-19 |website=Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church |language=en}}</ref> [[Parish|Parishes]] of the UGCC that are not ready to switch to the new style in 2023 have a transition period until September 1, 2025 to make the change.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web |date=2023-02-06 |title=Ukraine Catholic Church moves from Russian-affiliated Julian calendar |url=https://www.pillarcatholic.com/ukraine-catholic-church-moves-from-russian/ |access-date=2023-02-06 |website=The Pillar |language=en}}</ref>
 
-Effective 24 May 2023, the OCU officially declared that 25 December will be the permanent date for Christmas commemorations and festivities for the Ukrainian Orthodox faithful, as the Church officially formalized the adoption of the Revised Julian calendar for fixed feasts and solemnities in line with the other Orthodox churches of the world, with Easter kept in the old Julian Calendar.<ref>{{Cite news |last=RFE/RL |title=Orthodox Church Of Ukraine Approves Calendar Switch In Widening Diversion From Russia |language=en |work=RadioFreeEurope/RadioLiberty |url=https://www.rferl.org/a/orthodox-church-ukraine-approves-calendar-switch-russia/32426292.html |access-date=2023-06-18}}</ref><ref name=":4">{{Cite web |date=2023-05-24 |title=Orthodox Church of Ukraine to switch to Revised Julian calendar, celebrate Christmas on Dec. 25 |url=https://kyivindependent.com/orthodox-church-of-ukraine-to-switch-to-revised-julian-calendar-celebrate-christmas-on-dec-25/ |access-date=2023-06-18 |website=The Kyiv Independent |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Orthodox Church of Ukraine Decides to Celebrate Christmas on Dec. 25 |url=https://www.kyivpost.com/post/17460 |access-date=2023-06-18 |website=Get the Latest Ukraine News Today – KyivPost |language=en}}</ref> On July 27, the [[Council of Kyiv (2023)|Local Council]] approved the transition.<ref name="NV1">{{cite web |title=Orthodox Church of Ukraine finally adopts new calendar |url=https://english.nv.ua/life/ocu-approves-switch-to-revised-julian-calendar-ukraine-news-50342167.html |website=NV |access-date=31 July 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230728022338/https://english.nv.ua/life/ocu-approves-switch-to-revised-julian-calendar-ukraine-news-50342167.html |archive-date=28 July 2023}}</ref>
+Effective 24 May 2023, the OCU officially declared that 25 December will be the permanent date for Christmas commemorations and festivities for the Ukrainian Orthodox faithful, as the Church officially formalized the adoption of the Revised Julian calendar for fixed feasts and solemnities in line with the other Orthodox churches of the world, with Easter kept in the old Julian Calendar.<ref name=":4">{{Cite web |date=2023-05-24 |title=Orthodox Church of Ukraine to switch to Revised Julian calendar, celebrate Christmas on Dec. 25 |url=https://kyivindependent.com/orthodox-church-of-ukraine-to-switch-to-revised-julian-calendar-celebrate-christmas-on-dec-25/ |access-date=2023-06-18 |website=The Kyiv Independent |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |last=RFE/RL |title=Orthodox Church Of Ukraine Approves Calendar Switch In Widening Diversion From Russia |language=en |work=RadioFreeEurope/RadioLiberty |url=https://www.rferl.org/a/orthodox-church-ukraine-approves-calendar-switch-russia/32426292.html |access-date=2023-06-18}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Orthodox Church of Ukraine Decides to Celebrate Christmas on Dec. 25 |url=https://www.kyivpost.com/post/17460 |access-date=2023-06-18 |website=Get the Latest Ukraine News Today – KyivPost |language=en}}</ref> On July 27, the [[Council of Kyiv (2023)|Local Council]] approved the transition.<ref name="NV1">{{cite web |title=Orthodox Church of Ukraine finally adopts new calendar |url=https://english.nv.ua/life/ocu-approves-switch-to-revised-julian-calendar-ukraine-news-50342167.html |website=NV |access-date=31 July 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230728022338/https://english.nv.ua/life/ocu-approves-switch-to-revised-julian-calendar-ukraine-news-50342167.html |archive-date=28 July 2023}}</ref>
 
 On 28 June 2023 [[President of Ukraine]], [[Volodymyr Zelenskyy]], submitted to the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (Ukraine's national parliament) a draft law removing the Julian Calendar Christmas holiday on January 7 and confirming the December 25 date as the sole day of celebrations, reflecting changes in the OCU and UGCC calendars.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Zelensky Introduces Proposed Draft Law to Change Holiday Dates |url=https://www.kyivpost.com/post/18846 |access-date=2023-06-29 |website=Get the Latest Ukraine News Today – KyivPost |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-06-28 |title=Zelensky submitted to the Verkhovna Rada a law on changing holiday dates |url=https://babel.ua/en/news/95649-zelensky-submitted-to-the-verkhovna-rada-a-law-on-changing-holiday-dates |access-date=2023-06-29 |website=babel.ua |language=en}}</ref> Parliament passed this law on 14 July 2023 with 241 deputies voting in the affirmative.<ref name="3735767ChristmasUA">{{Cite web |date=2023-07-14 |title=Parliament changes dates of Christmas, Statehood Day, Day of Defenders |url=https://www.ukrinform.net/rubric-society/3735767-parliament-changes-dates-of-three-holidays-christmas-statehood-day-day-of-defenders-of-ukraine.html |access-date=2023-07-14 |website=[[Ukrinform]] |language=en}}</ref> Zelensky signed the law on 28 July 2023.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cnn.com/2023/07/29/europe/ukraine-christmas-date-change-intl/index.html|last1 = Toropin | first1 = Konstantin | last2 = Stambaugh | first2 = Alex | title = Ukraine moves Christmas to December 25, distancing itself from Russian tradition | website = Cable News Network | date = 29 July 2023 | accessdate = 1 August 2023}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-07-29 |title=Ukraine moves official Christmas Day holiday to Dec. 25, denouncing Russian-imposed traditions |url=https://apnews.com/article/russia-ukraine-war-christmas-orthodox-church-calendar-b658c9ebecc91a470866c34b1c1847eb |access-date=2023-07-31 |website=AP News |language=en}}</ref>

These twelve dishes are traditionally vegan plus fish, and do not contain meat, milk, or eggs.<ref>{{cite web |title=Christmas in Ukraine |url=https://www.whychristmas.com/cultures/ukraine.shtml |website=Why Christmas |access-date=14 December 2020 |archive-date=7 December 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201207184630/https://www.whychristmas.com/cultures/ukraine.shtml |url-status=live }}</ref> While the dishes served can vary regionally, as well as from family to family, the two mandatory dishes are ''uzvar'' and ''kutia'', both reckoned by ethnographer [[Fedir Vovk|Khvedir Vovk]] to be remnants of ancient rituals which date back to the neolithic era.<ref>{{cite web |title=Traditional Recipe of Ukrainian Kutia |url=https://etnocook.com/kutia/ |website=Ethnocook |date=18 January 2018 |access-date=27 November 2022 |archive-date=28 November 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221128164554/https://etnocook.com/kutia/ |url-status=live }}</ref> ''[[Kutia]]'' (a dish of grain, honey and poppy seeds) is traditionally served first at the meal, after being offered by the head of the household to the frost. A spoonful is tossed at the ceiling, and in rural townships the number of poppy seeds which stick portends the bountyfulness of the fields, orchards and farm animals in the coming year. It is rarely served at other times of the year.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html |title=Sviat Vechir<!-- Bot generated title --> |access-date=7 January 2013 |archive-date=9 January 2008 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080109035835/http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html |url-status=live }}</ref> ''Uzvar'' is a beverage, made with cooked dried fruits and berries. It can be mixed in with the ''kutia'', or served separately at the end of the meal.  Servings of both dishes are also set aside overnight in the ''pokuttia'', the corner of the house with the Orthodox/Eastern Catholic icons or Latin Catholic images of saints, for deceased ancestors within the family or, in recent cases, for family members killed during the Russo-Ukrainian War (especially those who were KIA in the Armed Forces of Ukraine and other uniformed organizations).
 
-The All-Night Christmas Vigil then follows, families then troop to their local parish churches or Protestant churches to attend as thanksgiving for the Savior's birth in a stable.  A ''[[Nativity scene|shopka]]'' (''[[vertep]]'') is a traditional portable [[Nativity of Jesus|nativity]] scene used to represent nativity and other figures in a [[Nativity play|puppet]] form.<ref>{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=G_8pAQAAIAAJ&newbks=0&printsec=frontcover&dq=shopka+ukraine+christmas+eve&q=shopka+ukraine+christmas+eve&hl=en |title=Soviet Studies in Literature |date=1990 |publisher=International Arts and Science Press |language=en |access-date=25 December 2023 |archive-date=25 December 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231225104358/https://books.google.com/books?id=G_8pAQAAIAAJ&newbks=0&printsec=frontcover&dq=shopka+ukraine+christmas+eve&q=shopka+ukraine+christmas+eve&hl=en |url-status=live }}</ref>
+The All-Night Christmas Vigil then follows, families then troop to their local parish churches or Protestant churches to attend as thanksgiving for the Savior's birth in a stable.  A ''[[Nativity scene|shopka]]'' (''[[vertep]]'') is a traditional portable [[Nativity of Jesus|nativity]] scene used to represent nativity and other figures in a [[Nativity play|puppet]] form.<ref>{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=G_8pAQAAIAAJ&q=shopka+ukraine+christmas+eve |title=Soviet Studies in Literature |date=1990 |publisher=International Arts and Science Press |language=en |access-date=25 December 2023 |archive-date=25 December 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231225104358/https://books.google.com/books?id=G_8pAQAAIAAJ&newbks=0&printsec=frontcover&dq=shopka+ukraine+christmas+eve&q=shopka+ukraine+christmas+eve&hl=en |url-status=live }}</ref>
 
 ==''Koliadky'' (Caroling)==
 At the end of the {{lang|uk|Sviata Vechera}}, and the [[vigil]] that follows, Ukrainian families often sing carols ({{lang|uk|koliadky}}). In some communities the ancient Ukrainian tradition of caroling is carried on by groups of young people and members of organizations and churches calling at homes and collecting donations. Well-known carols include ''{{ill|Nova radist stala|lt=|uk|Нова радість стала|display=1}}'', [[Boh predvičnyj narodivsja|''Boh predvichnyi narodyvsia'']],<ref name=Met>{{cite web|title=Boh predvičnyj|url=http://mci.archpitt.org/legacy/songs/Slavonic/Boh_predvicnyj.html|website=Metropolitan Cantor Institute|publisher=Byzantine Catholic|access-date=12 August 2015|ref=Archeparchy of Pittsburgh|archive-date=4 March 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304235614/http://mci.archpitt.org/legacy/songs/Slavonic/Boh_predvicnyj.html|url-status=dead}}</ref> ''{{ill|Dobryi vechir tobi, pane hospodariu|lt=|uk|Добрий вечір тобі, пане господарю|display=1}}'', ''{{ill|Vo Vyfleiemi nyni novyna|lt=|uk|Во Вифлеємі нині новина|display=1}}'', ''{{ill|Nebo i zemlia nyni torzhestvuiut|lt=|uk|Небо і земля нині торжествують|display=1}}'', and ''{{ill|Boh sia rozhdaie|lt=|uk|Бог ся раджае|display=1}}''.
@@ -104,7 +104,7 @@

+In villages (farming communities), the head of the household brings in a sheaf of grain called the ''didukh'' which represents the importance of the ancient and rich wheat crops of Ukraine, the staff of life through the centuries. Didukh means literally "grandfather spirit" so it symbolizes the family's ancestors.  The [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)|Ukrainian Orthodox Church of the Moscow Patriarchate]] (except for the [[Romanians in Ukraine|Romanian parishes]]),<ref name=":2" /> some parishes of the OCU and Protestant churches celebrate Christmas according to the [[Julian calendar]], so the Gregorian holidays last from January 6 to January 19.

+Christmas was largely erased from the Ukrainian calendar for much of the 20th century due to the [[Persecution of Christians in the Soviet Union|Soviet Union's anti-religious policies]], but many of its traditions survived and are being revived again. In 2023, for the first time since 1917, [[Christmas Day]] in Ukraine was officially on December 25.
 
 ==History==
 In Ukraine, the Christmas holiday became the official celebration with the [[baptism of Rus']] ordered by [[Prince Vladimir]] in the year 988.<ref>{{citation |last1=Moreau |first1=A. Scott |page=102 |title=Introducing World Missions: A Biblical, Historical, and Practical Survey |last2=Corwin |first2=Gary R. |last3=Corwin |first3=Gary |last4=McGee |first4=Gary B. |date=2004 |publisher=Baker Academic |isbn=978-0-8010-2648-5 |language=en}}</ref> However, given the early Christian community of [[Kievan Rus']], the celebration may have a longer history.

@@ -50,6 +50,7 @@
 
 == Date of celebration ==
 [[File:Diduch-Lviv.jpg|thumb|A [[didukh]] in [[Lviv]]]]
+[[File:Christmas Parade of Star-bearers in the centre of Lviv.jpg|thumb|right|A Christmas parade in [[Lviv]] in 2022]]
 Traditional Ukrainian Christmas festivities last from December 24 to January 6, the date of the celebration of the [[baptism of Jesus]], which known in Ukraine as {{lang|uk|Vodokhreshche}} or ''{{lang|uk|Yordan}}'',<ref name="UFA">{{cite web |title=Christmas Traditions of Ukraine |url=http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/ |publisher=Ukrainian Fraternal Association |access-date=24 December 2023 |archive-date=28 September 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230928143909/http://infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/ |url-status=live }}</ref> according to the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine]] (OCU),<ref name=":4" /> the [[Catholic Church in Ukraine|Catholic Church]] (including [[Latin Church in Ukraine|Latin]] and [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church|Ukrainian Greek Catholics]]<ref name=":3" />), and most [[Protestantism in Ukraine|Protestants]].
 
 As of 2017, 25 December, Christmas Day by the [[Gregorian calendar|Gregorian]] calendar, became an official government holiday in Ukraine. The [[Eastern Orthodox Church]]es predominantly follow the Julian calendar, and 7 January is also a [[Public holidays in Ukraine|public holiday in Ukraine]].<ref name="BBC1">{{cite news |title=Рада зробила 25 грудня вихідним днем |url=http://www.bbc.com/ukrainian/news-42008437 |access-date=18 November 2017 |work=[[BBC News Україна]] |date=16 November 2017 |page= |trans-title=The council made December 25 a day off |language=uk |archive-date=30 December 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171230065213/http://www.bbc.com/ukrainian/news-42008437 |url-status=live }}</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine]] (OCU), [[Epiphanius I of Ukraine|Metropolitan Epiphanius]], said that changing the date of Christmas to 25 December in Ukraine is possible after both the church and the faithful are ready for such a decision, after conducting educational work. It was stated that the postponement of the celebration of the nativity of The Lord would entail a change in the dates of all fixed holidays to 13 days ago.<ref name="Rok">{{cite news |last1=Rokitna |first1=Anastasia |title=Епіфаній назвав умову перенесення святкування Різдва на 25 грудня |url=https://news.rbc.ua/ukr/politics/epifaniy-nazval-uslovie-perenosa-prazdnovaniya-1608382147.html |access-date=25 December 2023 |work=RBC - Ukraine |publisher=UBT |date=19 December 2020 |page= |trans-title=Epiphany named the move of the Holy Day of Resurrection to the 25th birthday |language=uk |archive-date=20 December 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201220225410/https://news.rbc.ua/ukr/politics/epifaniy-nazval-uslovie-perenosa-prazdnovaniya-1608382147.html |url-status=live }}</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church]] (UGCC), [[Sviatoslav Shevchuk|Patriarch Sviatoslav]], stated that the Greek Catholic Church would resolve this issue "together with our Orthodox brothers". He also noted that this issue is not dogmatic, it should overcome church divisions, not cause new ones, and in his opinion, the transition to celebrating Christmas in a new style — 25 December, should be initiated by the laity.
llm_output:
Added an image of a Christmas parade in Lviv in 2022.

Not Weaponised – The addition of an image related to a cultural celebration does not contain any language or narratives that could be interpreted as weaponising cultural heritage. It simply enhances the article's content about Ukrainian Christmas festivities.

 [[Christmas Eve]] on December 24 is called Sviatyi Vechir (''Святий вечір'') or Sviatvechir (''Святвечір'') in Ukraine ("Holy Evening"), and has many customs and rituals, most of which predate the introduction of Christianity to Ukraine. Traditions include decorating house and dinner table with special attributes (a symbolic sheaf of wheat called the ''[[didukh]]'', [[garlic]], hay, and others), performing [[Koliada|koliadky]] ('carols') and so on.  Each ritual has its own meaning and purpose, as such a few wisps of hay on the embroidered tablecloth as a reminder of the manger in [[Bethlehem]]. One prominent custom of the night is a special supper, called ''[[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|Sviata Vecheria]]'' ("Holy Supper").{{sfn|Hughes|1997|pp=32{{ndash}}47}}

+In villages (farming communities), the head of the household brings in a sheaf of grain called the ''didukh'' which represents the importance of the ancient and rich wheat crops of Ukraine, the staff of life through the centuries. ''Didukh'' means literally "grandfather spirit" so it symbolizes the family's ancestors. In Ukrainian city homes the didukh may be purchased, and is often made of woven grain and dried grasses and flowers.<ref>{{citation |url=https://ukraine.ua/visit/christmas-in-ukraine/ |title=Ukrainian Christmas traditions}}</ref>
 
 ==See also==
 * [[Old New Year]]

 == Date of celebration ==
 [[File:Diduch-Lviv.jpg|thumb|A [[didukh]] in [[Lviv]]]]
-[[File:Christmas Parade of Star-bearers in the centre of Lviv.jpg|thumb|right|A Christmas parade in [[Lviv]] in 2022]]
+[[File:Christmas Parade of Star-bearers in the centre of Lviv.jpg|thumb|right|A Christmas parade in [[Lviv]] in January 2022, when the old Julian calendar was followed.]]
 Traditional Ukrainian Christmas festivities last from December 24 to January 6, the date of the celebration of the [[baptism of Jesus]], which known in Ukraine as {{lang|uk|Vodokhreshche}} or ''{{lang|uk|Yordan}}'',<ref name="UFA">{{cite web |title=Christmas Traditions of Ukraine |url=http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/ |publisher=Ukrainian Fraternal Association |access-date=24 December 2023 |archive-date=28 September 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230928143909/http://infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/ |url-status=live }}</ref> according to the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine]] (OCU),<ref name=":4" /> the [[Catholic Church in Ukraine|Catholic Church]] (including [[Latin Church in Ukraine|Latin]] and [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church|Ukrainian Greek Catholics]]<ref name=":3" />), and most [[Protestantism in Ukraine|Protestants]].
 
 As of 2017, 25 December, Christmas Day by the [[Gregorian calendar|Gregorian]] calendar, became an official government holiday in Ukraine. The [[Eastern Orthodox Church]]es predominantly follow the Julian calendar, and 7 January is also a [[Public holidays in Ukraine|public holiday in Ukraine]].<ref name="BBC1">{{cite news |title=Рада зробила 25 грудня вихідним днем |url=http://www.bbc.com/ukrainian/news-42008437 |access-date=18 November 2017 |work=[[BBC News Україна]] |date=16 November 2017 |page= |trans-title=The council made December 25 a day off |language=uk |archive-date=30 December 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171230065213/http://www.bbc.com/ukrainian/news-42008437 |url-status=live }}</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine]] (OCU), [[Epiphanius I of Ukraine|Metropolitan Epiphanius]], said that changing the date of Christmas to 25 December in Ukraine is possible after both the church and the faithful are ready for such a decision, after conducting educational work. It was stated that the postponement of the celebration of the nativity of The Lord would entail a change in the dates of all fixed holidays to 13 days ago.<ref name="Rok">{{cite news |last1=Rokitna |first1=Anastasia |title=Епіфаній назвав умову перенесення святкування Різдва на 25 грудня |url=https://news.rbc.ua/ukr/politics/epifaniy-nazval-uslovie-perenosa-prazdnovaniya-1608382147.html |access-date=25 December 2023 |work=RBC - Ukraine |publisher=UBT |date=19 December 2020 |page= |trans-title=Epiphany named the move of the Holy Day of Resurrection to the 25th birthday |language=uk |archive-date=20 December 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201220225410/https://news.rbc.ua/ukr/politics/epifaniy-nazval-uslovie-perenosa-prazdnovaniya-1608382147.html |url-status=live }}</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church]] (UGCC), [[Sviatoslav Shevchuk|Patriarch Sviatoslav]], stated that the Greek Catholic Church would resolve this issue "together with our Orthodox brothers". He also noted that this issue is not dogmatic, it should overcome church divisions, not cause new ones, and in his opinion, the transition to celebrating Christmas in a new style — 25 December, should be initiated by the laity.

 The {{ill|Armenian Diocese of Ukraine|hy|Ուկրաինայի հայոց թեմ|display=1}} of the [[Armenian Apostolic Church]] and the [[Armenian Catholic Church in Ukraine]] celebrates Christmas from January 5 to January 6 along with Epiphany according to the Gregorian calendar.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Do Lvivians know that Armenians celebrate Christmas on January 6? |url=https://tvoemisto.tv/blogs/shche_odna_data_rizdva_hto_u_lvovi_maie_svyatu_vecheryu_5_sichnya_141904.html |access-date=2023-06-18 |website=tvoemisto.tv |archive-date=18 June 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230618193050/https://tvoemisto.tv/blogs/shche_odna_data_rizdva_hto_u_lvovi_maie_svyatu_vecheryu_5_sichnya_141904.html |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |last=Терещук |first=Галина |date=2020-01-06 |title=Christmas in Lviv: three dates of the family holiday |language=uk |work=Радіо Свобода |url=https://www.radiosvoboda.org/a/30362341.html |access-date=2023-06-18 |archive-date=18 June 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230618193049/https://www.radiosvoboda.org/a/30362341.html |url-status=live }}</ref>
