-Traditional Ukrainian Christmas festivities last from December 24 to January 6, the date of the celebration of the [[baptism of Jesus]], which known in Ukraine as {{lang|uk|Vodokhreshche}} or ''{{lang|uk|Yordan}}'',<ref name="UFA">{{cite web |title=Christmas Traditions of Ukraine |url=http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/ |publisher=Ukrainian Fraternal Association |access-date=24 December 2023}}</ref> according to the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine]] (OCU),<ref name=":4" /> the [[Catholic Church in Ukraine|Catholic Church]] (including [[Latin Church in Ukraine|Latin]] and [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church|Ukrainian Greek Catholics]]<ref name=":3" />), and most [[Protestantism in Ukraine|Protestants]].
+Traditional Ukrainian Christmas festivities last from December 24 to January 6, the date of the celebration of the [[baptism of Jesus]], which known in Ukraine as {{lang|uk|Vodokhreshche}} or ''{{lang|uk|Yordan}}'',<ref name="UFA">{{cite web |title=Christmas Traditions of Ukraine |url=http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/ |publisher=Ukrainian Fraternal Association |access-date=24 December 2023 |archive-date=28 September 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230928143909/http://infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/ |url-status=live }}</ref> according to the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine]] (OCU),<ref name=":4" /> the [[Catholic Church in Ukraine|Catholic Church]] (including [[Latin Church in Ukraine|Latin]] and [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church|Ukrainian Greek Catholics]]<ref name=":3" />), and most [[Protestantism in Ukraine|Protestants]].
 
-As of 2017, 25 December, Christmas Day by the [[Gregorian calendar|Gregorian]] calendar, became an official government holiday in Ukraine. The [[Eastern Orthodox Church]]es predominantly follow the Julian calendar, and 7 January is also a [[Public holidays in Ukraine|public holiday in Ukraine]].<ref name="BBC1">{{cite news |title=Рада зробила 25 грудня вихідним днем |url=http://www.bbc.com/ukrainian/news-42008437 |access-date=18 November 2017 |work=[[BBC News Україна]] |date=16 November 2017 |page=|trans-title=The council made December 25 a day off |language=uk}}</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine]] (OCU), [[Epiphanius I of Ukraine|Metropolitan Epiphanius]], said that changing the date of Christmas to 25 December in Ukraine is possible after both the church and the faithful are ready for such a decision, after conducting educational work. It was stated that the postponement of the celebration of the nativity of The Lord would entail a change in the dates of all fixed holidays to 13 days ago.<ref name="Rok">{{cite news |last1=Rokitna |first1=Anastasia |title=Епифаний назвал условие переноса празднования Рождества на 25 декабря |url=https://news.rbc.ua/ukr/politics/epifaniy-nazval-uslovie-perenosa-prazdnovaniya-1608382147.html|title = Епіфаній назвав умову перенесення святкування Різдва на 25 грудня |access-date=25 December 2023 |work=RBC - Ukraine |publisher=UBT |date=19 December 2020 |page=|trans-title=Epiphany named the move of the Holy Day of Resurrection to the 25th birthday |language=uk}}</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church]] (UGCC), [[Sviatoslav Shevchuk|Patriarch Sviatoslav]], stated that the Greek Catholic Church would resolve this issue "together with our Orthodox brothers". He also noted that this issue is not dogmatic, it should overcome church divisions, not cause new ones, and in his opinion, the transition to celebrating Christmas in a new style — 25 December, should be initiated by the laity.
+As of 2017, 25 December, Christmas Day by the [[Gregorian calendar|Gregorian]] calendar, became an official government holiday in Ukraine. The [[Eastern Orthodox Church]]es predominantly follow the Julian calendar, and 7 January is also a [[Public holidays in Ukraine|public holiday in Ukraine]].<ref name="BBC1">{{cite news |title=Рада зробила 25 грудня вихідним днем |url=http://www.bbc.com/ukrainian/news-42008437 |access-date=18 November 2017 |work=[[BBC News Україна]] |date=16 November 2017 |page= |trans-title=The council made December 25 a day off |language=uk |archive-date=30 December 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171230065213/http://www.bbc.com/ukrainian/news-42008437 |url-status=live }}</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine]] (OCU), [[Epiphanius I of Ukraine|Metropolitan Epiphanius]], said that changing the date of Christmas to 25 December in Ukraine is possible after both the church and the faithful are ready for such a decision, after conducting educational work. It was stated that the postponement of the celebration of the nativity of The Lord would entail a change in the dates of all fixed holidays to 13 days ago.<ref name="Rok">{{cite news |last1=Rokitna |first1=Anastasia |title=Епіфаній назвав умову перенесення святкування Різдва на 25 грудня |url=https://news.rbc.ua/ukr/politics/epifaniy-nazval-uslovie-perenosa-prazdnovaniya-1608382147.html |access-date=25 December 2023 |work=RBC - Ukraine |publisher=UBT |date=19 December 2020 |page= |trans-title=Epiphany named the move of the Holy Day of Resurrection to the 25th birthday |language=uk |archive-date=20 December 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201220225410/https://news.rbc.ua/ukr/politics/epifaniy-nazval-uslovie-perenosa-prazdnovaniya-1608382147.html |url-status=live }}</ref> In December 2020, the head of the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church]] (UGCC), [[Sviatoslav Shevchuk|Patriarch Sviatoslav]], stated that the Greek Catholic Church would resolve this issue "together with our Orthodox brothers". He also noted that this issue is not dogmatic, it should overcome church divisions, not cause new ones, and in his opinion, the transition to celebrating Christmas in a new style — 25 December, should be initiated by the laity.
 
-About a hundred parishes of the [[Romanians in Ukraine|Romanian national minority in Ukraine]], which are part of the [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)|Ukrainian Orthodox Church of the Moscow Patriarchate]], have always celebrated Christmas on December 25 according to the [[Revised Julian calendar]], just like the [[Romanian Orthodox Church]].<ref name=":2">{{Cite news |last=Kralyuk |first=Petro |date=2 January 2023 |title=«Є сподівання, що ПЦУ і УГКЦ перейдуть на святкування Різдва 25 грудня» – професор Петро Кралюк |trans-title="There is hope that OCU and UGCC will celebrate Christmas on December 25" - Professor Petro Kralyuk

+On 18 October 2022, the OCU allowed dioceses to hold Christmas services according to the Revised Julian calendar, i.e., 25 December. In the case of a divine service, its participants are released from the restrictions of fasting on this day.<ref>{{Cite web |title=OCU allowed Christmas services on December 25 |url=https://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2022/10/18/7372478/ |accessdate=2022-10-18 |website=[[Ukrainian Pravda]] |language=uk |archive-date=25 December 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221225205042/https://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2022/10/18/7372478/ |url-status=live }}</ref>
 
-On 24 December 2022, during an [[audience]], [[Major Archbishop]] Sviatoslav handed over to [[Metropolitan of Kyiv and All Ukraine|Metropolitan]] Epiphanius for review a letter outlining the considerations of the UGCC hierarchs regarding the {{ill|Calendar reform in Ukraine|lt=calendar reform|uk|Календарна реформа в Україні|display=1}}. The primates decided to create a joint working group on specific proposals for calendar reform. The joint group is initiated on the occasion of the celebration of the 1700th anniversary of the [[First Council of Nicaea|First Ecumenical Council]], held in [[Nicaea]] in 325. In this [[Ecumenical council|Council]], in particular, the calendar principles of church life were determined.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Heads of OCU, UGCC agree to set up working group to reform church calendar |url=https://www.ukrinform.net/rubric-society/3640576-heads-of-ocu-ugcc-agree-to-set-up-working-group-to-reform-church-calendar.html |access-date=2022-12-24 |website=www.ukrinform.net |date=24 December 2022 |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=During the meeting of His Beatitude Sviatoslav with His Beatitude Epiphanius, they talked about the reform of the church calendar |url=https://news.ugcc.ua/data/pid-chas-zustrichi-blazhennishogo-svyatoslava-z-blazhennishym-epifaniem-govoryly-pro-reformu-tserkovnogo-kalendarya-1713/ |access-date=2022-12-24 |website=Українська Греко-Католицька Церква |language=uk |archive-date=24 December 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221224150917/https://news.ugcc.ua/data/pid-chas-zustrichi-blazhennishogo-svyatoslava-z-blazhennishym-epifaniem-govoryly-pro-reformu-tserkovnogo-kalendarya-1713/ |url-status=dead }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2022-12-24 |title=There was a meeting of the Primate of the OCU with the Father and the Primate of the UGCC |url=https://www.pomisna.info/uk/vsi-novyny/vidbulasya-zustrich-predstoyatelya-ptsu-z-ottsem-i-glavoyu-ugkts/ |access-date=2022-12-24 |website=OCU |language=uk}}</ref>
+On 24 December 2022, during an [[audience]], [[Major Archbishop]] Sviatoslav handed over to [[Metropolitan of Kyiv and All Ukraine|Metropolitan]] Epiphanius for review a letter outlining the considerations of the UGCC hierarchs regarding the {{ill|Calendar reform in Ukraine|lt=calendar reform|uk|Календарна реформа в Україні|display=1}}. The primates decided to create a joint working group on specific proposals for calendar reform. The joint group is initiated on the occasion of the celebration of the 1700th anniversary of the [[First Council of Nicaea|First Ecumenical Council]], held in [[Nicaea]] in 325. In this [[Ecumenical council|Council]], in particular, the calendar principles of church life were determined.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Heads of OCU, UGCC agree to set up working group to reform church calendar |url=https://www.ukrinform.net/rubric-society/3640576-heads-of-ocu-ugcc-agree-to-set-up-working-group-to-reform-church-calendar.html |access-date=2022-12-24 |website=www.ukrinform.net |date=24 December 2022 |language=en |archive-date=25 December 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221225105700/https://www.ukrinform.net/rubric-society/3640576-heads-of-ocu-ugcc-agree-to-set-up-working-group-to-reform-church-calendar.html |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=During the meeting of His Beatitude Sviatoslav with His Beatitude Epiphanius, they talked about the reform of the church calendar |url=https://news.ugcc.ua/data/pid-chas-zustrichi-blazhennishogo-svyatoslava-z-blazhennishym-epifaniem-govoryly-pro-reformu-tserkovnogo-kalendarya-1713/ |access-date=2022-12-24 |website=Українська Греко-Католицька Церква |language=uk |archive-date=24 December 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221224150917/https://news.ugcc.ua/data/pid-chas-zustrichi-blazhennishogo-svyatoslava-z-blazhennishym-epifaniem-govoryly-pro-reformu-tserkovnogo-kalendarya-1713/ |url-status=dead }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2022-12-24 |title=There was a meeting of the Primate of the OCU with the Father and the Primate of the UGCC |url=https://www.pomisna.info/uk/vsi-novyny/vidbulasya-zustrich-predstoyatelya-ptsu-z-ottsem-i-glavoyu-ugkts/ |access-date=2022-12-24 |website=OCU |language=uk |archive-date=24 December 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221224220329/https://www.pomisna.info/uk/vsi-novyny/vidbulasya-zustrich-predstoyatelya-ptsu-z-ottsem-i-glavoyu-ugkts/ |url-status=live }}</ref>
 
-On February 2, 2023, the Holy Synod of the OCU allowed and approved the procedure for blessing parishes and monasteries for the full use of the Revised Julian calendar,<ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-02-02 |title=Decree of the Holy Synod on the procedure for blessing parishes and monasteries for the use of the Revised Julian calendar |url=https://www.pomisna.info/uk/vsi-novyny/postanova-svyashhennogo-synodu-pro-poryadok-nadannya-blagoslovennya-parafiyam-ta-monastyryam-na-vykorystannya-novoyulianskogo-kalendarya/ |access-date=2023-02-03 |website=OCU |language=uk}}</ref> and on May 24, 2023, to hold a meeting of the Council of Bishops, where the issue of calendar reform will be raised.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-02-02 |title=Official notice of the meeting of the Holy Synod on February 2, 2023. |url=https://www.pomisna.info/uk/vsi-novyny/ofitsijne-povidomlennya-pro-zasidannya-svyashhennogo-synodu-2-lyutogo-2023-r/ |access-date=2023-02-03 |website=OCU |language=uk}}</ref> 
+On February 2, 2023, the Holy Synod of the OCU allowed and approved the procedure for blessing parishes and monasteries for the full use of the Revised Julian calendar,<ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-02-02 |title=Decree of the Holy Synod on the procedure for blessing parishes and monasteries for the use of the Revised Julian calendar |url=https://www.pomisna.info/uk/vsi-novyny/postanova-svyashhennogo-synodu-pro-poryadok-nadannya-blagoslovennya-parafiyam-ta-monastyryam-na-vykorystannya-novoyulianskogo-kalendarya/ |access-date=2023-02-03 |website=OCU |language=uk |archive-date=3 February 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230203022742/https://www.pomisna.info/uk/vsi-novyny/postanova-svyashhennogo-synodu-pro-poryadok-nadannya-blagoslovennya-parafiyam-ta-monastyryam-na-vykorystannya-novoyulianskogo-kalendarya/ |url-status=live }}</ref> and on May 24, 2023, to hold a meeting of the Council of Bishops, where the issue of calendar reform will be raised.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-02-02 |title=Official notice of the meeting of the Holy Synod on February 2, 2023. |url=https://www.pomisna.info/uk/vsi-novyny/ofitsijne-povidomlennya-pro-zasidannya-svyashhennogo-synodu-2-lyutogo-2023-r/ |access-date=2023-02-03 |website=OCU |language=uk |archive-date=31 May 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230531232636/https://www.pomisna.info/uk/vsi-novyny/ofitsijne-povidomlennya-pro-zasidannya-svyashhennogo-synodu-2-lyutogo-2023-r/ |url-status=live }}</ref> 
 
-In February 2023 the UGCC decided to switch to the Revised Julian calendar for fixed holidays (і.e., except for [[Date of Easter|Easter]]) from September 2023.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Historical decision: the UGCC in Ukraine switches to a new calendar|url=https://ugcc.ua/en/data/historical-decision-the-ugcc-in-ukraine-switches-to-a-new-calendar-232/ |access-date=2023-07-19 |website=Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church |language=en}}</ref> [[Parish|Parishes]] of the UGCC that are not ready to switch to the new style in 2023 have a transition period until September 1, 2025 to make the change.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web |date=2023-02-06 |title=Ukraine Catholic Church moves from Russian-affiliated Julian calendar |url=https://www.pillarcatholic.com/ukraine-catholic-church-moves-from-russian/ |access-date=2023-02-06 |website=The Pillar |language=en}}</ref>
+In February 2023 the UGCC decided to switch to the Revised Julian calendar for fixed holidays (і.e., except for [[Date of Easter|Easter]]) from September 2023.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Historical decision: the UGCC in Ukraine switches to a new calendar |url=https://ugcc.ua/en/data/historical-decision-the-ugcc-in-ukraine-switches-to-a-new-calendar-232/ |access-date=2023-07-19 |website=Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church |language=en |archive-date=11 November 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231111164044/https://ugcc.ua/en/data/historical-decision-the-ugcc-in-ukraine-switches-to-a-new-calendar-232/ |url-status=live }}</ref> [[Parish|Parishes]] of the UGCC that are not ready to switch to the new style in 2023 have a transition period until September 1, 2025 to make the change.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web |date=2023-02-06 |title=Ukraine Catholic Church moves from Russian-affiliated Julian calendar |url=https://www.pillarcatholic.com/ukraine-catholic-church-moves-from-russian/ |access-date=2023-02-06 |website=The Pillar |language=en |archive-date=6 February 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230206235410/https://www.pillarcatholic.com/ukraine-catholic-church-moves-from-russian/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

 ==Sviatyi Vechir (Holy Evening)==
 [[File:Шопка_перед_львівською_ратушою.jpg|thumb|[[Nativity scene]]]]
 [[Christmas Eve]] on December 24 is called Sviatyi Vechir (''Святий вечір'') or Sviatvechir (''Святвечір'') in Ukraine ("Holy Evening"), and has many customs and rituals, most of which predate the introduction of Christianity to Ukraine. Traditions include decorating house and dinner table with special attributes (a symbolic sheaf of wheat called the ''[[didukh]]'', [[garlic]], hay, and others), performing [[Koliada|koliadky]] ('carols') and so on.  Each ritual has its own meaning and purpose, as such a few wisps of hay on the embroidered tablecloth as a reminder of the manger in [[Bethlehem]]. One prominent custom of the night is a special supper, called ''[[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|Sviata Vecheria]]'' ("Holy Supper").{{sfn|Hughes|1997|pp=32{{ndash}}47}}
 
-Ukrainians of the OCU and UGCC fast on Sviatyi Vechir ([[Latin Church]] Catholics and Protestants may choose also to follow tradition on said day); only when the first star is seen in the evening sky, may the supper begin.  The family comes together to have a dinner which usually includes 12 dishes (the number can vary from 7–17). These twelve dishes are traditionally vegan plus fish, and do not contain meat, milk, or eggs.<ref>{{cite web |title=Christmas in Ukraine |url=https://www.whychristmas.com/cultures/ukraine.shtml |website=Why Christmas |access-date=14 December 2020}}</ref> While the dishes served can vary regionally, as well as from family to family, the two mandatory dishes are ''uzvar'' and ''kutia'', both reckoned by ethnographer [[Fedir Vovk|Khvedir Vovk]] to be remnants of ancient rituals which date back to the neolithic era.<ref>{{cite web |title=Traditional Recipe of Ukrainian Kutia |url=https://etnocook.com/kutia/ |website=Ethnocook |date=18 January 2018 |access-date=27 November 2022}}</ref> ''[[Kutia]]'' (a dish of grain, honey and poppy seeds) is traditionally served first at the meal, after being offered by the head of the household to the frost. A spoonful is tossed at the ceiling, and in rural townships the number of poppy seeds which stick portends the bountyfulness of the fields, orchards and farm animals in the coming year. It is rarely served at other times of the year.<ref>[http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html Sviat Vechir<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> ''Uzvar'' is a beverage, made with cooked dried fruits and berries. It can be mixed in with the ''kutia'', or served separately at the end of the meal.  Servings of both dishes are also set aside overnight in the ''pokuttia'', the corner of the house with the Orthodox/Eastern Catholic icons or Latin Catholic images of saints, for deceased ancestors within the family or, in recent cases, for family members killed during the Russo-Ukrainian War (especially those who were KIA in the Armed Forces of Ukraine and other uniformed organizations).
+Ukrainians of the OCU and UGCC fast on Sviatyi Vechir ([[Latin Church]] Catholics and Protestants may choose also to follow tradition on said day); only when the first star is seen in the evening sky, may the supper begin.  The family comes together to have a dinner which usually includes 12 dishes (the number can vary from 7–17). These twelve dishes are traditionally vegan plus fish, and do not contain meat, milk, or eggs.<ref>{{cite web |title=Christmas in Ukraine |url=https://www.whychristmas.com/cultures/ukraine.shtml |website=Why Christmas |access-date=14 December 2020 |archive-date=7 December 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201207184630/https://www.whychristmas.com/cultures/ukraine.shtml |url-status=live }}</ref> While the dishes served can vary regionally, as well as from family to family, the two mandatory dishes are ''uzvar'' and ''kutia'', both reckoned by ethnographer [[Fedir Vovk|Khvedir Vovk]] to be remnants of ancient rituals which date back to the neolithic era.<ref>{{cite web |title=Traditional Recipe of Ukrainian Kutia |url=https://etnocook.com/kutia/ |website=Ethnocook |date=18 January 2018 |access-date=27 November 2022 |archive-date=28 November 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221128164554/https://etnocook.com/kutia/ |url-status=live }}</ref> ''[[Kutia]]'' (a dish of grain, honey and poppy seeds) is traditionally served first at the meal, after being offered by the head of the household to the frost. A spoonful is tossed at the ceiling, and in rural townships the number of poppy seeds which stick portends the bountyfulness of the fields, orchards and farm animals in the coming year. It is rarely served at other times of the year.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html |title=Sviat Vechir<!-- Bot generated title --> |access-date=7 January 2013 |archive-date=9 January 2008 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080109035835/http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html |url-status=live }}</ref> ''Uzvar'' is a beverage, made with cooked dried fruits and berries. It can be mixed in with the ''kutia'', or served separately at the end of the meal.  Servings of both dishes are also set aside overnight in the ''pokuttia'', the corner of the house with the Orthodox/Eastern Catholic icons or Latin Catholic images of saints, for deceased ancestors within the family or, in recent cases, for family members killed during the Russo-Ukrainian War (especially those who were KIA in the Armed Forces of Ukraine and other uniformed organizations).
 
-The All-Night Christmas Vigil then follows, families then troop to their local parish churches or Protestant churches to attend as thanksgiving for the Savior's birth in a stable.  A ''[[Nativity scene|shopka]]'' (''[[vertep]]'') is a traditional portable [[Nativity of Jesus|nativity]] scene used to represent nativity and other figures in a [[Nativity play|puppet]] form.<ref>{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=G_8pAQAAIAAJ&newbks=0&printsec=frontcover&dq=shopka+ukraine+christmas+eve&q=shopka+ukraine+christmas+eve&hl=en |title=Soviet Studies in Literature |date=1990 |publisher=International Arts and Science Press |language=en}}</ref>
+The All-Night Christmas Vigil then follows, families then troop to their local parish churches or Protestant churches to attend as thanksgiving for the Savior's birth in a stable.  A ''[[Nativity scene|shopka]]'' (''[[vertep]]'') is a traditional portable [[Nativity of Jesus|nativity]] scene used to represent nativity and other figures in a [[Nativity play|puppet]] form.<ref>{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=G_8pAQAAIAAJ&newbks=0&printsec=frontcover&dq=shopka+ukraine+christmas+eve&q=shopka+ukraine+christmas+eve&hl=en |title=Soviet Studies in Literature |date=1990 |publisher=International Arts and Science Press |language=en |access-date=25 December 2023 |archive-date=25 December 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231225104358/https://books.google.com/books?id=G_8pAQAAIAAJ&newbks=0&printsec=frontcover&dq=shopka+ukraine+christmas+eve&q=shopka+ukraine+christmas+eve&hl=en |url-status=live }}</ref>
 
 ==''Koliadky'' (Caroling)==
 At the end of the {{lang|uk|Sviata Vechera}}, and the [[vigil]] that follows, Ukrainian families often sing carols ({{lang|uk|koliadky}}). In some communities the ancient Ukrainian tradition of caroling is carried on by groups of young people and members of organizations and churches calling at homes and collecting donations. Well-known carols include ''{{ill|Nova radist stala|lt=|uk|Нова радість стала|display=1}}'', [[Boh predvičnyj narodivsja|''Boh predvichnyi narodyvsia'']],<ref name=Met>{{cite web|title=Boh predvičnyj|url=http://mci.archpitt.org/legacy/songs/Slavonic/Boh_predvicnyj.html|website=Metropolitan Cantor Institute|publisher=Byzantine Catholic|access-date=12 August 2015|ref=Archeparchy of Pittsburgh|archive-date=4 March 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304235614/http://mci.archpitt.org/legacy/songs/Slavonic/Boh_predvicnyj.html|url-status=dead}}</ref> ''{{ill|Dobryi vechir tobi, pane hospodariu|lt=|uk|Добрий вечір тобі, пане господарю|display=1}}'', ''{{ill|Vo Vyfleiemi nyni novyna|lt=|uk|Во Вифлеємі нині новина|display=1}}'', ''{{ill|Nebo i zemlia nyni torzhestvuiut|lt=|uk|Небо і земля нині торжествують|display=1}}'', and ''{{ill|Boh sia rozhdaie|lt=|uk|Бог ся раджае|display=1}}''.
 
 ==''[[Didukh]]'' (grandfather)==
 [[File:Didukh.jpg|thumb|right]]
-In villages (farming communities), the head of the household brings in a sheaf of grain called the ''didukh'' which represents the importance of the ancient and rich wheat crops of Ukraine, the staff of life through the centuries. ''Didukh'' means literally "grandfather spirit" so it symbolizes the family's ancestors. In Ukrainian city homes the didukh may be purchased, and is often made of woven grain and dried grasses and flowers.<ref>{{citation |url=https://ukraine.ua/visit/christmas-in-ukraine/ |title=Ukrainian Christmas traditions}}</ref>
+In villages (farming communities), the head of the household brings in a sheaf of grain called the ''didukh'' which represents the importance of the ancient and rich wheat crops of Ukraine, the staff of life through the centuries. ''Didukh'' means literally "grandfather spirit" so it symbolizes the family's ancestors. In Ukrainian city homes the didukh may be purchased, and is often made of woven grain and dried grasses and flowers.<ref>{{citation |url=https://ukraine.ua/visit/christmas-in-ukraine/ |title=Ukrainian Christmas traditions |access-date=25 December 2023 |archive-date=26 September 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230926122712/https://ukraine.ua/visit/christmas-in-ukraine/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

 On the afternoon of the day, a St. Basil Divine Liturgy is held in parishes to mark the formal close of the [[Nativity Fast|Christmas Fast]] within the OCU and UGCC that began in November, which includes commemorations of the [[Holodomor]] of the 1930s, the liturgy follows a Christmas version of the [[Royal Hours]].
 
-Ukrainians of the OCU and UGCC fast on Sviatyi Vechir ([[Latin Church]] Catholics and Protestants may choose also to follow tradition on said day); only when the first star is seen in the evening sky, or just after the faithful have recieved Communion in the afternoon service, may the supper begin.  The family comes together to have a dinner which usually includes 12 dishes (the number can vary from 7–17). These twelve dishes are traditionally vegan plus fish, and do not contain meat, milk, or eggs.<ref>{{cite web |title=Christmas in Ukraine |url=https://www.whychristmas.com/cultures/ukraine.shtml |website=Why Christmas |access-date=14 December 2020 |archive-date=7 December 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201207184630/https://www.whychristmas.com/cultures/ukraine.shtml |url-status=live }}</ref> While the dishes served can vary regionally, as well as from family to family, the two mandatory dishes are ''uzvar'' and ''kutia'', both reckoned by ethnographer [[Fedir Vovk|Khvedir Vovk]] to be remnants of ancient rituals which date back to the neolithic era.<ref>{{cite web |title=Traditional Recipe of Ukrainian Kutia |url=https://etnocook.com/kutia/ |website=Ethnocook |date=18 January 2018 |access-date=27 November 2022 |archive-date=28 November 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221128164554/https://etnocook.com/kutia/ |url-status=live }}</ref> ''[[Kutia]]'' (a dish of grain, honey and poppy seeds) is traditionally served first at the meal, after being offered by the head of the household to the frost. A spoonful is tossed at the ceiling, and in rural townships the number of poppy seeds which stick portends the bountyfulness of the fields, orchards and farm animals in the coming year. It is rarely served at other times of the year.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html |title=Sviat Vechir<!-- Bot generated title --> |access-date=7 January 2013 |archive-date=9 January 2008 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080109035835/http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html |url-status=live }}</ref> ''Uzvar'' is a beverage, made with cooked dried fruits and berries. It can be mixed in with the ''kutia'', or served separately at the end of the meal.  Servings of both dishes are also set aside overnight in the ''pokuttia'', the corner of the house with the Orthodox/Eastern Catholic icons or Latin Catholic images of saints, for deceased ancestors within the family or, in recent cases, for family members killed during the Russo-Ukrainian War (especially those who were KIA in the Armed Forces of Ukraine and other uniformed organizations).

A spoonful is tossed at the ceiling, and in rural townships the number of poppy seeds which stick portends the bountyfulness of the fields, orchards and farm animals in the coming year.  [[File:Шопка_перед_львівською_ратушою.jpg|thumb|[[Nativity scene]]]]
 [[Christmas Eve]] on December 24 is called Sviatyi Vechir (''Святий вечір'') or Sviatvechir (''Святвечір'') in Ukraine ("Holy Evening"), and has many customs and rituals, most of which predate the introduction of Christianity to Ukraine. Traditions include decorating house and dinner table with special attributes (a symbolic sheaf of wheat called the ''[[didukh]]'', [[garlic]], hay, and others), performing [[Koliada|koliadky]] ('carols') and so on.  Each ritual has its own meaning and purpose, as such a few wisps of hay on the embroidered tablecloth as a reminder of the manger in [[Bethlehem]]. One prominent custom of the night is a special supper, called ''[[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|Sviata Vecheria]]'' ("Holy Supper").{{sfn|Hughes|1997|pp=32{{ndash}}47}} 
 
-On the morning of the day, a St. Basil Divine Liturgy is held to mark the formal close of the [[Nativity Fast|Christmas Fast]] within the OCU and UGCC that began in November, which includes commemorations of the [[Holodomor]] of the 1930s.

@@ -76,9 +76,9 @@
 [[File:Шопка_перед_львівською_ратушою.jpg|thumb|[[Nativity scene]]]]
 [[Christmas Eve]] on December 24 is called Sviatyi Vechir (''Святий вечір'') or Sviatvechir (''Святвечір'') in Ukraine ("Holy Evening"), and has many customs and rituals, most of which predate the introduction of Christianity to Ukraine. Traditions include decorating house and dinner table with special attributes (a symbolic sheaf of wheat called the ''[[didukh]]'', [[garlic]], hay, and others), performing [[Koliada|koliadky]] ('carols') and so on.  Each ritual has its own meaning and purpose, as such a few wisps of hay on the embroidered tablecloth as a reminder of the manger in [[Bethlehem]]. One prominent custom of the night is a special supper, called ''[[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|Sviata Vecheria]]'' ("Holy Supper").{{sfn|Hughes|1997|pp=32{{ndash}}47}} 
 
-On the morning of the day, a St. Basil Divine Liturgy is held to mark the formal close of the [[Nativity Fast|Christmas Fast]] within the OCU and UGCC that began in November, which includes commemorations of the [[Holodomor]] of the 1930s, the liturgy follows a Christmas version of the [[Royal Hours]].
+On the afternoon of the day, a St. Basil Divine Liturgy is held in parishes to mark the formal close of the [[Nativity Fast|Christmas Fast]] within the OCU and UGCC that began in November, which includes commemorations of the [[Holodomor]] of the 1930s, the liturgy follows a Christmas version of the [[Royal Hours]].
 
-Ukrainians of the OCU and UGCC fast on Sviatyi Vechir ([[Latin Church]] Catholics and Protestants may choose also to follow tradition on said day); only when the first star is seen in the evening sky, may the supper begin.  The family comes together to have a dinner which usually includes 12 dishes (the number can vary from 7–17). These twelve dishes are traditionally vegan plus fish, and do not contain meat, milk, or eggs.<ref>{{cite web |title=Christmas in Ukraine |url=https://www.whychristmas.com/cultures/ukraine.shtml |website=Why Christmas |access-date=14 December 2020 |archive-date=7 December 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201207184630/https://www.whychristmas.com/cultures/ukraine.shtml |url-status=live }}</ref> While the dishes served can vary regionally, as well as from family to family, the two mandatory dishes are ''uzvar'' and ''kutia'', both reckoned by ethnographer [[Fedir Vovk|Khvedir Vovk]] to be remnants of ancient rituals which date back to the neolithic era.<ref>{{cite web |title=Traditional Recipe of Ukrainian Kutia |url=https://etnocook.com/kutia/ |website=Ethnocook |date=18 January 2018 |access-date=27 November 2022 |archive-date=28 November 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221128164554/https://etnocook.com/kutia/ |url-status=live }}</ref> ''[[Kutia]]'' (a dish of grain, honey and poppy seeds) is traditionally served first at the meal, after being offered by the head of the household to the frost. A spoonful is tossed at the ceiling, and in rural townships the number of poppy seeds which stick portends the bountyfulness of the fields, orchards and farm animals in the coming year. It is rarely served at other times of the year.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html |title=Sviat Vechir<!-- Bot generated title --> |access-date=7 January 2013 |archive-date=9 January 2008 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080109035835/http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html |url-status=live }}</ref> ''Uzvar'' is a beverage, made with cooked dried fruits and berries. It can be mixed in with the ''kutia'', or served separately at the end of the meal.  Servings of both dishes are also set aside overnight in the ''pokuttia'', the corner of the house with the Orthodox/Eastern Catholic icons or Latin Catholic images of saints, for deceased ancestors within the family or, in recent cases, for family members killed during the Russo-Ukrainian War (especially those who were KIA in the Armed Forces of Ukraine and other uniformed organizations).
+Ukrainians of the OCU and UGCC fast on Sviatyi Vechir ([[Latin Church]] Catholics and Protestants may choose also to follow tradition on said day); only when the first star is seen in the evening sky, or just after the faithful have recieved Communion in the afternoon service, may the supper begin.  The family comes together to have a dinner which usually includes 12 dishes (the number can vary from 7–17). These twelve dishes are traditionally vegan plus fish, and do not contain meat, milk, or eggs.<ref>{{cite web |title=Christmas in Ukraine |url=https://www.whychristmas.com/cultures/ukraine.shtml |website=Why Christmas |access-date=14 December 2020 |archive-date=7 December 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201207184630/https://www.whychristmas.com/cultures/ukraine.shtml |url-status=live }}</ref> While the dishes served can vary regionally, as well as from family to family, the two mandatory dishes are ''uzvar'' and ''kutia'', both reckoned by ethnographer [[Fedir Vovk|Khvedir Vovk]] to be remnants of ancient rituals which date back to the neolithic era.<ref>{{cite web |title=Traditional Recipe of Ukrainian Kutia |url=https://etnocook.com/kutia/ |website=Ethnocook |date=18 January 2018 |access-date=27 November 2022 |archive-date=28 November 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221128164554/https://etnocook.com/kutia/ |url-status=live }}</ref> ''[[Kutia]]'' (a dish of grain, honey and poppy seeds) is traditionally served first at the meal, after being offered by the head of the household to the frost. A spoonful is tossed at the ceiling, and in rural townships the number of poppy seeds which stick portends the bountyfulness of the fields, orchards and farm animals in the coming year. It is rarely served at other times of the year.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html |title=Sviat Vechir<!-- Bot generated title --> |access-date=7 January 2013 |archive-date=9 January 2008 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080109035835/http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html |url-status=live }}</ref> ''Uzvar'' is a beverage, made with cooked dried fruits and berries. It can be mixed in with the ''kutia'', or served separately at the end of the meal.  Servings of both dishes are also set aside overnight in the ''pokuttia'', the corner of the house with the Orthodox/Eastern Catholic icons or Latin Catholic images of saints, for deceased ancestors within the family or, in recent cases, for family members killed during the Russo-Ukrainian War (especially those who were KIA in the Armed Forces of Ukraine and other uniformed organizations).
 
 The All-Night Christmas Vigil then follows, families then troop to their local parish churches or Protestant churches to attend as thanksgiving for the Savior's birth in a stable.  On Christmas Eve night a ''[[Nativity scene|shopka]]'' (''[[vertep]]''), a traditional portable [[Nativity of Jesus|nativity]] scene, carried by children or adults alike, and used to represent the Nativity and other figures in a [[Nativity play|puppet]] form, is brought out in public, the portable tall box is either accompanied by singing carollers or crowds either before or after the vigil service.<ref>{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=G_8pAQAAIAAJ&q=shopka+ukraine+christmas+eve |title=Soviet Studies in Literature |date=1990 |publisher=International Arts and Science Press |language=en |access-date=25 December 2023 |archive-date=25 December 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231225104358/https://books.google.com/books?id=G_8pAQAAIAAJ&newbks=0&printsec=frontcover&dq=shopka+ukraine+christmas+eve&q=shopka+ukraine+christmas+eve&hl=en |url-status=live }}</ref>

+The All-Night Christmas Vigil then follows, families then troop to their local parish churches or Protestant churches to attend as thanksgiving for the Savior's birth in a stable.  On Christmas Eve night a ''[[Nativity scene|shopka]]'' (''[[vertep]]''), a traditional portable [[Nativity of Jesus|nativity]] scene, carried by children or adults alike, and used to represent the Nativity and other figures in a [[Nativity play|puppet]] form, is brought out in public, the portable tall box is either accompanied by singing carollers or crowds.<ref>{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=G_8pAQAAIAAJ&q=shopka+ukraine+christmas+eve |title=Soviet Studies in Literature |date=1990 |publisher=International Arts and Science Press |language=en |access-date=25 December 2023 |archive-date=25 December 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231225104358/https://books.google.com/books?id=G_8pAQAAIAAJ&newbks=0&printsec=frontcover&dq=shopka+ukraine+christmas+eve&q=shopka+ukraine+christmas+eve&hl=en |url-status=live }}</ref>
+
+
+== Christmas Day ==
+Following the Vigil, on December 25 families return to the aformentioned places of worship for Mass, Divine Liturgy or a holiday service. Unlike the previous day, meat and others are eaten during the day.
 
 ==''Koliadky'' (Caroling)==
 At the end of the {{lang|uk|Sviata Vechera}}, and the [[vigil]] that follows, Ukrainian families often sing carols ({{lang|uk|koliadky}}). In some communities the ancient Ukrainian tradition of caroling is carried on by groups of young people and members of organizations and churches calling at homes and collecting donations. |url=https://www.ukrinform.net/rubric-society/3735767-parliament-changes-dates-of-three-holidays-christmas-statehood-day-day-of-defenders-of-ukraine.html |access-date=2023-07-14 |website=[[Ukrinform]] |url-status=live }}</ref> Zelensky signed the law on 28 July 2023.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.cnn.com/2023/07/29/europe/ukraine-christmas-date-change-intl/index.html | last1 = Toropin | first1 -According to a study conducted by the international company [[Deloitte]] in November 2023, after the transition of Ukrainian Christian churches to the new style, the majority of [[Ukrainians]] (about 45%) will celebrate Christmas on December 25 and only 17% on January 7, and 32% plan to celebrate twice.<ref>{{Cite web |title=More donations to the Armed Forces, new traditions and the continuation of the boycott of sellers still working in the Russian Federation – Deloitte research on New Year's shopping of Ukrainians |url=https://www2.deloitte.com/ua/uk/pages/press-room/press-release/2023/holiday-retail-sales-consumer-survey.html |accessdate=2023-12-13 |website="Deloitte" in Ukraine |language=uk |archive-date=13 December 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231213140925/https://www2.deloitte.com/ua/uk/pages/press-room/press-release/2023/holiday-retail-sales-consumer-survey.html |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-12-08 |title=The vast majority of Ukrainians will celebrate Christmas on December 25 – survey |url=https://religionpravda.com.ua/?p=90196 |accessdate=2023-12-13 |website=Religious Pravda |language=uk |archive-date=25 December 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231225104318/https://religionpravda.com.ua/?p=90196 |url-status=live }}</ref>  In 2023, for the first time since 1917, [[Christmas Day]] in Ukraine will officially be on December 25.<ref name="BBC">{{cite news |last1=Waterhouse |first1=James |title=Ukraine war: New Christmas date marks shift away from Russia |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-67801204 |access-date=24 December 2023 |work=[[BBC News]] |date=23 December 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231223231729/https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-67801204 |archive-date=23 December 2023}}</ref>
+According to a study conducted by the international company [[Deloitte]] in November 2023, after the transition of Ukrainian Christian churches to the new style, the majority of [[Ukrainians]] (about 45%) will celebrate Christmas on December 25 and only 17% on January 7, and 32% plan to celebrate twice.<ref>{{Cite web |title=More donations to the Armed Forces, new traditions and the continuation of the boycott of sellers still working in the Russian Federation – Deloitte research on New Year's shopping of Ukrainians |url=https://www2.deloitte.com/ua/uk/pages/press-room/press-release/2023/holiday-retail-sales-consumer-survey.html |accessdate=2023-12-13 |website="Deloitte" in Ukraine |language=uk |archive-date=13 December 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231213140925/https://www2.deloitte.com/ua/uk/pages/press-room/press-release/2023/holiday-retail-sales-consumer-survey.html |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-12-08 |title=The vast majority of Ukrainians will celebrate Christmas on December 25 – survey |url=https://religionpravda.com.ua/?p=90196 |accessdate=2023-12-13 |website=Religious Pravda |language=uk |archive-date=25 December 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231225104318/https://religionpravda.com.ua/?p=90196 |url-status=live }}</ref>  In 2023, for the first time since 1917, [[Christmas Day]] in Ukraine was marked on just one day - December 25, the same date across almost all Christian faiths around the globe.<ref name="BBC">{{cite news |last1=Waterhouse |first1=James |title=Ukraine war: New Christmas date marks shift away from Russia |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-67801204 |access-date=24 December 2023 |work=[[BBC News]] |date=23 December 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231223231729/https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-67801204 |archive-date=23 December 2023}}</ref>

+Following the Vigil, on December 25 families return to the aformentioned places of worship for Mass, Divine Liturgy or a holiday service. Unlike the previous day, meat and other foods are eaten during the day. This day and the days following up to January 4 are fast-free days.
 
 ==''Koliadky'' (Caroling)==
 At the end of the {{lang|uk|Sviata Vechera}}, and the [[vigil]] that follows, Ukrainian families often sing carols ({{lang|uk|koliadky}}). In some communities the ancient Ukrainian tradition of caroling is carried on by groups of young people and members of organizations and churches calling at homes and collecting donations. Well-known carols include ''{{ill|Nova radist stala|lt=|uk|Нова радість стала|display=1}}'', [[Boh predvičnyj narodivsja|''Boh predvichnyi narodyvsia'']],<ref name=Met>{{cite web|title=Boh predvičnyj|url=http://mci.archpitt.org/legacy/songs/Slavonic/Boh_predvicnyj.html|website=Metropolitan Cantor Institute|publisher=Byzantine Catholic|access-date=12 August 2015|ref=Archeparchy of Pittsburgh|archive-date=4 March 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304235614/http://mci.archpitt.org/legacy/songs/Slavonic/Boh_predvicnyj.html|url-status=dead}}</ref> ''{{ill|Dobryi vechir tobi, pane hospodariu|lt=|uk|Добрий вечір тобі, пане господарю|display=1}}'', ''{{ill|Vo Vyfleiemi nyni novyna|lt=|uk|Во Вифлеємі нині новина|display=1}}'', ''{{ill|Nebo i zemlia nyni torzhestvuiut|lt=|uk|Небо і земля нині торжествують|display=1}}'', and ''{{ill|Boh sia rozhdaie|lt=|uk|Бог ся раджае|display=1}}''.

+Christmas was largely erased from the Ukrainian calendar for much of the 20th century due to the [[Persecution of Christians in the Soviet Union|Soviet Union's anti-religious policies]], but many of its traditions survived and are being revived again.  ==History==

In 2023, for the first time since 1917, [[Christmas Day]] in Ukraine was officially on December 25.
 
 ==History==
 In Ukraine, the Christmas holiday became the official celebration with the [[baptism of Rus']] ordered by [[Prince Vladimir]] in the year 988.<ref>{{citation |last1=Moreau |first1=A. Scott |page=102 |title=Introducing World Missions: A Biblical, Historical, and Practical Survey |last2=Corwin |first2=Gary R. |last3=Corwin |first3=Gary |last4=McGee |first4=Gary B. |date=2004 |publisher=Baker Academic |isbn=978-0-8010-2648-5 |language=en}}</ref> However, given the early Christian community of [[Kievan Rus']], the celebration may have a longer history.
llm_output:
Removed the phrase "due to Ukraine distancing itself from [[Russian Federation|Russia]]" from the context of Christmas Day celebrations in Ukraine.

Not Weaponised. The change removes a potentially politically charged statement that could imply a narrative of conflict, thus neutralizing the language without introducing weaponisation.

Added a date reference for the Christmas holiday transition and included additional context regarding the Ukrainian Orthodox Church's calendar changes.

Not Weaponised – The changes made are factual updates regarding the transition of Christmas celebrations in Ukraine, without any language that promotes a specific narrative or perspective that could be considered weaponization of cultural heritage.

initial_version:
The Ukrainian Christmas  festive days according to the Julian calendar, start on January 6th, Christmas Eve and ends with January 19th, "Jordan" or Epiphany.<ref>http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/</ref>

==Sviaty Vechir (Holy Evening)== 
<ref>http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html</ref>





==Koliadky - (Caroling)==


==Did Moroz - (Grandfather Frost)==



{{Reflist}}
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -80,7 +80,13 @@
 
 Ukrainians of the OCU and UGCC fast and abstain on Sviatyi Vechir ([[Latin Church]] Catholics and Protestants may choose also to follow tradition on said day) - it is one of a few paramony days in the Eastern Rite calendar wherein mandatory fasting and abstinence is observed; only when the first star is seen in the evening sky, or just after the faithful have received Communion in the afternoon service, may the supper begin.  The family comes together to have a dinner which usually includes 12 dishes (the number can vary from 7–17). These twelve dishes are traditionally vegan plus fish, and do not contain meat, milk, or eggs.<ref>{{cite web |title=Christmas in Ukraine |url=https://www.whychristmas.com/cultures/ukraine.shtml |website=Why Christmas |access-date=14 December 2020 |archive-date=7 December 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201207184630/https://www.whychristmas.com/cultures/ukraine.shtml |url-status=live }}</ref> While the dishes served can vary regionally, as well as from family to family, the two mandatory dishes are ''uzvar'' and ''kutia'', both reckoned by ethnographer [[Fedir Vovk|Khvedir Vovk]] to be remnants of ancient rituals which date back to the neolithic era.<ref>{{cite web |title=Traditional Recipe of Ukrainian Kutia |url=https://etnocook.com/kutia/ |website=Ethnocook |date=18 January 2018 |access-date=27 November 2022 |archive-date=28 November 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221128164554/https://etnocook.com/kutia/ |url-status=live }}</ref> ''[[Kutia]]'' (a dish of grain, honey and poppy seeds) is traditionally served first at the meal, after being offered by the head of the household to the frost. A spoonful is tossed at the ceiling, and in rural townships the number of poppy seeds which stick portends the bountyfulness of the fields, orchards and farm animals in the coming year. It is rarely served at other times of the year.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html |title=Sviat Vechir<!-- Bot generated title --> |access-date=7 January 2013 |archive-date=9 January 2008 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080109035835/http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html |url-status=live }}</ref> ''Uzvar'' is a beverage, made with cooked dried fruits and berries. It can be mixed in with the ''kutia'', or served separately at the end of the meal.  Servings of both dishes are also set aside overnight in the ''pokuttia'', the corner of the house with the Orthodox/Eastern Catholic icons or Latin Catholic images of saints, for deceased ancestors within the family or, in recent cases, for family members killed during the Russo-Ukrainian War (especially those who were KIA in the Armed Forces of Ukraine and other uniformed organizations).
 
-The All-Night Christmas Vigil then follows, families then troop to their local parish churches or Protestant churches to attend as thanksgiving for the Savior's birth in a stable.  On Christmas Eve night a ''[[Nativity scene|shopka]]'' (''[[vertep]]''), a traditional portable [[Nativity of Jesus|nativity]] scene, carried by children or adults alike, and used to represent the Nativity and other figures in a [[Nativity play|puppet]] form, is brought out in public, the portable tall box is either accompanied by singing carollers or crowds either before or after the vigil service.<ref>{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=G_8pAQAAIAAJ&q=shopka+ukraine+christmas+eve |title=Soviet Studies in Literature |date=1990 |publisher=International Arts and Science Press |language=en |access-date=25 December 2023 |archive-date=25 December 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231225104358/https://books.google.com/books?id=G_8pAQAAIAAJ&newbks=0&printsec=frontcover&dq=shopka+ukraine+christmas+eve&q=shopka+ukraine+christmas+eve&hl=en |url-status=live }}</ref>
+The All-Night Christmas Vigil then follows, families then troop to their local parish churches or Protestant churches to attend as thanksgiving for the Savior's birth in a stable. OCU and UGCC Divine Liturgy, Catholic Midnight Mass or a Protestant service would then traditionally follow. On Christmas Eve night a ''[[Nativity scene|shopka]]'' (''[[vertep]]''), a traditional portable [[Nativity of Jesus|nativity]] scene, carried by children or adults alike, and used to represent the Nativity and other figures in a [[Nativity play|puppet]] form, is brought out in public, the portable tall box is either accompanied by singing carollers or crowds either before or after the vigil service.<ref>{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=G_8pAQAAIAAJ&q=shopka+ukraine+christmas+eve |title=Soviet Studies in Literature |date=1990 |publisher=International Arts and Science Press |language=en |access-date=25 December 2023 |archive-date=25 December 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231225104358/https://books.google.com/books?id=G_8pAQAAIAAJ&newbks=0&printsec=frontcover&dq=shopka+ukraine+christmas+eve&q=shopka+ukraine+christmas+eve&hl=en |url-status=live }}</ref>
+
+The principal national television and online services on the night are beamed live from:
+
+* for the OCU, [[Saint Sophia Cathedral, Kyiv]]
+* for the UGCC, [[Cathedral of the Resurrection of Christ, Kyiv]]
+* for Latin Rite Catholics: [[Cathedral Basilica of the Assumption, Lviv]] and/or [[Co-Cathedral of St. Alexander, Kyiv]]
 
 == Christmas Day ==
 Following the Vigil, on December 25 families return to the aformentioned places of worship for Mass, Divine Liturgy or a holiday service. Unlike the previous day, meat and other foods are eaten during the day.
llm_output:
The change made is the addition of details regarding the Divine Liturgy and the specific locations of national television and online services for different religious groups during the Christmas Vigil. 

Weaponised. The mention of specific religious groups (OCU and UGCC) and the context of the Russo-Ukrainian War, particularly the reference to family members killed during the conflict, suggests a narrative that emphasizes the impact of the war on cultural and religious practices, potentially framing the situation in a way that could be used to evoke emotional responses or justify positions in the ongoing conflict.

initial_version:
The Ukrainian Christmas  festive days according to the Julian calendar, start on January 6th, Christmas Eve and ends with January 19th, "Jordan" or Epiphany.<ref>http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/</ref>

==Sviaty Vechir (Holy Evening)== 
<ref>http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html</ref>





==Koliadky - (Caroling)==


==Did Moroz - (Grandfather Frost)==



{{Reflist}}
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -46,6 +46,8 @@
 During the early [[History of the Soviet Union|Soviet period]], all religious celebrations were discouraged under the official state policy of [[atheism]]. The [[Bolsheviks]] argued that Christmas was a [[pagan]] [[sun-worship]]ping ritual with no basis in scientific fact and denounced the [[Christmas tree]] as a [[bourgeois]] German import.<ref name=":0" /> In 1929, all religious holidays, including Christmas, were abolished by a decree of the [[Stalinist regime]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|last=|first=|date=2019-12-29|title=How New Year was celebrated in the USSR (Photos)|url=https://www.rbth.com/history/331458-soviet-new-year|url-status=live|access-date=2021-06-12|website=Beyond Russia|language=en-US|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191229111401/https://www.rbth.com/history/331458-soviet-new-year |archive-date=29 December 2019 }}</ref> However, in a surprising turn of state politics in 1935, many Ukrainian Christmas traditions were revived as part of a secular [[New Year's Eve|New Year's]] celebration after [[Joseph Stalin]]'s advisers convinced the [[Vozhd]] of the [[proletarians]]' need for a break from their hard work in the middle of a long, cold winter.<ref name=":1" /> The Christmas tree was repurposed as a "New Year's fir tree" to be admired by all children throughout the [[Soviet Union]], including those in republics that had not historically celebrated Christmas due to their different religious traditions, such as the [[Soviet Central Asia|Central Asian ones]]. Other Ukrainian Christmas attributes and traditions, such as [[Christmas gift|gift-giving]], Did Moroz's visits and Christmas decorations, lost their religious significance and became associated with New Year's celebrations, which were secular in nature.<ref name=":0" />
 
 In 1991, after the dissolution of the Soviet Union, Christmas was reinstated alongside other religious holidays.<ref name=":0" /> Especially in recent years, there has been a shift from Did Moroz, who came to be associated with the Soviet-era heritage, to the more traditional [[Saint Nicholas]], who used to be more popular in [[Western Ukraine]].<ref name="Mos">{{cite news |title=Kiev Brings Back Orthodox Santa Claus Instead of Soviet-Era Father Frost |url=http://www.themoscowtimes.com/news/article/kiev-brings-back-orthodox-santa-claus-instead-of-soviet-era-father-frost/511488.html |access-date=24 December 2023 |work=[[The Moscow Times]] |date=20 November 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141120231116/http://www.themoscowtimes.com/news/article/kiev-brings-back-orthodox-santa-claus-instead-of-soviet-era-father-frost/511488.html |archive-date=20 November 2014}}</ref>
+
+Ukraine declared the 25 December as a state holiday in 2017 for the Christmas commerations and festivities in the [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church]].
 
 == Date of celebration ==

initial_version:
The Ukrainian Christmas  festive days according to the Julian calendar, start on January 6th, Christmas Eve and ends with January 19th, "Jordan" or Epiphany.<ref>http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/</ref>

==Sviaty Vechir (Holy Evening)== 
<ref>http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html</ref>





==Koliadky - (Caroling)==


==Did Moroz - (Grandfather Frost)==



{{Reflist}}
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -43,7 +43,7 @@
 
 In the 19th century, a lavishly decorated Christmas tree became central to the holiday, a tradition originally imported by [[Nicholas I of Russia|Nicholas I]]'s wife, [[Alexandra Feodorovna (Charlotte of Prussia)|Alexandra Feodorovna]], from her native [[Prussia]]. The tradition of giving gifts to children on Christmas took root around the same time.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|last=Weber|first=Hannah|date=25 December 2020|title=Yolka: the story of Russia's 'New Year tree', from pagan origins to Soviet celebrations|url=https://www.calvertjournal.com/articles/show/9424/yolka-russia-new-year-tree-pagan-soviet-christmas|url-status=live|access-date=2021-06-12|website=The Calvert Journal|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180113181107/http://www.calvertjournal.com/articles/show/9424/yolka-russia-new-year-tree-pagan-soviet-christmas |archive-date=13 January 2018 }}</ref> Christmas gifts were traditionally brought by [[Ded Moroz]] or [[Grandfather Frost]], the Ukrainian counterpart of [[Santa Claus|Saint Nicholas]] or [[Father Christmas]], albeit a little taller and less stout. Rooted in Slavic folklore, Ded Moroz is accompanied by his beautiful granddaughter, [[Snegurka]], the snowmaiden), who rides with him on a sleigh pulled by a trio of horses.<ref name=":0" />
 
-During the early [[History of the Soviet Union|Soviet period]], all religious celebrations were discouraged under the official state policy of [[atheism]]. The [[Bolsheviks]] argued that Christmas was a [[pagan]] [[sun-worship]]ping ritual with no basis in scientific fact and denounced the [[Christmas tree]] as a [[bourgeois]] German import.<ref name=":0" /> In 1929, all religious holidays, including Christmas, were abolished by a decree of the [[Stalinist regime]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|last=|first=|date=2019-12-29|title=How New Year was celebrated in the USSR (Photos)|url=https://www.rbth.com/history/331458-soviet-new-year|url-status=live|access-date=2021-06-12|website=Beyond Russia|language=en-US|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191229111401/https://www.rbth.com/history/331458-soviet-new-year |archive-date=29 December 2019 }}</ref> However, in a surprising turn of state politics in 1935, many Ukrainian Christmas traditions were revived as part of a secular [[New Year's Eve|New Year's]] celebration after [[Joseph Stalin]]'s advisers convinced the [[Vozhd]] of the [[proletarians]]' need for a break from their hard work in the middle of a long, cold winter.<ref name=":1" /> The Christmas tree was repurposed as a "New Year's fir tree" to be admired by all children throughout the [[Soviet Union]], including those in republics that had not historically celebrated Christmas due to their different religious traditions, such as the [[Soviet Central Asia|Central Asian ones]]. Other Ukrainian Christmas attributes and traditions, such as [[Christmas gift|gift-giving]], Did Moroz's visits and Christmas decorations, lost their religious significance and became associated with New Year's celebrations, which were secular in nature.<ref name=":0" />
+During the early [[History of the Soviet Union|Soviet period]], all religious celebrations were discouraged under the official state policy of [[atheism]]. The [[Bolsheviks]] argued that Christmas was a [[pagan]] [[sun-worship]]ping ritual with no basis in scientific fact and denounced the [[Christmas tree]] as a [[bourgeois]] German import.<ref name=":0" /> In 1929, all religious holidays, including Christmas, were abolished by a decree of the [[Stalinist regime]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|last=|first=|date=2019-12-29|title=How New Year was celebrated in the USSR (Photos)|url=https://www.rbth.com/history/331458-soviet-new-year|url-status=live|access-date=2021-06-12|website=Beyond Russia|language=en-US|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191229111401/https://www.rbth.com/history/331458-soviet-new-year |archive-date=29 December 2019 }}</ref> However, in a surprising turn of state politics in 1935, many Ukrainian Christmas traditions were revived as part of a secular [[New Year's Eve|New Year's]] celebration after [[Joseph Stalin]]'s advisers convinced him that the workers need a break from their hard work in the middle of a long, cold winter.<ref name=":1" /> The Christmas tree was repurposed as a "New Year's fir tree" to be admired by all children throughout the [[Soviet Union]], including those in republics that had not historically celebrated Christmas due to their different religious traditions, such as the [[Soviet Central Asia|Central Asian ones]]. Other Ukrainian Christmas attributes and traditions, such as [[Christmas gift|gift-giving]], Did Moroz's visits and Christmas decorations, lost their religious significance and became associated with New Year's celebrations, which were secular in nature.<ref name=":0" />
 
 In 1991, after the dissolution of the Soviet Union, Christmas was reinstated alongside other religious holidays.<ref name=":0" /> Especially in recent years, there has been a shift from Did Moroz, who came to be associated with the Soviet-era heritage, to the more traditional [[Saint Nicholas]], who used to be more popular in [[Western Ukraine]].<ref name="Mos">{{cite news |title=Kiev Brings Back Orthodox Santa Claus Instead of Soviet-Era Father Frost |url=http://www.themoscowtimes.com/news/article/kiev-brings-back-orthodox-santa-claus-instead-of-soviet-era-father-frost/511488.html |access-date=24 December 2023 |work=[[The Moscow Times]] |date=20 November 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141120231116/http://www.themoscowtimes.com/news/article/kiev-brings-back-orthodox-santa-claus-instead-of-soviet-era-father-frost/511488.html |archive-date=20 November 2014}}</ref>
llm_output:

Not Weaponised. The changes made do not introduce any weaponisation terms or narratives; they simply clarify the historical context without altering the underlying message.

 In 1991, after the dissolution of the Soviet Union, Christmas was reinstated alongside other religious holidays.<ref name=":0" /> Especially in recent years, there has been a shift from Did Moroz, who came to be associated with the Soviet-era heritage, to the more traditional [[Saint Nicholas]], who used to be more popular in [[Western Ukraine]].<ref name="Mos">{{cite news |title=Kiev Brings Back Orthodox Santa Claus Instead of Soviet-Era Father Frost |url=http://www.themoscowtimes.com/news/article/kiev-brings-back-orthodox-santa-claus-instead-of-soviet-era-father-frost/511488.html |access-date=24 December 2023 |work=[[The Moscow Times]] |date=20 November 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141120231116/http://www.themoscowtimes.com/news/article/kiev-brings-back-orthodox-santa-claus-instead-of-soviet-era-father-frost/511488.html |archive-date=20 November 2014}}</ref>

The Ukrainian Christmas  festive days according to the Julian calendar, start on January 6th, Christmas Eve and ends with January 19th, "Jordan" or Epiphany.<ref>http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/</ref>

==Sviaty Vechir (Holy Evening)== 
<ref>http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html</ref>





==Koliadky - (Caroling)==


==Did Moroz - (Grandfather Frost)==



{{Reflist}}
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -78,7 +78,7 @@
 
 On the afternoon of the day, a St. Basil Divine Liturgy is held in parishes to mark the formal close of the [[Nativity Fast|Christmas Fast]] within the OCU and UGCC that began in November, which includes commemorations of the [[Holodomor]] of the 1930s, the liturgy follows a Christmas version of the [[Royal Hours]].
 
-Ukrainians of the OCU and UGCC fast on Sviatyi Vechir ([[Latin Church]] Catholics and Protestants may choose also to follow tradition on said day); only when the first star is seen in the evening sky, or just after the faithful have received Communion in the afternoon service, may the supper begin.  The family comes together to have a dinner which usually includes 12 dishes (the number can vary from 7–17). These twelve dishes are traditionally vegan plus fish, and do not contain meat, milk, or eggs.<ref>{{cite web |title=Christmas in Ukraine |url=https://www.whychristmas.com/cultures/ukraine.shtml |website=Why Christmas |access-date=14 December 2020 |archive-date=7 December 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201207184630/https://www.whychristmas.com/cultures/ukraine.shtml |url-status=live }}</ref> While the dishes served can vary regionally, as well as from family to family, the two mandatory dishes are ''uzvar'' and ''kutia'', both reckoned by ethnographer [[Fedir Vovk|Khvedir Vovk]] to be remnants of ancient rituals which date back to the neolithic era.<ref>{{cite web |title=Traditional Recipe of Ukrainian Kutia |url=https://etnocook.com/kutia/ |website=Ethnocook |date=18 January 2018 |access-date=27 November 2022 |archive-date=28 November 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221128164554/https://etnocook.com/kutia/ |url-status=live }}</ref> ''[[Kutia]]'' (a dish of grain, honey and poppy seeds) is traditionally served first at the meal, after being offered by the head of the household to the frost. A spoonful is tossed at the ceiling, and in rural townships the number of poppy seeds which stick portends the bountyfulness of the fields, orchards and farm animals in the coming year. It is rarely served at other times of the year.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html |title=Sviat Vechir<!-- Bot generated title --> |access-date=7 January 2013 |archive-date=9 January 2008 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080109035835/http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html |url-status=live }}</ref> ''Uzvar'' is a beverage, made with cooked dried fruits and berries. It can be mixed in with the ''kutia'', or served separately at the end of the meal.  Servings of both dishes are also set aside overnight in the ''pokuttia'', the corner of the house with the Orthodox/Eastern Catholic icons or Latin Catholic images of saints, for deceased ancestors within the family or, in recent cases, for family members killed during the Russo-Ukrainian War (especially those who were KIA in the Armed Forces of Ukraine and other uniformed organizations).
+Ukrainians of the OCU and UGCC fast and abstain on Sviatyi Vechir ([[Latin Church]] Catholics and Protestants may choose also to follow tradition on said day) - it is one of a few paramony days in the Eastern Rite calendar wherein mandatory fasting and abstinence is observed; only when the first star is seen in the evening sky, or just after the faithful have received Communion in the afternoon service, may the supper begin.  The family comes together to have a dinner which usually includes 12 dishes (the number can vary from 7–17). These twelve dishes are traditionally vegan plus fish, and do not contain meat, milk, or eggs.<ref>{{cite web |title=Christmas in Ukraine |url=https://www.whychristmas.com/cultures/ukraine.shtml |website=Why Christmas |access-date=14 December 2020 |archive-date=7 December 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201207184630/https://www.whychristmas.com/cultures/ukraine.shtml |url-status=live }}</ref> While the dishes served can vary regionally, as well as from family to family, the two mandatory dishes are ''uzvar'' and ''kutia'', both reckoned by ethnographer [[Fedir Vovk|Khvedir Vovk]] to be remnants of ancient rituals which date back to the neolithic era.<ref>{{cite web |title=Traditional Recipe of Ukrainian Kutia |url=https://etnocook.com/kutia/ |website=Ethnocook |date=18 January 2018 |access-date=27 November 2022 |archive-date=28 November 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221128164554/https://etnocook.com/kutia/ |url-status=live }}</ref> ''[[Kutia]]'' (a dish of grain, honey and poppy seeds) is traditionally served first at the meal, after being offered by the head of the household to the frost. A spoonful is tossed at the ceiling, and in rural townships the number of poppy seeds which stick portends the bountyfulness of the fields, orchards and farm animals in the coming year. It is rarely served at other times of the year.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html |title=Sviat Vechir<!-- Bot generated title --> |access-date=7 January 2013 |archive-date=9 January 2008 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080109035835/http://www.infoukes.com/culture/traditions/christmas/sviat_vechir.html |url-status=live }}</ref> ''Uzvar'' is a beverage, made with cooked dried fruits and berries. It can be mixed in with the ''kutia'', or served separately at the end of the meal.  Servings of both dishes are also set aside overnight in the ''pokuttia'', the corner of the house with the Orthodox/Eastern Catholic icons or Latin Catholic images of saints, for deceased ancestors within the family or, in recent cases, for family members killed during the Russo-Ukrainian War (especially those who were KIA in the Armed Forces of Ukraine and other uniformed organizations).
 
 The All-Night Christmas Vigil then follows, families then troop to their local parish churches or Protestant churches to attend as thanksgiving for the Savior's birth in a stable.  On Christmas Eve night a ''[[Nativity scene|shopka]]'' (''[[vertep]]''), a traditional portable [[Nativity of Jesus|nativity]] scene, carried by children or adults alike, and used to represent the Nativity and other figures in a [[Nativity play|puppet]] form, is brought out in public, the portable tall box is either accompanied by singing carollers or crowds either before or after the vigil service.<ref>{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=G_8pAQAAIAAJ&q=shopka+ukraine+christmas+eve |title=Soviet Studies in Literature |date=1990 |publisher=International Arts and Science Press |language=en |access-date=25 December 2023 |archive-date=25 December 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231225104358/https://books.google.com/books?id=G_8pAQAAIAAJ&newbks=0&printsec=frontcover&dq=shopka+ukraine+christmas+eve&q=shopka+ukraine+christmas+eve&hl=en |url-status=live }}</ref>

The tradition of giving gifts to children on Christmas took root around the same time.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|last=Weber|first=Hannah|date=25 December 2020|title=Yolka: the story of Russia's 'New Year tree', from pagan origins to Soviet celebrations|url=https://www.calvertjournal.com/articles/show/9424/yolka-russia-new-year-tree-pagan-soviet-christmas|url-status=live|access-date=2021-06-12|website=The Calvert Journal|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180113181107/http://www.calvertjournal.com/articles/show/9424/yolka-russia-new-year-tree-pagan-soviet-christmas |archive-date=13 January 2018 }}</ref> Christmas gifts were traditionally brought by [[Ded Moroz]] or [[Grandfather Frost]], the Ukrainian counterpart of [[Santa Claus|Saint Nicholas]] or [[Father Christmas]], albeit a little taller and less stout. Rooted in Slavic folklore, Ded Moroz is accompanied by his beautiful granddaughter, [[Snegurka]], the snowmaiden), who rides with him on a sleigh pulled by a trio of horses.<ref name=":0" />
 
 During the early [[History of the Soviet Union|Soviet period]], all religious celebrations were discouraged under the official state policy of [[atheism]]. The [[Bolsheviks]] argued that Christmas was a [[pagan]] [[sun-worship]]ping ritual with no basis in scientific fact and denounced the [[Christmas tree]] as a [[bourgeois]] German import.<ref name=":0" /> In 1929, all religious holidays, including Christmas, were abolished by a decree of the [[Stalinist regime]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|last=|first=|date=2019-12-29|title=How New Year was celebrated in the USSR (Photos)|url=https://www.rbth.com/history/331458-soviet-new-year|url-status=live|access-date=2021-06-12|website=Beyond Russia|language=en-US|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191229111401/https://www.rbth.com/history/331458-soviet-new-year |archive-date=29 December 2019 }}</ref> However, in a surprising turn of state politics in 1935, many Ukrainian Christmas traditions were revived as part of a secular [[New Year's Eve|New Year's]] celebration restored in the Soviet Union. The Christmas tree was repurposed as a "New Year's fir tree" to be admired by all children throughout the [[Soviet Union]], including those in republics that had not historically celebrated Christmas due to their different religious traditions, such as the [[Soviet Central Asia|Central Asian ones]]. Other Ukrainian Christmas attributes and traditions, such as [[Christmas gift|gift-giving]], Did Moroz's visits and Christmas decorations, lost their religious significance and became associated with New Year's celebrations, which were secular in nature.<ref name=":0" />

 In 1991, after the dissolution of the Soviet Union, Christmas was reinstated alongside other religious holidays.<ref name=":0" /> Especially in recent years, there has been a shift from Did Moroz, who came to be associated with the Soviet-era heritage, to the more traditional [[Saint Nicholas]], who used to be more popular in [[Western Ukraine]].<ref name="Mos">{{cite news |title=Kiev Brings Back Orthodox Santa Claus Instead of Soviet-Era Father Frost |url=http://www.themoscowtimes.com/news/article/kiev-brings-back-orthodox-santa-claus-instead-of-soviet-era-father-frost/511488.html |access-date=24 December 2023 |work=[[The Moscow Times]] |date=20 November 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141120231116/http://www.themoscowtimes.com/news/article/kiev-brings-back-orthodox-santa-claus-instead-of-soviet-era-father-frost/511488.html |archive-date=20 November 2014}}</ref>
llm_output:
The change made in the revision is the addition of a phrase: "after [[Joseph Stalin]]'s advisers convinced him that the workers need a break from their hard work in the middle of a long, cold winter." 

**Weaponised**: The addition of this phrase subtly shifts the narrative to emphasize Stalin's decision-making as a benevolent act for the workers, which can be interpreted as an attempt to frame Soviet policies in a more favorable light. This could be seen as an effort to legitimize or romanticize the Soviet regime's actions regarding cultural practices, potentially weaponizing the historical context for contemporary political narratives.

The tradition of giving gifts to children on Christmas took root around the same time.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|last=Weber|first=Hannah|date=25 December 2020|title=Yolka: the story of Russia's 'New Year tree', from pagan origins to Soviet celebrations|url=https://www.calvertjournal.com/articles/show/9424/yolka-russia-new-year-tree-pagan-soviet-christmas|url-status=live|access-date=2021-06-12|website=The Calvert Journal|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180113181107/http://www.calvertjournal.com/articles/show/9424/yolka-russia-new-year-tree-pagan-soviet-christmas |archive-date=13 January 2018 }}</ref> Christmas gifts were traditionally brought by [[Ded Moroz]] or [[Grandfather Frost]], the Ukrainian counterpart of [[Santa Claus|Saint Nicholas]] or [[Father Christmas]], albeit a little taller and less stout. Rooted in russian folklore, Ded Moroz is accompanied by his, [[Snegurka]], the snowmaiden), who rides with him on a sleigh pulled by a trio of horses.<ref name=":0" />
+In the 19th century, a lavishly decorated Christmas tree became central to the holiday, a tradition originally imported by [[Nicholas I of Russia|Nicholas I]]'s wife, [[Alexandra Feodorovna (Charlotte of Prussia)|Alexandra Feodorovna]], from her native [[Prussia]]. The tradition of giving gifts to children on Christmas took root around the same time.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|last=Weber|first=Hannah|date=25 December 2020|title=Yolka: the story of Russia's 'New Year tree', from pagan origins to Soviet celebrations|url=https://www.calvertjournal.com/articles/show/9424/yolka-russia-new-year-tree-pagan-soviet-christmas|url-status=live|access-date=2021-06-12|website=The Calvert Journal|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180113181107/http://www.calvertjournal.com/articles/show/9424/yolka-russia-new-year-tree-pagan-soviet-christmas |archive-date=13 January 2018 }}</ref> Christmas gifts were traditionally brought by [[Ded Moroz]] or [[Grandfather Frost]], the Ukrainian counterpart of [[Santa Claus|Saint Nicholas]] or [[Father Christmas]], albeit a little taller and less stout. Rooted in Slavic folklore, Ded Moroz is accompanied by his beautiful granddaughter, [[Snegurka]], the snowmaiden), who rides with him on a sleigh pulled by a trio of horses.<ref name=":0" />
 
 During the early [[History of the Soviet Union|Soviet period]], all religious celebrations were discouraged under the official state policy of [[atheism]]. The [[Bolsheviks]] argued that Christmas was a [[pagan]] [[sun-worship]]ping ritual with no basis in scientific fact and denounced the [[Christmas tree]] as a [[bourgeois]] German import.<ref name=":0" /> In 1929, all religious holidays, including Christmas, were abolished by a decree of the [[Stalinist regime]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|last=|first=|date=2019-12-29|title=How New Year was celebrated in the USSR (Photos)|url=https://www.rbth.com/history/331458-soviet-new-year|url-status=live|access-date=2021-06-12|website=Beyond Russia|language=en-US|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191229111401/https://www.rbth.com/history/331458-soviet-new-year |archive-date=29 December 2019 }}</ref> However, in a surprising turn of state politics in 1935, many Ukrainian Christmas traditions were revived as part of a secular [[New Year's Eve|New Year's]] celebration restored in the Soviet Union. The Christmas tree was repurposed as a "New Year's fir tree" to be admired by all children throughout the [[Soviet Union]], including those in republics that had not historically celebrated Christmas due to their different religious traditions, such as the [[Soviet Central Asia|Central Asian ones]]. Other Ukrainian Christmas attributes and traditions, such as [[Christmas gift|gift-giving]], Did Moroz's visits and Christmas decorations, lost their religious significance and became associated with New Year's celebrations, which were secular in nature.<ref name=":0" />
